msItem.l: (traces)
/ -y- gīna. tsāṣṭa battai. tta ma le.dai śaʾma leparya
/ . kūṣṭa parī tsve. īka śaina mi na khara; māṃʾ kṣvya pha ḍī khara ṣa tsū. jū śa. parya
vą̄ paryai. tcū le. paryą ṇaiʾśtai. x x. parya panīyai. haiya. a stā; haiʾya śai ḍa. a
stā kītha tsvāṃ: haiʾya ga ḍai ra. kuṣḍau vī tsāṃ; haiʾyą u ḍaitcyau tta ma le: mā vą̄ bara. hvą
śai haṃ tta mą le; khī hvana. āṣaʾ paryą yuḍai. tsaiyą ttą ma le. pūhara vā barakva tta
ma le; byāra vą̄ bara. hau kva tta ma lettrruysa vā bara: kī tsaiyą. tcahaiʾ. hū jñā
śa. a hauḍa vastya: ana khą le yą. draṣṭa yai. ca ḍīra: ṣaʾ yai; hąna ḍī haiʾyą pa haiʾyą
caigāṃ bvą ā nai. haiya śą ttāṃ; a stā bai baiśa; cī ma ttāṃ. bvaysną. pī pī. draijsai. vara
hadarāṃ. ira: kṣama-ṃhuāṃ: pa ysą̄va. na kṣami. khavą. ttą̄ra. ganatcaimañai. śaʾ tvągvaṃ
pīra khumą. haysgyai. ttą̄ hvąra: raṃgya baida tcaṃjsa; ttai bą. kāṃhąʾ thāṃ: īka. ttyai
ba. śą̄-v-ą̄ thāṃ pąrą̄thāṃ; bai tsąva; gīnū. śī. dasta. kyąhąʾ; pā:

-y- gīna → tsāṣṭa battai “calmly ...”
ttama le 擔來 (dān lái) → (...) “(bring)”
dai śaʾma le 帶甚麼來 (dài shénme lái) → parya “please (bring something)!”
[...] → kūṣṭa parī tsve “where are you going?”

ī ka śaina mi na khara一個甚麼哪去 (yī-ge shénme ne qù) → māṃʾ kṣvya “...”
pha ḍī khara 。。。去 (... qù) → ṣa tsū “he is going”
jū śa 入。。。(rù ...?) → parya vą̄ paryai “please enter!”

tcū le坐來 (zuò lái) → paryą ṇaiʾśtai “please sit!”
x x → parya panīyai “please ...!”
haiya 奚 (xī “servant girl”) → astā “*your servants”
haiʾya śai ḍa 奚城來 (xī chéng lái) → astā kītha tsvāṃ “we, *your servants, are going to town”

haiʾya ga ḍai ra奚衙來啊 (xī yá lái ā) → kuṣḍau vī tsāṃ “I am going to the palace”
haiʾyą u ḍai 。。。→ (...) “(...)”
tcyau ttama le 酒擔來 (jiû dān le) → mā-v-āṃ bara “bring us wine!”

hvaṃ śaihaṃ ttamaṃ le飯食擔來 (fàn shī dān lái) → (...) “(bring ... rice!)”
khī hvana 慶。。。 (qìng ...) → āṣaʾ paryą yuḍai “please make worthy!”
tsaiyaṃ ttąma le 菜擔來 (cào dān lái) → pūhara vā bara “bring me vegetables!”

kva ttama le瓜擔來 (gua dān lái) → byāra vą̄ bara “bring me cucumbers!”
hau kva ttama le 胡瓜擔來 (hú gua dān lái) → ttrruysa vā bara “bring me a gourd!”
kī tsaiyaṃ 。。。 → tcahaiʾ “...”
hū jñā śa 。。。 → a hauḍa vastya “I have *given ...”

ana khaṃ leyaṃ。。。→ draṣṭa yai “...”
ca ḍī ra 。。。→ ṣaʾ yai “...”
hąna ḍī haiʾyaṃ pa haiʾ 漢禮解不解 (hàn lî xiè bù xiè) → caigāṃ bvą ā nai “do you know Chinese?”

haiya śaṃ ttāṃ奚知多 (xī zhī duō?) → astā bai baiśa “(I) your servant *know everything”
cī ma ttā 。。。→ bvaysną “for long(?)”
pī pī 皮皮 (pí pí?) → draijsai. vara hadarāṃ “... of the others”

ira悅 (yuè < jwiat?) → kṣama-ṃ “it pleases (me to do)”
huāṃ pa ysą̄va 。。。→ na kṣami “it does not please”
khavaṃ 口 (kôu) → ttą̄ra “mouth”
gana 眼 (yân → tcaimañai “eyes”
śaʾ tvaṃ 耳朶 (êr duo) → gvaṃ “ears”

pīra khumaṃ鼻孔 (bí kông) → haysgyai “nostrils”
ttą̄ hvąra 頭髮 (tóu fà) → raṃgya baida tcaṃjsa “hair on the head”
ttai bą 大麼 (dà má) → kāṃhąʾ thāṃ “hemp cloth”

ī ka ttyai ba一個衫賣 (yī ge zhên? mài) → śą̄-v-ą̄ thāṃ pąrą̄thāṃ “I sell you(?) one cloth”
bai tsąva 買 ... (mâi ...) → gīnū “I am buying”
śī 手 (shôu) → dasta “hand”
kyąhą 腳 (jiâo < kiak) → pā “foot”

note.p: Versified letter from Nāgaiʾdrravarrda to the monastery in Gūśaʾṃdā including an account of Viśaʾ Saṃgrāma. Verse numbers added here.

q.l: pva pvaisai saddhami ya tta magala sakala para
|| [1] pvaisai ttā haṣḍä yūḍai janavai vīrāṣṭa: atvaḍarū maista bīsaga
: [2] pvaisai ttā haṣḍä yūḍai janavai vīrāṣṭa: atvaḍa{ru}rū drraya rana vīra beysau śāśaʾ: [3] ṣaʾ ttyai
dīśaʾ vīra pūñūdyai u pāṣai: beysū{x}ñai vyāraṇa nva hvasta mīḍauja kīla: [4] ranījai ttā-
ja baida āvāysa śūʾstai: gūśaʾdau cū rājagrrīheʾ hīya attīka: [5] mūja ṣava ya parīyastā haudyāṃ
ttana ką̄le ą̄na vąña būrāṃ va ttaiṣṭyai: [6] ca va na jārai hąjva {pūśīda} są̄jīdä pūśīda. parā-
haʾ paraihīda vasvai naṣaʾrīmą ṣadyū: [7] haṃdąrāṃ jsāṃ vyaucą yąnīdą. dara bīsagą va: pūśīda
sājīdą askhąjsa bą̄yīda śāśaʾ— : [8] mahāsamą rāṃda vī ā rāṃda dīryaudą rą̄śtą dā jsa
pūñā jsą rą̄ja-vyąstāṃ nvīyą [9] hva hvą śų̄ʾstāṃdą draina raną̄na vąska sakhārma śairką jaittąva jsa pakyairmą
[10] khvai hāCorr’d from ttā? pārrva rą̄śtą janavai vīra:
śrī vījatta sagrauma rai hamyai pūñūda śura

q.p: [1] (14) I ask (permission) to make a report to you to the (Golden) Land, (to) the supreme great bhikṣusaṅgha.
[2] (15) I ask (permission) to make a report to you to the (Golden) Land, (to) the supreme teaching of the Buddha (based) upon the Three Jewels.
[3] It is in that (16) direction meritorious and ... According to the prophecy of the Buddha the gracious ... has been ...
[4] In the Jewel River (17) he purified the āvāsanas. ... the ... of Rājagṛha.
[5] It was the ... night of the seven āryas. (18) From that time until now he stayed here.
[6] Those who do not perish here, the wise, teach, read. They (19) practice restraint, pure, taintless, full of faith.
[7] They make ... for others, for the entire bhikṣusaṅgha. They read, (20) teach, bring the teaching ....
[8] From under King Mahāsaṃmata the kings upheld the kingdom by the Law, (21) by merits, following the royal code (rāja-vyavasthāna).
[9] Severally they purified for the Three Jewels nice saṅghārāmas, *equal to the Jetavana.
[10] (22) When the rule of the (Golden) Land was to be delivered to him, (22a) Śrī Vijita Saṃgrāma became king, full of merits and brave.

q.l: [11] dvāsa sala āną ṇaistą rą̄ysayaṃ baida . ttana ką̄leną yą ja-
navą thą̄rsą̄vą bīją̄tta. [12] ttaṃdī vą sparąhaudą̄ hīna nąradą. bāstai ttañai baiʾḍa hīna jaṃbvī vīra. [13] śūrī pai-
ñā jsa dara jabvī pą̄rrdai. khvai mī āṃ vastai karma baśdāṃ haṃjsāmą: [14] daiśana ą̄yīmą śūʾsta tcarṣū āvāysa
[15] hūḍai hā haura vasvą arthūbauga: [16] u gūśadāṃgū corr’d from tt? bīsa bīśa pharāka. vaña bura va draya raną nvaśtā byaihī-
gųśaʾda ną̄ma jaittava jsa hamaga mista
da [17] cū va varāśāʾra hvaḍa khaṣṭa panūḍai: ttā jsā āvą̄ysa māṇḍa badąjanai [18] ṣaiʾ ysīnī bą̄stai khva na jsāṃ vą
harga. ttai āṃ vaña kaidą ṇaistya śą̄śaʾ burakyai: [19] tcaurrvą̄ śą̄mvą̄ pvāhąʾ kījsanū bvaiysą. mista sīma mistą
ayai valekyai pharą̄kyai. [20] phaṣu pāḍa ñāña ną̄lą̄ gaṃtsa mistą. ñānarthāṃ pāṣa prravaitta
ramanī tcaṣū [21] paima bīsai jista baiʾysa satvāṃ ttrvą̄yą̄ka: khvai vījsyārą sattą naphanīdą tsāṣṭa
jsa. [22] cīyai vījsyą̄vai ṣaʾ satsą̄ra jsa thyau gūśta: tcaurrvā śāmvā hvāhye mista saragyai. [23] baiʾsų̄ bau-
spaujañāñą ranīnai stūpą: cāvą̄ tta tta daittą khu raṃnā male ttraikha: [24] pū{va}ñūda va sątta ysathą
upapattī nāsīdä. śajsā vą prravają nādą prraṇąhaunā {kaiṇą prraṇahaunā kaiṇa}: kaiṇą [25] ų-
stamājsī kąlyāka bą̄ḍa akhskąją̄ śāśaʾ khvau ttā vañau {ttā} khąstai vąṣṭa mistyau

q.p: [11] For twelve years he sat on the royal throne (rājāsana?). At that time the (Golden) Land was (23) oppressed, destroyed.
[12] An army of only seventy-five went out there. At that time, he led the army to Jambudvīpa.
[13] With valor (24) and powers he conquered the entire Jambudvīpa, so that, thus, the accumulation of his karma sins ...
[14] He erected in Gumattīra a saṅghārāma. In the desire to (make) confession he purified a splendid āvāsana.
[15] (25a) It was called Guśaʾdā, as large as the Jetavana. (25) He gave to it gifts, pure artha-bhogas.
[16] And all the servants of Guśaʾdā were many. Still today they obtain there the examination of the Three Jewels.
[17] (26) Those who enjoy there food and drink every day, for them the āvāsana ...
[18] He took them in his protection when there (was) no (27) escape for them there. So now they look at him, *firmly ensconced(?) in the teaching.
[19] At the four mouths (= gates) there is long striking of drums. There is a great boundary (sīmā), many great and (28) small mirrors(?).
[20] ... in the river (there is) a great *ditch of reeds, their ... well-informed, ... (29) delightful, splendid.
[21] Dwelling in the ... is the Lord Buddha, deliverer of beings. If they look at him, beings ... in happiness.
[22] (30) When one looks at him, one is quickly delivered from saṃsāra. At the four mouths there are broad, great halls.
[23] Their shrine is (31) ..., a bejeweled stūpa. The ... appears like a bejeweled peak of rock.
[24] There meritorious beings (32) obtain birth, rebirth. ... they have taken up the pravrajyā on account of (their) vows.
[25] In future ... time may he further the teaching as now ...

q.l: ra pañai haira jsa. jsīną̄ hų̄ṣa tsī svaheʾe corr’d from au. byau byau tsīdai. [27] ttī-v-āṃ jsā hīra baiʾśa nva kṣamą hąmādai. sa-
khārma daivą̄ttą̄ āṃ ysīnī. yąną̄vaivai corr’d from sī. [28] bą̄ḍau sarbī khu ą̄rmaysda paḍą̄ byauṣṭa. jasta baiʾysa dīvyai vā
āysda yanāṃdai. [29] brruñą̄va śāśąʾñą tta khu cadą̄vąña rana: From here to 40 also in Paris Z 1-9 KT 3, p. 126 (55).phara sī bvą̄mayą. hajū vą̄ysyą-a-
ysmū [30] draya pīle sīyą śāstra ṭīka {ka} vībą̄ṣäʾ. abīdarma yą̄gaśą̄strra hīṣṣṭaiParis Z haṣṭa. yāgasthauna [31] ttu tta
bauttai sa khu hīya ną̄ma. {ttaya śī vąmaleśīle}. rrvī aysmū ārą̄hāką pañai jsāṃ brrī. [32] ttayą śī vamale-
śīle bvaijsīnai rana: drayą pīla sīyą baida prrakąraṇą haṣṭi. [33] svārtha parą̄rtha vīra hajū ną̄-
hauysa naṣaʾgaiʾsta. śāstrvā bīsai artha bą̄yą daśa khaiṇḍa aha. [34] gūttaira askhają̄ka. dahū pañai hai-
ra jsa. hamaysą̄va ṣai brrą̄vą hūṣai tsīyai jsīna. [35] ttayą śī daivaisū bvaijsyā haphau: jsaiʾṇą carya jsāṃ vą {pūñū}
{ma pañai ha} ahaṣṭą sagąkrrą varttai. [36] *sīyąMs. srīyą. drayą pīle. śāsttra prrakaraṇą ṭīka: sāja pūśa ra-
ṣṭą ahaṣṭą bą̄vaną yadai: [37] bāḍai sarbī. jsīna ṣāʾvai hūṣa tsī: pyara māñadą brrāva pąysą̄: hvaṇḍīnai
rana: [38] nāgrābada thaiyą ttīka. ādara tta yaṃ: valaka auna
khu tsvai jsaiṇa padaja {jsaiṇa baiysa śaiña.} śā ṣa yaṃda [39] ṣāmaña sakrra yāda tvą̄ hū-
ṣa bą̄stai sīyai jsāṃ dą̄ draina pīlvā ṣadyą̄yą tsāṣṭaka.

q.p: [26] The reverend ones will further the saṅghārāma (34) in every thing. Their life will increase. More and more they will go to bliss.
[27] Then all things will be for them according to wish. (35) May the devatā take the saṅghārāma in his/her protection.
[28] May their time arise like the sun first appeared at dawn. And may the lord buddhas, the deities (36) protect him!
[29] May he shine in the teaching like the cintāmaṇi jewel! Much instructed, knowledgeable, wise, (37) his mind impressed (vāsita).
[30] Instructed in the three piṭakas, the śāstras, ṭīkas, vibhāṣa, abhidharma, yogaśāstra, the eight yogasthānas.
[31] That (38) he knows like his own name. The propitiator of the royal mind, dear to everybody.
[32] The dashi 大師 Vimalaśīla, (39) a jewel of virtues, instructed in the three piṭakas, the eight prakaraṇas.
[33] Wise in the svārtha and parārtha, (40) outstanding, far evolved(?). He leads to the meanings inherent in all the śāstras, like a banner, a *noose.
[34] The furtherer of the gotra, manly in every thing. (41) Also (my/his?) brother german, may his life increase,
[35] the dashi Daivaisū, a collection of virtues. In the fine career, (42) he practices ... satkriyā.
[36] Instructed in the three piṭakas, the śāstras, prakaraṇas, and ṭīkas, he teaches, reads, and performs correct (43) ... bhāvanas.
[37] May his time arise, may his life increase! Like a father (my) brother germane (44) a jewel of a man,
[38] Nāgrābada the dade 大德 looks after (me/them?) thus. From childhood, (44a) when he came to a fine constitution, alone, he always
[39] in monkhood satkriyā always (45) he led it to increase. He is learned in the Law, the three piṭakas, he is full of faith, calm.

q.l: [40] thaiyą ttīka daivacadrą: baiysūśta bvą̄ thyau: parā-
ha parą̄ste vasvai baiʾysą parą̄yą: [41] sagakrrą saumañaFor ṣau° (B). cąryą tvā hų̄ṣa bą̄stai āstaka mūdai valaka au-
na śāśaʾña: [42] ya ṣṭau pūña śaikyai ahaṣṭą drayvā ranvā. cą̄ sa yai śaika vīśu hatcą̄yai baiśa. [43] prraṇahauną̄
sagrą̄vą̄sa paijsa baysgą yai. ñaśą prravai na mīrā nai pārśaʾ ttā dāśū: [44] thaiyą ttīka bvaida-śīla arthāṃ
haphā: vajrąyānī hajū thaiyą ttīka mista raijsai ṣadū [45] dadą idrai śakalaka. haiga ñahalmā khana-
dai. ų prraysą̄ u daidrą̄karabhądrą thaiyą ttīka krrādaḍa raijsai vagastą:. [46] brrą̄ra ñahalmā khana{dai}
dai u prraysā baiysā dą̄ sāja draina pīlvā ṣadyą̄yą: [47] vajrrą̄yāna sīvą: ahaṣṭa ṣīyą ha-
ḍāya ṣadū śakalaka padī āśī hīyai. [48] thaiyą ttīka dairāhasū hvaṇḍīnai rana: sagakrra
varttai ahaṣṭa ṣīya hąḍą̄ya. [49] āstāka *mūdaiB.; ms. pūdai. yāṃda sagasthāña kaḍą̄ṇabhadra ną̄ma
ysāra bvaijsai prraumų̄haʾ baiysa yāna dā baidą rą̄ysnādą [50] gūmā dąśta pajsa sūttra sīyą ttattrą
kailpe pharāka rāda hīyai kaḍą̄ṇamittrą jsīna pądairāka: [51] daivarāca ną̄ma. khu vajrasatta
spāśa: nāgrą̄ṣaikṣa brrą̄vą dąhų̄ raṣṭū śakalaka. [52] bhvaiśaʾsaidaśīle haigąleka ñahmāṃ. mattrā-
vą̄dą dā bai[da] rāysdādą amaṃgąle [53] kṣaidrākarapą̄ña ttravīle drāśakūleś changed to s (B.)? {ra} ysīra tsūmaṃdai caistą
są̄jara brrą̄vai drayą pīle sīyą baida [54] auttaraśą̄sttra vīñīdai {jsai} dąra vartta sakrrą avąrī. ttunai
ysaira mūnai ysaira hama haira yai.

q.p: [40] The dade Devacadra, may he quickly realize bodhi! (46) He practiced pure restraint at the order of the Buddha.
[41] He led this career of ... monkhood to increase. He dwelt in Ustaka from childhood (47) in the teaching.
[42] His merits were good ... in the Three Jewels. Just as he was good he ... all evil.
[43] (48) He (had) very thick ... of vows. May I humble pravrajita not die, may I not finish (my) service to him!
[44] The dade Buddhaśīla, (49) a mass of arthas, follower of Vajrayāna, wise (is) the Daide, great, sharp, full of faith.
[45] So much (are) his senses *complete, meek, humble, smiling, and full of grace. And the Daide Daidrākarabhadra, ..., sharp, ...
[46] ..., humble, smiling (51) and full of grace. He teaches the law of the buddhas, in faith in the three piṭakas.
[47] Learned in the Vajrayāna, ... by night and by day, (52) and full of faith, in *complete manner ...
[48] The Daide Dairāhasū, a jewel of a man. ... (53) by night and by day.
[49] He always dwelt at Ustāka, in a saṅghasthāna called Kaḍānabhadra (Kalyānabhadra). (54) He had a thousand merits, a director, master in the law of the Buddha-yāna;
[50] experienced, very clever, learned in the sūtras, tantras (55) for many kalpas. The kalyānamitra of many kings, the upholder of life.
[51] Devaruci by name: as when (56) one looks at the vajrasattva. Nāgrāśikṣa (my/his) brother, manly, truthful, and *complete.
[52] Bhvaiśaʾsiddhaśīlai, meek, humble, *maitrīvāda, (57) master in the law, ...
[53] Kṣaidrākarapuña, knower of the three piṭakas, ..., walking in the heart (? already as) a child. (58) Teacher brother, learned in the three piṭakas,
[54] the uttaraśāstra ... your hearts (59) my heart ...

q.l: [55] gvaṣṭaṃdūṃ hairtha vī śujai jsa hva hva. hąspīsa namasą cąryą ṣauma-
ña [56] tta rą̄śąʾ tsrīyą garśa khā dadą-idrai mų̄ña: khvai tta jvī hīʾnai byāvaira hamānai. [57] ysīnī maṃ ttą̄ bą̄yą
ayīṣṭhya daiśa vānvą̄. aśką̄ hama ṣiʾka są̄hą cā thyautta yai: [58] prrañaisū ttravīle jīyai ttą̄ gīha alā-
śva nvītha kuśale caryą pattaja. [59] {stānaḍa prraumūha ttravīlā u dvīlā daryai bīsagną auska au}
{nana burai [60] x ñaśa prravai baka-vąrṣą̄ka baka-sī nāgaiʾdravąrrda. hāysyai dīśaʾ vīra brrīyą jūhaunai ṣṭā}
[61] {ṣacū auna sakaica tsūṃ ttą̄ṣṭa aurga} hamārīja māśtą drairabaistamyai hąḍai. [62] śvaiʾ au bą̄stai hąḍā nakṣa-
ttra śattavaiṣa: nā hīya jsāṃ ttradą salī gvāysa ją̄ra. [63] gvą̄ysū paiṣkącą cā pądaidą bą̄ḍa jsa
utvaḍarų samągrą bīsagą vara gūśaʾdī vara. [64] ca ya ñūska mūja dadą salī vaṣṭa. pīruyā kī-
rāṃ hīyai pvaihą prracaina. [65] haṣḍa yuḍai rāṃdą pyaṃtsą caigvą̄ haḍa tsū. rrvīyāṃ ṣavāṃ jsa
hąraṣṭa mveśda āvaśaʾ mą̄ñada. [66] hva kaṣṭų̄ haiysda hāysą cą̄rą̄na vījsai parīya ñū-
vai dą̄ jsa satva pharāka: [67] vyachara baiysūśta paryą̄va jsā byaudai raysgą vī dą̄ya
rāśta. pūrą̄va jsāṃ māra tcahau hīña jsa hatsa: [68] āra baiśą̄vą dą̄yī cakrrą vainīyā va
parīją̄va satva aprraṣṭą nąravą̄ṇą kīthāṣṭa: [69] paryą̄vą jsāṃ sīyai raysgą vī vąjāysa

q.p: [55] We were separated suddenly from one another each and every one. Strive in the career of reverence, in monkhood!
[56] (60) He who is thus in command remains ... As I thus live may I be recalling ...
[57] Lead me into your care! (61) Place me firmly in the ten temples(?)! Perhaps I shall have the bliss I had before.
[58] Prañaisū, knower of the three piṭakas, assist his life(?)! Subdue sloth, (62) develop the kuśala-caryā!
[59] The *teachers, directors, knowers of the three and two piṭakas, to the entire bhikṣusaṅgha, from high to low,
[60] (63) I the humble pravrajita of few years, of little learning, Nāgendravardha, in a distant place, in love and affection,
[61] (64) in Shazhou, I go to you with honor in reverence. Of the month of Hamārīja the 23rd day,
[62] the day led by the Dog, the nakṣatra (65) Śatabhiṣa, having entered the year of the Dragon. May the separations end!
[63] The separation and division made for me from the (Jewel) Land (66) and even more the entire bhikṣusaṅgha there in Gūśaṃdā,
[64] which was my ... for so many years (67) on account of the blow of former karmas.
[65] I made a report to the king, but he has gone to China. From the royal ... (68) the grace has reached out like space.
[66] I have fallen far away now ... Please instruct (69) many beings with the Law!
[67] Devote yourselves to bodhi! May you please quickly obtain (70) the rule of the Law! May you overcome Māra with his four(-fold) army!
[68] ... the wheel of the Law ... (71) May you deliver the beings ... in the city of nirvāṇa!
[69] May you please teach quickly ... (72) Devote yourselves to bodhi! Go out to the nirupadhiśeṣa (nirvāṇa)!

q.l: abvāmaya. baka valąka. bąką-sī. nāgeʾdravarrda. pīḍaka ttą̄ hąṣḍi yuḍai ṣacū
āna. daryai bīsagą vą auska au naną burai. [72] na hamyai īyai drāṃ khu bīsaja āṣaʾ. ñaśa
prravai pąhvastą yai nāṃdą stā vąmāḍa: [73] dara parą̄hąʾ ājīde ṣacų̄ kītha. baiʾysūña śaikṣą̄-
va jsaṃją hīya mista. [74] tvā iṣṭai śaka na ra gatcañūṃ ną̄ ysathą. parāhą paraihaume hī-
ya hauva mista ya. [75] vīna sāna vīna gą̄ḍai mara āvūṃ drunai: utvąḍarrvīā pīrmāttamā pū-
ñāṃ jsa rrvīyā. {ñaśa prravai na mīrā nai pāśaʾ ttā dāśu} [76] ca ttā ysūrāaiñai mista ālo jsaʾ vąleka
ñaśa abausta aysmū kaiṇa cai na paysādai. [77] prrahaja aysmū klaiʾśauʾ jsa pvīstą ṣṭi. satsą̄ra jsāṃ kālākadvai bvāmañāe
ṣṭa. [78] vaña au ttą̄ baiʾysūña aysmū jsa kṣamiyūṃ: ca ttą̄ [a]ysmūau jsai ñaiysāra ttā na yąnīryāṃ [79] ñaśa prravai na
mīrą̄ nai pārśaʾ ttą̄ dą̄śų Change of hand.ttaña ka ttā: ttāṃ ñaśa

q.p: [70] I humble pravrajita foolish, ignorant, obstructed, (73) lacking knowledge, a little child, of little learning, Nāgeʾdrravarrda,
[71] I have sent you this letter (while) in Shazhou, (74) for the entire bhikṣusaṅgha from high to low.
[72] It could not be such as would be worthy of the bhikṣusaṅgha. I humble (75) pravrajita was beaten, humbled, weary, worn out,
[73] I brought the entire śīla to the city of Shazhou, the order of the Buddha, (76) the great one regarding killing.
[74] ... that well. I will not break it for *nine births. (77) The power of practicing restraint was great.
[75] Without enemies, without ... I have come here safely—by superior outstanding merits—to the court.
[76] What toward you ... great ... a child, (79) humble, what I have not recognized on acount of an ignorant mind.
[77] The mind of a common person (pṛthagjana) is covered by kleśas; saṃsāra is ...
[78] Here and now may I please you with a mind (directed toward) bodhi! Those who belittle you in their minds, may they not do that to you!
[79] May I humble pravrajita not die (before) I have finished my service to you! ...

note.p: Beginning of a summary of the Saddharmapuṇḍarīka-sūtra, ed. Bailey, 1971. Guide² [18.18].

q.l: : saidhama aikayāṃ bārai śau baiʾysūña {da} padai: aurga ī tyai hālai ṣadyā
: ya vaña: rahāsä kīḍa mesta tvara pūīstī garkha: draya padā-v-ū hagrra-

q.p: (82) Welfare! To the Ekayāna vehicle, the one path to bodhi,
may there be reverence toward it in faith.
(83) Now, the very great mystery, exceedingly covered, heavy (to fathom).
Three paths and (84) one crossroad.

q.l: tta pyūṣṭä śāstāra śīña baiḍa grradhakūṭä gara vī āstai yai maista raṣaʾyi gai bī-
sagäjai karvīną̄ mista: phara ysāra baudhasatvä ūvāra ttyāau hālai hauda-pa-
dya sapatta hvai: gabīra hvai vara dva maista rahāsa: drayi vara śā-v-ū nirä-
: vą̄ṇva katha pva pasvai bīśa mauñadū: auvama hva va ttyai pasvai bīśa jsa
: cū au satsāra sūśtä pahaisīda ṣāvā: kīḍa mvaiśdūʾ baka mvaiśdīʾjai pyaura jsa
: hā tta jasta baiʾysa nīśīda satvau baidai dāvīnai bārä pūra aurmaysdau māña-
: dū bvaiya harūñīda dharma-pada rāśīʾda hamaga naravauṇa

q.p: Thus it is heard: The teacher at one time dwelt on Mount Gṛdhrakūṭa, the great ṛṣi, surrounded (85) by a great assembly of monks.
Many thousand exalted bodhisattvas, to them he spoke the seven-fold (86) success (sampatti).
There the two profound great mysteries, there the three and the one and (87) the city of nirvāṇa.
Listen to the likeness of the burning house. He spoke there the parable: From that burning house,
(88) when saṃsāra is purified, the śrāvakas escape—being very pitiful and small—by the cloud of mercy.
(89) The lord buddhas throw down upon those beings the rain of the Law. Like the moon and the sun, (90) they shine (upon them) rays.
They straighten the dharma path, making it equal (toward) nirvāṇa.

note.p: Letter from Tathāgataśrībhadra, director of the Drūttīra monastery, ed. Kumamoto, 1982, Text III, which the translation below follows in the main. The paragraph division from line 125 is that of Kumamoto.

q.l: {bvaiya has}pvaisū ttā hāysye dīśaʾ vīra byūra jū ā
āśirī:Change of hand. uvārya garkhyau vaistārya pūñau kūśala-mūla: u garkhyai haura varāśauʾmai u bvamai
parāhaʾ jsa haphve u nva vīnī śaikṣāvau dījsą̄ka: u baʾysūñai parau paṣṭauñāka:
u baʾysūñai jsaiṇai caryai tsāka: u lyāye lyākauttarye phara virā thanyeB.: tta ttye and ttanye. vīrā
u haiysdai daścai sañai virā gūmāva: u maistyai aurmaysda mą̄ñada jastāṃ baʾysai hī-
ya attīka hīye x x {nva} nva aysmū parau hagrāhāʾka hama-vakṣaunara ha-
ma-ysāvaṣau brrāvarau dharmajñāna: kṣattapūña javaidrākarapūñaOr.kṣanta°? (B.). vīdāśū-
ra-pūña hāysye dīśaʾ vīra naysdai grau brrīyausta jūhauʾnai aysmū jsa
ṣacū au aurga drunā pvaisauma pvaisū khu tta vaña haiysda vī ttyai śairkya ja-
sta baʾysau jsa ayīkṣai vaṣāʾvāysau jsāṃ kāla vīra uvārrvā draiyvā saskhā-
rrvā u tcaurya m{ā}hābūvau avaysamāśca hadravya u pajsi skadau baida

q.p: (91) I ask about you in distant land ten thousand times.

(92) Reverend one. — Equipped with exalted, heavy, extended merits and roots of goodness, and the heavy śīla of the experiencing of generosity and of knowledge (93) and upholder of the śikṣāpadas according to the vinaya, and promoter of the order of the buddhas, (94) and walker in the fine career of the buddhas, and experienced in the speech of the world and that which is beyond the world, in ..., (95) and in the present skill in the means, and, like the great sun, (96) assembler of the order according to (the) mind of the ... of the ... of the lord buddhas, to the brothers performing the same upasthāna, (97) of the same birth: Dharmajñāna, Kṣitapuña, Javendrākarapuña, Vidāśūrapuña (98) in a distant place, I, with a near, warm, loving and caring mind (99) in Shazhou in reverence ask the question of (your) health, so that thus now at present (100) at that good time of the varṣāvāsa ... from the lord buddhas he may be well, at peace, and healthy in the middle of the ... of the three (101) saṃskāras and four mahābhūtas and in the five skandhas.

q.l: ttyai kaiṇau ma ñaśa prravai āśaʾ jastāṃ jsa u dī
śadai nāvau jsa ttadī aisa āva ttuka paijai khu tta sa-ysāra salī vaṣṭa
śairkya hamai tsāṣṭa u drunai: jasta baʾysa dīvya-v-au āysda yanaudai jsī-
nau hūṣa tsī svahau bye bye tsīdai ttī-v-au jsāṃ harabaśa nva kṣama hamaudai
ma jsāṃ sa pūña spyaudai khvai jsa na gvaiysai:

q.p:
(102) For that reason here, (I) the humble pravrajita request from the gods of space and (103) and from the
nāgas under the earth (as my) only desire and wish the following: that thus for a hundred thousand years *you may be (104) well, at peace, and healthy. May the lord buddhas (and) the deities protect you! (105) May your life increase! May blessings come to you more and more! May then all things be for you according to wish! (106) May here only merits be in sufficient quantity, so that *I may may not be separated from him(?)!

q.l: : uvārya garkhya vaistārya pūñau kūśala-mūla u garkhyai haura varā-
śauʾmai u hauva u śarī ttīśaʾ jsa haphvai u vrraśama yakṣana rauda hī-
ye ttīśaʾ jsa pakairma u hīña bāyaumai vīra gūmā daścai u
kyaisara sarau mauñada ñauhīñai ttīśaʾsta {avamāvyau śāsanāvaca-
{u śau-ysā} : rrvī parau u śau-ysā pūra māñada rrvī aysmū ārā
rya dīhīñau bvajsāṃ gūṇa ṣahaunau jsą} hāʾka rājsadauda pakūṣdä brrañadai
{haphvai ca} dā {vaśaʾrana māñada} : — sa-ysārya pāraysau hadravya
āśaʾ jastāṃ jsa u dī śadai nāvau jsa u hadravya hvaṇḍä jsa ysūṣṭä u
bvaijai u śau-ysā pūra mą̄ñada uvī aysmū ārāhāka u rājadau pakūṣḍä
sa-ysārya pāraysau hadrai-vya brrauñadai avamāvyau śāsanāvaca-
rya dahīñau bvaujsāṃ gūṇa ṣahaunau jsa haphvai ca {x} nvavara naṣkastyai vīysa
spūlaka mauñada: a{mū}ścu {ī}ḍai ysīra kaścai heʾthīye. ca ṣṭāṃ vaña ttaOr.ttu (B.)?
śca hauda kāla panvauḍai: aścai īḍa drai kṣa aścū gvaṣṭaigv{e}°. ysathūā: śā-janavai
hvaṇḍa ca brrī satva jsa hva hamya:
śą̄ haḍā ysāra jūna byāva tsū valaka ñauysarañauys{e}ra. ṣaiṣṭai līka nvavara {x}
naṣkaista vīysa spūlaka mą̄ñada: ysāryau bvaujsāṃ jsa bvaujsāda: nva a-
ysmū hvaṇḍīnai rana: bakalakyai amanā kaiṇa: haiysde ysūra kaiṇa jīya-
ka padaida khu paradaiśai tcīrauka: khvai ṣṭāṃ spāśū jsīna ma pā pha naiśta
hasta khu mūḍa kṣīra khu jve kṣīra vīnau sauhaʾ:

q.p: (107) Equipped with exalted, heavy, extended merits and roots of goodness and the experiencing of heavy generosity (108) and power and glory (and) splendor, (109) and similar to the splendor of Vaiśramana king of yakṣas, and experienced and skilled in the leading of the army and (110) similar to the lion with its mane, preeminent, resplendent {equipped with innumerable ... teachings, manly virtues, good qualities, and merits, and single-born}, like the king’s command and a single-born son the pleaser of the royal mind, shining in the royal palace {like a vajra}—among a hundred thousand servants (113) acknowledged and praised by the gods in space, by the nāgas under the earth, and by men in the intermediate realm. (114) And like a single-born son the pleaser of the senses and the mind, and in the royal palace (115) shining among a hundred thousand servants, equipped with innumerable ... teachings, (116) manly virtues, good qualities, and merits, like a new, opening lotus (117) bud. He has drawn out ... who now (118) ... at the seven times daily, he has made some(?) three (six), some(?) are separated from you in births(?), (119) the men of the Land of Copper(?), who have become separated from dear beings. (120) A thousand times in one day he was (they were) remembered, like a young, ..., ..., new (121) opening lotus bud, virtuous with a thousand virtues, at (122) will a jewel of a man, because of a little unpleasantness, now, because of anger, (123) he has made (his) life(?) like the exiled cakravāka bird. When I look at him, there is not much life for me hereafter. (124) It is better if one died in (one’s own) land than if one lived in a land without happiness.

q.l: rrvī vī haṣḍä yanau: drūttīrai prraumą̄haʾ ttathāgatta śrībhadra āstana āśaʾ-
ryai: maihai ttā rrvī aysmū ārāhaʾmai kaiṇa haṣḍa caiga kṣīrīrāṣṭa
u khu mara ṣacu āvadū rrvīye mvaśta jsāṃ ma ḍai ku paiʾjsa śairka pasta spāṣṭai:
auda vaña būrai: u pada hīye ma hairī pacaḍa na yai: khu ttā ttaujai-
ra mą̄śta hva sa khuī gaisā ttī hā ḍai kū pyatsa haṣḍä yūḍādū sa ca maihai
ṣṭāṃ āśaʾ mą̄ña rrvī parau tta tta ṣṭai sa cada anvaśta caiga kṣīrāṣṭa bāḍa hamāvai
ama āśaʾrya āda yanīryau khu tsū hamīryau: ttī-v-au ḍai kū tta tta pasta sa śaphī-
ḍa bāḍa ṣṭai u kamacuvau hadrajīda: u drau haira hvañara ca na dyāṃdaThus Kumamoto; B.: nyāṃda u na ṣṭau jai. u na pyauṣṭā-
ṣṭada u nau pasta paśāvai u ttī na bāysdaudū yauda hā haṣḍa yūḍādū sa
mą̄ñau parya paśāvai: u däda hā baṣṭadū khu draiyau kaṇa parau pasta sa dra-
ya tsūva u baiśa na tsvai hamīryau: u ttyau kaṇāṃ jsāṃ parau tta tta pasta sa khu au-
na bāysdai tta tta khalavī vā padīmyaira sa khu tta āśaʾ avadāya kaśaudai
ca vā rrvī jsa āra naraumīyai ama hagrīhyara: u khalavī hā padaidāṃdū
u āśaʾrya gākṣā hā akṣara nīśūdū: u draya tsūda gūśaʾdī thaiya
ttīka nāgaidravarda: u viśeʾsagrārmī dvīle sīvadākarauca: u gūmattī-
rai āśaʾrī vīrapūña brrakhaysda mą̄śtai: tsūdai: u ttī vā {ca} cvāvaja mą̄śta ja-
navai vī au haḍā āva ana vaijalaka u syau haḍai u parau-v-au ṣa ṣṭaiau sa gaisīryau
parau vā na nījsą̄ṣṭauda sa paḍā vā haira hūryaira cau vā śaikä parau ājedeṃ sa gaisara

q.p: [61] (125) We make a report to the court, the directors of the Drūttīrai (monastery), Ttathāgattaśrībhadra and the other reverend ones. (126) We (made) the report to you on our way to China in order to gratify the royal mind.
[62] (127) And when we came here to Shazhou, the Linggong deigned look very kindly upon the royal favor (= gift) here. (128) Until now, and the manner of the road hither was not the pristine one.

[63] When (129) in the month of Ttāmjāra he said to you: “However are you going to return?” — then we made a report before the Linggong: “As for us (130) now, the monks, ours is a royal order; it is as follows: “However difficult the land (on the way) to China may be, (131) you, reverend ones, take care that you will have left!”

[64] Then the Linggong deigned utter: “The land is in turmoil, and the men of Ganzhou will detain you. And you must say such things as you have not seen and not heard.” (133) And he did not deign to release us.

[65] And then we did not take heed. And we repeatedly made a report: (134) “Deign release our men!” And we went to him so much that he gave the order for three of us: “(You) three (135) may go, but you may not all go!”See Kumamoto, Studies II, p. 105.

[66] And he gave us now an order regarding those: “If you now take heed, then make me a *written promise: ‘If the monks fall upon a non-road, (137) whatever blame might issue from the court for us, you will take upon yourselves!”

[67] And we made a *written promise to him, (138) and we, the monks and the home-dwellers, put our akṣaras on it. And the three went: the dade of Gūśaṃʾda, (139) Nāgendravardha; the dvaipiṭika of the Viśesagrārma monastery, Sīvadākarauca; and (140) the reverend Vīrapuña of the Gūmattīra monastery. They went in the (8th) month of Braṃkhaysda.

[68] And then, in the (1st) month of Cvātaja, (141) the envoys came from the (Golden) Land, Ana, Vaijalaka, and Syau Haḍai, and the order for is us: “Return!” (142) But they did not show (us) the order (saying): “First give us something, since we brought you the nice order: ‘Return!’”

q.l: u ḍaikū-v-au ysūmauñai bairai pasta hūḍai śā śā u hada-v-au ma haira na ye u
tta hā baira hūḍādū tcaurai u ttī-v-au ana vaijaleka tta tta hvai sa haira ba-
kala hamyai u adravā{ya}ysa vā ṇaiyaraThus Kumamoto; B.: ṇai yu u. tta ttai hvadū sa paḍā vā parau
nījsāña: u parau vā nījsą̄ṣṭai u parau-v-au tta tta ye kaumya pad^saña jsa tsva hamāṃdai
tsīdī u ttau ra vā baiʾrai na hūḍai: u tta ttau hvai sa ama caiga kṣīra khu na tsūda u ttī-
v-au ḍai kū vā śūʾ vī hū{ñai}ḍaiga pasta hūḍai śą̄ u tta ttau hvai sa ttu vā vāsta hū-
ryara u nai hvaḍādū u tta ttau hvai sa vañau sa naṣphaścūB.: naṣkaścū with “unusual shape of ṣka.”: u ttī maihai tta tta hvāṃdū
sa tsau maihai vā caiga kṣīrāṣṭa tsūdū: u tta hvāṃdū sa aurāsa ha paśara maihai tsau
u aurāsa hā paśauda: u ḍai kū va tta tta pasta sa khu draya āśaʾ tsūda haudama mą̄śta
hairī vā phara na āva ttaka ra būḍa na paśā hamārai: u khu bausta sa ḍai kū va na pa-
sta paśāvai: u ttyau bairau kaṇa ḍai kū pasta pyūṣṭai u ysaura pasta yuḍai: u dīdai mā-
ścai vā hūḍai: u ttī-v-au {tta tta hvai} jsāThus Kumamoto; B.: jsa. ma pharāka śahvaistaThus Kumamoto; B.: śa hvaiñū.: u ttī jsāṃ ma gūmattīrai āśarī ye
dharmaidrākarapūña nauma: u nārai hā ṇaistai u ca va haiysda śā-v-ī mūra ā
ra haira ya ttu-v-ai ysyai pvaica śā haiysdai kaumadai śai u haʾḍa baista chā u cīva-
rau phaurthaka śau būśīʾnai śā pvaica āra u ttī-v-ai jsi ttā janaivai vīrāṣṭa
khalavī padaidai śā baysgye kabala u ttī jsä-ṃ ma kamacu-pa sīca yavanaidra-
ja ną̄ma u ttu jsā ttā hāysa bāstai janavai vīrāṣṭai khalavī padädai pajsūsa

q.p: [69] (143) And the Linggong had deigned give us a winter coat each. And we had nothing else, so (144) we gave them four coats. Then Ana the Younger said to us: (145) “That was too little! Put (some) underwear (on top of the pile)!”
[70] We said to him: “First (146) show us the order!” And so he showed (us) the order. And the order to us was thus: “In whatever manner (by whatever expedient) they can go (147) they shall go!”

[71] And he did not give them the coats. And he said to them thus: “How is it that you did not go to China?” And then (148) the Linggong *in the meantime had deigned give us one *soft coat. And he said to us thus: “Give me that garment!” (149) And we did not give (it) to him. And he said to us thus: “Now I’ll just throw you out!”
[72] And then we said: (150) “We are going!” We went hither to China. And (first) we said: “Send the information to them—we are going” (151) And they sent the information.
[73] And there the Linggong deigned utter: “If the three monks have left (and) in the seventh month (152) no word has come at all to us, those (with you) shall no more be sent!”

[74] And when they (we?) learned: “the Linggong has not deigned (153) send (any more), and the Linggong has heard about these coats and has become angry,” and in the third month (154) he gave it to us/them. And then {he said to us} he *chastizedSee Kumamoto, Studies II, p. 137. many of us/them here.

[75] And then there was here a reverend one from the Gūmattīra (monastery), (155) a certain Dharmaidrākarapūña. And he settled his wife there. And at present whatever things there were worth even a single copper mūrā (156) that he took for her(?): one roll of cloth, one pair of trousers that he had, and a *coat of 20 chās, and (157) one phaurtaka coat, one *goat fur coat(?) worth one roll of cloth. And then (158) he made a *sworn statement of it for you in the (Golden) Land: “one thick blanket.”

[76] And then here (there was) a certain Ganzhou’eseSee Emmerick, 1985b, pp. 307-8. Sīca Yavanaindraja (159). And him he led away to you. He made a *sworn statement to the (Golden) Land: (160) “fifteen blankets.”

q.l: u ttī-v-ai hā a drūttīrai prraumą̄haʾ ttathāgatta śrībhadra pyāste sa tta
{a} kau au aścai kaiṇa hāysa bāya: u māñau jsāṃ ma aścai kaṇa paśa u pakūṣṭa
auna kau baida tcauttai paijsāṃ arīśaʾ avajsāmā yūḍai khu vaña haiysda vī
ttyai baʾysau śāśaʾ hīye āysāja parā spāṣṭai u ñaśau prravaiyau hī-
ye pārśaʾ byāva paryā yūḍai khu vā śaiʾ pada śai parau
khu ma hadravya na jau khu ma hadravya na jau
hīya mvaśta haraysdai khva dada vī būrai na (ha)myai na bīysajārai khu pada na
dāśauma nāvai byaudai khva ma na aihaiʾjīda
u ḍai kū maista hvaṇḍa pyūṣṭāṃda u tta tta hvada sa khu däda ṣadarai ṣṭai cą au āśauʾ
ttira jsa parī auryai ttī ṣa hvai āśauʾ baida khu tcauttai u vīśūʾ nauma ma padadai

q.p: [77] And then I, Tathāgataśrībhadra, director of the Drūttīra (monastery), said to him: (161) “For what reason are you leading (them) away? And for what reason are you sending off our men here? And in the palace, (162) whom did you ... upon? You did them great unpleasantness and dishonor, if at present (163) you shall deign to see the grace of the teaching of the Buddha and (164, b2) you shall deign to recall the service of (us) humble pravrajitas. How does the favor of one order extend to a second road? How (can) they not seize it as far as that? (b1) How (can there be) no fighting here?Cf. Kumamoto, Studies II, pp. 155-6. How (can) we not take (and) find(?) the road and be done with it? How (can) they not control it here?”

[78] And the Linggong (and) the great men heard and said: “He has so much faith that he deigns to revere the monks with his forehead.” Then he said: “How could I *restrain the monks! I made a bad name here!”

note.p: Report to the Court. Lines a6-b21 (= P 2786 lines 172-250) ed. Kumamoto, 1982, Text II, which the translation below follows in the main. The paragraph division from line 125 on is that of Kumamoto. Additions to text and translation are from P 2786. See also Kumamoto, 1991a, b.

q.l: parau tta tta ye khu pada sūrā ṣṭi v[ā t]sū[va
sa tsūva : ttī-v-au hvañīye sa mūñara pā[t]ca /
rya pātca vā hāysa tsūva khu /
hvañīye tta tta yada: parau-v-au tta tta [y]e

q.p: The order to was thus: “If the road is *clear come here!... just come!” Then, if he should say to you: “Remain!” then [... if] he should say: “The road is not clear....... then, in that case, go away.” If he should say: “Do thus!” thus was the order to you:

q.l: ñaśe bīsaP 2786 line 172 ñaśau jsā bīsau : . —
: parau {vau} tta tta ye rrvī jsa au cega kṣīrāṣṭa na [parīdä vījaiṣṭä]
ca pade ṣṭe ttye hīya au habā capasta[kä ...]
se tcerthūśī khau *paḍāMs. a[ña]ḍā, P 2786 line 174 capastąkä khu [pa]ḍā. hīsyara khū pa[da sūrā ṣṭāvai]
ḍai kau habā bvāvai : īra u hūra u bvīysana [hąʾmiʾtcī]
{nva} nauhya hīsīye : ttaka pārysā ca ttā rrv[ī] v[ī] [haṣḍä yu]-
ḍauda sa pārśauʾ au kṣama yūḍai caiga kṣīra js[a ttyau kaiṇa]
parau tta tta ye sa tsīda khu mara āvadū ka[mäcū vī bā]-

q.p: [33] Humble servants, (7) the order was thus: “From the court to China [they] do not [deign to look]. (8) How the road is (the Ling Gong knows) its current condition.” Capastaka [said ...] (9) the jiédùshî: “Come as before!” If the road [is clear], (10) the Ling Gong will know (its) condition. The jade and the *liquor and the *goat skin(?) should come (11) at the beginning of ...”

[34] Those servants (of yours) who [reported] to you to the court (12): “It pleases us to do service (and) to go to China.”Kumamoto, Studies II, p. 30. [For them] (13) the order was thus, that they should go.

q.l: parau tta tta ye sa tsīda khu mara āvadū ka[mäcū vī bā]-
ḍa bījaudaP 2786 lines 178-9 bīją̄tta. ye : raijsai ma pada hīya tsūma na [ya. parau jsau]
tta tta ya sa pada sūrā na ṣṭāvai pharākyai ra [vä pā]P 2786 lines 180-1 pharākyau hvąṇḍā hīyai ravä pā kīrä.
hīye kīra naiśta khvai jsāṃ sa ṣacū bīsa ḍe [kau capasta]-
ka hvañīye tta tta yana pada hīye au habā [ttakä bvā]-
ṣacu ḍe kau tta tta hve
re| |ca pada hīye habā ṣṭe ṣa ī[ma...]
{thai-śī ṣaʾ} jsāṃ ā drau kāla khu raysga

vaña būra haryadū {khu}P 2786 lines 182-4 tta tta yąną pada hīyai au habā ttakä bvārai : ṣacū ḍī kau tta hvai sa. cą pada hīyai habā ṣṭai ṣąʾ īmą aśa naiśtą svī hąmai : u vąña būrä haryadū : ca jsā vā vaijalakä gauśtą : .

q.p: [35] When we came here to Ganzhou the land was destroyed. [There was] no going on the sharp (harsh?) road here. [The order] was thus: “(If) the road is not clear, (16) it is not the business of the many ... Whatever the Ling Gong in Shazhou (17) should say to Capastaka, do that. (As for) the current condition of the road, [those with you] know (it).”

[36] (17a) The Ling Gong of Shazhou said: (18) “What is the condition of the road to Shazhou, that (is): today [there are no horses, tomorrow there will be]. (19) {The dashi } has come as much time as fast [horses take?]. (20) We have survived till now(?).”

q.l: ca jsāṃ vā [vaijalakä gauśtą]P 2786 lines 184-5 a jsā vā vaijalakä gauśtą : .
parau ā ṣaʾ jsāṃ tta tta ṣṭe sa khu sa ḍai k[au hvāñīye tta tta]
yada : ḍai kau jsāṃ tta tta hveCorr’d from ysge. sa khu [vā rrvī *jsa caiga kṣī]-
rāṣṭa īra hīya u haura u bvīysana u [h]ai[matcī? hīyą mvaiśdaʾ]-
na haraṣṭa ya ama pā hāysa tsāva ma[ra] j[s]āṃ [vīśauʾ ną̄]-P 2786 lines 187-8 u haʾmatcī hīyą : mvaiśdaʾna.
ma na hamīya {vaña ttā draya māśta tsū [...]
vā phara na a ṣṭa a} vaña ṣaʾ rrvī śkyaise x [ma aśtą caiga]P 2786 lines 189-90 śkyaisą cą ma aśtą caiga.
kṣīra na hīsīye ama ra pā hāysa na tsū /
ca tta āśaʾrya rrvī vī haṣḍa yūḍauda [pā]r[ś]auʾ au [kṣamä yūḍai]
caga kṣī tsauai ttyau va ttadī baida cīvara ye [ṣāʾ jsā maṃgā]-

q.p: [37] (21) The order which has come [in the hand of Vaijalaka], that is thus: “As soon as the Ling Gong [says it, thus] (22) you must do.” Now the Ling Gong said thus: “If [from the court (23-25) the favor (= gift) of the jade and the *liquor and the *goat skin and [...] should not have reached [China], then you must go away (and) there will not be here a reputation [of bad men?]. Now, should the gift of the court ... not arrive in China, then you can not go away (?).”Deleted line: Now to you for three months gone ... but ... there is not much.
[38] (28) Those monks who reported thus to the court (that): “[It pleases us to do] service (and) to go to China,” for them there there was only an overcoat. (30) It has gone old.

q.l: ca jsāṃ ñaśa bīsa: sagai ṣṭe ṣaʾ jsāṃ va [pā haḍa hī]-
ye nva padajai na tsū hamye tta tta khu habū[saṃ: u rrvī]
parau tta ra haugrrautta yanī{tta}na paiʾjsa hatcasta ye [...]
ra hā naspava ca jsāṃ kamacu bāḍa ṣaʾ jsāṃ x [...]P 2786 lines 195-6 hatcastą yai hauvą hā nasyąvą : .
ranījai janavai hīya u ysarnai bāḍa hī[ya nauma]P 2786 lines 196-7 bāḍa ṣąʾ jsā śaphīḍa ṣṭai : ca jsā ranījai.
ṣaʾ jsāṃ maista ṣṭai khu {ra} tta pvai tsūñai ha[māve khu sauhacū hī]-
sau varau nva bāḍa u janavai hīye [ną̄ma kamacū hana va]
u auhaʾvau va u bīrukau va u mai[śtaryau hva]-
ṇḍa vī bura ca sa thautta rrvīya mva[ś]ca [hagrrauttaudä ī]-
ya ttyau vaskau varī śkyaisa jsą̄vai tta tta khu thautta

q.p: [39] As far as the humble servant (Ana) Saṃgai, is concerned, (31) he has not then been able to go according to the manner of [an envoy], as befitting. (32) [And] the order [of the court], may I be able to uphold (it). He (I) was not very broken (33) and [(his/my) strength] not sufficient. As for the land of Ganzhou, it is now [in confusion. As for the name] (34) of the Land of Jewels and the Golden Land, (35) it is great. When he hears thus, he will have to go.

[40] [When] (36) we come [to Suzhou], there for us/them according to the [name] of the Land (of Jewels) and the (Golden) Land (37), [to the Khan of Ganzhou], to the öges, and to the buyruqs, and to the (other) greater (38) men to whom *just as before the royal favor may have been [extended], (39) to them the favor shall go right away, just like before.

q.l: sau hā hauva nayseye {khu ttā haṣḍä na}
ttā haṣḍa na darrvai ya bīsau parau na kṣa[ma u ā]-P 2786 line 203 nasyaiyą : vaṣṭä vī ttā haṣdä na darrvai.
ra baida hīsū khu tta rrvī vī jastuña a[ysmya tta tta īyai]
sa khu ṣaʾ pada prrahīśta khu vā kamacu bāḍa /P 2786 line 205-6 kamacū vāṣṭä lakyai śkyaisa hīyą.
hīya mvaśca haraysde ttī va rrvīya mva[śca na habūsa]-

q.p: [41] (40) The power of (these) humble servants is failing. (41) I did not dare make a report to you. Please do not make (these humble) servants [uphold] the order, and (42) I shall incur a sin.

[42] If [it should be] like that in the lordly mind toward the court: (43) “If the road opens up or if [to] the land of Ganzhou (44) the favor of [(even) a small favor] extends, then (45) it shall not be fitting as a royal favor.”

q.l: ttī pā ma pāraysā ya ca ttā rrvī vī [haṣḍä yūḍāṃdä]
sa caga kṣīra tsau pāraśaʾ yanau ca lāOr.lī. ṣī kau sagīna ka [ṣąʾ āśīʾ]P 2786 lines 208-9 sagīna yai ṣąʾ āśīʾ yai.
ye {mārāpyarau} va u ṣaumaña paśāvai gākṣau [brrāvąrāṃ jsä]
jsa ttvaiThus Kumamoto for B.’s tsvai. – Possibly for ttavai (OKhot. ttagata-). mārāpyarau nāvai baiśa parāvai [haṣḍä yūḍai]
sa caga kṣīra tsū rrvīya mvaśca nāvai u hāysa x /P 2786 line 211 hāysą ttā tsvai ca.

q.p: [43] Then there were here servants who [made a report] to you to the court]: (46) “We are going to China to do service.” There was a certain Lā Ṣīkau from Saga [a monk]. (47) He relinquished monkhood together with his two home-dwelling brothers. (48) He received his *property from his parents and sold all of it. [He reported]: (49) “I am going to China.” He received the royal favor and [went] away [to you].

q.l: mau thāle tcūhaʾ paṣaʾP 2786 line 211 paḍä. ttā rrvī vī haṣḍä yūḍ[ai sa caigą kṣī]-
ra tsū chū bīra vīrāṣṭa hā hagaiṣṭa hūḍai x /

na tsīnai rrvī vī hā kabala haiśūʾ ssaP 2786 lines 213-6 hagauṣṭa hūḍai rrvī vī ttā kabala haiśūʾ ssa khu caiga kṣīrą na tsīnai : vīna ttakyai hadana yai ca salā na hamaiʾstai parau na pacai : mara au pā hvai sa parauvä hagrrīhāña ttai : .

q.p: [44] (50) Mau Thāle Tcūhaʾ Paḍä reported to you to the court: (51) “I am going [to China].” He gave (his) finger to Chū Bīrä [(saying):]See Kumamoto, Studies II, p. 151. (52) “Were I not to go [to China], I should give a hundred blankets to the court.”
[45] (P 2786: Apart from him, there was no other who did not change the word or conceal the order. Later, he said here: “You must uphold the orders!”)

q.l: śau ye ṣaʾ bīsakvā bīse kadūja ye [... nā]-
vai hāa-a. P 2786 lines 216-8 cą būnīyaṃja kharaśau yai ṣąʾ bīsakvā bīsai kadvaja yai u kadvajä au thī u bvaiysya nāvai hāysą ttā tsvai. japha ṇaista kadūeja au thī gu hīya /
mvaśca haraṣṭa mvaśta hagrauttai u gaisā ttā :

q.p: [46] There was a certain Kharaśau from Būnīya. (53) (Though living) among the Bīsakas, he was from Kadva. (P 2786 then: And, being from Kadva, he *pulled (out? and) took the ... (and) went away.)
[47] (54) The *dispute was settled for him (in his favor?). Now the man from Kadva ... (55) the (royal) mercy was extended. He accepted the mercy and returned to you(?).

q.l: | ja vaijalaka ye ṣaʾ īra parāvai u kūṣḍa vī[ra bastau]-
da haṣḍä ttā yūḍai sa caiga kṣīra tsū u īra [parāthū? u va?]-
ra japha na hamye tcagalaṃ auna jsā gū rrvīya mvaśta /

hāysa ttā tsūe —a-a. P 2786 lines 218-20 cą būnīyaṃjya vaijalakä yai ṣąʾ īra parāvai : u kūṣḍa vīrai bastauda u japhai āṣṭaṃdą hamau japhai ra na hamyai u mvaiśdaʾ hagrrauttai u gaisāttą̄ . x byanyami

q.p: [48] There was a certain (56) Vaijalaka from Būnīya. He sold jade. And they bound him at the court gate.
[49] (P 2786: A dispute was about to arise, but there was no dipute. He accepted the favor and returned to you.)

[50] (57) He made a report to you: “I am going to China [to sell?] jade. (58) There was no dispute *there.” Now he has escaped the *chain.See Kumamoto, Studies II, pp. 48-49. [He obtained] the royal mercy. (59) He went away to you.

q.l: / x [paḍ]e [tcai]na ye ttu hauʾ tcaisyau bīysī
/ x -ā -ā parau mūnai bīsa ṣṭe haṣḍä ttā yūḍe

/ x va x bīsa na hamū:P 2786 lines 221-6 ca dārakau paḍa-tcaina yai : ttu hvāṃʾ tcaisyau bīysīyai tta tta sa mūnai bīsa ttą haṣḍä ttā yūḍa sa caigą kṣīra tsū khu bīsa na hamūṃ u tcaina ma jsā vā parau hīyą mvaiśdaʾ hagauttai gaiʾsāttā. jsaina ma jsā vā-
[yai hamyai dasau k]ūs[ai] gubai re hīyau sturau baida u
[drai māśtai tcaina] ma mūñau ye u ysīḍa parau hīya

q.p: [51] (b1) [There was [a certain Dārakau] Paḍe-tcaina. Hauʾ Tcaisyau seized him. (b2) ... the order, he is our servant. He made a report to you[: I shall go to China]. (b3) I shall not be a servant for ... . *Tcaina [could] now [be] held here (b4) [(at the price of?) [ten] kūsas (of fodder) upon the pack animals of Gubai Re. And (b5) [Tcaina] was to remain here [for three months]. And [he obtained the favor] of the yellow order [and returned to you].

q.l: tt]ā aujsa drūyāja haṣḍä yūḍauda tta tta
/ x byūdaudū ḍai-se jsa auna byai-
[hau rrvī jsai caiga kṣīrā]ṣ[ṭa] pastauda naiṣkeśce khu ttyau drūyā-

[jau adā jīyai : gaiʾ]sāttāP 2786 lines 226-30 ca drūyāṃja kairä ḍai-sai yai ttyai kaiṇa ttā u jsa drūyāja haṣḍä yūḍāṃdä tta tta sa cada hana paḍa-tsā ądā yūḍai ṣų̄ʾra drai jū ttya ya ḍa īḍai : paḍa-tsā jsä tsāṣṭą̄ bīdaudū ḍai-sai jsa auna byaihau.

q.p: [52] There was [a certain] Kaira Ḍaise from Drūyāṃ. (b7) The *villagers of Drūyāṃ made a report [to you regarding him] thus (b8) [: “However much] unlawfulness [Paḍa-tsā] did, that much [... has done] all alone. (b9) We have obtained [peace from Paḍa-tsā]. Let us now obtain (it) from Ḍaise.” (b10) Some have set out [from the court] for [China], to *investigate how [the unlawfulness] may be reduced for those (villagers) of Drūyāṃ. (b11) He has returned to you.

msItem.q:
ca jsāṃ badalai hīye
[pūra yai mvąkale nau]ma: ttyai pā drayau śūma kenau hī-
[ya.........................] ye śūma kainau hīya mvaśta ha-
[grauttai................tt]āP 2786 lines 231-3 ca badäle hīyai pūra yai mvąkale naumä ttyai rrvī vī varāṣṭa drai śvakyaina japha yai mvaśdaʾ hagrrauttai u geʾsāttā.

q.p: [53] [There was a certain son] of Badalai, (b12) [Mvakalai] by name. For him there was then [a dispute] about three śūma-kenas. (b13) He *acknowledged the favor of the śūma-kenas (b14) [and returned] to you.

q.l: ca hagīñai khara painaka ye ttye
/ {h- khu mai na kraśīsa vīrāṣṭa parau ha} /
/ nañau tta parau hamyai tta tta sa caga kṣī
par]au py[ū]ṣ[ṭ]e gaisāttāP 2786 lines 233-5 ca hagīñai khara paiʾnakä yai ttyai hā tcā salī au parau hamyai tta tta sa cągą kṣīrai tsūñī hąmai parau pyūṣṭai gaisāttā.

q.p: [54] There was a certain Khara Painaka from Haga. For him (b16) [there was an order for four years] an order thus: “[You must go to] China!” (b17) He heard [the order (but) returned to you.(b15) ... Kraśīsa order to the court ...

q.l: / na habūsana ṣṭāvai khu vā ttyau pā
mva]śta haraysde ca va rrvī parau hagrīhauʾ-

[nau..................................................] dara hamai —P 2786 lines 235-8 khu vā kamacū rrvī śkyaisa hyī mvaisdąʾna habūsana ttāvai khu vā ttyau pā jsā hīyą mvaiśdąʾ hąraysdai cą va rrvī parau hagrrīhāmivai haira tsīyai śūjai baiʾda samaiyāṃ ādara yanau khu rrvī parau dara hamai.

q.p: [55] If there for the court in Ganzhou the [royal] gift (b18) should prove not to be fitting, how then does [now] (b19) their favor extend? Whoever there [is in charge of] the obtaining the royal favor, (b20) we shall look after their agreement with one another, (b21) [so that the royal order] is complete.

For Khalaṃ, son of Jsāka, barley 7 kūsas, wheat 2 kūsas.
For Suhadatta, son of Puñabuda, wheat 7 kūsas.
For Vismaṃ, son of Punara, wheat 6 kūsas.
For Salbī,Cf. Or.8212/1720, Or.9268B, Or.12637/21.3a. son of Saḍidva, barley 7 kūsas, wheat ... kūsas.
For Āra, son of Śathaṃja in ... barley ... kūsas.

/ x hānä balysi pūra — tcamiña balysä näṣaʾstä ........... — rä mu nā .... -ä /
/ kīrä vi x -ā́re — tcamna nas- ndä uysnaura — r- vā ṣā -āma /
/ ndī harbiśśä västāndä — .... tāndä ...... — ru braṣṭ- śrīggarbha /
... there everywhere deep ... on account of beings ...
... under] the bodhi tree the Buddha ... the Buddha- ...
... shines — appears just like Mount Sumeru appears — or the Pāracitraka tree — ...
... thirty[-two] pure lakṣaṇas — with them all the fields ... together with the buddhas ...
... of the Buddha — ... they sat—thus of king Prabhāsa ...
... bodhisattva — who has not yet arisen a buddha ...
... sons of the Buddha — in which the Buddha was sitting ...
... it/him all stood — they -ed ... — asked Śrīgarbha ...

q.l: @ ttuā pāḍa pharṣṣa bara pyaṣṭi u braṃgalä

note.p: (at the other end of the cover tablet, SD I/IV 1a)

q.l: jsa śau haḍā śā ṣṣava bastä ñāna ūtca dva
bā(ga) ūtca pharṣa bara bāyi u śau bāgä yagurä
khu pharṣa bara hīvye mūri haurī ā vā phaṃnāja
yagurä nauhyä salye mūri 2000 500 nāsti saṃ bisalū
ni nāsti u haṃda hveʾ himāte cu pyaḍa ūtca u-

note.p: (on the edge of the under-tablet, SD I/IV 1a, V 1c)

q.l: ysgināte mūri śau dva heḍä tti buri va byāṃ vya pharṣa chuṃ-
gulä u malārrjųnāṃ ṣṣanīrä u sucaṃdrä

q.p: (1) This document the pharṣa Bara signed and Braṃgala.

(2) This document (was written) for this reason that (3) Yagura has received water *to make money* (4) from the pharṣa Bara and Braṃgala (5) for 2500 mūrās. From the pool of Phaṃnai, (6) one day one night the water from the dammed-up river—two (7) parts water the pharṣa Bara leads off and one part Yagura.

(8) When the pharṣa Bara pays his mūrās or the people of Phaṃnai,phaṃnāja- may be the adjective of Phęma, i.e., “from Phęma,” rather than “from Phaṃnai.” (then) Yagura, (9) at the beginning of the year, gets 2,500 mūrās, only he does not receive *yearly interest*. (10) And (if) another man shall in turn buy *stray water (from him), (11) (then) he (only) pays a couple of mūrās.
These were the witnesses there: the pharṣa Chuṃgula (12) and Ṣṣanīra son of Malārrjuṃ(?) and Sucaṃdra.

q.l: @ salī x māśt[ä] 8 haḍā 20 7 ṣiʾ kṣųṇä miṣḍāṃ gyastä hvaṃnä mistä rruṃdänu rru-
ṃdä viśaʾ dharmä ttye scye ttiña beḍa śeʾyye ṣau hviṃdū salya mara
birgaṃdara auva ṣiʾ gvārä vye cu pharṣa bara u braṃgalä tta hvāṃdä si a-
śtä mānī hīvya ūtca phaṃnāją̄ñi āṣṣeṃji jsa śau haḍā śā ṣṣava ba-
stä ñāna ttuā ṣṭą̄na vaṃña draṃmāja viśtuṃ didä bāgä vī 2000 500 mūri nā-
ti mī yagurä ttuā ūtca draṃmāja hīvyau mūryau hį̄mya dąmyāṣṭa hāvägārī-
na hauḍä mī ṣiʾ yagurä tti mūri 2000 500. nāṃdų̄mūṃ mihi braṃgalä u saṃgaśū-
rai u puñadarmä tti mūri uspurri 2000 500 aurīṣṭa pharṣa bara u pyaṃtsä

note.p: (inside of under-tablet, SD I/V 1c, where the top of first line is obscured)

q.l: busvārāṃ āṃ gvārä tta tta padedāṃdä si hamya miṣa haṃtsa kīrä yanā-
dä paśä haṃbīśa 2 kūsa jsārä pharṣa bara nāsti u śau kūsä yagurä
nāsti khu phaṃnāja auvya ūtca uysgināṃde ttī vā yagurä hīvye mū-
ri 2000 500 nāsti u khu pātcä pharṣa bara hīvye mūri himāṃde ya-
gurä vā hīvye mūri 2000 500 nāsti samū haḍi bisalū ni nāsti vi pharṣṣa
bara haḍi vina phaṃnājāṃ yagurä mūri ni nāsti ṣiʾ gvārä haṃgrīma ā vye pyaṃtsä pharṣa
chuṃgula u pharṣa vikrą̄ntadattä. tti buri vara byāṃ vya parramai ṣanīrä saṃgadattä
sucaṃdrä. īrasaṃgä. puñaudakä. paʾjä suvidattä. phaṃnājä buttąnakä
ttī rä ṣāʾ pāḍa prąmą̄na himi khuī pharṣa bara pyaśdä

q.p: (b1) Year X days 27 of the month. This (is) the regnal year of the gracious lord king of kings of Khotan (2) Viśaʾ Dharma.

At that time in the second year of the ṣau Hviṃdū, here (3) in the village (of) Birgaṃdara there was this case, that the pharṣa Bara and Braṃgala said: “We have (4) our water from the pool of the people of Phaṃnai,Cf. Or.11344/9. one day and one night from the dammed-up (5) river. This we now put up (for sale/lease) as money-maker (for the buyer?), 2,500 mūrās for a third share.”

So Yagura received (6) this water as money-maker (for him?)—(paying) with his own mūrās—together with (any) profit-maker (to lead off) to *his own *property. (7) So Yagura paid those 2,500 mūrās. We Braṃgala and Saṃgaśūrai and Puñadarma received those 2,500 mūrās in full.
In the presence of the pharṣa Bara and before (c1) the relatives they construed the case thus:
They shall work together in the same field (2) (in order) to send (grain) into storage. The pharṣa Bara receives 2 kūsas grain from the store and Yagura receives one.
(3) If the villagers of Phaṃnai buy up the water, then Yagura receives his 2,500 mūrās.

(4) And if afterward the pharṣa Bara has his own mūrās and Yagura (5) receives his 2,500 mūrās, only he would not receive *yearly interest* from them. The pharṣa (6) Bara, however, does not receive Yagura’s mūrās without the people of Phaṃnai.
This case had come into the *assembly before the pharṣa (7) Chuṃgula and the pharṣa Vikrāntadatta.
The following were the witnesses: Ṣanīra, Saṃgadatta, (8) Sucaṃdra, Īrasaṃga, Puñaudaka, Suvidatta of Paʾ, Buttąnaka of Phaṃnai.
(9) And this document shall become authoritative when the pharṣa Bara signs it.

note.p: (inside of raised edge of under-tablet, SD I/V 2b)

q.l: mā pyaysīdä ʾīysīFor aysī, with wrong placement of vowel mark (as in a9 auśaki) and impossibility of erasure. pīḍe kaʾrä biheri

q.p: (a1) Year 17, month of Mūdracaja, thereof 11 days.

(2) At that time, in the year of the ṣau Vidyadatta here in the village of Birgaṃdara there was this (3) case, that there is a man (called) Puñadatta. He said thus: “I have (4) a son Haryāsaka by name. I am giving this son in *adoption to the wife (5) of my *half brother *Aśnadāysa for this reason that *we have no (6) (other) refuge, (seeing) that, when I, (once) born (and) alive, die, who will even raise (him?).”

(7) So Aśnadāysa took Puñadatta’s son Haryāsaka (8) in adoption in the presence of the haṃdasta, the spāta (9) Salbī,Cf. Or.8212/1720. and the parramai *Aśauka, the parramai Dattaka, the parramai (b1) Cegadatta, the parramai Saṃgabuda.
And before those men (2) he paid the prahänaja in full, (3) exactly as much as the parents requested: 500 mūrās and (4) 3 chās of white silk (worth) 200 mūrās.

From the day of today Haryāsaka (5) is the son of that Aśnadāysa. Nobody else has any legal claim there. (6) Whoever may change this case from (what has been) prepared and construed, to the court (7) he will pay 200 mūrās and receive 50 strokes of the stick. And he shall give as prahänaja (8) one mūrā (and) 5 (?).Cf. D. iii.12 (IOL Khot 3/1) lines 7-8.
And this deed of adoption shall become authoritative when the parramais (9) put their seals on it.
I, the scribe Bihera, wrote it from the word of Puñadatta. Haryāsaka 3 years.

garuvoʾ ārañānuvoʾ o hveʾtuvoʾ o rrundä kūṣḍu vätä aysu hā tsīmä kāmo diśo ṣätä suvarṇabhāysūttamä sūtrāṇu rrundänu
rre brūñāte bäraṣṭä vä[s]t[ā]r[ī]B.: västarna. īyä ku halci mäḍāna gyasta balysa kāmo śśąndo ye dāta-hvāñei ṣṣamanä dharmāysanä baṣṭarrdä ʾī-
yä kāmu āysanu vätä dāta-hvāñei nättä u ttūB.: ttu. suvarṇabhāysūttamu <sū> sūtrāṇu rrundänu rruṃdu västarna bärāśīyä uysdīśśīyä
[x x x x x] mä[ḍ]āna gyas[t]a balysa s[tyū]da b[ū]madīva[ta] t[t]ä[v]o[ʾ]B.: t[tyau] t[yau]. ś[ś]aṃdye päṣkalvauB.: °l[y]au. ā[ʾ]mato yane u t[t]äna dharmāysanui a[dy]ā[n]ein[a ttaranda]-

hämāre hāruvīndä biśśe paljsäte bāysañä banhya biśśä biśśūnya bāggare späte hīyāra u jsārañä ūśäna hastara hämāre
b[uśśān]aiyatära hämāre. tcārbätara hä[māre] dyānätaraB.: dyanatara. u mästara hāmāre. u ttānu rro uysnaurāṇu hvera khaśa vicitra x -ä [pa]-
gyā[ysāña j]s[ī]na n[ä] cchat[a] indr[i]y[e] p[ä]ṣaʾ huṣṣ[ī]nd[ä u] hastara h[ä]mār[e] c[ī]y[ä] tt[ī]ś[ä]na p[ä]ṣy[au]ʾ chat[e] jsa uspurra h[ä]m[ā́]r[e] ha[ṃ]phuta biśśūn[īna śśä]-
rna raysäna. ttīyä biśśūnya vicitra śśandau vätä jsānä pharāka-padya kīre satä-ysāre yanīndä panamāre haspäsīndä pätaʾgarya kīre ya-
nīndä. ttäna härna mäḍāna gya[sta] balysa ṣätä biśśä Jaṃbvīyä tsātä hämäte u samarthä hämäte. ramanī hämäte pharākyau uysnauryo kī-
śśänä hämäte. u hvąʾndä u ttä biśśä uysnaura suhäta hämāre u biśśūnye hayirūṇe varāśāre. ttä uysnaura ttīśäna päṣaʾñyau
chate jsa dätäna uspurra [haṃ]phuta hämāre. ttīye va Suvarṇabhāysūttamä sūtrāṇu rrundänu rrundi śśäratete jsa ttānu ttīye sū-
trāṇu rrundänu rrundi däjsākānu ṣṣamanānu aśyānu dāta-hvāñānu dharmabhānānu vätä āṇānu hā ttä vara tsuñauB.: tsūñau. cīyä hā tsī-
ndä ttä uysnaura vasutäna aysmūna biśśānu uysnaurāṇu hāvä käḍäna hätä suhä käḍäna u ttä ju dāta-hvāña ājīṣā[ro]

q.p: (a1) The reverend *Śikṣabhadra(?) and (his/my) boy *Śalyāsa I, the dvaipiṭika Javendraśikṣa(?), ask how well it is (for them and whether they are) healthy. I here with (2) mother reckon it a blessing. But for us it is not so well and healthy. When you were here and went away you said: (3) “I will come back here,” but so far you have not come back to us. Think about this: When you went away the care for the boy was not so good as ... (4) So then, come back to us. Perhaps we can settle the matter. You bring the boy to us (5) to (this) land. Afterward I shall *put him in the *census register(?).
Of the month of Mūñaṃja the thirteenth (6) day.
(b1) To be delivered to the reverend *Śikṣabhadra.

q.l: / rāhaji māśti bistamye haḍai ṣiʾ pīḍa[ka

“Embracing [the earth at the feet] of -edrrai [I] make a report ...”

note.p: Ed. Bailey, 1937a. Cf. the Sanskrit text published by Lüders (1933) with very different predictions.

q.l: [salya-b]āyā 10 2 cu śiri dīri ʾī varai bva dvāsi salya-bāyā śau
[haḍā bā]yīdi khu śau haḍā bāstä yanīdi ttī śā śā salī bāyīdi
(r1) The *year leaders (are) twelve. Whatever is good (or) bad, there you know it. The twelve year leaders lead one (r2) [day]. When they have led one day, then one by one (day?) they lead a year.
/ ś- tti salya-bāyā śau kāla bāyīdi būna būna
“... begins to get *dark for you(?). Dog.”
“... those year leaders lead one time ... by ... ”
| paḍauysa mula mulä salya hve ysaiyi muysga-jsīnī hime u rrauḍi u
[x x x] barīji ni śiri hi himāre u hve yaulajsi hime u sahautti
[ni himi] kh[u] jvīdi ba-jsīnya himāre u ñāviB.: ttrāvi. pharāka himāre u hīni pha-

First the Rat. A man is born in the Year of the Rat. He will be short-lived and ... and ... the harvests will not be good. And he will be a quarrelsome man. And [he will not be] blessed (with wealth). If they live, they will be short-lived. And he will have many rivers (to cross?). And armies *many ...
[|| x x] x śvaʾ ṣṣava cu gūhi salya hve ysaiyi sahautti hime u cuai ma pū-
ra himāde biśī sahautta himāre u cu barīja kerīaia śirai hime u stū-
[ra] pharāka himāre u girye parā śirä yuḍi yaṃde u ūci jsai pvaʾṇi u dai

... midnight. A man who is born in the Year of the Ox becomes happy. And whatever sons he has here, they will all of them be happy. And whatever harvests he sows will be good for him. And he will have many draught animals. And he will be able to conduct purchases and sales well. And he will have fear of water and fire.
[|| muyi sal]ya hve ysaiyi bihāysä hime u jauysä u barījai ni śiri himi
A man is born in the Year [of the Tiger]. He will be a merchant and litiginous, and his harvests will not be good. And his speech will be disturbed and his life long.
[|| sa]haici salya hve ysaiyi biśina sahautti hime mūryau jsa stūryau jsa aśau jsa
[suhyau?] biśau jsa biśina suhye hime u hāysai paṃdi ni himye u bedai āʾsye
[himā]ri u khu barīja keri śirai ni hime u biśāʾna vaśūʾ hime aysmūna

A man is born in the Year of the Hare. He will be altogether happy. He will be altogether blessed with money, cattle, horses, and all [blessings?]. And he will not have to go far away. And on him there will be a lot of itching. And when he sows harvest it will not be good for him. And he will be evil in tongue. And he will be evil in mind. He will die of the grasp (of an evil planet).
|| nā salya bāri pha hime u braṃthi tsīdi u ūtca pha hime u hīni
pha tsīdi bāḍa hamyāri u biśi purrīdi u dai pītti daina pvaṇi

In the Year of the Dragon there will be much rain. And gales will blow. And there will be much water. And many armies will travel (through). The lands (times?) will change, and they will conquer all. And fire will fall. [There will be] fear of fire. [If] a man is born, he will be long-lived.
[| śaysdi sa]lya hvai ysaiyi ūtcai pha hime u bāri pha hime u ba-
[rījai] śiri {hime} ni himāre u āchai pha hime hvaṃḍi mirą̄re u
[x x] pvaʾṇi cu hve ysyāʾte buysa-jsīnī hime

A man is born in the Year of the Snake. He will have much water, and there will be much rain. And the harvests will not be good for him. And he will have much illness. (His) men will die. And [there will be] fear [of ...]. If a man is born, he will be long-lived.
[||] aśi salya hve ysaiyi hāysai tsuñai hime u khu hiri ma śāʾyīdi
[x] -ī ni parsti īdi u hvaṃḍāṃ sāni pha himāri u ba dū haysīdi

A man is born in the Year of the Horse. And he will have to go far away. And if they *steal(?) something here, he will not be able to do anything about it(?). And there will be many enemies for (among his?) the men. And they will send little ... There will be illness [for ...]. They will die.
[|| pa]sä salya hve ysaiyi sahautti hime puñaudi biśe hirina sa-
[hau]tti hime jsārina u mūryau jsa u āchinūḍi hime u muʾysga-jsī-
nī bedai vaśūna āchā himāre u āʾsye-t-ī sarbīdi u vranī ka
[x] m[i]stä-ūri mijṣī mirāre u cu pura ysanīde muysga-jsīñya hi-

A man is born in the Year of the Sheep. He will be blessed, meritorious. He will be blessed in everything, in crop and money. And he will be sickly and short-lived. There will be bad illnesses upon him. And a lot of itching will arise for him as well as a wound. If his wifes [become] pregnant, they will die. And whatever sons they bear will be short-lived.
[||] makala salya hve ysaiyi hāysai śaṃdā tsuñai hime u pūrai pha himāre
[u h?]aurina śiri hime bīsai pha himāri u aśa u khu hiri ma śāʾ-
[yīdi n]i ārhī ʾīdi biśī ysīnīdi u pūryau jsa āspāta ni bye-

A man is born in the Year of the Monkey. He will have to go to a land far away. And he will have many sons. And he will be good with respect to *gift(s). He will have many servants and horses. And if they *steal(?) something here he will [not?] be able to restrain (them). They will take all he has(?). And they will have no refuge from (their) sons, and they leave or die.
[|| krregä] salya hve ysaiyi cuai pūra himāde biśī muysga-jsīñya hi-
[māre] u sahautta himāre rrusa ganaṃ aśa mūri paṃñe hirina sahau-
tta himāri u kīrī ni parstī yanīdi daina pvaʾṇi u śaʾlarbi hīsī-

A man is born in the Year of the [Cock]. If he has sons, they will all of them be short-lived. And they will be blessed. Barley, wheat, money, they will be blessed with everything. And they will not be able to order any work upon him(?). (He will have) fear for fire. And locusts will come (and) eat his crop.
|| śvā salya hve ysaiyi muysga-jsīnī hime u dikhau u cuai {mū} pūra
[ysy]ā[r]e biśī muysga-jsīñya himāre u biśāʾ yi na u haphāra-sa-
[lāva u] rrauḍa u śalarbi hīsīdi jsārä hvąrīdi

A man is born in the Year of the Dog. He will be short-lived and poor. And whatever sons are [born] to him, they will all of them be short-lived. And his tongue will not (...?) and (his) speech (will be) confused. And ... And locusts will come (and) eat his crop.
[|| ] cu pāsi salya hve ysaiyi muysga-jsīnī hime u pūrai biśi muʾysga-
ysga-jsīñya himāri u āchinūḍa kṣīra biśi āchai hime pharā
[ka] u hīni ni tsīdi u biśāʾna satta vaśūʾna himāri u śalarbi

A man who is born in the Year of the Pig will be short-lived. And all his sons will be short-lived and sickly. In the land all will be much illness. And armies will not(?) travel (through). And beings will be evil with respect to tongue. And locusts will come (and) eat his crop.

q.p: (a1) Order from the Gracious Lord:

In Cira in the Six Villages, *accordingly the section’s (2) grain-providing men of the year (were) in all 53. For each man is ordered—according to the ṣaṃga of the Tibetans’ 7 śiṃgas—(3) 11 kūsas 9 ṣaṃgas of grain. In all it amounts to 6[30] (4) [kūsas] 7 ṣaṃgas of grain.53*(11*10+9) = 630*10 + 7 = 6,307. 225 kūsas 4 ṣaṃgas of lucerne. ✓
(5) [18]4 kūsas of wheat. 221 kūsas 3 ṣaṃgas of millet.

Seven men (6) from *Cira, they deliver only millet. In all, their millet amounts to 83 kūsas 3 ṣaṃgas: (7) ... Visarrjāṃ 52; Haskadarma son of Viṃgula 29; Khąṣṭarāṃ among the Jīvas(?) (8) ... x2; Vismadatta son of Hvrrīviḍta son of/from(?) Ysāḍa 18. ✓
(9) ... 34; Si Vidatta 35.
46 men, they deliver 3 pilas of grain. (10) [In all their grain] amounts to 547 kūsas 4 ṣaṃgas.46*119 = 547*10 + 4 = 5,474. That is 4 kūsas and 9 ṣaṃgas of lucerne.
(11) [x kūsas] of wheat. 3 kūsas of millet. 225 kūsas, 4 ṣaṃgas of lucerne.
(12) 2[x]4 kūsas of wheat. 138 kūsas of millet. ✓

(13) In Birgaṃdara: Ṣanīraka son of Mattiśka 34; Ṣanīraka 24; Vidarrjāṃ 2[x]; (14) Namaubuda, Hunaka son of Dumesalāṃ, Sahadatta, Suhadāysa, (15) Īrasaṃga son of Suhīka, Virgāṃ from *Spai, Naṃdaka son of Mattiśka, Śāṃdatta, Śude *Vaśaʾrasaṃga, (16) -datta. Sāmadatta’s son Darauka, {Ṣanīra son of Bikina}, the khau ... Sīlāṃ from *Spai, (17) ... *Mādāśa.
In Paʾ: Sudatta son of the *Sogdian(?), Kharajsajsa, Puñausa, Sude, *Sudatta, (18) In Āskura: Sīlāṃ in Puñiśāla, Altāṃ, Svarrjāṃ, Makala, Vasade, *Maṃñe, (19) Puʾysdaka.
In Baʾsa: Suhadāysa, Puñade.

In Phaṃnaa:Cf. Or.11252/14 b3. Si Vidatta from *Spai, (20) Senila, Yseviḍta, the khau Sudatta from Kūla(?),Cf. Or.11252/39.6 khau kūlāna ṣanīraki, 34 a2 khau kūlā sudatti, Or.11344/3.3. Kharamurraa son of Buttakāṃ.

q.p: (a1) [N.N. orders thus.(?)] To Sude and Sudatta of Paʾ.Cf. Or.11252/2.17, 4 a2.

Your chaskas (are too) *little. (2) Bring ... *other pack-animals! And for one man [you shall send] *without delayCf. Or.11252/12 b2, Or.11252/19, IOL Khot Wood 29, Hedin 33b1. barley 2 ṣaṃgas. (3) ... you (shall?) deliver to me ...
On the 26th day of Seṃjsīja he orders the order thus:

(4) 3 roads he had been able to go, you still owe *roads.Cf. Or.11252/33.2, 11344/1.27, 11344/13.6. Now for you my ... (5) ... you shall go ... *load this seat. If the Tibetans *kill you (all) ... (6) ...
... *ButtaṃdaiIn Or.11252/35.4. — Suhade Svarrnade in Āskura.

q.p: (b1) Councilor rMąmä ŚiʾräCf. blon maṅ-bźre [sic] “Councilor Maṅ-bźre” in a document from Mazar Tagh (Thomas, 1951, pp. 411-12; Takeuchi, 1998a, p. 28 no. 87), blon rma-bźer “Councilor Rma-bźer” in a document from Miran (ibid., pp. 413-14). orders thus: [To the spāta?] *SuhenaSuhena does not seem to be a spāta elsewhere. (2) and to the spāta Vīsa, (and) to all the merchants together.

[Now] ... (3) And here in Phęma I have no tasty wine. Now, send me one wine! ... (4) If they do not have one khūra, ... those two kūsas *Puñamaya (?) ... (5) you look after ... If it comes here in this month on the 7th day ...
(6) On the 6th day of Seṃjsīja the order (went out to you). TIB.

q.p: (b1) The spāta Sudārrjuṃ orders thus: To the pharṣa Sāṃdara.

Now, an *order has come (2) [that: ...] are requesting cattle for the *silk-worm raisers.Studies III, pp. 91-93. Only today *did they began to request (it) from me for you here in the town. Then I made a report to them that:
“*Here (3) ...’ Then he ordered that: ‘If they close the gates of the town for me and do not come here, (then) your workers [will all get the] stick.’

(4) Ysāḍadatta has gone to you. Agree on pack-animals for him there quickly, and put one man there for him! If your (5) ... if they come here to the town before dawn. The *silk-worm raisers delivered a writ to me (saying) that:
(6) ... have -ed ... Your men are about to die of hunger. Whatever grain *you may have there, why don’t you collect it all together. The Masters for you (7) ... make -bāʾka.

When you hear the order, whatever grain he may have there, as quickly as possible order it loaded. If there is no man there, *withdraw(?) all of his collateral. (8) ... [until?] the grain has *ripened. All has been collected in Cira.B. took cära as OKhot. cärä “as much as.” COPY

q.p: (a1) To the Lord spāta Sudārrjuṃ thus [I make] a report:

... (2) ... the villagers of *Cira. O Lord, We here ... from the river six thousand ... (3) ... *Śirakyesī Budesa has gone to you, and those of the Masters ... (4) is not to be done, who had a very young son, (and) he does not do any work for him. ... (5) sends .... And his father has two mastauñis and ... (6) is sending work upon us. If the old men ... (7) ... And there are those men here who ... those of the Masters ... [Now our refuge is] (8) with the Lord, if we obtain justice ...

Councilor Maṃ Śiʾrä ... (9) and the spāta Yąniviḍtä’s son ... here ... (10) ... has gone to the Inner Fort. Budesa [has gone to?] the Inner [Fort ... (11) has gone to the Inner Fort. Vidyabuda, he ...
(b5) (To be delivered) to the spāta Sudārrjuṃ.

q.p: (a1) ... you (must) speak ... In the Masters’ mouth there is no word here. Thus it torments my heart. Now, you (must) *say (that) ...

(2) I have made a report [to ...] that my work is difficult. I am getting a būka.Cf. Hedin 11.3 būki āṃ ni byehī “let me not get a būka!” You (must) speak to Councilor Mąmi [Śäʾrä] thus: ... (3) If you seek work for me there (where you are), say to Puñarucita how [I/he? must take] care of ...
(4) ... I ask you: Are you ordering me to get it from himOr read *ttinī “at once”? or not yet? SIGN

q.p: (1) The spāta Sudārrjuṃ orders thus: To the pharṣa Sāṃdara.

Makala had not sent the wine *to him. (2) Now he has sent. Naṃdaka has obtained (some). From today order Makala (to do) the work! Naṃdaka does not ... (3) And then Naṃdaka brought a dispute to the *inspectorate and *obstructed it. He [... went] there to *canteen duty.See KT IV, p. 100: “kitchen.” Cf. the Tib. byan-ḡyog “cook-service” (Thomas, 1951, p. 252).

[When] (4) you hear the order, the *canteen duties—those which have now been *canceled.—Naṃdaka ought not to have done *canteen duties. The *canteen duties ought to been done by that [Makala?]. (5) Today, those *canteen duties, when they come [= the turn comes] to Naṃdaka, order them on Makala! COPY

note.p: The reaction to this order is in Or.11252/19. The original order from Councilor rMamä Śäʾrä may be Or.11252/3 and Or.11252/29.

q.p: (a1) Councilor Śaʾma rrJai orders thus: To the pharṣa Sāṃdara.

Come here with the workers! (2) You owe grain! Whatever grain you have obtained, bring it here today! ... (3) And I need oil. The spāta Yąniviṭi passed through (here). He ordered you about oil: Bring me (some)! ... (4) And then (he ordered) you about cotton. Hviṃdū bought it for you for the second (?).
First day of Mūtcaʾca.
To be sent to the pharṣa Sāṃdara.

And the following *shifts of the second būka were set: Altāṃ one, Suhena one, Saṃgapuña one, Gauda one.

q.p: (b1) I make a report [to the spāta Sudārrjāṃ]:

I, the pharṣa Sāṃdara, (2) ... you (must) agree on the *canteen workers. Then send them without delay to Cira. For one (3) [man? ...] ... Place the spāta Vīsa’sAlso in Hedin 10. q.p: (a1) We make a report to the gracious Lord thus: in the Six Towns, (we) the tsīṣī (2) Sudārrjāṃ and the merchants in the Six Towns and all the people. And whoever/whatever ... (3) we in the ... section are alive only by the merits of Your Lordship.

Whatever [...] (4) there deign be for you, Your Lordship *at all times ..., now, Your Lordship, I have many court works (ordered) by you. And with the stānaḍasB.: Tib. *ston-bla “teacher-superior” (KT IV, p. 119). (5) ... I have three stānaḍas, but one of them is very old, (and) he just does not [do] court [works] ... (6) And your (men) there (with you) at the Inner Fort are requesting lyibaʾ [claim exemption?] and thus do not [do] court works. ... (7) ... deigns obtain the Lord’s mercy. And when for you the five sections ... (b1) ... those of ... *section.

On account of the court tax and on account of the state works I went to ... to *make a complaint(?). (2) ... in ... Now, I had already paid twice the price, (but) there is no *relief (?). So now ... to you ... court ... (3) ... I shall serve as(?) price together with the wife and the sons. In the future I shall serve the hīyaude. ... (4) ... in that town, they do not make people unhappy. The stānaḍas are so lawless. ... (5) I had already done the [state?] works. If I manage to send (it) in the future, he will protect me now. ...

note.p: Personal ductus, with backward twist on bottoms.

q.p: (1) The following (were) the men when they delivered pieces of cloth for wool cloths:
Yseviḍti and ... four ...

(2) For one man for a wool cloth a hatcaṃ of three chās six tsunas is needed. The *spāta ... (3) together with Kharajsajsa and Suramarṣa, Īrasaṃga ... (4) Suhena owes a cloth of five chās. Sūradatta owes a cloth of five [chās ...].

(5) In Āskura accordingly (there is?) a hatcaṃ of pieces of cloth of 16 chās. Of pieces of cloth from Phaṃnai there is accordingly a hatcaṃ [of x chās]. (6) [In ...] *they have a hatcaṃ of pieces of cloth of 19 chās.
Saṃga owes a cloth of 12 chās ... (7) ... chās ... *delivered four chās ...

q.p: (1) Order from Councilor rMąmi Śäʾrä:

New grain is needed for the silk-worm raisers, (2) 58 kharas, 6 ṣaṃgas, three śiṃgas. If you do not deliver new (grain), then here of that grain ... (3) and the men who send sack (cloth). Thus deliver the grain to them precisely 64 kharas, six ṣaṃgas, 2 śiṃgas!

q.p: (1) On the 14th day [of M.M. those] of the first būka work in the town:

(2) ... Surade, Maṃñe, Puñade, Ysāḍadatta, Sude, Gachauka, Sahadatta, Viloka, (3) ... Ṣanīra, Śirībuda, Są̄madatta, Namaubuda, Aniruda, Hunaka, *Hunila, (4) *Yulmaha, Vidarrjāṃ, Sudaśta, Akānadatta, Suhadāysa, Herrjaka, Svarrnade, Maṃgala, (5) ... *Hattikaṃ, Mādāśa, Paṃjamaka, Kalidrra, Budāṣṭira, Gauda, Suhena, Hvurihvāda, (6) (U?) q.p: (1) ... the ṣau Sī began ...

The men of the first būka in the town of Phęma: ... (2) -ra, *Puysdaka, Sudiva, Sudatta, Gachauka, Arsäla, Kucalai (3) [-]ra, Sīlāṃ, Śāṃdatta, Si Vidyadatta, Ṣanīra the khau, Śirīdatta, (4) Hunaka, Hunila, Yulmaha, Vidarrjāṃ, Svarrnade, (5) *Suhadāysa, (6) [-]a, Saṃgulai, Maṣidatta, Budāṣṭira, Si Vidyadatta, (7) ... Salaka, Sirphūka, (8) Bhadrradatta, Salaka, Ṣanīraka the spāta-son ... (9) ... Kalidrra, Gauda, Svarrjāṃ, Maṃgala, (10) ... *Suhadāysa, Makala, Vasade, Śīʾlaṃ, Īrvadatta, Brūnade, (11) ... [-]de, Sarkāṃ, Naṃdaka, Ṣarrnai, Virgāṃ, Upadatta, Vasade, Aśta, (12) ... Haryāsaka, Vidyadatta, “Tall” Ṣanīra, Vaśiʾraka, (13) ...[-a]ʾbuda, Suhade.
(13) And the following (were) the Ciranians of first [būka] (who) came on the 12th day of Haṃdyaja: (14) ... Saṃgalaka, Saṃganaṃda, Yuduysa, Matsara the kīsa, (15) ... Nahvąna.
(15) And the following (were the ones) of the second būka: Naṃdaka, Braṃga, Brąnaṃda, Īrvadatta, (16) ... -datta, Nine Viṣaʾla, Arrjāṃ, Budesa, Skarai. *Checked.
(16) And these (were the ones) of the third [būka]: (17) ... Ttīśąna, Saṃgabuda, Sedrruṃ, Visarrjāṃ, Īraka, Śirīde, (18) ... Īysadatta, Śirībuda, Khāysadatta, “Old” Vilocaṃ, Budesa

(20) When you hear the order, any man there may be who shall receive water, all of them *buy court ... (21) ...

q.p: (1) And the following are going on inspection the 8th day of the month of Siṃjsīja: Arsäla, Marṣaʾdatta, (2) Īrvadatta, the khau Sudatta from Kūla(?), Suhadatta from Birgaṃdara, Kharamūrrai, Saloka, (3) Sīlāṃ.
(4) And the following of the second būka are going on inspection: Kharajsajsa, Suhadāysa, Suhena, Virgām, Naṃdaka, (5) Ṣanīraka, Sūradatta, Si Vidyadatta, Ṣanīraka.
(6) And the following are the ones of the third būka who are going on inspection: Puʾysdaka, Maṃñe, (7) Kucalai from Phaṃnai, Sarkāṃ, Saṃgade, the khau Si Vidyadatta, Sudatta from Paʾ.

q.p: (a8) Year 36, 11 days of the month of Rarūya.

This agreement (is) for this reason that (9) the men of the (Six?) Towns have made a report to the Inner Fort regarding inspectors, those from Cira: *U Senila, (10) *U Makala, *U Naṃdaka, Namaubuda, Ṣanīraka, Brūnade, *Gachauka.Cf. Or.11252/31.

(11) ... have received a ṣaṃga (amount?) of one hundred. This wheat they have now tendered. The men were 58 ... (12) the wheat was one ṣaṃga, five śiṃgas from the mātargā.Cf. IOL Khot 44/5. (The men) from Āskura (are) 15, [they deliver] wheat x (13) *kūsas 3 ṣaṃgas. The (men) from Phaṃnai and Paʾ (are) 17, they deliver wheat 2 kūsas six ṣaṃgas. The (men) from Birgaṃdara [(are) xx, (14) they deliver wheat 3 kūsas 8 ṣaṃgas.
The spāta Sudārrjāṃ orders thus: (15) ... do request ... according to the agreement!
In (the month) of Rarūya (16) the order (went out to you). COPY

q.p: (1) [The following (are)] the men who have to go on inspection on the third day of the month of Mūñaṃja: Instead of Śarkāṃ Vaśiʾraka *goes. (2) ... -datta, Budāṣṭira, Kaledra. *Checked. In Cira, Svarrnade māśa-worker,B.: “house-worker.” (3) ... {Śarkāṃ} māśa-worker, Surade māśa-worker, Saṃgapuña, Vidarrjāṃ, (4) ... Salamai the haubarai of Sīhai, Buttaṃdai māśa-worker ... (5) *Suhadāysa māśa-worker ... Nahvąna. COPY Instead of Vidarrjāṃ Svarrnade goes.

q.p: (1) The spāta Sudārrjāṃ orders thus: To the pharṣa Sāṃdara.

I sent the (following) order to you that: (2) Come right here into (the city)! We will make a report to you about the grain. (If) you do not come in here (now), (3) it will be too late (?). (So) come quickly right here together with the cattle as many of yours go.
And no būkas of *canteen workers (4) are *coming, and now the men, their *ears keep no(thing) of mine(?). Quickly send me *canteen workers!Cf. Or.11252/25.2. COPY

q.p: (1) And this is ... for 80 cloths. Fifteen the āmāca collected from the *Sogdian. And he took two cloths (2) of 14 chās. Woolen [cloths ...] *Ṣanīraka received (them). Brų̄nade received 3 cloths. Two pieces of cloth (3) according to the mūrās went out ... *thousand ... 53 *pieces of cloth, those the *Sogdians received for (= in order to make?) seven cloths.
(4) Afterward ... have come in for an amount of one thousand.
