note.p: Or.11252/40-42 from the same manuscripts. a-side bold script, b-side thin.
Two hands alternate—one bold, one thin. Note: -i is often indistinguishable from the left-turning -e.

q.p: (1) The following (are) the men who are going on inspection on the 4th day of the month of Rrāhaja. In Āskura: Nahvąna, (2) Surade, Maṃñe, Kharajsajsa, Puʾysdaka, Saṃgapuña, Sarkāṃ, Saṃgada, {Khara (3) Īrvadatta}, Kucalai, Brīna, Si Vidyadatta, Jsajsaka, Vidyabuda, Hvrrīviḍta, Ttāṃguysa.

(4) The following are going on inspection on the 21th day of the month of Rrāhaja. In Āskura: Sudatta, Saṃgūlai, Puñade, Burmaka, (5) {Braṃga, Ttāṃguysi}, Sūradatta, Jsajsaka, Yaduysa, Paṃjamaka, Sudarma, Mulaka, Vidyadatta, (6) Sirphūka, Vidyadatta from Gaysāta, Maṃgala.

(7) The following went on inspection on the 6th day of the month of Cvātaja: Haryāsaka, Aką̄nadatta, Tcaṃjsai, Ṣanīra, (8) the khau Ṣanīra, Vidyabuda, Īrvadatta of Cira, Sūrada, Nahvąna, Gauda, (9) Śīlaṃ, for Sude the Tibetan went, Sudatta from Paʾ, Kucalai instead of Si Vidyadatta, Saloka, Hā-

q.p: (10) The following went on the 21th day of the month of Cvātaja: Kharajsajsa, Suhadāysa, Sūradatta, Īrvadatta, (11) Suhadatta from Phaṃnai, Marṣaʾdatta, Arsäla, Virgāṃ, Śāṃdatta, Si Vidyadatta the khau, Suhena, (12) Ṣanīraka, Ṣanīraka the second, Naṃdaka.
(13) These went on the 7th day of the month of Kaja: Śīʾlaṃ, Puʾysdaka, Maṃñe, Suhadatta, Kucalai instead of Kharamūrrai, Sarkāṃ, Saṃgade, for Sude the Tibetan went, Sīlāṃ, Si Vidyadatti the khau.

q.p: (15) And the following are going on inspection on the 21st day of the month of Cvātaja. In Āskura: Kharajsajsa, Suhadāysa, (16) Sūradatta from Phaṃnai, Īrvadatta, Suhadatta, Arsäla. In Birgaṃdara: Suhadatta, (17) Śāṃdatta, Si Vidyadatta, Marṣaʾdatta, Suhena, Ṣanīraka, (the second) Ṣanīraka, Naṃdaka.

q.p: (23) These are going on inspection on the 23th day of of Kaja: Arsäla, Marṣaʾdatta for Gauda, Saloka, {Ṣanīraka}, Si *Vidyadatta in *Āskura, (24) Sudatta the khau, Śiraka for Śāṃdatta, Suhadatta went on inspection instead of Kharamurrai. Now *Kharamurrai (25) is going instead of Suhadatta, {Suramarṣaʾ}. COPY

q.p: (26) The following on the 7th day of Hamārrīja: Kharajsajsa, Suhadāysa, Suhena, Virgāṃ, Naṃdaka, Ṣanīraka, (27) Sūradatta, Īrvadatta, Ṣanīraka (was) at the *dams. Sude had *gone over one road.Cf. Or.11252/3.4, Or.11252/33.2.
(28) The following are going on inspection on the 19th day of of Hamārrīja: Śīʾlaṃ, Puʾysdaka, Maṃñe, Suhadatta, (29) Kucalai, Sarkāṃ, Saṃgade, Si Vidyadatta the khau, Sudatta from Paʾ.
(30) The following went on inspection on the 8th day of Siṃjsīja: Arsäla, Marṣaʾdatta, Īrvadatta, the khau Si Vidyadatta (31) Śāṃdatta, Suhadatta from/son of Śirgula, Kharamūrrai, Sīlāṃ, Saloka.

(32) 29th day of Siṃjsīja: Kharajsajsa, Suhadāysa, Suhena, Virgāṃ, Naṃdaka, Ṣanīraka, (33) Īrvadatta, (the 2nd) Ṣanīraka (was) at the *dams. Sude had *gone over one road.Cf. Or.11252/3.4, Or.11252/33.2.

q.p: (1) The following were the town āsalyai men here of the first būka: (2) ... Puñade, Ysāḍadatta, Puʾysdaka, Sude, -i ...
(3) Next: Suhadatta, Sīlāṃ, Śāṃdatta, ... (4) Aniruda, Hunaka, Hunila.

(5) And the following were the men of the second (būka): Sudatta, Altāṃ, Hvurihvāda, Saṃgulai, Marṣadatta, ... (4) Paṃjamaka, Sudarma, Mādāśa, Śaṃphaka, Hattikaṃ, Mulaka, Si Vi- ..., ... (7) Śude Sāmadatta, Samādrradatta, Saloka, Ṣanīraka, the spāta’s son Budadatta(?), ... (8) Kaledrra, Svarrjāṃ, Maṃgala.

(9) And the following were the men present in the town from the second (būka) onward: Maṃgala, Śirībuda, Sura- ..., (10) Mulaka, Haryāsaka, Darauka, Ṣanīra, Vidyadatta, (10) ... -ra, Paṃjamaka, Ysāḍadatta, Saṃgapuña, ... (12) *Suhena, Svarrjāṃ, Budadatta.
And the following were the Ciranians: Vi-, ..., (13) -de, Vidyabuda, Khāhadatta, Yaduysa, ...

(14) And the following were the men present here on the 23rd day of Haṃdyaja: ... (15) Mu- ..., Są̄madatta, Suhena, Hvurihvāda, Altāṃ, Sudatta, ... (16) -datta, Kucalai, Kalidrra, Hunila, Sudaśta, ...
... (17) to ... the others the Master sent. Salamai’s *shifts (were) 10 days.
Then ...

q.p: (18) Suhadāysa one, Si Vidatti one.

The following (were) the *shifts of the second būka: Samgapuña, (19) ... Mādāśa X days, Maṃñe 5 days, Si Vidyadatta from Phaṃnai 5 (20) [days], ... Īysadatta, Marṣadatta was on inspection, Ṣanīraka was on inspection, (21) ..., -rrjāṃ, Aniruda had gone to Cira, Ṣanīra the dashi had sent (on a mission), U Svarrnade (22) ... was [on inspection?], ... Si Vidyadatta was on inspection. In Birgaṃdara: [Suhadatta?] (23) ... (was on) *inspection.

q.p: (a1) The following went on inspection in the month of Haṃdyaja: Śīʾlaṃ, Puʾysdaka, Sahadatta from Phaṃnai, Maṃñe, (2) Kucalai, Sarkāṃ, Saṃgade, the khau Si Vidyadatta. Ṣanīraka (was) at the *dams.

(3) The following went on the 15th day of Haṃdyaja: Arsäla, Marṣaʾdatta, Īrvadatta, the khau Sudatta from Kūla(?), (4) Śāṃdatta. In Birgaṃdara: Suhadatta, Kharamurrai, Saloka; Sīlāṃ (was) at the *dams.

(5) The following went on inspection in the month of Rarūya: Kharajsajsa, Suhadāysa, Suhena, Virgāṃ, (6) Naṃdaka, Saloka, Sūradatta, Si Vidyadatta, Sudatti (was) at the *dams, Sude had *gone over three roads.
(7) {Next, the following went on inspection in the month of Rarūya: Kharajsajsa, Suhadāysa, [Suhena], Virgāṃ, Naṃdaka.}
(8) Next, the following went on inspection in the month of Rarūya: Śīʾlaṃ, Puʾysdaka, ... (9) Suhadatta from Phaṃnai, Kucalai, Sarkāṃ, Saṃgade, ... (10) Sudatta from Paʾ.
(10) The following went day 10 of the month of Ttuṃjārā: Arsäla, ... (11) Īrvadatta, the khau Sudatta, Śāṃdatta, Suhadatta in Birgaṃdara, Kharamurrai, Ṣanīra, ... (12) *Sīlā.

q.p: (c1) ... went 28: Jsajsaka, Vidyadatta, Sūrade, Śarkāṃ, Budarma, Sudatta, Sudatta, Puñade, ... (2) *Darauka.

q.l: [@] spāta sudārrjuṃ tta parī pharṣa sāṃdarä vara vaña vā hvaṃḍä
[phe]ma āna tta ma hvāṃdä si peʾ vī tta paṃdä paskyāṣṭa muttūṃ himye u tti ṣi jsāṃ tta birgaṃdarajāṃ /
biṃdä khų̄ṇā ṣṭe ṣiʾ cä ṣäʾ hirä ṣṭä cu āṃ hā hvaṃḍä haḍā-kīrä jänīdä u paṃdä āṃ bų̄ma nä /
parau pvaʾ hvaṃḍä hā bāya 10 var-e-ṃ kīrä parya khu burä nä dāśīde bāra bāra hā gaysä x /
jsāṃ āṣaijä jä vī kaṃthä hālai narą̄maṃcä pātcä bāra bāra gaysä parya näśāta ʾā /
būma hime khu tta hvāṣṭāna stūrapānä hamāre vaña thyau khu ttī nä hų̄ñä sä nä pyūṣṭeṃ x /

q.p: (b1) The spāta Sudārrjuṃ orders thus: To the pharṣa Sāṃdara.

And now men in ... (2) ... They said to me thus: In Paʾ the road back has thus become muttūṃ. And so he [sent?] them to Birgaṃdara. ... (3) there are holes on (?). Whatever the matter is, that the men are wasting days on working there? And he *came on a road ... ground ...

[When] (4) you hear the order bring 10 men there. Order them to do your(?) work there until they have finished. Load by load [bring?] reeds there. [There is] (5) a pond in the .?. that debouches toward the town. Next, order them to put all the loads of reed (into it). ... (6) the ground becomes ... when thus the Masters’ pack animals will be ... .
Now (act) quickly so that you do not then say that: “I have not heard(?).”

ttä x x salya-bāyai pharṣa sāṃdari vara u kīrarā vara mara kītha kūsä p-

biśi vā hirä haurą̄ñi caṃda pajīde 30 3 kṣuṇi braṃkhaysji kṣemye haḍai ttā parau tsve /

q.p: (7) The dashi Councilor rMąmi Śiʾrä orders thus: In the Six Towns ... (8) ... to the president of the year, the pharṣa Sāṃdara and to the workers.

Here in the town [there is] a drum. ... (9) ... -ed ... you must consider it as *learned. And when he ordered the drum (to be beaten?), the pharṣa ... -ed the drum. You (...?) (10) must provide *everything as much as they request.
Regnal year 33, 6th day of Braṃkhaysja the order went out to you.

note.p: This is a variant draft(?) of the same document as Hedin 1 (KT IV, p. 55).

q.l: [30] 5 mye kṣuṇi cira kṣvā auvā kīrarā hvaṃ(ḍi) tcahauratcaʾhauʾsi śe hvaṃḍye peʾmīnai thau [20 3 chā]
tta nva hvaḍā thauna himārä 20 5 u 10 2 chā tsīṣī u hārvāṃ u tsā́tā[ṃ

x [t]suna thauna dva hālai sūlya hauḍāṃdi kṣau na ra byaidi tti cu spāta śeʾmaki /

di thau puḍi 20 chā ṣanīraki 20 chā budarmä 20 3 chā hrrīviṭi u visarr[jā]ṃ /

vāra mūrä ysārä kṣi-si tcahausi paʾ sudatti vāra —

q.p: (1) In the *35th regnal year four workmen in Cira of the Six Towns [sold/bought?] forty-four per man (of) woolen cloth. (2) Those accordingly shall be 25 cloths and 12 chās for the men.
For the tsīṣī and the merchants and the *wealthyCf. Or.11252/30.3. ... (3) there shall be 7 cloths and 30 chās.
Now, according to the vouchers the cloths sold were 23 and ... (4) tsunas.
Two and a half cloths the *Sogdians have sold, though there are no vouchers yet (for them).
Those which the spāta Śeʾmaka [sold ...]

(5) 3 cloths shall be given to the tsīṣī, the spāta Sudārrjuṃ, and one to the spāta Yąniviṭi. One of fourteen chās ... [the pharṣa Sāma](6)da promised a cloth of 20 chās, Ṣanīraka 20 chās, Budarma 23 chās, Hrrīviṭi and ...
(7) 1,614 mūrās for it are owed by Yaudara. 2,215 mūrās are owed by Sūradatta. (8) 1,614 are owed by Sudatta from Paʾ.
(1) sparadirsamye kṣu kīrarā hvaṃḍi 40 4 śe hvaṃḍye peʾmīnai thau 20 3 chā
tta nva hvaṃḍāṃ (2) thauna himārä 20 5 u 10 2 chā tsīṣī u hārvā
thauna himārä hauda u dirsä chā (3) *biśna haṃbaʾca thauna haurą̄ña 30 3 u dva chā — vaña nva kṣauvāṃ hauḍa himya (4) 20 3 u śūdasi chā —
tsīṣī spāta sudārrjāṃ thauna haurą̄ña 3 spāta yąni(5)vi caʾhauʾsi chā — pharṣa sāma-
di puḍi 20 chā — ṣanīraki 20 chā budarmä 20 3 (6) chā hvīviṭi u visarrjāṃ kṣi chā
u thauna dva hālai u sūlya thaunaka nāṃdi (7) thini ttiki biśa bisā ttyā spāta śeʾmaki paphūka nāti kṣau na ra byaidi sūlau jsa
(8) mūrai ysāra kṣi-se caʾhauʾsi yaudarä hīye vāra mūri dvī ysā dvī-sa paṃjsāsi sūradatti hīye
(9) vāra mūrä ysārä kṣi-si cahausi paʾ sudatti vāra

q.p: (1) The spāta Sudārrjuṃ orders thus: [To] the pharṣa [Sāṃdara ...

(2) I have given a writ for the spāta Budarma that: They have ordered (gone off) to buy me a horse. ... (3) were present in [...]. And four of them here were top quality. For them here hemp ... (4) ... a ṣaṃga of fifty, and the hemp amounted to 15 kūsas one ṣaṃga. ... (5) For each man he ordered you 16 ṣaṃgas of hemp.

When you hear the order [quickly deliver] this [hemp].Cf. IOL Khot Wood 32.a1 khu parau pvaʾ ttū jsāra. (6) When you bring me the *debt recordCf. OIOC Photo 392/57 T.O. 46 (Domoko F 11; cf. KT IV, p. 76: B.: “quittance of debts”); SI P 103.43 pāra-vaysdāṃ, Emmerick “the quittance of the debts.” of spāta Budarma, when (it is) present here ... (7) there will be no interest. And if they do not request ... for the pack-animals,Cf. SI P 97.5.1 stūrāṃ va hvaiya-ṃ heḍi. *new ...
[On ...] the order went out [to you]. SIGN

q.p: (1) The following nine men have gone on inspection: Naṃdaka, Ṣanīraka, Virgāṃ, (the 2nd) Ṣanīraka, Suhena, Kharajsajsa, (2) Suhadāysa, Īrvadatta, Suradatta.
Two men are carriers of letters: Vasade, Altāṃ.
U/And Mulaka the inspector (3) in Birgaṃdara is in Tibet.
Ysiviḍta has gone to the Inner Fort for the disposal of cloths.
In Cira (there are) 3 grain-carriers: (4) Suhadatta, Puʾysdaka, Ysāḍadatta.
Five men, messengers, are staying in (their?) houses.
Two men have gone to Cira: Aniruda and Svarrjāṃ.
(5) Three men belonging to the ṣau Viṣṇadatta are (still) owed: Surade, Sudatta, Saṃganaṃda.
(6) Five men belonging to his Lordship the Young King are (still) owed: Aśnadatta, Kharrjāṃ, Tcaṃjsai, Hvurihvāda, Saṃgaka.
(7) Five men (are) *defectors(?): Suramarṣaʾ, Vidarrjāṃ, Haskadarma, Puñadatta, Sumatt-.
(8) 24 men belonging to the gracious Lord are sesame-sowers and wheat-sowers.

The hatcaṃ which they brought to the Kaṃdva in Phema to us/them *is to be [brought?] back to Phema: (3) 11 kūsas 3 ṣaṃgas.
(4) 15 kūsas 8 ṣaṃgas of wheat—that is to be delivered in Cira.

q.p: [70.4] [... Beings who have not planted roots of goodness can not sit] (a1) on [these] seats.

[70.5] [The Lord buddha spoke thus to me:] (a3) Listen, O noble son. [Those beings who listen to this] Saṅghāṭa-sūtra, conveyor of the Law, [can sit on these seats ...

[72.1] [The Lord] (b5) Buddha spoke thus: [Listen,] O noble son, you, Sarvaśūra [...].

q.p: Year 14. This (is) the regnal year of the the gracious lord great king of kings of Khotan Viśya Vikrraṃ.

This saṃjā is for the reason that in Phęma, in the spāta Pakaḍa’s *section, Puñadatta made a *withdrawal of wheat, the one of (destined for?) the court in Birgaṃdara. The people from Kaṃdva in the *section of [the pharṣa Mahaka?] have received it: 108 kūsas 4 khas. Nothing (further) [was promised(?)].
And this saṃjā shall take effect when the pharṣa [Mahaka] seals it.

śya vi[krr]aṃ [ṣ]ā[ʾ] saṃja ttye pracainaB.: pramāna. cu phe-
ḍādä ttū ganaṃ uspurrä nāṃdīLooks like nāṃtyī.
ja uspurrä ni ne puḍa ttī ra
ṣāʾ saṃja pramāna himä khvī pha-

q.p: Year 14. This (is) the regnal year of the the gracious lord great king of kings of Khotan Viśya Vikrraṃ.

This saṃjā is for the reason that in Phęma, in the spāta Pakaḍa’s piṣkala, Puñadatta made a *withdrawal of wheat of the court in Birgaṃdara: 108 kūsas 4 khas. They have delivered this wheat. The people from Kaṃdva in the *section of the pharṣa Mahaka have received it in full. Nothing (further) was promised(?).
And this saṃjā shall take effect when the pharṣa Mahara seals it.

q.p: (1) Suradatta son of Khadara from Āskūra paid the people of Birgaṃdara 893 mūrās for wheat in the māśa field. The āsala has received them. (2) Virsa from Birgaṃdara delivered wheat 31 kūsas ... -vāsala has received them. Suśdaṃ from Khāhya delivered wheat 10 kūsas 4 khas. (3) Suśdaṃ *canceled wheat (4) 2 kūsas 7 khas. (5) Virsa *canceled 6 kūsas.

note.p: With Hardinge 074.5,7. Doc. concerning workmen from Birgaṃdara dated in the first regnal year of the yauvarāya, year of the ṣṣau Hviṃdū (cf. Or.11252/2, SI M 33). List of workmen and their ages.

q.p: (1) ... Whoever [makes] this polished and settled case invalid ... (2) ... [as] agrees with the place.Cf. Urumqi 1: (r8-v1) cu ttū gvārä śūʾstä padeṃdā -au x na hamīhyī ā-[t]-ī vā aprąmā yanāte saṃ x tta tta daṃḍä braśtä khu kṣīrū dāna samī “Whoever should change this case which has been *prepared and executed* ... or makes it invalid, only [...] thus the stick will fall as is according to the law of the land” (see Skjærvø, 2002b).
And I wrote it ... (3) from KhaCf. kaʾra si kha ysanaji “the scribe Si Kha from Ysana” (Or.11252/16). Yausa’s word.
And this letter [shall take] effect (4) [when X] places (his) finger [on it].

Cloths belonging to the *Sogdian Krrapūśira from a certain *Surade. In this account, thirteen chās are (still) owed of them/to me(?).
23 cloths belonging to Si Vidatta son of Sargīsa.
16 cloths belonging to Nuṃdārrjuṃ of Pajūma(?). The biśta’s(?) cloths became [...].
Among the ...-s of Pajūma, Nuṃdārrjuṃ the biśta’s(?) men (are) 7. So if (it was) 53 mūrās per man, his mūrās became 371 [= 53x7].
... (has) 3 armyCf. Hedin 42, a list of army persons owing (missing) in various towns. men. His cloths became *53. The working men (were) 13. For each man 2. His cloths became [26].
... *Ḍī Kvāṃ (Ling Gong?) (had) 12 men. So if (it was) 52 mūrās per man, his mūrās became 636 [= 13x52!].
... *army men (were) 4. The cloths were — chās. The working men, their cloths were [...].

q.p: (2) ... they did ... Sarvaṃdāta ... (3) Lattärhaṃ’s wife accepts her into (her) jurisdiction. If the wife ... the husband ... (4) ... afterward in her jurisdiction. But as for her daughter, Yaśāśärī Khattunä by name, (5) the spāta raises (her). When she grows up, then Lattärhaṃ ... her ... (6) ... and he himself provides her with a husband. And whatever in future *time (7) ... she has ...-ed. Whoever may change this polished and settled case, [to] the court (8) he will pay ... mūrās and receive 30 strokes.Cf. Or 9268B b6-7.
And then (9) [this writ takes effect when] Lattärhaṃ puts his finger on it.
These (10) [were] *witnesses. — Lattärhaṃ’s finger.

q.l: sāre. u ṣṭātä ysāre kalpa vaṣṭa ttä uysnora cu halci pyūvāʾre balysānu hvanau biśvī draiśśu vājāre. u satä-ysāre kalpa vaṣṭa ttä ysnora prāṇāvāt[ä]na pathīsīndä. duṣkara haḍ[e] sarvvaśūra ttä-
täye dāti pyūṣāʾmata || ttītä vā sarvvaśūrä mästä balysūñavūysei āysanna panatä syandai suti vätä prahoṇu prahoṣṭe hvarandau ysānū śando västāte kāmu hālau gyastä balysä āstä hālsto namasä-
te u haṃju dasta nāte gyastānu gyastu balysu tta braṣṭe. tta cerä vā gyasta balysa ttye uysnori käḍägānīnei haṃbīsä hämäte kye ttū saṃghāṭu sūtru apramānu yande. gyastānu gyastä balysä tta hva-
te pharāka sarvvaśūra ttä uysnora käḍägānīnau haṃbīsu pagyāysāre. gyastānu gyastä balysī tta hvate ma ne sarvvaśūra muho dīri käḍägāni haṃbīsu pulsa kye va ju āya sarvvaśūra uysnorä
ce tteränu balysānu kho dvāśuvoʾ gaṃguvoʾ nätātuṣoʾ grūkyau syata u ttānu ye ysurgyä ṣṭānä ttarandaru guhei ku hūnä narāmätä cu ttye käḍägānä ttattī käḍätānä mästarä hämäte u baśdainei haṃbīsä.
ttītä sarvvaśūrä bodhisatvä tta hvate se pharākä gyasta balysa pharākä mäṣḍāna gyasta balysa. gyastä balysī tta hvate se ttye sarvvaśūra buḍaru käḍägānä hämäte u baśdainei haṃbīsä kye mahāyānu.

dātu vätä ośu aysmū panemäte. padīta ttä sarvvaśūra uysnora huvadīta dyāña || ttītä vā sarvvaśūrä bodhisatvä tta hvate tta kho vā gyasta balysa ttä uysnora parräta hämāre balysī vā tta hvate se tta sarvvaśūra
kho hvatai ttrāmu māñandu sarvvaśūra kho ye hvaʾndiye kamalu patäʾttä u ttīye aruveʾ saṃkhalī o mākṣī o śakaru o gulu o gvīhu rrūṇu o kujsatīnau kamalu vätä. tta uspūstä rro sarvvaśūra ṣä uysnorä
hämäte. sarvaśśurä bodhisatvä tta hvate se ne gyasta balysa gyastä balysī tta hvate se pātcu sarvvaśūra ttrāmu māñandu ko ye śitu hvaṃʾdu rräjseina kāḍarna pihei u nai ye haḍe śäna pihyū-
näna jīvätu nātu yanä tta cu mānau sarvvaśūra ttye hvaʾndi väraṇä hämäte ṣai rro haḍe aruvaʾ tcera ttītī ṣä vraṇä haṃbruīttä. u cītī ṣä vraṇä haṃbruīttä ttītä butte se aysu [du]-
khäna parrätämä vaṃña mä jīvätä nägatä hämätä ku buro jvīñi ne ne gāvu aysu asädu dīru häru yanīmä häru yanīmä ttrāmī ttu näjsaḍu sarvvaśūra uysnorä ttutu ttausau byāta yande biśyau dīryau häryau
pa[th]īśtä. ttītä biśä hära byāta yande u cītä biśśä hära byāta yuḍu yande ttītī biśśi śära hära hämāre || ttrāmu māñandu sarvvaśūra bodhisatva kho muḍye hvaʾndi mārā-pätara

q.l: rāṇu dukha bera hämāre kye ttu dātu apramānu yąnāre || ttätäye hvatye hvanai sarvaśśūrä mästä balysūña-
vūysai gyastānu gyastä balysi tta hvate dukha mä nä gyasta balysa ne kṣamīndä. dukha mä nä mäṣḍāna gyasta ba-
lysa nä kṣamīndä pyūṣṭä. || ttī ttu bāḍu gyastä balysä ttä gāha hvate. cu mānau ne usahyäta pyūṣṭä
ttäte pvaʾṇavīya salāva. haṃggūjsu naryo dukhyau jsa cu ttä vaśīvīndä uysnora 1 kye haḍä śśäru yī-
ndä śśäruī bīḍä [ky]e vā dīru yanīṃdä dukha vaśīvīdä naryo ṣṭāna crrāma karma yäḍāṃdä 2 ysyāmatu maraṇu
dukha kā[ṣk]ye [t]camäna basta uysnaura: jaḍa rro vā oṣku dukhautta suhi ju nyānartha ne [ī]ndä 3 hajva vā oṣku
suhautta balysä väte haurä nä byāta ṣada nä rro aśtä mahāyāña ttä ne avāyä ne tsīdi 4 tvī padī
karma sarvaśśūra paḍāṃjsya yanu byāta: batäna kiḍägānäna satva mästä vīvāgä barīndä 5
bata ku jve ttīma pärendä pharu ye vīvāgu pajāysde. ku ye ttu mäṣa byehäte balysāna ku karä ttīma
ne jīye 6 hajvānu ṣä suhä cu hayärīṃdi oṣku balysi parauya: cu ro parehāre häryau dīryau oṣkä [...]

q.l: trāmī u ttuśau ye uysānau vajsiṣḍe ku ye ttuśāttetu dye yīndi nai nä saṃtsera āspāta häme. pyūʾ thu bhai-
ṣajyasena mā salāvu muho hā haḍu hāʾmä bodhisatvānu käḍena u balysūñavūysā karīha ne khijāma-
to kaiʾndi styūda-vrata ṣkaugyānu gaṃjse byāta yanāre uysnorāṇu hāvu yanīdi tso thu hā kāmo diśo
gyastä balysä mājeina salāvänai brāska hvāña se śiru biysāndī grata-hvāñā ma jsau ju khiji gyasta balysa
u purdai māru haṃtsa hīñe jsa haṃtsa paʾñyau u śäre dātä bärūñaṃdei sarvvasatvānu uysnaurāṇu vaska hā-
vaṃgārä u kāmi dātä pyūvāʾñe ku ye thato balysä paname thatau tsu mäḍāna sthīra māvu śirate käḍä-
na ttāmu muhu ne panamāmane kāmu balysu na-ro dätu yanāma kye dvāvaredärśyätau lakṣaṇyau haṃphu-
te kvī pajsamu yanāmä. ttītä nä bheiṣajyasenä bodhisatvä tta hve se āysda yanīru uskyāstu se
cu daiya vaṃña ttītä ttä nūvarā satva uskālstuo uysdätānde paṃjsa se ysāre kulāra dätāndete hau-
dyau ratanyau kye ratanīnyau dāmyau pajusta u myāño nä haṣprīyä viysäte buśānätai [....]

q.l: dasamo bhūmu väte vistāta hämāre u īmu ttu dhātīnau kūsu pajsabaʾjīndi. u ʾīmä nä mästä haṃphau
häme dai thu bhaiṣajyasena tte kulāra bhaiṣajyasenä bodhisatvä tta hve se daimä gyasta balysa daimä mäḍāna gya-
sta balysa īmu tte nūvarā satva dātīnau bāḍäna thānu byehīndä: u īmu tte biśānu śirā-
ṇu härāṇu bāgo haṃberīndä u īmu dātīnau kūsu kaljīndä u anaṃkhiṣṭa gyasta kye īmu dātu pa-
ysānīndä u pharāka īmu narīya uysnaura dīrvoʾ gavoʾ ṣṭāre kye gyastānu gyastä hajvattetīgyo dātä
hvāñāmato pyūvāʾre biśä saṃtsārīya dukha purrīndä paraṃjsa ni hamänīndä. ttītä ttu bāḍu nauvarenau-
tä ysāre kūla paḍāṃjsya hvąndä paḍā phārrä busta u biśe ttä uysnaura śäryo häryau haṃphuta hämāre
u bäśä ttä bheiṣajyasena uysnaura bäśyau dukhyau parsīnde u bäśä ttä bheiṣajyasena uysnaura gya-
sti balysä dyāmatu väte näta hämāre u bäśä ttä bheiṣajyasena uysnaura dhātīnaina bajāṣṇa haṃphva hä-
māri. ʾā́ysda yanu bheiṣajyasena tcahaurä hālā. ttī bheiṣajyasenä mästä balysūñavūysei dye biśä tcahauri hālā sarbaṃdäna [...]

q.l: hūsaṃkya saṃña gyaḍīna. – kye ttu hūña daiyä cu niśtä – prattyātmaggaucarä aṃggä – paba[st-
bäysāndye saṃña ni huśtä – viñānä harbiśśä ʾīste. – ttathāggatadharmä haraysde. – nika /
ratanīnai māñätä vūḍä – diśa ratnakettu aggaṃjsu. – sarvañä baysä briyūnä – ṣī tta hva[te
prattyātmaggaucarä dvāsu. – ttätä aṃgga pracai ʾīñä – paba(sta) saindä jaḍīna anāstanä – mu /
kho ju cāʾya närmändä handa – ru rūvu hūsandä śśānye – pātco hų̄ña däte handa /
ttrāmu ttätä jaḍī dvāsu. – pabastau jsīrgye hanāsä – abhāväna ttārä ne byaure – ku /
ggandharvanaggarä ṣa kaṃtha – *padanda näMs. padandä na. hirṣṭai niśtä – ttrāmu hira biśśä avadanda – samu hivi /
ggrrī-vaktrrä ggrrī-(pā)ysä – u ggrrī-dasta uīʾ loviye daśte – hamatä saṃkalpä vikalpi – saṃbā /
dyūlä biḍa ttaṃda u baurä – haṃdurna lovī jñānä – dyūlä saṃkalpa vikalpa. – saṃbā /
saṃkalpa-mātrā. ātma – parikalpa-māttrā ggeʾha – vikalpa-māttrā haṃjsārra – saṃ /
trāmu samu jaḍī cu ṣkauṅje – samu kho hajsārra u pīsä – vijñānä rūvä u yāva kā /
jaḍī ju hirṣṭai niśtä – vina aysmuī kar-ju ni byaude – vina jaḍī aysmū śśūkä – āgāśä /
Conceptualizing (saṃjñā) is sleeping through folly. He who sees in sleep what is not, an organ that is the domain of individual souls, connected ...
the conceptualizing of someone awakened does not sleep. Every discursive knowledge returns. The dharma of the tathāgata stretches out. *Tarnished ...
resembles ... covered with jewels. ... unblemished Ratnaketu, the omniscient, lovely Buddha. He it is who spoke thus: ...
The twelve domains of individual souls, these organs on account of a cause seem connected. Through folly without beginning ...
When in magic he conjures up another shape for him who lies sleeping. Thereafter he saw in sleep other ...
Like that (are) these twelve of folly, continually deceptions, distraction. On account of (their) non-being those are not found. Where ...
The gandharva-nagara city is not at all constructed. Thus all things are unconstructed, only ... own ...
... mouth ... *face ... hands (are) the senses worldly, able, themselves a saṃkalpa, vikalpa, sambhāraṇa ...
... only deception, *deceit, and a .?. of snow (is) the world’s knowledge, deception (are) the saṃkalpas, vikalpas, sambhāraṇas ...
The selfs are only saṃkalpas. Logs are only parikalpas. *Art works are only vikalpas. ...
Folly is just like the skandhas, just like *art works and a *painting, vijñāna and form, up to ...
For folly does not exist. Without the mind nothing is found at all. Without folly the mind (is?) alone, ... space ...

... he circumambulated Lokeśvararāja seven times, [placed] the right knee on the ground ...

... [Then] the [Lord] Buddha praised Lokeśvararāja with the following verses: Immeasurable ...

q.l: @ gulä ṣvīdina ją̄ʾñą̄ñä : grrą̄mä khāśą̄ʾñä bīysma prrahāje /
Molasses is to be boiled with milk. It should be eaten warm. It opens the urine.
4 bhāgas of nalada. 4 bhāgas of costus.

6 khas of wheat. Viśaʾkāntā paid the price ...
2 kūsas of wheat. She brought them(?) to the Inner Fort. The monks ... [the month] of Rrāhaja ...]
... should give ... constructed by the mind, from the prison of saṃsāra, *parikalpas ... for them ... (?)
... bound by a chain (is) the self. And other beings ... six ...
... may deign to separate (us) from woes and all sins. And all ...
... And according to the order of the buddhas he may deign to look (after us?). And not well-obtained ...

note.p: Z var. 12.67-78. With Or.12637/13.19 (r5-6, v1-2). Combined text:

“... I do homage, I the dānapati ...”

“... he heard, therefore now to you ...”

prañāprabhä nāma gyastaṣṣai 3 u suryagarbhä nāma gyastaṣṣai 4 u sattyä nā-
ma gyastaṣṣai 5 u abhiprāyaparipūraṇä nāma gyastaṣṣai 6 u nakṣatra-
rājä nāma jastaṣṣai 7 u cāritramata nāma gyastaṣṣai 8 || ttäte haṣṭa gyasta-
ṣṣā ttätu bodhisatvä ānatä yanīndä u haspījīndī ttye dārañe byehāṣce
käḍäna ce tvo dārañu vätä haspäsaṃdai hīṭhei hämāñu sagauravä śe-
rākä. cändäkī ye vätä śśäru yīndä ṣī bvāñä u bustä ṣṭānī ne hāmu-
ru ne tcerä śtä. gaṃbhīrye dātä vamaseme käḍäna ācyavaṃdä hämāñu.
biśī hära ahämäta nvaśtāña. kho jve haṃdarye heḍä cindä hanu nasu yīndä.

to the *merciless strength-robbers [= bhūtas]. You will turn them about with an expedient so that they do not go to an evil state (apāya) ...
gods, harsh through folly with no peace (of mind) take *them into (your) mind (when) afraid. 20. You ...

q.l: īndä. ttītī vā tta tta ciṃdāñä si vaña mamānai uṣṇīläna āṣṣiṇi bāʾyä naraṃdi biśāṃ satvāṃ tteri vīra pārautti.
u biśśä satva muhu jsa balysña balysūśtāṣṭa aviṣṣī nāṃdä. u biśśä satva balysa himya biśśī mī satva tta tta balysāṃ rū-
na ciṃdña. tta tta khu ra hīvya uysānā cidye. tta ttai mī ttye byātaji jsa haṃgrīna aysmūna hahiʾsaṃdai ramaṃdai āʾñä.
ṣi mī tta byātaja biśśä-pīrmāttamä upāyakauśalyä buddhānusmrye yaugga-mukhä nūvarakä balysūñavūysai kama jsa
biśśä (a)harīna baudhisatvacarya haṣkīmi ttina cu aysmū-masi haḍi biśśä hira. cu buri aysmū āyauysäna satva
āyauysāri. u hīvī aysmū vasvatte jsa vā vasusīndä. hva ra ṣṭia si balysāna balysūśtä ni c[i] tty[e] hāysa u ni ci ttye na-
ysdä ci ttye aysmū āyauṣṭä ttye hāysa ci ttye aysmū vasve ttye naysdä khu ra hva ṣṭi pātcä dharma-saṃgittä sūträ vīra balysā-
na balysūśtä ni kāmäna jä hauḍa himya himi. u ni kāmī jä vā nā īndä. samu hīvī aysmvī prratari va-
svatte jsa balysāna balysūśtä u ṣiʾ balysä hvīnde. ci kiṇa mī biśśä hira hīvī aysmūna ttye kiṇa mī ṣāʾ byātarja
tcerā. ttye kiṇa mī ṣaʾ byātarja tta tta tcerā. ttye kiṇa mī ṣāʾ byātarja ttirä buri uvāra pārṣṣa puñauda maṃgalīya ttathā-
... are ... Then he should think thus: (Just) now blue rays came out of my uṣṇīṣa supported on the forhead of all beings,
and all beings were taken by me for consecration toward the bodhi of the Buddha, and all beings have become buddhas. Just so should he consider all beings through the form of the buddhas.
And just as he has thought his own self, just so he should always sit concentrating with that memory with collected mind.
Thus is that memory: Best of all upāya-kauśalya, buddhānusmṛti, yoga-mukha, the new bodhisatva by whom
I construct all the bodhisatva-caryās without remainder. Because after all all things are the size of the mind (citta-mātra). As many beings suffer turmoil through the turmoil of the mind,
they also are purified by the purity of their own mind. And it has been said: The bodhi of the buddhas—there is none it is far from and none it is

close to. He whose mind is in turmoil it is far from, he whose mind is purified it is close to. And, moreover, as it has been said in the Dharmagīti-sūtra: The bodhi of the buddhas can not be given by anybody, nor can anybody seize it. Only from the purity of the nature (prakṛti) of one’s own mind
(comes) the bodhi of the buddhas. And that is what is called “buddha.” For the same reason that all things (come) from one’s own mind, for the same reason this memory

should be performed. For that reason that memory should be performed thus. For that reason now (is) this memory. So many exalted, meritorious, propitious tathāgatas *shall purify the molasses oil (?).

note.p: Archaizing MKhot. The same ms. as Kha. ii.18.2 (IOL Khot 35/5); see also IOL Khot 147/2.

“... ghee and sesame honey and sugar and rice and the juice of salt (brine?) and [the ...] of wild animals [...]
become heretical. So many benefits arise in the world. And now in that manner [one refrains] from heresy. ...
... who themselves have refrained from heresy and who have held others back from heresy. ..
have produced great benefits for them. But hear now this! And there then [the Buddha], Lord of Lords, called [Śāriputra]
and spoke to him thus: Śāriputra, the beings who are heretical become ungrateful toward me [and toward the Law and]
toward the saṅgha and toward (their) parents and toward all well-doing beings, because the three ...
they polish off evil deeds and thus perform great, heavy sins, he polishes off the saddharma-prakṣepa-karman (= the sin arising from the rejection of the true Law) and so on
(thinking): Did not the Lord Buddha say: The differences (between) either the śrāvakayāna or the pratyekabuddhayāna ... the *Mahayana ...
[However many] sinful acts there may be, there is no sinful deed greater than just this saddharma-prakṣepa-karman. [On account?] of this ...
... there may be, and woes do not please him. *Therefore I shall be grateful toward the three jewels and [toward] (my) parents ...
... he should seek good kalyāṇamitras, who expound to him the right Law of the Buddha, how false views do not ...
O Śāriputra, great bodhi-seeker, many beings have performed right views. ...

... those merits, roots of goodness—*deposited—actions. The merits I have rejoiced at, with those merits, roots of goodness

may all reach out to the bodhisatvabhūmicakras in (all the buddha) fields, ... in the sphere of the lord buddhas

on account of purity. The dhāraṇī of the sarvākārāvaropitas they ...-ed ... . They tied vows. Thus,
of the protectors of the buddha-śāsana—gods, nāgas ...—they will become [the ...] toward best bodhi. Because,
for the sake of bodhi, for the sake of the upholding of the saddharma, certainly for me the ... shall be ...-śīla-gandha-samanvāgata. Because,
through utilities for goodness and roots of goodness that are trailokya-lokottara, all the buddha fields will stand supariśuddha.

shall stand. And those merits, roots of goodness, bad acts, sins we confess. By those merits, roots of goodness all *sarvākārāvaropita ...

[Buddha ...] they ...-ed ... The dharmakāya, rūpakāya, nirvikalpa, jñā-
... firmly established (adhiṣṭhita), asthāna at the feet of the lord buddhas, they took me into (their) protection.
... may I be able to destroy evil, heavy sins. In one and the same
... hail! May Āryāvalokiteśvara bodhisattva [extend?] to me his mercy
... may I become the *conveyor across distress, the destroyer of sufferings. Hail! Āryā-
... may I realize ... I shall break up the mountains of heresies of all beings.

[He whose] right side of the head twitches, (the signs) should be known (to be) good. When the left
[side of the head twitches ...] [Those whose right ear] twitches shall know: I shall obtain a good dwelling. And those whose left ear twitches
[shall know: ...] [Those whose right cheek twitches] shall come to where one receives honor. He whose left cheek twitches shall know
[...] [He whose nose twitches ...] [Those whose] nostrils twitch should know: [We shall have] a nice talk with relatives and friends.
[He whose right] eyebrow twitches shall know: I shall be victorious in the assembly. He whose left
[eyebrow twitches shall know: ...] [He whose right side of the eye twitches] shall know: I shall be victorious (in fight) with enemies. He whose left side of the eye twitches .... women ...
He whose ... twitches (there is) profit for him. He whose lower lip twitches (there is) a profit for him. He whose upper
[lip twitches (there is) ... [...] He whose tongue twitches should count on his death (to be) by poison. He whose ...(?) twitches
... He whose ...] twitches should count on illness. He whose palate twitches should know that
... [He whose] ... twitches should know: quarrels will arise for me/them. He whose right shoulder twitches
[...] [He whose right shoulder twitches ...] He whose heart twitches shall soon (have) business. Those whose right arm
[twitches ...] Those whose left arm [twitches ...] shall [soon] have a meeting. He whose right ...(?) twitches ... they obtain for him female ...

for the ... beings. On account of those merits let all beings be beautiful to behold.
I shall produce *compassion ... this false view, on account of those merits
let all always have correct views. Not (only?) three times [but
constantly?] I shall practice those (ten) paths of action (karmapatha). Thereby they will obtain a nice human birth.
In this way I shall obtain the best. However many merits I have performed
in this birth and in that birth, however many I shall (still) perform in the future
in all births until bodhi, those merits I share with all
beings altogether. May those merits be purified for me here
(and become) imperishable just like space. The ten vows—before long definitely
I shall have *laid (them) down, the ten *laid down together with a hundred thousand and ten
*securities. I shall obtain omniscient knowledge, the ten powers, the four
intrepidities, the eighteen *āveṇika dharmas. May I realize best bodhi.

(I?), the spāta Īramaña embracing the earth (before my) wife, say: I ask you after Īrasaṃga and the other children, Jsijsīya and
Vilāya, and (our) other kinsmen, with small and big. I am fine here (and) in good health. How could it be otherwise (?) if you are fine
(and) in good health, (then) I here consider it an honor to me. About the harvest, take care that you have watered the grain in due time
and that you have looked after the mastauña.B.: tentatively “fodder,” but uncertain. Look after the sheep and the other cattle so that you do not lose them.
The paʾsīñapaʾsīña- also IOL Khot Wood 33a1. pomegranates from Aśnesala(?), give them to ... so that they do not dry out.B. “perish.” Now Īraka from Kaṃdva has gone to you.
Take the wheat from him that is for you: six kūsas. And grind the wheat in the house, when the flour has been cleaned.
Gather twelve kūsas of flour for me. And if your own pack-animals can go hither, then carry it hither on your own pack-animals,
and let just one man drive the animals to me. If they can not go, then let *rented animals carry it here.
But only if it is easier for you do it that way. Gather for me three śiṃgas of sesame oil,
three ṣaṃgas of dry kūras, a half pārakā of crude sugar, and two thyeba khalavīs.See Emmerick, 1985b, pp. 302-3, 307. And do give him a sāṃśka for me and
felt for cloth. I have given *Baṃṣṭa *bows to deliver to you personally. And thus ... for him a good janā, and place it on him/it(?) if that janā does not fit him
(or) those who brought (it?). *Let Īrasaṃga come here to me, (though) it is a long way. And there, you just take care of everything on your own!
The 16th day of the month Hamārrīja I gave the letter (to be brought) to you.
The spāta Īramaña. To be delivered.Apparently not: “To the spāta Īramaña”?

I, Sidavaṃda, much embracing the earth (at my) mother’s (feet), say (to her) and [to] (my) *brothers ...
If] she is calm for them (?) healthy, (then) I, being here far away, consider (it) an honor. Here for me...
with ... till now is well. Here for me now for many days ...
I have had no quarrel [with ...]. I am concerned for all of you (thinking) “how will you not go hungry?”See Emmerick in Studies II, p. 111. ...
have sat down ... and I *request from you one cup with cold water ...
... Now, he for three months has not even gone for my sake ...
... came ... I ask you, only take great care so [that ...]!
I shall come ... On the 26th [day] of the month of Kaja I gave the letter (to be taken) to you.

q.l: @ aysä pīsai seṃdū pīsai vasädattä puʾsū khve tta śerka ṣ[ṭ]āve drrūnai a maṃ
pajsa pachīśeʾ maṃ maṃ pā śerka [ṣṭe] drrūnai dūkhū maṃ tta-ṃ x [x] x ce āṃ maṃ ahā
ne vejsyai mere maṃ pā śerka drrūnai pyūṣṭemä sä āchänai tta hamyai tt-e haṃbu-
saṃ ye khv-e ttā arrva hajsaudä yaña a maṃ pā anavāśäʾ ye ttī jsāṃ
t[t]ā mūna hvaṃḍä ne byaude a ma nā -e [x x x] -i
I, the teacher Seṃdū ask after the teacher Vasädatta. If things are well with you (and) healthy, I
consider it an honor for me. As for me here, then, things are well (and) healthy. For me the (only) sorrow ... that
I have not seen you (all) here. For my mother here, then, things are well. I have heard that you have become so ill. Thus
it was proper for you(?) that you were able to gather your medicines. I here have had no *opportunity. And then
you did not receive my men (who were going) to you. I here ...
To be given to the teacher.

q.l: || |||| || cī ṣiʾ śiri bāḍä ye ttma khu ṣiʾ bhadrrakalpī mistä miṣḍi ḡyastä marä ysaṃthä nāte viśaʾ kīrttä pū-
ñāṃ prrabhāvina 1 subhikṣi mari paṃñe hirna rruṃdi hīyau {jsi} pūñau jsa ttāguttyau hvāṣṭyau pātci ci ṣṭāṃ ttū hvaṃ-
kṣīri kaiʾdi 2 kṣasimī ṣṭāṃ tsve kṣuṇi panatai gaurivi mista parvālāṃ pajsaṃ prracaina hā dharmä āhāri keṃṇa 3
ṣiʾ mī vā ṣada jsi brīya namaṃdrrye gari vīrāṣṭa āśaʾrya dva ṣiʾ ttū kālä rrāhaji āstaṃ māśte 4 kṣīri āysdarrji
prracaina haspisyari vari ā vña śā salī śiri apvaṣṭi khu vyachīṃdi harbaiśi pīle 5 ūpakarąṇi ci bū-
rāṃ śtāka ra ṇi harbäśūṃ vāṣṭi hajsau[de] —
(1) When that good time was—at the time when that bhadrakalpika great (2) gracious Lord took birth here, Viśaʾ Kīrtta, by the power of (his) merits. 1.
(There is) abundance here in every thing because of the merits of the king, as well as because of the Master Tibetans, who are guarding this land of Khotan. 2.
(3) His sixteenth regnal year has passed. Great respect has arisen for him.Because of the honor of the watchers for the sake of promoting the Law 3
(4) he with faith (and) in love has invited thither, to Gara, two reverend ones. He at this time, at the beginning of the month of Rrāhaja 4
for the sake of the protection of the land (...) (5) (So) strive therein the temple for one year well (and) *uninterrupted, so that all sufferings disapppear! 5.
Utilities as many (6) as they need, all of them *he has gathered for them here.

q.l: || cū būra krrä ṣṭāre ttī ʾau ṣāv nva yną ttuśāttā ṣaʾmārīdą u mara vajrrayauną nva ttuśai na ṣṭe vargaustą ṣṭe: tta ttai hvñma ṣṭą sa aśte kaiṇą ganaittrai. aśte vīrāṣṭi ganaittrai
kālanāṣṭä ganaittrai aśte prracainą ganaittrai aśte kaiṇą ganaittrai kmanai samādna devattą nāsāve ttakye hīye x hrradaya u sārą byāvą yanme kaiṇa ganaittrai: aśtai vīrāṣṭä ganai-
ttrai śrī-vajrrasattä vīrāṣṭä ganaittrai: kālenāṣṭa ganaittrai. samaṃttabhadryai rrähāśai daivatta hīye rrihāśai vaiysä x vīrāṣṭa anamaudma aśtai prracenä ganaittrai kāya-vāga-
paysānmai pajsamevāme baiysāṃ ysyñme prracaina āvairāmai
cetta rrihāśe saidhä sījāṣṭi pracaina ganaittrai : viña tta ganaittrai kāmīnai pīsai āśīʾrī ūysdīśai || u kāmyai ttatträ jsai vā thīye || u kāmye ynä hālai || u aśtai pracainai vā ū-
ysdīśai || u ʾauskana ʾauma cī arthä jsāvai: || cū ūysdīśākä pīsai āśīʾrī x kāye ṣiʾ ciga kṣīʾra x tta ttīśąnä ysāye baśrīmajsu nma ye : cu saidä gīhāka daivatta ṣaiʾ brmäysattī nʾma ya. hīdv
jsa ravye pa ñūhuṃjsadä samyasa ysye labhasalāspāñä u ttattīśanä mūdä u khamasa
kṣīʾra d sīye || ū rahāśe haṃdarmai nätcarīmai dā harbiśä ṇaiʾhvastai || u vara sedä byaudai drrāṃ cū x vrrīśämaṃ vaṭhāye mñaṃdä kīrar padaide. u haṃdrrauysya tsūma u śaṃdya vecūly-
tcārä nāgapāla u dasā dīśā pāla
ma u mahāsamdrra kavä mñaṃdä tsīya. ttäkyāṃ būrai beʾjsyau jsa haṃphve vaivā saidhaprrāptai pīse āśiʾrī uysdīśe kmye ttaṃtträ jsai vā thīye avattarä ttaṃtträ vā thīye : aśte
cu pīse biṃdä attaravāysa māhākāśä ghya cakrra jsā vā u

pracainai vā uysdīśai haiysdājsyāṃ u ästamāṃjsyā yaugänāṃ śrī-vajrrasattä jsa hamaṃgä haphīśāma väkṣäʾmāṃ sījāṣṭyi ūdäśāyi u maṃdrrä u mdrra simādāna devattä ahaumaurrjä prracena. tta tta khvai hā mūrakyi
ṇaiyī-y-ī vi gavīnā ynä jsā tcrä raudä vai nva sahä jabakä nau kūla akadättä parya vīstve myāṃ de ñīye na sūjsīye jsīna biṃdi byeda rāśiʾ bvaiyausta ttaradarä

However many kriyās there are, those(?) the śrāvakas, according to yāna, count (as) emptiness. And here, according to the Vajrayāna, it is not empty; it contains vargas. And just thus there is the teaching that: On account of what is the ganetra? Toward what is the ganetra?

In what direction is ganetra? For the sake of what is the ganetra? On account of what is the ganetra? — Whatever samādāna deity he takes (obtains?), on account the recollection of the heart and essence of that one (is) the ganetra. Toward what is the ganetra? —

Toward Śrī Vajrasattva is the ganetra. In what direction is ganetra? — *Rejoicing toward ...-ing for the sake of recognition and worshiping the lotus of the mystery of the deity in the mystery of Samantabhadra (and for) producing buddhas. For the sake of what is the ganetra? —

For the sake of the succeeding of the siddhi of the mystery of kāya-vāk-citta is the ganetra. Now, which (is) thus the reverend teacher (who) expounded the ganetra? And from what tantra did he draw it? And toward which yāna? And for the sake of what did he expound it to us?

And when(?) will he go to the meaning of the *dwelling on high? As for the body of the reverend teacher who expounds it, he was born in the southern region, western samyasa(?) in China. He dwelt in Labhasalāspāñä and Ttattīśanä, and he was born in Ttattīśanä in Khamasa. His name was Baśrīmajsu. As for the deity who helped (his) siddhi, (her) name was Brmäysattī. In India

he learnt the Law. And he overcame the internal and external mysteries, the entire Law. And there he obtained siddhi so great that he *raised (upasthāpaya?) the four nāga-pālas and ten guardians of the directions and constructed workers similar to them(?). And (he achieved) walking in the air and moving in(?) the earth

, and he would go in the great ocean like a fish. Equipped with all those good qualities, having obtained the siddi of (his) vipāka, the reverend teacher expounded (the ganetra). — Because upon the teacher (was) the antaravāsa-mahākāśa-guhya-cakra. (?)

And from what tantra did he draw it? — He drew it (from?) the *abhyanantara-tantra. And for the sake of what did he expound it? — To present and future yogins, like Śrī Vajrasattva, with a view to the succeeding of the väkṣäʾmas of ...-ing and for the sake of not forgetting the mantra and the deity of the mudrā-samād(h)āna(?), for instance(?), if he were to place *mudrakās on her(?) the yāna ... the four kings ... Saha Jabaka nine koṭis he placed in the command of Akadatta, he might sit in the fire (and) it would not burn (him). He obtained control over (his) life. The bodies full of rays

byāvä tsīdä u madrre hā byāva jsāve || khvai hā maṃdrrä byāvi jsāvai || u mdrrai hā byāvi jsā | khvai hā mdra byāvi jsā | u samdhnä devittai hā byāvä jsāvai || simādhna daivattä byāvi yinme jsai jsāṃ. kye-vāga-cettä

hīvī sedä byehe x u satsāra jsa guśti : u avāyga satva ttrvāye x drra-bāḍvi kāmye yna hālenā ṣṭāre.. vajrraynä hāle ṣṭāre ʾauskana ʾaumą cī artha jsāvai däsau-padya ʾaumä mūrakyāṃ gutterä nījsāñme hīvī
rahāśe pīrmātta sāhyattā hīrñä pīchaṣṭū yidį tc-padya kīrv sījāṣṭä byehe.

artha jsāve.. ṣaiʾkä yauginä. cu mūrakye bīḍä x u mūrakyā hīvī artha ni bvāvi u samai vai pā niśtä x ttyai ʾauma jasta baʾysa daṃda hamrai khu jsīna paśai hīśanvā ʾaiʾjsvā bañāmai byaihai u śąʾmä kāṃ bya-
pajsa-padya u samį abiṣyekä. an vajrrayānyāṃ gajsa yade I u rahāśai gūstya nasa dā hīvī jāpā arthū pajsamevāma na bvāve maṇḍale pā ttrmāṣṭä na ʾīye

ña pīttä u virä ʾauna ra vā guscyi ni byaihe x cu ttyā mūrakyāṃ ṣiʾmerāme hīya saṃñä ṣṭe ṣiʾ paḍauśiʾkyi pīchaṣṭū simdhna devattä jāyma ṣṭe : u dyāma dāvīne ttaradara jsa haphīśma u harbi(śāṃ) sątvāṃ vīra hamaṃ-
vajrra yikṣį u agna ttāla krrdä u vajrra śrī herūkä krraudä-rājä ysīräjä hūñä khāśīʾdä ysaira jarä svī dī vatsa thajīdä hauda gu gūttaira jīye

ga mista mūaiśdäʾ ūpaivāña. u syadai dastä hīvī āṣṭi samaṃttabhadrrä u hagauṣṭa samaṃttabhadrra u jñna u dharmadāttä : tta tta si cu harbiśā jastāṃ baʾysa naraumauma ṣṭāve u ysyāma. biśä au vā jñānä u dharmadhā-

ttä haṃdryivya ʾauna nirmīdä u ysyārai : drra-haṣkalyā ysimaśadya bīsā harbiśāṃ satvā hīye pā kme kleśiʾ vāysina jñānä u darma-dhttä hadrryivya ʾauna vasve hamārai : u hagāḍai. ttyai pracaina syaṃ-
dai āṣṭī u haṃgauṣṭi hadrryivya ginaittrai dījsña {x} u hvaraṃde dąstä hīye āṣṭī u dvī hagauṣṭi kāyi-vāga-caittä hīya prrara ayekṣñä u āṣṭī vairaucä. u paḍauysa haṃgauṣṭi
armyāyi u śaʾ hagauṣṭi vajrra-sattä u dīda hagauṣṭa rahna-sabhavä u kaṇaiska amgasaida u tta ʾau vā paṃjsa jasta baʾysi jñāna u dharmadhttä hadrryivya ʾauna naraumīdä avāyāga satta hagā-

are remembered. And the *mantra is remembered by him. When the *mantra is remembered by him, then the mudrā is remembered by him. When the mudrā is remembered by him, then the samād(h)āna deity is remembered by him. Then, by remembering the samād(h)āna deity

he obtains the siddhi of the mystery of kāya-vāk-citta. He brings into full view the state of foremost happiness. He obtains success in the four-fold acts, and he is delivered from saṃsāra. And he delivers the beings *in apāyas of(?) the three times, on the side of whatever yāna they stand, they stand on the side of the Vajrayāna. And when(?) will he go to the meaning of the *dwelling on high? — He will go to the meaning of the showing of the gotra of the mudrās of the *dwelling on high. That yogin who carries the five-fold mudrās, and the *samaya-abhiṣeka without vajrayānikas, performs a sin, and he will not know the meaning of the mudrās, and henceforth there will be no samaya for him. And he will not know the meaning and worship of the jāpas of the ... mystery (and) release ...(?), and thenceforth there would be no entering the maṇḍala for him. In that dwelling there will be so many lord buddhas. When he relinquishes life he will obtain binding in iron fetters and into whichever(?) obstruction of Yama’s

he falls, then he will not obtain release back here. Vajrayakṣa, Aguṇatālakrodha, and Vajraśrīherūka Krodharāja will drink the blood of (his) heart, they will pull out (his) heart, liver, lungs under the *breast. The seven-fold gotra will be lost (for him). As for the notion of counting those mudrās, the first one is the meditation on the samādhāna deity in full view, and the seeing, the *union with the dharma-kāya, and

the production of equal great compassion for all beings. And the thumb of the left hand (is) Samantabhadra, and the fingers (are) Samantabhadra and knowledge (jñāna) and the dharmadhātu. Just like that is that which will be the exit and birth of all the lord buddhas: all

will go out and be born between knowledge and the dharmadhātu. The vāsanas, kleśas, and (false) views of all beings residing in the triple-tiered world will all be purified between knowledge and the dharmadhātu and *drawn out(?). Therefore,

the ganetra should be held between the left thumb and a finger. And the thumb of the right hand and two fingers should be *established (adhiṣṭhā) as the underlying nature (prakṛti) of kāya-vāk-citta. And the thumb is Vairocana, and the first finger (is)

Amitāyu, and the second finger (is) Vajrasattva, and the third finger is Ratnasambhava, and the little finger is Amoghasiddha. And thus then five lord buddhas go out between knowledge and the dharmadhātu. They *draw out the beings ....
rīdą baʾysuśti vīra ʾau pārīphīdä. cu mūraka bida ṣṭe ṣiʾ maista mveśdäʾ ṣṭai u baʾysūśtāṣṭa pade cu jsā mū(ra)kyi ṣṭārai tti jsā drrahaṣkalya ysamaśadya bīsā satvā hīya prara ṣṭe : u nau yauñaṃ hīya
pacaḍäka jsa sarbma : cu mūrakyā hīye nha ṣṭe ṣiʾ ysathāṃ. hīvī nhä ṣṭe u grathä ṣiʾ jsā dāvīnai ttaraṃdärä ṣṭe. u śau pacaḍä jsā väjrrācārī pīse āśaʾrī ṣṭai. cu mūrakyāṃ
hīya khuṇā ṣṭe ṣiʾ haṣṭusa-padya ttuśāttā ṣṭe haṣṭusa-padya jsā ttuśāttā jñānīnai tcai ṣṭe. cu ʾau mvaiśdäʾ jsa satvadhāttä ysimaśadai sśai x cu dvīnai ttaradära u vajrrācārī tti a-
vaiṣkesta ṣṭāre mūrakyā hagārme beḍa ñāña bhīse gratha ni parsāña gaʾsāña khu ttī parsīye dāvīnai ttaradarä u vajrrācārī-v-ai au byāśāʾma hamai : x u samai gatcyma u parau gatciñāmä mistä
gatcasta samai ṣṭai. paḍauśiʾkyi mūrakyā hīvī guttairä tta tta nījsāṣṭa si ṣāvā x ranīnai ganaittrai. u āstīnai u vargastā bahyā hīyāṃ gīchaukāṃ jsa na habūsa tta tta cva va madrra maudrra samai
prrattīkabdā arahadā bdasatvāṃ pajsa-padya pā ganaittrai na habusanä
naiśti. u ttī jsā vajrrayāna ṣāvāyāna jsa x tcau-padya paryai līkä ṣṭe dyāme jsa u caryai jsa u sījāṣṭyā jsa u samai jsa dyāmai jsa khu paryai sa(ma)ttabhadrrye dyāmai jsa paryai cirya praña
ūpāya jsa paryai sījyāṣṭyi kāya-vāga-citta hīvī maṇḍala jsa paryai tcu mūrakyā hīvī dasau-padya guttara nījsāṣṭa ṣṭai. ṣāʾ pā guttaira jsa haphīśñä
cu ttathāgattakūla ṣṭe x ṣiʾ myau ṣṭe : vara ganaittrai pāttarajīvīnai ttyai hvāñauma jsa jāpa ni habusa niṣāʾmate hagrñä jabvīdvīpa rrivye pa ʾiḍārai hīdva kṣīrä samattai
vajrrakūla padmakūla karmakūla varä ganaittrai nva nva kūlā haphīśñä

They establish them in bodhi. As for what is on(?) the mudrā, that is great compassion and the path to bodhi. As for the mudrās there are, that is the underlying nature (prakṛti) of the residing in the triple-tiered world.

And the rising up from the ... of the nine yonis. As for the tip of the mudrā, that is the tip of births. And the knot, that is the Body of the Law. And one ... is the reverend teacher of the vajrācārya. As for the

... of the mudrās, that is the 18-fold emptiness, it is the eye of knowledge. As for the teaching of the world of the sattva-dhātu through compassion, as for the Bodhi of the Law and the vajrācārya, those are undistinguished.

At the time of *drawing out the mudrās, one should sit down(?), the knots of ... should be released, one should turn (them?). If one were to release them (then), there would be for him crossing of the Body of the Law and the vajrācārya and *breaking of the samaya, and great(?) causing to break of the command.

Broken is the samaya(?). The first gotra of the mudrās is shown as follows: henceforth the five-fold ganetra is not suited for the śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, arhats, bodhisattvas. The jewel ganetra and the one of bone and the one from the *kernels of the vargasta trees are not suitable. Thus (it is in the case of) those who do not have mantra, mudrā, (or) samaya.

Next, the Vajrayāna has *surpassed the Śrāvaka-yāna and the Pratyekabuddha-yāna in four ways: in view, career, success, and samaya. How has it *surpassed it in view? — It has *surpassed it in the view of Samantabhadra. The career has *surpassed it in prajñā (and)
upāya. The success has *surpassed it in the maṇḍala of kāya-vāk-citta, because it has shown the ten-fold gotra of the mudrās. This(?) must henceforth be joined with the gotra.

As for the tathāgata-kula (and) the vajra-kula, karma-kula: there the ganetra should be joined according to each kula. That is the middle. There the ganetra is from putrajīva (nuts). jāpa is not suitable together with its pronouncement. ... must be *drawn out. In the southern region of Jambudvīpa in yonder land of India
nmä kṣīra ṣṭe u viriñaupūra śau bhahye ysā u ttyai bhahyi śīña hīyāraña ssa haṣṭa pātta(ra)jīvā naraumīdä u śākyamūna jasta baʾysa hīvī mr-pyärau ṣiʾka ṣṭe. u
ṣiʾ bihyą u ūdūbąra spyai u kyesara sar śākhyamūna jasta baiysa haña baiḍa hamya : u ttyai pracaini ṣiʾ pāttarajīvīnai ganaittrai harbīśā jastā baiysā hīye pīrmāttä
ganaittrai ṣṭe u vajrrakūlą ʾīrä rahnakūla raṃnä u padamakūla vaiysä karmakūla lodrrākṣāʾ u pajsa-padya jsāṃ rrihāśai ginaittrai ṣṭe || |||| || || (cursive:) ttyāṃ hīvī
jāpā artha hvīde cuḍi ssa {20 1 stą} hva u ssa 20 1 stä u ssa haṣṭä ṣaʾ kāya-vāga-caitta hīya prrara bvñä
there is a land called Samattai, and in Viriñaupura one tree was born and in one fruit from that tree 108 putrajīva nuts come out. And that is that of the parents of the Lord Buddha Śākyamuni. And
that tree and the Udumbara flower and the kesarin lion were at the same time as the Lord Buddha Śākyamuni. And therefore the ganetra made of putrjīva is the foremost ganetra of all the lord buddhas.

And the vajra-kula (is) jade, the ratna-kula jewel, the padmakula lotus, and the karma-kula rudrākṣa. And that is the five-fold mystery ganetra. The meaning of those jāpas is expounded. Why was it said “a hundred” and “a hundred and 21” and “a hundred and eight”? — That is to be known as the underlying nature of kāya-vāk-citta.

note.p: Yellow paper. Variant of the beginning of the confession text in Ch.00268 (IOL Khot S. 12) and Ch.00277 (IOL Khot 85/1-86/6). Ed. in Emmerick, 1977b. Guide2 [18.34].

cu bęśa āyauysą naṣāʾda āyīma ṣṭāṃ ttyāṃ pąna ahąrīna karmāṃ jegä cu
avaysāṃda ąysmū keṇa hajsaudai ʾīme hecä ttana cū aysmvą-masą baiśä

stą. nayūta jastą beʾysa hąmye aysmūna hąmye bījāṣna ttū ąparamąttāyą-sūttra hvāṃda

q.l: paysānāma kṣamī vajrracchaidakyi prrajñā-pārme nva carya tsūma ttāra tcaʾca hīs-
ma dharmamūkha mūkha niṣkalyāme hīya padaja || cu prrajñāttīrṇa āśiʾrī mi-
styau jāyaryau gaṃbhīra jāryau gaṃbhīra jāyaka brraṣṭa. humädāṃ kītha ysāyī hāvä bujse
vīra anihvarrda biśä ysirrnai baʾysna baʾysūśtä kṣąmä ṣiʾ mī tvaḍa bistä salī garrvā mūṃde
vara na śūjye nva dva mārgaupadeśā parṣeʾ parrīyasta cu biśe caignye jana-
ve vira kalyṇamittra ya. hīya biśāʾ-y-ūṃ jsa tvā gaṃbhīra jāyaka pacaḍana ka ba
... wishes to recognize (prajānitu-kāma) ..., to perform the career according to the Vajracchedikā-prajñāpāramitā, to come to yonder shore,
(to learn) the method of ... the entrance to the Law (dharmamukha). What the reverend Prajñāttīra
with great ... the profound ... the profound ... has asked. In the town of Humädāṃ born, unattached to his profits and praises
all golden the bodhi of the buddhas pleases him. He has dwelt in the mountains for more than 20 years.
While there one after the other two mārgopadeśakasCf. KT IV, p. 88. the *arhats of the assembly, who were in the entire Chinese
land the kalyāṇamitras. Their own tongue from them this profound ... in due order ...

note.p: Aparimitāyuḥ-sūtra fols. 1-4. Fol. 1v on Ser., pl. CL.

q.l: The ṣau Krraśīsä, Cā Ḍī Pyainä, ordered this Aparimitāyuḥ-sūtra to be written in love of bodhi.

q.l: rāṃ hīvī agä cā kīmä śąnä pasta pīḍai biysūśtä brrīyi ttye pūñä kūśalä-mūla pārrjsai jsa cakavartta śai tcūnä aṇiʾscyä rāśäʾ gavu ga-vaśiṣa hamāvä upa-
ttavaśeṣa sthnä-vīśaiṣa haiysdi vīra jsā vīśäʾrä-rāśäʾ rādä bvįysye jsīñä prrīygä hamāvį : maiscyi aṇeʾscynä bvaiysa jsīna hamāvi kalpa jsa
hajsaidiṃ karma bįśdiʾ jādi bįśa-pīrmttama ttā baiysśti parīdi vyechai tta ṣṭāṃ pūñä padä śānä pyarä pū-hyä cā pina jsa habrrīhū gavi vasasīdä : mira hū-
māṃ bveysa jsīnä hamāvä tta ṣṭāṃ pūñä pyara hīye paysāye brrvära cā ttaiha tcainä kharūṣa jsa habrrīhū u pūrā dvarā jsa ttu ṣṭāṃ pūñä naira kīma hva jsa habrrīhū u dvīra
rūpājīva jsa : dvīrä jvālakya jsa brrāvara ttravīlai sīdyakavarrda jsa ttravīlai darmajñā jsa harbīśāṃ aśiʾrya gāṭhā vajrrayaunyāṃ jsa biśä satva bi-
ysūśtāṣṭä vyārṇa byehīdä aysa ttā pā cā kīmä śanä byehīme thyau madrrāṃ sījāṣṭä baiysūśtä vyichīme KymSogdian-Uigur.ʾna paysāvye hvārakyä sūraimaitrra jsa
This Jātakastava, the limb of the difficult/marvelous deeds of the buddas,

Cā Kīmä Śąnä ordered it to be written in love of bodhi. Through support upon the merits and roots of goodness (resulting) from it, may the cakravartin Śai Tcūnä have eternal rule. May my gati be a special gati,

a special rebirth (upapatti), a special place (sthāna)! At present, may the vajra-rāja king have the enjoyment of a long life! May he have a great, endless, long life! May the karmas (and) sins that I have accumulated for kalpas

disappear from me! May *He deign to devote Himself to the very foremost bodhi! (?) These merits I now share with my father, Padä Śānä (and) the pū-hyä (puye h i) Cā Pina. May (their) gatis be purified! May my mother

Humāṃ have a long life! I now share these merits with my father’s brother german Cā Taiba Tcainä Kharūṣa,Kharūṣa: see Or.8210/S. 2469. and with (his?) sons (and) daughters. That merit with (my) wife, Kīma Hva and (my) daughter

Rūpājīvā (and my) daughter Jvālakyā, (my) brother, the traipiṭika Sīdyakavarrda, the traipiṭika Dharmajña, with all the monks, householders, (and) Vajrayāṇa-followers. May all beings obtain a prophecy toward bodhi!
May I, too, Kīmä Śanä obtain one! May I devote myself to the quick success of the mantras (and) to bodhi! Kim-πan together with his sister german Sūraimaitrrā.

note.p: Fol. 1r contains, apparently, the colophon of a preceding text and an introduction to the Vajracchedikā. It has a Chinese stamp. There are three different hands. The original(?) colophon is written in bold script in three lines: the single word āśiʾrī at the top edge to the right (line 0) and two lines (1-2), followed by the intro¬duction to the Vajracchedikā (line 3). The lower left corner has writing apparently in the same hand (line 4). At the top of the folio are two lines (0a-b) continued between lines 1 and 2 (1a) and below (the akṣara ska) and to the right of line 2 (2a-b) containing a note regarding a legal dispute. At the bottom edge of the folio (2c) is a triśaraṇa. Hoernle, MR., pls. v-xi; fols. 1r/v and 33r in Ser., pl. CXLIX. The Vajracchedikā begins on fol. 1v, decorated with a yellow buddha and flowery decorations. PLATE 7a.

q.l: tta ttū kalperāja-suttra vīśaʾttīrai āśaʾrī savajaidākarä hiʾṃña pasta
STAMP ddhā śaʾ kīrai āśaʾ (?) ka vī ska sta ra ña ha
30myä kṣauṇa gūha salyī hamārīja māścä pajsūsamyä dasamyai māśca ttā kṣī-
rrvī vī vī mūñaja māścai kamäla jaista śā baysga dvāsa saira gvāra tta basta sasta
CHALarge akṣara that looks like cha. rrvī vī va ttūThe top part of the akṣåra is like tta at the beginning of line 1, the bottom part like bottom of cha.
siddham drrai padya namasmä baʾysä dṛbāḍva ṣadi jsa tva-
rä ttṛyṇī namasmä dāta tti vā drrai-padya
bisaṃgä || ttū padī namasmä sūträ prajñā-pā-
rma baʾysnä māta biśnä pārmāṃ hvāṣṭä gabhī-
Thus, this Kalpa-rāja-sūtra the monk Sarvajinākara of the Vīśattīrai (monastery?) ordered to be written in red(?).
He ordered merits to be written.
I do three-fold reverence to the buddhas.
(On) the 15th day of the month of Hamārīja of the 30th regnal year, Year of the Ox, in the tenth month,

to the court to you. In the month of Muñaṃja, Kabula requested one thick blanket, 12 ounces. The dispute was thus closed to everybody’s satisfaction(?). To the court. It (will) then (become) authoritative, when Jsaska puts (his) finger (on it).
Welfare! I do homage in three ways to the buddhas of the three times with exceeding faith.
I do homage to the three yānas, to the Law, and then in three ways to
the bhikṣu-saṅgha. [1] In this way I do homage to the Prajñāpāramitā sūtra,
the mother of buddhas, the best/master of all pāramitās, profound, (2r1) an excellent *remedy—

hvañāri: paḍāṃjsyāṃ bāḍāṃ śiña kṣīra śau lakṣa
This much the Lord Buddha spoke. They were (all) content: the reverend Subhūti *and the remaining monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, and the world-encompassing assembly of gods,
goddesses, asuras, gandharvas, etc. The Lord Buddha,
however, concluded the Vajracchedikā-prajñāpāramitā in three hundred verses.
Welfare! The diṣṭāntas of the Vajrachedikā
are spoken to you, (those) of former times, in one land, one lakh(?).

... that: They have abducted here the married women. And the Linggong made a report to us thus
[that]: At the court, is the būjsaṃja for (Our) consort the great queen (the) better (one?) or Our life? And
They deigned ... to us that: They can not abduct the married women (and bring them?) *here (for wives). Then
we brought before Them a report regarding Āśiʾrkā that: If those are married women and they can not be abducted (and brought?) *here, then there is a problem there. Then
order Āśiʾrkā to be given to me because she is unmarried, as long as there will be no problem here. And
regarding ... they sent word here that: If this one were needed, then there would come an order from the Chinese
populace, or else he would deign(?) (to go) thither, Hvainä to the court and ārūku (8) to the court there would be an order
with words(?). He did not send a word of an order to us(?). {And then thither the humble}
servants {daily, all the time, we went ...} and thus he ordered us that: ...
... from/with ... we entered the city. And when we came before the palace, we went before them, and according to
the order of the court we stated the entire order to them. And we met ... with the ttuṃgas and then ... and whatever about(?) the Ling-gong, the prince, and

the royal consort, respectively, for Ñāṃ-tcāṃ, the ttuṃgas, the tsanä-śīs the Ling-gong was *happyBailey suggested Chin. hâo xing j á “of good family,” but perhaps rather j ≥ haô xìng “good-natured.” with, all that we put together for them according to the order and the ... .
On the seventh day, we went before (him) and presented to him the order about *kinship, and he spoke
as follows: ‘So We say: We (sent) a message to you, (but) you have not sent any to us.’ And then Svanaka,
the humble servant Kvāṃ-pa Lyehsaka, Maśänä Pauka, and Rca Paḍä-tsā Pācä and Yinä(?). We went before him.
Thus, the orders for the Chinese Khotanese, to wherever their ... was, thither we brought them before them.
... spoke as follows: “Here We say.” And then they *accepted,
and in the assembly they produced the following speech: ‘This one
at first goes in saṃsāra, and for these five and for that one here it is not better than this. And now
there will come messengers to you and your land. The information from the Ling-gong will come and
that of your humble servants. And if the compassion of the messengers
quickly reaches out to us(?), when Kī-svąña sets out ..., if we can turn back to you,
then, in the month of Muñaṃja, we shall bring the ... to you. And
if the compassion of the *blessing [Tib. bkra-śis?], of the ritsuyarūṣa, of *Hbum
Rdo-rje, of Kvāṃ Pinaka, and of Saṃgai son of Maṃdūysa(?)
reaches out to us, and the ... of Mahamūtta ... And if then later there comes from the city for us humble ...-born such a beautiful order, then we shall make it ...
Then we shall be the Ling-gong’s royal sevants and at all ...

harbaiśa padya bvākä hīrñä vīra (10) kma abauste avajsañme hālai narujme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīr-
ñä vīra : (11) kma abauste apanamme hālai sājanai harbaiśa padya bvākä hīrñä vīra : (12) kma ṣkāṃjāṃ jiṃgya hālai sāja-
nai harbaiśä padya bvākä hīrñä vīra : (13) kāma ṣkāṃjāṃ avajsañme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (14) kma ṣkāṃjāṃ
narrujme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvākä hīrñä vīra : (15) kma ṣkāṃjāṃ apanamme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvākä hīr-
ñä vīra : (16) kma aysmu jaigya hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (17) kmä aysmu avajsañme hālai sājanai harbai .
śä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (18) kma aysmu narrujme hālai sājanai harbaiśa padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (19) kma aysmu apana-
mme hālai sājanai harbaiśa padya bvāka hīrñä vīva : (20) kma nma-rru jaigyä hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (21) kma
{kma} nma-rru avajsañme hālai sājanai harbaiśa padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (22) kma nma-rū narūjme hālai sājanai ha-
rbaiśa [padya] bvāka hīrñä vīra : (23) kma nma-rru apanamme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (24) kmä kṣyāṃ
tvārāṃ jaigya hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (25) kma kṣyāṃ tvārāṃ avajsañme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvā-
ka hīrñä vīra : (26) kma kṣyāṃ tvārāṃ narrujme hālai sājanai harbaiśa padya bvākä hīrñä vīra : (27) kma kṣyāṃ tvārāṃ apanamme
hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (28) kāmä skvāme jaigyä hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (29) kāmä skvme
avajsañme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (30) kāma skvme narrujme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka
hīrñä vīra : (31) kma skvme apanamme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (32) kma varśʾme jaigyä hā-
(lai) sājanai harbaiśä padya bvākä hīrñä vīra : (33) kmä varāśʾme avājsañme hālai sājanai harbaiśa padya bvākä hīrñä vī
ra : (34) kma varāśʾme narrujme hālai sājanai harbaiśa padya bvka hīrñä vīra : (35) kma varāśāʾme apanamme hālai sājanai
harbaiśa padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (36) kma eʾsāṃ jaigya hālai sājänai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (37) kma eʾsāṃ avajsañāme hālai sā-
janai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (38) kma eʾsāṃ narrujme hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (39) kma aiʾsā apanamāme
hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvkä hīrñä vīra : (40) kma pasujsanāṃ jaigyä hālai sājanai harbaiśä padya bvāka hīrñä vīra : (41) k[ma . ]

msIdentifier.idno: Ch.cvi.001: KT II, p. 59 (18); SD I/VIII; SD, TV, p. 14

note.p: Sheet of paper from scroll(?). Two Tib. texts (poems) at the end of b-side (twenty-six lines). Cf. Hoernle, 1911, pp. 474-75. Ser., pl. CXLVIII. The translation is based on Bailey’s notes in SD, TV, pp. 15-17 (see also Emmerick, 1985b).

q.l: || makala salya cvāvaja māśtä bistämye haḍai ṣaʾ khalavī cu ratanavaraikṣä āśīʾ u
prrakaittu būrä ṣacu vāṣṭä bauḍä va herä nauda. gaḍā-hvasta thauracaihä bera śā
u śaca prraiysge bira śā u kabalīja baysgyi hvāhyä kmadä śe u hūḍaigä
ysīḍai attaravāysä śau u hūḍaiga ysīḍai lahäpī śau u kra kagä khau-
ṣa thracaihä pabanā śa u khaucīja khauśka śā u ījīnai hī-
rāsä hvattarakīnai ūra-bada śau u gaḍā-hvastä śīyi haysänā-
līkä thauracaihä dva u mījī jūna baysgyi kabala dvī u haija mai-
stä kabala u pe u śīyi maistä kabala śā u aysūra-gūna da-
jūna baimya kamaiśkä śā u nämāya śau baraka u ya.ma. hainai gaḍā hvastä
baysgi thauracaihä śau u haysnālīka gaḍā hvastä thauracaihä
dva u paha drau vī haysnālīkä śacī śau u haija baysgyi kabala
dvī u hainai thauna śacī u haysnālīkä thauna śaca dräya u śīya
baysgyi kabala tcaure u paima-vīstā kabalīnai draijsai śau u gahai śau u
{x} eysnaṃ śā maista u dairśvā khaucvā drauhye bitcä dairsa u tcaurrvā starrvā ñū-
ṣṭyelīka u śau barä khaucä pajsāsä sera u paima-vīstāva thauna śacä ha-
darā śa u gaḍā hvastä thauracaihä jsa dā-gū baysgye paima jsa bira śā
u kagīja ṣkaumaka vīlaka śā hatca ttrraba jsa u drmīnai ṣkma dale śau u
habastā gahā śa : gahai va maistä śau u valaka gahai śau u hatca hasña jsa
aiysna śā u nauṣṭara śau u kabalījä bįrga kagyä karastä śe u kabalī-
nai rūśkagä thūḍa-pa śau u kaimeja ysīḍā-mejanya kamaiśka śā u hai-
ja baysgyä kabala pajse u hainā thauna : n u ysīra gū śacī śau u pai-
mīnā thauna tcaura u phrramaina kabala śā u kra-kagä khauṣa śa hatca
āvasakāṃ jsa u mījī jūna śadā kaimejä īśīma śa u {ysīcä spī-
yi drai gūna mnan pa kamaiśka śā} u painajä śī nama śau u thauna śacī nūvarä {-e}
parekṣi śau u chava nū kāṃhä parakṣa śau u hainā śadā damarāśīʾnai maista kai-
mejä śau u śeʾ āṣana śadā damarāśīʾnai maistä kaimejä śau u dai-
dä āṣana śadā śagīnai maistä kaimejä śau u paha drauvī sya-
dai hvaradai thauracaihä śau u haysnālīka hūḍaigä śau baysgi u hadā
naṣkūmāya namavīña thavalakañä khauca haudūsä sera pyaṣṭalīka
u hūḍaiga yma-bakä śau u thauracaihä śūkyainä dva u hnaugyä
jsaiṇyāṃ hīrāṃ jsa habaḍa pyaṣṭalīkya khadīrakya śe u pūstyna tcairma
tha valaka śā u mījījunä thauracaihä birä śā u maistä pū-
stye śau u ejsīnai vasīyikä śau u nūvarä barä u vatsāvīśīʾ-
nai hamauka śau pajūka śau u būśaunāṃ barakä śau habaḍa u ūla-ka-
gä baraka śau u nvadāvaunä auramūṣa pajsa u gahā śa maistä gahai
śau u valakä śau u thūra-ma śau u pūstynä : namavīja thavalakä śā
pūstyāṃ jsa habaḍa u badana dräya u ṣkmye herä nāsākä ranavarai-
kṣä āśīʾ akṣärä  u prrakai akṣäʾrä CHIN byaunä kvāṃ ṣī-
thau āśīʾ akṣärä SIGNUM byauna būyunä śau-śū śvauñakä akṣärä SIGNUM
In the Year of the Monkey, the month of Cvātaja, the 20th day. This (is) a record because the reverend Ratnavṛkṣa and
Praketu rode to Shazhou and obtained things: one ... coat;
one ... coat of ... silk; one pair of trousers of thick and wide blanket cloth;
one undergarment of yellow ... ; one ... of yellow cloth [Tib. lag-phyis];
one pair of shoes of ... leather with laces of ...(?); and one ...;
one lether belt of black ...; two white ...; two blankets ...; a red large
blanket; one ... and white large blanket; and one asura-colored flaming
one thick ... of beaten red ...; two ... of beaten ... for *washing;
one silk cloth for *washing with ...; two thick red blankets;
three silk red cloths and wash cloths(?);
one large ...; one wool-.. ... for blankets; thirty ... in thirty ...; ... in four ...;
one ... of 15 ounces; one wool-... silk ...;
one smoke-colored coat of thick wool with ... of beaten ...; one small ... of leather; ... ...
one large ... and one small ...; ... ... one skin of wolf hide for blankets;
one sheep-skin fur [Tib. thul-pa] for blankets; ... ...
five thick red blankets; nine red cloths; one gold-colored silk (cloth);
four woolen cloths; one *silver-gilt [Tib. phra-men] blanket; one shoe of ...-leather;
one yellow-white three-color ...; one white ... felt (cloth); one new ... of cloth-silk;
one large *cover for a dharmarājika (stupa) of red earth;
a second large *cover for a dharmarājika (stupa) of dark earth; (28) a third large *cover for a ... of dark earth;
a third large *cover for a ... of dark earth;
one left and right ... of ... hair(?); one thick ... for *washing; a ... of 17 ounces ...;
one goblet mde of vasaka wood; one ...; one full perfume *purse; one purse of camel-skin;
five ...; one ...; one large ... and one small; one spoon [Tib. thur-ma]; one ... of felt, filled with ...;
three *ropes; and a container for ... things.
The reverend Ratnavṛkṣa’s akṣara. Praketu’s akṣara. The witness Kvāṃ Ṣīthau’s akṣara. The witness Būyunä Śauśū Śvaunaka’s akṣara.

note.p: From “Bundle I.” Sgh [24] 203.1-205.1. Neb., p. 32 (S3 [92]). Right half of Reuter I (Reuter, 1913-18, pp. 33-37 Fragment 11). Vowels frequently omitted. Combined text in SSt., pp. 93-95:

q.l: ttīyä bhaiṣṣajyasenä bodhisatvä tta hve sä pulsumā gyasta ba/lysa sä ttä dva hvaṃdä kuṣṭa ysaṃthu nāṃdäB. nāṃdä.
gyastä balysä tta hve sä ne śśäru ṣṭe bhaiṣṣajyasena ma ma ne pulsa / Bhaiṣṣajyasenä bodhisatvä tta hve sä pu-
lsumā gyasta balysa pulsumā mäḍāna gyasta balysa/.ttīyä gyastä balysä tta hve se mātai bhai-
ṣṣajyasena ttye naḍaunä narī rauravä mästä narī āta / u pye-t-ī saṃghāttä narī ātä. u pūrä
nä ttavanä mästä narī ātä u mātṛvālai avīśä mä/stä mahānarī ātä bhaiṣṣajyasenä vā bo
dhisatvä tta hve sä anārrä gyasta balysa naḍä ysaṃthu / kuṣṭa byaudi. u kuī hīskya hämäta gyastä balysī
tta hve sä anārrä bhaiṣṣajyasena naḍe ttāvatrīśvo gya/s[t]uo ātä bhaiṣṣajyasenä vā bodhisatvä ttaNot B. hve sä
ce käḍäna gyasta balysa u cu pracai ṣä naḍä ttāvatrīśvo / gyastuo ātä gyastä balysī tta hve sä pyū bhai-
ṣṣajyasena ṣä naḍe maraṇu väte gystānu gyastu ba/lysu vara aysmū vasve u hatarra nonda yä-
ḍe. ttyau puñyau bhaiṣṣajyasena ṣä naḍe kṣaṣṭä kalpa va/ṣṭa ttāvatrīśvo gyastuvoʾ suha vaśīväte
u haṣṭā kalpa vaṣṭa jātäsmarä hämäte. u ysātänai bi/śśä kāṣce jyāre u khu haḍe ysaiyä ha-
(r)biśśä dukha näṣeme u sarvasatva ne hautāre biśśä dukha näṣe/mä bhaiṣajyasenä bodhisatvä. || [...]
hä]ra dyāre — trāme ttäte ṣkaugye biśśe 50 5
/ saindä — cu ttätä hära sai[n]d[ä ja]ḍi 50 8
/ sä — cu ṣeiʾ saṃtsārä x x [60]
/ ṣṭä — ttätä harbiśśä d[ain]d[äB. saindä. x x 60 1]
/ re — kho ye hūñä daiyä hära [60 2]
/ byore? B. dyāre. — samu kho ātāśä [bi]śśä 60 3
/ na mamä vaysña — uho jsa āspāta samu 60 6
... things appear, thus (are) these skandhas all. 55
... many, of all kinds things appear. 56
... through folly, all these appear awake. 57
... seem, because these things appear to the fool. 58
... in (one’s) mind, the fools long for the skandhas. 59
... as one sees things in a dream. [62]
... beings, they appropriate all the skandhas. 64
... for me now only with you (is) refuge. 66

note.p: From “Bundle I.” Sgh [24] 87.3-89.2. Neb., p. 19 (S3 39). This signature is that of fol. 39 only, see H. 142 NS 48 (IOL Khot 144/1).

q.l: lysānu pajsamu yanä kho draiśvo ggaṃgvo nätāvo säyata. kye biśśä klaiśa tvīṣṣe yäḍāndä u hastama rraṣṭa ba-
lysūśtu busta cerä ttye puña himāre phara u kye ṣä āya uysnaurä kye ttīye saṃghāṭi sūträ väte śśau tca-
ramu tcūrä-salāvä ggāhu pyūṣṭu yanä. tterī ttye uysnaurä mästä puñīnai hambīsä hämäte
tta cu ne rro vā kyai bäśśu uspurro pyūṣṭu yīndä. ttītä gyastä balysa tta hve se pyūʾ bisīvärāṣṣā kye
ṣä kye ttū saṃghāṭu sūtru dātu biśśu uspurro pyūṣṭu yīndä cirī pharä puña hämāre. trāmu māñaṃdu
kye va ju ṣä uysnaurä āya kye bäśśu tṛsahasrya mahāsahasrya balysāna tcārīmä väte kuṃjsatu kerä
cerä tti kuṃjsatīṅje dāne pharāke hämāre u ttirä cakravartta rruṃdi hämāra u ṣi ju hveʾ hämya
tsātä ce biśśūnī ttagä anaṃkhiṣṭä u ṣi ju naḍe biśśānu ttyānu cakrravarttānu rrundinu haurä hau-
rä kyerä ttye puña hämāre u kye vā śye prauda-phārri haurä heḍä ttye vā mästarä puñīnai haṃ-
bīsä hämäte || cu buru vā tṛsahasrye mahāsahasrye balysāña tcārīma paryāvanna
uysnaura u tti bäśśä paḍāna phārräna hämāre. u ttyānu ye biśśānu hauru haurä cu tti puña hi-
māre ttārä vā puña mästara hämāre ce śye ttye satvä hauru heḍä ce śye phārru bustä || cu buru vā tṛsa-
hasrye mahāsahasrye balysāña tcārīma paryāvanna uysnaura u tti vā biśśä śätena phārrina hämā-
ro u ttānu ye hauru haurä cu tti puña himāre. ttārä vā puña mästara hämāre kye śye ttye satvä haurä
heḍä ce didu phārru bustä. u cu buro vā tṛsahasrye mahāsahasrye balysāña tcārīma paryā-
vanna satva u tti vā biśśä didäna phārräna hämāra. u ttānu ye biśśānu hauro haurä cu tti puña hi-
māre ttārye puñīnai haṃbīsä buḍaru hämä. kye śye ttye satvä hauru heḍä ce tcūramä phārrä bustä u cu buro
vā trisahasrye mahāsahasrye balysāña tcārīma paryāvanna uysnaura tti biśśä arahanda
hämāro u ttānu ye biśśānu haurä hauru cu tti puña hämāre. ttye vā mästarä puñīnai haṃbī-
sä himäte ce śye pracyasaṃbuddhä hauru heḍä || cu buro vā tṛsahasrye mahāsahasrye balysā-
ña tcārīma paryāvanna uysnau u tti biśśä pracyasaṃbuddha hämāro ttānu ye biśśānu
haurä ttye vā mästarä puñīnai haṃbīsä hämäte. ce śye balysūñavūysai hauru heḍä ||
cu buru vā tṛsahasrye mahāsahasrye balysāña tcārīma paryāvanna uysnora u tti bi-
śśä bodhisatva hämāre u ttānu ye biśśānu haura haurä cu tti puña hämāre. ttye vā mästarä
puñīnai haṃbīsä hämäte kye śśau gyastu balysu vara aysmū vasūjäte || cu buro vā trisahasrye
mahāsahasrye balysāña tcārīma paryāvaṃna uysnaura u tti biśśä gyasta balysa himāro u
tte ye biśśä gyasta balysa vara aysmū vasūjäte cu tti puña himāre ttārye vā mästarä
puñīnai haṃbīsä hämäte kye ttū saṃghāṭu dātu pyūvāʾte tta cu ne rro vā pātco sarva-
śśūra vara hvanai ce ttū saṃghāṭu dātu pūstya pīrāte dijsāte vāśīyä arthuī kätaʾyä tta cu
ne rro [v]ā sarvaśśūra vara hvanai. kye ttū saṃghāṭu sūtri dātä ttuvāro vasutena aysmūna
namasīyä tta cu te saittä sarvaśśūra hautāre jaḍa prahujana uysnaura ttu saṃghāṭu dātu
pyūvāʾṇa. ṣṣai kuī nāma pyūvāʾre ne nä hā praysātä hämäte. pyū sarvaśśūra aśtä ce hanä
jaḍä hveʾ prahujanä ce va darrauva mahāsamundro vahīysānä. sarvaśśūrä bodhisatvä tta hve
se nä gyasta balysa gyastä balysī tta hve se aśtä sarvaśśūra ce hanä hve ce śśäna dastäna
mahāsamuṃdrru bajauttu yanä sarvaśśūrä bodhisatvä tta hve sä nä gyasta balysa. ne miḍā-
na gyasta balysa. gyastä balysī tta hvate se crrāmu sarvaśśūra niśtä uysnaurä ce hautta ma-
hāsamuṃdru hūʾ trāmī ttu näjsaḍu sarvaśśūra ce ttä uysnaura kye vamasāmata v[ā]rūḍya ne hautā-
re ttū dātu pyūṣṭe. ce ttä sarvaśūra uysnora kye ttirä gyasta balysa dätāndä kho haṣṭevoʾ kū-
lvo ggaṃguoʾ nätāvuo gruīcyau syata ṣṣai tti nä hotāre ttū saṃghāṭu sūträ pyūṣṭe || u ce ṣä
uysnorä ce ttärä gyasta balysa däte paḍā kho nvevoʾ ggaṃguvoʾ nitāvuo grīcyo syata ne tti ṣṣai
ttū saṃghāṭu dātu pyūṣṭä yanīndä || u cu tti uysnora ce kūlu sate-ysāre gyasta balysa nä
dätāndä ʾīndä cīyä ttū saṃghāṭu dātu pyūvāʾre apramānvī yanāre || u ce ttä sarvaśśū-
ra ce ttärä gyasta balysa dyāṃdi kho kūlvo ggaṃguvuo nätāvauʾ gruīcyo syata tti uysnaura cīyä saṃ-
ghāṭu dātu pyūvāre aysmū nä hā praysaiyä ttū suträ vara sīra hämārä kho rraṣṭu ttai a-
ysmūna paysānīndä. u ce vā ttū saṃghāṭu dātu väte rraṣṭo pīrāttetu yande u nai a-
pramānä yande pyū sarvaśśūra u ce ro halci ttū saṃghāṭu dātu väte śśo tcaramu cātu-
ṣpato ggāhu pūstya pīrāte cīyä ṣä uysnau ttū ysaṃthu paśśete ku ye pusparenotä ysā-
re kūla balysāne tcārīmä parräte häme vara balysāna tcārīmä aśtä trāma kho suhāvatä ṣä uysno-
rä vara hīśtä u ttānu sarvaśśūra uysnaurāṇu vara ttye lovadātä tcahaurähaṣṭātä ysāre kalpa
vaṣṭa jsīna hämäte || pyū sarvaśśūra kye halci balysūñavūysā īndä mara saṃghāṭu sūtri vä-
te tcūrä-salāvu śśau ggāhu pyūvānde o ce vā sarvaśśūra handarä uysnaurä ʾīyä ce paṃ-
jsa anantanarya käḍägāne yäḍe ʾīyä o vā kāṣṭe ʾīyä ṣä vā mara ttäye
saṃghāṭu dātä väte tcūrä-salāvu śśau tcaramu ggāhu pyūvāte ttye uysnaurä biśśä dīra kä-
ḍyāne jyāre. pyū sarvaśśūra pātco te ttädikä ttīye sūträ buljse hvāñīmä. kau j[u]B. kau ja; upper paper layer missing. sarvaśśūra
ṣä hveʾ hämäte ce balysānä cīya hatcañäte u balysūñavūysau satvo samāhānäna usthaṃjä
u balysūśte jsa uysnaurä byanu yanä u merä jīvätu nāsta u ustamu ṣä uysnorä ākṣūba

note.p: MKhot. Neb., p. 101. Story involving the laywoman Viśākhā.

q.l: hā tvā diśi buḍä. ku vīra ātä ttū mirāhīnai hārä dye ggumācai yuḍe ṣi hā[ra ājavi]-
ṣi himye hvaṃḍä āṣṭä kṣiṃjä. ttī rre drrātai himye vīja haṃgrīyä cu beʾ vaska vījya bu[vīru?
pastä si jsanāñä ṣi ājaviṣi ā maṃdrrāṃ pąʾñyau jsa au praharaṇāṃ pąʾñyau au biśśa [bañāñä?]
au daina padajsāñä thyau nyana ṣiʾ mirāhīnai hārna uysnaura jsīre satva pada /
canä yuḍä īndä ttī ttä vīja rrundä hīvī ttū parau pyūṣṭāndä haṃdāra ysinauttān[d]ä [āṣṭā ?]-
ndä hvāñä. u haṃdāra pārṣṣä aggadä śūstāndä. biśśä vīra h- x [x x x x]
ṇihaʾjāmä. biśśä śrāvastä kṣīra hvaṃḍä ārautta. ttiri khu viśśākha ūŸ[vāysya pyūṣṭā]-
tä saṃ kuī pyūṣṭi yuḍā biśśä-pīrmāttamä saṃduṣṭa-aysmva [h]imya. tta tta [hvātä ma]-
mānaiCf. v6. hāri ṣṭä. ni jä ājaviṣi. ttina cu ni ūtca u nä dei [x x x nä]
jä vā ttrātä u nä pąʾñauB. pąʾñyau. jsa hvaṃḍye arthä pirauḍi yanīndä u nä ysye [x x x]
stryau kīryau jsa haṃjsaundä darrauna aysä ttū salāvä tta tta hvāñūṃ. ttī viśśākha ū[vāysya
hamayä hāB. hāysa. tsuā. ṣa mī bīśśä tta tta pastā. nä ṣi ājaviṣi mamānei ṣi saṃ hāri ṣṭä /
... he rode in that direction. When he came to the gate, he saw this pearl necklace. He doubted: “That necklace
has become a snake. It begins to long for men.” Then the king became faint. He gathered the medics: “What medicine do [you] know for poison?”
He ordered: “That snake must be killed, either by the powers of spells or by the powers of weapons! Either [it must be bound?] in the house
or be burnt by fire. Quickly ... That pearl necklace *deceives people, it ... people ... [so that]
they can not do ...” Then those medics heard this order of the king’s. Some washed, [some began]
to recite, and some purified ... Everywhere ...
we shall restrain (it). All men in the land of Śrāvasti were in commotion, so much so that the laywoman Viśākhā [heard it?]
As soon as she had heard it, her mind became extremely pleased. Thus she [said]:
“It is my necklace, and it is definitely not a snake, because neither water nor fire [... nor]
indeed ..., and they do not with their powers make people’s things full of worms, and [they do not] take (them) away.
With the intrepitude accumulated through works of ... I shall pronounce this word thus.” Then the laywoman Viśākhā
herself went there. She ordered thus to the servant girl: “That is not a snake. That is just my necklace.” ...

note.p: MKhot. Neb., p. 114. Ms. similar to Kha. i.185.1 (IOL Khot 28/15) and Kha. i.306b (IOL Khot 34/2).

/ ttye vipaśyä sarvañä balysä biṣṭyau jsa haṃtsa
/ x . śśāstārä vipaśyä balysä ttye balysä bi
/ ā vipaśyä balysä aysī ttye biṣṭū pāba
