/ -ye satvä aysī ttye biṣṭūṃ balysä tta tta
/ ka khu yi balysä nāma ni pyūṣḍe vañai
/ x vaṃña varai jsāṃ pajsamä yanāmä
/ la pīhi jsa ysīrrä nādä u hā tsuādä
/ x hauḍādä u ttai hvādä se pūraka ṣe mā
/ x mihyau jse harbi śśä rrāśa
... that youngster ... of his own parents ...
... to that Vipaśyin omniscient Buddha with the disciples
... the teacher, the Buddha Vipaśyin ... of that Buddha ...
... came the Buddha Vipaśyin. I have *made it for him, daddy!
... took from ..., O dear ones, for there are no others.
... being. I have *made it for that Buddha. Thus
... when one does not hear the Buddha’s name, now for him
... now I shall pay homage to him right there.
... they took (bought) the gold at the price .. and went there.
... they gave (paid) ... and said to him: “Little son, that ...
... by us everything [has been given] into your jurisdiction.

saña ttū balysu padaṃdātä hamatu ttatvatu niśti. trāmu ysamaśandā draya samu hīviñe saṃñe jsa ʾīndi
kvī vikalpīmi balysä dätte. ku ne kar-ju ne dätte trāmu ttätä harbiśi dharma samu hīvī a[ysmuī] īñä 70 cvī citra-mātra
... Without destruction they are destroyed. Without the skandhas they appear. 61. Without speaking they have spoken the correct, profound Law.
Without going they have gone. Without vijñāna they know. (6)2. Without soul, life, being, without poṣa, person,
saṃjñā, without maker, realizer, knower, goer, eater. (63) Without the skandhas there are no skandhas,
18 dhātus, 12 āyatanas. All those are not with them, nor without them. (64) Because
in reality all dharmas are equal to all those. And the Buddha is of one kind. (65) Just like a mirage
all the world is just saṃjñā, all the buddhas are just saṃjñā, all the fields are just saṃjñā. Through saṃjñā it appears just like this. 66.
Because of vijñāna there are forms. Forms themselves are not at all. Vijñāna, O Buddha, is obstructed. Therefore it should be viewed as without form. (6)7. Whatever
appears only by saṃjñā and what (are) all the buddhas themselves—there is no difference even the size of a hair. It is just equal to space. 68.
Saṃjñā has made this Buddha. By itself nothing is in reality. Thus the three earths: they are only by one’s own saṃjñā. (69)
When I construct him (vikalpaya) the Buddha appears, when I don’t he does not appear at all. All these dharmas (are) only on account of one’s own *mind. 70. What ... its nothing but *citta ...

Śāriputra karaṇyau haṃphve bodhisatvä ttuo dhārañu byehätä. kā[myau tcū]ryau ka brīyau
vätä ne nähvarrde ka ne arāyä nä hämäte sarvasatvānu vätä bi[ś]ś[ä] hära vätä
patätsānai hämäte. vänau ttausai sīruṣṭanä ṣṣīve haḍāya. dātä ā[tī]mānai hä-
mäte. u dātä vīrī hayärūṇa ttyau tcūryau śśāriputra karaṇyau haṃphv|e baudhisatvä
ttuo dārañu byehäte || ttīyä gyastä balysä ttū hvanau āysda yäḍe u gā[hä]nei hvate ||

vara hämäte uysnorä bätaṃdīna baśdā yade tcamäna pu[ṣṣo *pīttä a]vāyä. va-

Actual: No.vii 150 6 . Neb., p. 156. With H. vii.150.17 (next) to the right. Combined text:

q.l: lysa bodhisatvu balysūñavūysai kalyāṇamittru kūś/āñä. balysī tta hvate ka bi-
sīvrāṣṣā bodhisatvä balysūñavūysai haṃ vīr/ä kalyāṇamättrā[ṃ] dyāmata
āyīmäte u kalyāṇamätrāṃ käḍäna vīryap/ārā[mata] yande satä ggaṃpha
patäna jsāte padīya dāña tsuñau hā kvī ttädärä / dātä brrī. ttyau tcūryau dharmyo haṃ-
phutä bodhisatvu mästu (ba)lysūñavūysauB. °ysai. kalyāṇami/tru kūśāñu || ttī vā Vajrrap[ā]-
ṇi bodhisatvu tta tta hvate kho vā miḍāna gyasta / balysa bodhisatvu ārañā-
nä māñāñä ku ggāṭhāñyo vyāvulyo jsa pahäṣṭä / hämäte. u cu akalyā-
ṇamittryau jsa haṃphau ttye käḍäna bäsa paśśāña u cin/dikī ju aśtä ṣai biśśu patsā[ñä ...

[... said, “How, O gracious Lord] Buddha, should a bodhi-seeking bodhisattva seek a kalyāṇamitra?” The Buddha said to him: “If, son of the house (kulaputra), a bodhi-seeking bodhisattva always wishes to see kalyāṇamitras and he performs the pāramitā of energy (vīryapāramitā) for the sake of (obtaining) kalyāṇamitras, then he should walk 100 leagues (yojana) on burning fire to where he loves the Law. Equipped with those four dharmas a bodhi-seeking bodhisattva should seek a kalyāṇamitra.” Then the bodhisattva Vajrapāṇi spoke thus to the Buddha: “How, gracious Lord Buddha, should a bodhisattva remain in a forest retreat (āraṇyāyatana) where he is free from the troubles related to a householder (gṛhastha)? And as for the meeting with non-kalyāṇamitras, should he therefore leave (his) house and should he leave behind whatever little he has? ...”

note.p: Actual: No.vii 150 17 . Right end of H. vii.150.17 (preceding).

jä gyastä balysä vätä hāṣṭu tsute ku hā tsute hämät[e] tty[e] gyastä balysä poʾ ttere jsa namasäte drai tcīra nä tvaṃdanu tsute u śau hālau [västā-
tä u ku śau hālau västātä hämätä saumachatträ rräspūrä ttu gyastu balysu tta braṣṭe dharmapūśa hvīnde gyasta balysa kāma ṣa dharmap[ūśa
gyastä balysä. ttī vā ṣä bhaiṣajyarājä gyastä balysä somacchatträ rräspūrä tta hvate dharmapūśa hvīnde. alysānā cu ttä balysāna h[uhvata

ya : siddhyaṃtu maṃtra-padā. svāhā ttīye maṃdrrä ṣei upa-
cārä baña āryāvalokiteśvarä baudhisatvä gvīhä satä-
na kārṣa tcera. harmu pamjeśä vätä tcahaura vara ṣvīdīnā ra-

-ā ne nāsāña. u drrai jūna haḍe ysināhāña u gyastānu
[ṣ]e tta ṣṭāna maṃdṛ hvāñai. pātcu vā haṃdara hau[da] haḍā panūḍāṃjsya
haṣṭa jūna maṃdrri hvañä. u tta ṣīve hvañai[.] śīya-vrrahauṇä
This upacāra should be tied onto this mantra.
A circle of cow dung should be made for the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara.
Four juices mixed with milk should be placed there at fifteen harmus(?),
and flower wreaths with four perfumes, with eight perfumes, and with four perfumes, (and) perfumed flowers.
For three nights and days ... should not be taken,
but three times a day one should wash, and standing thus this mantra should be recited for the gods.
And next, for another seven days eight times daily the mantra should be recited, and thus (too) at night. [One should wear] white garments ...

note.p: Neb., p. 148 (Ha). Right piece of H. 143 NS 35 (IOL Khot 159/4), see H. 142 NSB 12 (IOL Khot 151/5).
With Kha. i.303a.1. See IOL Khot 32/6.
MKhot. According to Emmerick and Vorob’yeva- Desyatovskaya (SD, TV III, p. 24) this is fol. 21 of the Adhyardhaśatikā-prajñāpāramitā.

... by this kuśalamūla whoever ... of the three [jewels] ...
I shall go ... I shall meet with the standing lord buddhas, whatever ...
I shall fulfill the pāramitās, I shall share (my) merits with all beings ...
I shall make ... here birth shall be relinquished ...
shall be extinguished for me. I shall purify the eyes of the Law for me. ... [When]
this life is finished my arising (utpāda) [will be] in the buddha fields ...

note.p: Ratnadvīpa text 15-31 (1-16), see H. 147 MBD 24a (IOL Khot 165/1a).
Late(?) MKhot. Ratnadvīpa text 1-14, followed by H. 147 MBD 23a (IOL Khot 164/1a) and H. 147 MBD 25a (IOL Khot 166/1a). Punctuation (here: – ) seems to delimit metrical units.

[rä.] hīya ysūṣka tta vā brātarä pātcä 10 1 ci ttye ni kṣamīde dukha
x pyauca. yanīryau dāna puñau āsā pātcä. khvau ni himi paʾjsä ustaṃ vī
-ā. ttyau vaska hīśtä ṣiʾ mara ysaṃ[thä] snä 10 2 vaña ri saṃ ustaṃ vī harbi-
[śa x x] kṣamevūṃ dasau diśiʾ harbiśä baʾysä. ttriyāṇī ttradhve dātīnai

[x x] . ttaraṃdarä ttī jsāṃ aysmūna biśāʾna. ysurri jaḍī brīye nva viṣayāṃ pā-

[x x x] x gāra kāra. maṃ vīra braura āśiʾrya thu karīha. hai ratnabhadra kṣame muhu jsa ysirastä vyejä ttī dī yai ysira śnai thaṃjä
[tt]yā[ṃ] vṛkṣa vasva ramaña brūna. āspāta mista biśāṃ dukhāṃ jināka. āśiʾrya cātaka hai

q.l: [brau]ttīra jsā brātarä bhadreśvarasidä 7 mittrabhadrä bhadreśvaraśudä jsā pātca ya āstaṃ biśä maṃ jsa kṣamyarä. x
nā maṃ vī kṣa{tra}ṇamātträ. mai nä śarä ysąʾña {biśī} muʾśdi prracai brautīra jsāṃ brātarä bhadreśvaraśudä 8 cī ttā x
[x x] bāʾyausta uvārä. āśiʾrya eṃdrayaśa kṣama ma jsa ttāṣṭa. prrabhākarabhadrä
-ai. udayabhadräna haṃtsa. suprrabhadrä skārakä sthīrä āstaṃnau {śna ysi} biśä maṃ jsa kṣamyarä [9]
āśiʾrya brātari ysani cu buri himāta. kṣamāta muhu jsa audä mittrai baʾysä.
[x x x x x] nā cu ra vīysai auysä. ni śirkä ye thaṃjarī ysira śā biśä 20 hai daha
[x x x] snädna agaṃjsa. maṃ vīra braura thu bra ysarrnā nika khu ysā māca kṣame [x]
. pūraka-ṃ kāʾya suhä beḍau. khu maṃ ni himāri paʾjsa kuysva ni ysīya. mu ttā paribhūta u paʾjsä śaṃdya hvasta ñysirä vāḍa pūra du-
[ta] . thu dattā kṣama ma jsa nā nerä jsa haṃtsa. pūrakyau dvaryau saṃ cu buri himāta
{ma na tsni ma ni daina brau} 2 nāeauni dyai ustaṃ vī dyma brna 2 viysa ysāra-vera va-
[ña ?] x d[y]ma brna pārāka pūraka biśä hirrna añaṣṭa. haryāsaka kṣama ma jsa ttā-
[ṣṭa.] nerä pūryau jsa cvau jä amanā ī 3 hai vasva nūvara naṣkhasta uvāra. kāṃjañe ysī

[nā] 4 {kāṃja ysa}. raṃna-bāʾyausta vasva daga-prrasāda. dūtakā ñysirä tsūmaṃ-

[rä ? 5] mātarga brau pūryau cvau ya nvaśta. pyarīja pyaṃtsāṣṭä dukhāṃ jināka. tvau vaṃña stau
q.p: H. 147 MBD 25a
q.l: [x] x ṇ- nmai snä rāhä daga-rakṣaysä ttirä tsaudä avīpa 6 śirka ma maṃ
maraña burai śka. tta tta khu parśaʾ mąña paysā hīvī pye. ttye pñä naṣkāra
[x bi]śä uskhajsa tsāta. diśiʾ vīra ārāhāta sāmuha baʾysa 7 ysira mi-
[sta ?] x stya tsmaṃcā brī. kharakā kṣama ma ttā ustaṃ vīra. naṃ sa u nī jsā pādū
[x] x . suhaṃbara āstaṃ saṃ biśä kṣamyarä 8 ttą ttą yai nvaśta khu caṃdātąñä mū-
[ra x] -i dijsme va tta khu ñąnai mistä. salā-mātträ cve ttā hvai īme haʾcä.
... *great deceit. That one is today, the other one is tomorrow. All of them ...
... – without refuge ... is alone in another (re)birth. 10. When not in saṃsāra ...
– That one provides just instant satisfaction, ... – When you have lost in the land of the living a dear, very dear son, –
then his brothers (are) your pleasant ones. 11. The woes that do not please him
[and] the *counteragents, – make according to the Law the memorized teaching of merits then! If you have no strong ... in the end, –
the enemy birth comes for them here. 12. And now only at the end ... all
... – I propitiate all the buddhas in the ten directions, – the ... of the three vehicles, of the three times, of the Law
... – of the bhikṣu-saṅgha, *equal to the ratnadvīpa. 13. However much I have done, this mind
... – of the body, as well as with mind (and) tongue, – and (through) anger, folly, (or) lust according to the domains (of the senses), next,
– I fall into (?) the Confession now, lying prostrate. 15. [sic] Whatever ... I have ... only ...
– the ten karma-pathas that I have ruined for me, – the ... confession of all deeds

– so that I may not fall into an evil existence. 15. Like Ratnadvīpa full of praises, exalted kalyāṇamitra, the bhikṣu-saṅgha of Ustāka, – to those lying in it I make eight ..., – and given confession for all acts. 16.
... – for me you, O Reverend Braura, the energetic one. O Ratnabhadra, accept me pitiful ... pull out the .. lying in the heart.
*Their trees, pure, delightful, splendid. – O great refuge, destroyer of all woes, – Reverend Cātaka. O
brothers in Brauttīra, Bhadreśvarasiddha. 17. Next, Mittrabhadra, Bhadreśvaraśuddha, and the others. Accept me all! –
... for me even as much as a moment – *nor in their good heart for the sake of compassion, my brothers in Brauttīra, Bhadraśvaraśuddha. 18. When ...
full of rays, exalted, – O Reverend Aindrayaśa, accept me (and let me come) to you! Prrabhākarabhadra
... – together with Udayabhadra, Suprrabhadra, Elder Skāraka, and the others, accept me all! [19.]
Reverend brothers, kinsmen, as many as you are, – forgive me (and let me come) to the buddha Maitreya! –
... whatever anger ... – was not good, pull it out of the heart, one (and?) all. 20. O men
... devoid of *evil, free of sins, – to me you, O dear Braura, O golden ... Minister Khu Ysā, accept ...
Sons, look at me at the time of bliss and – if I have not much ... nor ... – ... and beaten much *against the ground. ... sons (and) daughters, –
you Dattā deign to accept (?) me together with my wife. – O sons (and) daughters, as many as you are –
... I have seen in the end a dear vision. 22. In a lotus with a thousand leaves ...
... dear nourishers, sons, not to be despised in every respect, – O Haryāsaka, let me come to you,
– with wife and sons whatever is unpleasant for *us/you. 23. O pure, new, ..., exalted one, of golden gold (?)
, delightful, (and) *having beautiful skin. – ... sons, *counteragents of woes, – let them come to you, even if it is unpleasant to you(?).
24. Full of the rays of jewels, pure Dagaprrasādā, – daughters ... coming

... let them come to you now with their father ... – you saw them accepted, daddy, this I ... [25.] *Mātarga, O dear sons, whatever was difficult for you, – in the future destroyers of the woes of *your father. – this now ... of yours
... its name enemy, illness, “rākṣasa of *fever” so many digested *unprepared. 26. It is nice for me here
until death, – just like ... my own birth father. – His ...
... wealthy, – you shall propitiate the buddhas in full view in (all) directions. 27. In my heart ... going dear, – Kharakai, let me come to you at the end. – ...
... – Suhaṃbara and the others only accept me. 28. *You were difficult for me like the cintāmaṇi jewel

note.p: Late(?) MKhot. Amṛtaprabha-dhāraṇī 1-21, followed by H. 147 MBD 23b (IOL Khot 164/1b) and H. 147 MBD 25b (IOL Khot 166/1b).

māti khū hvai prrattiñe āya ne ḡyasta baʾysä kuṣṭa ttyāṃ satvāṃ dukha himādä aysa vara ne hīvī /
ṣkala ttāräB. nārä. tcaṃphāti u baysūśte vyāreṇi ni byihīmī sidhami namau māttaṃgā-rājāya [x] /
gattadārakānāṃ ttad yathā pattra vidana phaṭ vaśīkaraṇīyaṃ phaṭ sarva-rauga-prraśamanīyaṃ svāhā [||]
... should be ... speech with evil tongue, ...
... that the harvests should be good for once(?), beings blessed with all means of living, the fools [be born] among ghosts and in hell ...
... that Bara be able to sustain them among ..., there will be many kinds of illnesses for men. If only there are no ... for a man ...
discharge from(?) *swelling together with blood, red discharge, illness in the ear, wind, a combination, jaundice, illness in the head, all these illnesses
whereby men die. Whoever keeps the samād(h)āna of this sutra, he is delivered from those illnesses. I look after the men, each and every one. [By]
writing it once the men of one houseCf. Emmerick, Studies II, p. 112. have gone out from illness, and they will not die. He who writes it twice, for kinsmen, relatives, father ...
He who writes it three times, they bring faith to growth, the men will be healthy from one ... of it. When a man has listened to this sutra ...
... and ... it, that man ... the roots (of goodness and) dies. This sutra should be written, the ... in its ... [that]
man becomes. He who inspects this sutra and shows faith in it and treats it with respect, he is delivered from all illnesses. He who ... kṣetra ...
and shows faith in them. He who obtains this sutra and is greedy about it and does not expound it to others ...
dies. This sutra ... in the Year of the Pig, the 28th day of the month of Siṃjsījsa. The great prince ... this sound of ...
But in the middle of that sound, one great stone fell down. That stone split up (and) went into two sections. There in that entire ...
pulled out of the book this one three-year-old child. Next, at that time, an old man travelling on a road ... by great snakes. ...
who had a human head. That snake (also) had chicken feet. That snake’s body had ... of 10,000 chās.
... called the old men and said to him: In the region called Thaṣana 10,000 great women and 10,000 great oxen ...
will become ... In old days it was difficult to request them. By pronouncing the name of the Lord Buddha Amitāyu you will become ...
You will escape from all those sufferings of untimely deaths which ... for men in summer in the month of Haṃdyaja. And ...
... so many pack animals will die that in three houses there will not be a single animal. On the 23rd day of the month so many women will die [that]
it will be hard for men to find a single wife. Monks and laymen, go singly to the houses of the householders, [bring] them this sutra and
order them to write [its] merits! If that matter is true or false, a storm will come from the western direction and from [the southern]
direction a red yakṣa will come. At that time, he who does not produce trembling on that account, who ... that nirmāṇa ...
For that reason let go of your false views! With good faith speak the name of the Lord Buddha Amitāyu!
Perform good acts, stay ... and never thereafter shall you become equipped with the causes for hardships. When that man ...
shows faith and respect to [this] sutra and orders it to be written and teaches it to others, he will escape from fever and hot spells, etc.,
He will increase with respect to the things and matters (needed) for long life for a good career, for the *avoidance of an evil career, for the sake of escape from untimely deaths.
(When) this sutra is expounded with the compassion of the great bodhisattvas with the nirmāṇa found in space, to every ...
is ... he should adopt the śikṣāpadas, then he should ..., go to the refuge of the three jewels, to those better than himself ...
and ...he should do homage, he should honor his parents, his teachers and kalyāṇamitras. According to ...
*so many times he should speak the name of the Lord Buddha Amitāyu. The Amṛtaprabha-dhāraṇī and the Seven Buddhas ...
a refuge should be made for ... and pitiful, refugeless beings and honored. dhāraṇī.
He should do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-[...], the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara. It should be written by the ... in houses. Sufferings will be dispelled.
Welfare! And then in the dwelling of ... the Lord Buddha spoke thus: Next, I shall give beings a mantra ...
... troubles shall not come upon (them). And if they do come, that they obtain separation from them.
Whoever that woman may be who carries this protection upon herself,Cf. IOL Khot 18/14. she will not become guilty of killing the king or the great teachers. [If]
they bring [her] elsewhere, she just has to lift that protection high, (and) I shall come there.
they turn this man back. I shall fulfill that man’s wishes. I shall make him free of guilt. I shall make his ... powerful, ...
successful. Dear to everyone, if ever he should fear ministers, monks, brahmins, ... in the villages ... with sticks, ...
from litigators, merhcants, even if he is walking on the road he just has to lift up this protection, he will be purified of all ...

They will talk nicely to him, meritorious sons. He will be victorious in litigation with ... All the ... kalabhūtanas there are all the way up to space, they are all under my command. There are no beings whom he might be able to (do) harm to, even if ... him ...
could seize him. Nor will they give away completely the water in his house ... he will have no hot spells or long illnesses ...
... will [not] be ... when the man is a pratijña, nor a lord buddha. Where there are woes for these beings, I shall not ... there ...
... and I shall not obtain the explanation of bodhi.

note.p: Ratnadvīpa text 32-39 (1-7), see H. 147 MBD 24a (IOL Khot 165/1a). At end: “Bundle II.”
Pādas 78-89 if Bailey’s verso and recto are reversed and 6 lines counted. Leumann, 1967, p. 374. Note the use of high -ā́ in nā́ and bā́.

... embracing the earth [before ...], I make a report.
... he spoke not nicely with me. 21 [days] me ...
... the complaint and anger of the -s I did not find *nice. Until now
... there I do not recognize many nice things. And pitiful ...
... men came for me. What I had today you knew it, and only my
throat hurt, (and) for an (entire) day I did not dare (go) before them, so that I might have brought (them) the mūrās. (But?) I was alive!
Don’t lay them upon yourself(?)! As I have always ... the men ... your outside success(?) so far
I was to be left (alone ?). For eight months hardship had to be endured which I have all held out(?). But as you did not go yourself
your five śiṃgas [...] *altogether had to be given into the hand of one man. ... but I was to be left
without protection. But I had plenty of spirit (?) ... I know something special(?): that you have looked at (= after) me so nicely.
Thus you have received (?) my 800 mūrās. 800 of them Puñaśūra’s *wife promised and 1000 Śūrabudā ...
... Give 1000 to my sister, wife of Īrapuña.
... sister ... not in doubt about that ...

ṣaʾ cų. pvāmavīja bvama. u cidāmavīja bvma
śamatha, i.e, extinction; vipaśyana, i.e, seeing.
The śamatha of the Law (?) was in vipaśyana, that of the śrāvakas and
that of the pratyekabuddhas and that of the bodhisatvas and
that of the Lord Buddha. The innumerable samādhis
stand fastened firmly. hetu, i.e., ...; nīv,
i.e., knowledge through hearing and knowledge through thinking.

/ x ttaru kho balysäna ttänau / śäru ce vīvāgä kṣamīyä ku ye / ne puña yande ṣä vīvātä ku nāste || ttītä bh[ai]ṣajyas[e-
[nä mästä balysūña]vūysai gyastānu gyastä / balysu tta braṣṭe se ce käḍäna / [gyast]ānu gyastä balysä u cu pracai ttätä därsä kūla āmā-
[cā abhiñä byaudānd]ä [u d]asau-/[bhū]mu busta ttītä gyastä gyastā/[nu gyastä ba]lysä tta hvate se pyūʾ Bhaiṣajyasena aysu tä hvāñä-
[mä dyāñ]äte t[tu] scätu gyastä gyastā/[nu gyastä ba]lysä tturräna haṣṭātä ysāre bāʾyä narąnde. a-
[naṃkhäṣṭa ysā]lve. hätägye[. / śīyi]ñi. ttarūne. sphālya-gūne. āljsätūne. tte vā bāʾ- [yä ...

note.p: Sgh [8] 225.1-227.8. Right end of folio, joined by Khot(IO) 18.6 (IOL Khot 186/8) to the left.

q.l: / b[ā]ysū haraṣ/ṭe tcūryau hālyau diśyau jsa hā u-
[ysnora ................. ky]e vara uysnora hīsī/ndä. ttītī gyastä balysä tta
/ nä pätāyä u ne dā/tīnau haṃjätu paysendä
dai]ndä. u na-ro ysyā/mato daindä u na-ro
u na-]ro vā ysäṣṭäna / haṃphau u na-ro ma-
/ mäḍā]na gyasta balysa / x nūvara satva hī-
[sīndä ............ bvā]re. gyast[ä] balysī tta /[hva]te se pyū bhaiṣajyasenä
/ -ä u ne bätāʾkä u ne / [p]vāysä. u ne rruṃdä puvaʾsta
ysaṃ]th[u] nāsāre tta / pātcu pātcu tsarrai bhai[ṣa- [jyasena ...

note.p: Sgh [9] 124.3-126.2. With fragm. (IOL Khot 177/8); + FK. 914 Kh. 29 + Khot(IO) 16 (IOL Khot 185/7) + 18.8 (IOL Khot 186/9). Canevascini does not include the fragm.

q.l: pārśu tīndä kho ne gysta balysa ā/ṣaṇa tta aysu yäḍ/[aimä tt]īta aysu vyāgaraṇ[o] / byaudaimä [hastamo ba]-
lysūśtu vārāṣṭo na-ro mä ha[ḍ]e / [b]āḍä s[ky]ä[t]ä ātä śtä [4 || byā]ta yane aysu sa[rvaśūra marata ysama]-
śaṃdya kṣasu kūla balysa [panata biśi vima]laprabhās[ä nā]ma väta biśi klaiśa tvīṣ[e yäḍāndä u hasta]-
mo rraṣṭo balysūśtu busta t[tu skyätä ttu bā]ḍu aysu kṣun[d]ai bi[ś]śe v[ä]tämä tsātä biśūnīna [ttagatäna a]-
najsāneina bīśūnī ho[ru x x x x x ] x y x śu nu kūla gyastānu ba[lysānu pajsamu yäḍaimä /
nei baṣṭarna prahoṇyau bu[śanyau palsāryau vilī]vanyau kho nä y[e] āysändä kho nä gyasta ba[lysa pajsamä ā]-
ṣaṇä tta nä aysu pajsa[mu yäḍaimä. ttī]yä aysu vyāta/raṇo byaudaimä [ha]stamo b[alysūśtu varāṣṭo na]-
ro mä hāḍe bāḍä skyä[tä ātä śtä v]yāgaraṇo h- [x tta] hve || pyūʾ sarvaśūra [byāta yane aysu ma]-
rata ysamaśaṃdya puspar[e]no[tä] kūla [ba]lysa pana[ta biśi] śākyamuni nāma v[äta gyasta balysa hutsutu]
pando ts[u]āndä u biśi klaiśa tvīṣe y[äḍ]āndä hastamo rraṣṭo [ba]lysūśtu busta ttu skyätä / ttu bāḍu a[ysu rre vätämä]
ga u hvaṃʾdä avätsare āysaṃna panata balysi baña patäna v[ä]stāta ha[ṃju ] tta [h]v[a]-
tāndä muhu gyastānu gyasta balysa dātu vätä ttarrā mä haṃberät[u gyastānu gyasta ba]lysä [ .............................................................biśśā]nu u-
ysnaurāṇu ātamä || ttīyä vā gyastä balysi [ttu] bāḍu kha[nau cä]ru [yäḍe. ttī]yä sarvaśū[rä mäs]t[ä] balysū-
ñavūysai āysąnna panatä [k]āmu hālau gyastā[nu] gyastä balysä ā[s]t[ä] h[ā]ls[to na]masäte u haṃju dasta
nāte gyastānu gyastä balysi tta hvate se kye käḍäna cu pracai gyastānu gyasta balysa khanau cärä yäḍai || ttīyä gya-
stānu gyastä balysä sarvaśūru mästu balysūñavūysau ggurṣṭe u ttai hvate se kyerä sarvaśśūra uysnaura vā ttattī tsu
tāndä dātu pyūṣṭe biśśi ttä uysnora biśśānu pīrmo rraṣṭo balysūśtu buvāre. biśśä ttätäña balysāña rahāśśa
näta viśpasta hämāre. ttīyä vā sarvaśśūrä mästä balysūñavūysai tta hvate se kyi käḍäna gyasta balysa cu pra
cai ttätä uysnora vā tsvāndä u hastamu rro rraṣṭo balysūśtu bvāre gyastä balysi [tta] hvate se śśiru śśiru sarva-
śśūra cu thu gyastānu gyastu balysu ttäte ttändrāme bätame pulśä [mara sarvaśśūra] praṇihānä viśśeṣä
dyāñä || byāta yane sarvaśśūra paḍāṃjsyānu bāḍānu parrät[ā]nu a[naṃkhäṣṭa ka]lpa x [x x ma]ra t[t]at[tī]
ysamaśśaṃdya ratnaśrī nāma vätä gyastānu gyastä balysä panatä rraṣṭo ts[ū]mato [tsute ha]jva[tte]tīn[yau] x x x u[- ...]
śśūra bäsīvärāṣṣai o bäsīvärāṣṣeiñe nai ju ne ttändäka [dīre käḍätāne īndä] cuī va harsāro. ne ju ne ttye uysno-
rä vätä mārä pāpīmä rrāśu byehäte u ne ne ś[ūnä mä]s[t]e t[t]ä sarvaśūra uysnora kye ttū
saṃghāṭu dātu byehīndä pyū[ṣṭe] u tte uysno[ra x x x x a]ysmū x pays[ā]n- x [anaṃ]khäṣṭa kalpa vaṣṭa ne dī-
rau śandā-ysaṃthu ne nāsāre. u haṣṭātä ysāre kalpa vaṣṭa [t]t[ä] uysn[o]ra [...] pyūvāre balysānu hvanau biśvī
draiśśu vājāre u satä-ysāre kalpa vaṣṭa ttä ysnora prāṇāvātäna pathīsīndä u [...] ysāre kalpa vaṣṭa ttä uy[sn]ora kye
drūje jsa pathaṃko vätä vaṣṭīndä u drrai ysāre kalpa vaṣṭa ttä uysnora byūṃjāmate jsa pathīsīndä. duṣkara hāḍe sa[rva]śū-
ra ttätäye dātä pyūvāʾmata || ttīyä vā sarvaśūrä mästä balys[ū]ñavūysai āysaṃna panatä syandai su[tä vä]t[ä]
prahoṇä prrahauṣṭe u hvarandau ysānū śando västāte kāmu hālau gyastä balysä āstä hālsto namasäte u haṃju dasta nā-
te gyastānu gyastu balysu tta brraṣṭe[.] tta cerä vā gyasta baly[s]a t[t]ye uysnorä käḍätānīnai haṃbīsä hämäte kye ttu-
tu saṃghāṭu sūtru [a]prramā[nu ya]nde gyastān[u] gyastä [] pharāka [sa]r[va]śūra ttä uysnora käḍätā-
nīnau haṃbīsu pajāysāre gyastä gyastānu balysī tta [h]v[ate käḍätā]nānu haṃbīsu pulsa.
kye va ju āya sarvaśūra uysnorä kye tternu balysānu kho dvā[śuvoʾ ...] syata u ttānu ye ysu-[rgyä ...]
ru uhu nyaṇḍyau jaḍyau ku suhū x niśtä tta kuṣṭau purrauṣca häm[āte - 5 -] x kho n- p- l[s]- x x x x x x tta kuṣṭau purrauṣca häm[ā]-
te aysu pandāya näjsätāʾkä [m]ä x x -au x x x [x x x] x x [x] -īyi ha x [x] t- daimä. ttīyä ttä nyaṇḍa
gyastānu gyastä balysi vara[ta ysu]rru x -n- x x x x [x x] nä hā [ba]lysu va[rata] aysmya panata. ttīyä tty[e]
scätä ttu bāḍu śakṛ gyastānu [rre] ttānu niyaṇḍānu x x [va]śirna ātä. ttīyä ttä haṣṭū-ysāre kūla nya-
ṇḍa puvaʾsta harīysäta mästäna dukhäna ākṣuttāndä ʾī-garśä bremä u gyastānu gyastä balysi ttīyä [h]ī[vyo u]ys[ā]-
nā nänauto d[y]āñäte. u ttīyä ttä nyaṇḍa āṣkaraundäna śāmaṃna bremandā ku ne gyastānu gyastä [balysi däyāka]
ʾīndä gāhäna tta hvatāndä se. ne ne ju muhu vaṃña ttattīka māta päte trāstu yanīndä. sa[mu ś]śū[- ]
ne ne ju nyāpätä nīrä. ne ne ju vara gyasta ne hvaʾndä ne banhya o vā kṛṅga vara tto diśo daindä anāsp[eta u ne] n[e] dä-
stä śtä balysä || ttu scätu vā pātco ttä haṣ[ṭū]-ysāre k[ū]la nya[ṇḍa] āysana panata dvyau ysānvyau jsaunäta västāta [snä]-
däna bajāṣṣäna tta hvāndä se[. gya]stānu gyasta [balysa x x x] ha [x x] hämu [bvā]matu bustī u yana hajuvā-
nu hāvu || ttīyä gyastānu gyastä balysä bihaṃtte u sarvaśūrä [bodhisatvä ggurṣṭe] u ttai hvate se. tso thu Sarvaśūra ttätā-
nu nyaṇḍānu anyattīrthyānu dātu hvāña. ttätäye hvat[ä]t[ye hvanai Sarva]śūrä mästä [ba]lysūñavūysai gyastānu

note.p: Mirrored overlaid akṣara on a-side: / -ī x vya /.

q.l: gyastä balysi tta hvate se. kyau gyasta balysa haryāsānu ggariṇu kamalu hanemäte baña sumīrä garāṇu rrundä
ttäṣṭhandye gyastānu gyastä balysi aysu ni[ya]ṇḍānu dātu hvāñämä. gyastä balysi tta hvate se paśa thu bäsīvrrāṣ[ṣā]
pharāka gyastānu balysānu saña dā[tä] bvāmata. tso thu sarvaśūra dasau dīśe vätä āysda yanu ku buro gya-
stānu gyasta balysa dai u kuṣṭa vā gya[stānu .....................................] hamatä sarvaśūra kū-
ra-d[ṛ]ṣṭānu nyaṇḍānu dātu hvāñīmä. ttīyä sarvaśūrä mästä ba[lysūñavūys]ai [tta hvat]e [s]e [...] gyastānu gya-
[sta balysa] hīviñe hvetä jsa au gyastānu gyastä balysä hvet[ä] jsa gyastānu gyastä balysä [tta hvate se sarvaśū]ra hīviñe hve-
tä jsa tso u hīvyau pätaʾñyau || ttīyä sarvaśūrä mästä balysūñavūysai āy[sanna panatä gya]stānu gyastä balysä hvaraṃcī-
ñä tvaṃdanu tsute varī nänautä hämäte || ttīyä gyastānu gyastä ba[lysi ttānu an]y[attīrthyānu nya]ṇḍānu dātu hvate. ysyā-
ma śśäratyau dukhä. ysātye ṣṭānä dukhä ku hveʾ ysātä h[ämäte pharākai rro puvaʾ]ṇ[a panamā]re. ysātye ṣṭānä āchaina
pvataṇa panamāre. āchinai vā ysaroñäna pvataṇa panamāre u ysāḍye uysnorä maraṇäna pvaṇa pana-
māre. ttīyä ttä nyaṇḍa tta hvatāndä tta kāmä v[ā] gyasta balysa ysātye ṣṭānä pvaṇa panamāre gyastānu gyastä balysä
nä tta hve se. ysātä ysātä ṣätä nāma hvandä pvaṇä ysātye hvandä rro ttätä ttändrāma pvataṇa ysātye uysnorä āstanna
hastama balysūśtu busta namasätaimä gyasta balysa aysu ttä biśśi gyastānu gyasta balysa kye biśśä [kleśa tvīṣṣe yä]-
ḍāndä hastamo balysūśtu busta u drai tcīra ṇä hvaraṃcīñä tvaṃdanu tsutaimä u varī vā hvetä jsa nänautä hämätämä.
kṣaṣṭuvo kūlvo vā gyasta balysa buddha-kṣetruvoʾ gyasta balysa dä[tai]mä namasätaimä ttä gyasta balysa aysu tte balys[ā]-
ne tcārīmä u tta ttä gyasta balysa [va]rī vā [pa]s[t]āt[umä ... gya]sta balysa balysānvo tcārīmvo u ttä gyasta ba-
lysa paranärvṛtāndä u namasätaimä nä aysu ttä x [......va]rī vā pastātumä u dätaimä aysu gyasta ba-
lysa pusparenvetuo kūluvo balysānvo tcārīmvo [..........] haysguṣṭanä hämäta gyasta balysa [br]au-
ndaimä aysu ku dätaimä bremaṃdā gyasta nāga yakṣa [rakṣaysa kye] brīyau[śta]-päṣkala mästäna kāṣcīnaina pa[tä]-
maṃthäna bästa u ttu padī tte balysāne tcārīmä harbi[śśe sūte haṃtsa] mahāsamudṛṇa u haṃtsa sumīräṇa garna
u śaṃdye jsa namasätaimä aysu gyasta balysa [t]t[ä paranärvä]ta gyasta balysa. u tta tte sūte balysāne tcārī-
mä anāspetä hämätemä vara ṣṭānä pastātumä ttāmu gyasta balysa ku padmottare balysāña tcārīma
ātumä u cīyä gyasta balysa vara ātumä kūlu sate-ysāre āysąna baṣṭarrda dätaimä hvarandai hālai [u kū]-
lu sate-ysāre āysąna baṣṭarrda dätaimä syaṃdai hālai kūlu se-ysāre āysana baṣṭarrda dätaimä sarbaṃ[dä h]ā[l]ai [kūlu sat]ä-[ysāre]
āysana baṣṭarrda dätaimä hauda-riṃchānu hālai diśe jsa kūlu sate-ysāre āysana baṣṭarrda dät[ai]mä. [uskyāṣṭo diśä jsa kūlu]
sate-ysāre āysana baṣṭarrda dätaimä u natāṣṭo diśe jsa kūlu sate ysāre āysana baṣṭarrda d[ä]taimä [u ttä gyastā]-
nu gyasta balysa ttä āysana bi[śśä hau]dyau ratanyau jsa u bi[śśānu] ttānu āysanānu pīro gyasta balysa dätaimä
āṇaṃdā kye āṇa dātu hvā[ñīndä ] duṣkaru sastu ttä gyasta balysa tta braṣṭaimä se
cu nāma gyastyau balysyau ṣā balysāna tcā[ra]mä ttä [balysa tta hva]tāndä se [padmo]ttara nāma bäsīvrāṣṣā ṣā
balysāna tcāramä ttīyä aysu gyasta [balysa hvaraṃ]cīñä tvaṃdanu tsutaimä u ttä gyasta balysa tta brra-
ṣṭaimä se cu nāma gyastyau balysyau mara ttīye lova[dātä gyastä balysä.] ttä mä gya[sta ba]lysa tta x x hvatān[d]ä se padmaga[rbhä]
nāma gyastānu gyastä balysi kye biśśä kl[aiśa] tvīṣṣe y[äḍe ba]lysūśtu bu[stä x x] x u balysāña tcārīma ba-
lysūña kīre tīndä ttīyä aysu tta hvat[ai]mä phar[āka sate]-ysāre gyasta balysa ttu ne ne bve se kāmä ṣä padma-
garbhä gyastä balysi kye biśśä klaiśa [pu]rrde u rraṣṭo balysū[ś]tu bustä ttīyä mä gyastä balysä tta hvate se aysu te bä[sī]-
vrrāṣṣā näjsäteʾ se ṣätä ṣä pa[dma]ggarbhi gyastä balysi kye biśśä parrūṣka tvīṣe yiḍe u rraṣṭo hastamo balysūśtu bustä u
ttä biśśä gyastānu balysānu ttarandara nänaut[a] hämäta ʾīndä balysūñavūysai rūväna vā dyāre s[amu] x [x x x] x x [x x x]
u kye käḍäna gyastä balysi bihaṃttai ṣä mä gyastä balysi tta hvate se pyūʾ bäsīvärāṣṣā thu sarvaśūra mäst[a bal]ysū[ña-
vūysā kye käḍe mästa hauta trāmu māñaṃdu sarvaśūra ko ju cakrravarttä rre hämäte tcūrvoʾ dīvuo rrāyse u ṣä ju cakra-
varttä rre tcūrvo dīvuo mäṣvo biśśu vätä kuṃjsatu kerä aśtä ko ṣe kuṃjsati t[t]īma pharākä hämäta ttīyä sarvaśū-
rä bodhisatvä tta hvate se pharākä gyasta balysa pharā[k]ä mä[ṣḍāna ........ ttīy]ä vā gyastä balysä
tta hvate se ko ju sarvaśūra ṣä hveʾ āya kye ttū biśu kuṃjsatī[nau .....................] kälstä u ṣä
ju hveʾ ttu kuṃjsatu śau śau dāna ṣumārä u śäte hālau viśtäta a[śtä ko ................. ku]ṃjsatīgye
dāne biśśi haṃkhäṣṭu yanä māñandäna ttīyä vā sarvaśūrä bodhi[satvä tta hvate se. ne gyasta ba]lysa ne jve
mäṣḍāna gyasta balysa ṣa hauta śtä ce va ttu kuṃjsatīnau haṃbīsu [haṃkhäṣṭu yanä ttīyä] ṣä padmaga-
rbhä gyastä balysä tta hvate se. ttrāmī ttu näjsaḍu sarva[śūra ttīye saṃghāṭä sū]tṛ pu[ñī]nai haṃbīsä
ne haṃkhäṣṭä hämäte u nai ye māñando ūva[mu] yuḍu yīndä vänau gyastānu balysānu u kyerä vā tte kuṃjsatīṃ
gye dāne u tterä ju gyasta balysa hämāro u biśśä ttä gyasta balysa ttīye saṃghāṭä dātä nāmani bulje hvāñāro
cai pyūṣḍe u puñīnai haṃbīsä vīvātu hvāñāro ṣṣai ūvama ne yäḍa hämäte tta cu rro vā pātcu [x x x x]
sta balysa däte tsutāndä ttī gyasta balysa tta hvāñīndä se pyūʾ bäsīvrrāṣṣā thu hvīʾyä ysaṃthu byaudai [u saṃghāṭä] dātä
gvaʾ ātä ttäna tvī ttederä buro mästä puñīnai hambīsä hämäte ṣä vā [tta] hvāñäte tta ku mamä gyastyau balysy[au ttede]-
rä mästä puñīnai hambīsä hämäte tta c[u] ne rro vā kye ttū sū[tr]ä [uspurr]ä pyūṣḍe biśśu ttītä ttä gyasta balysa tta
hvāñīndä se paśa paśa bäsīvärāṣā kye ttū [sūtr]ä py[ūvāʾte ........... vät]ä [tcūrapa?]tä salāvä gāhä
puñīnai haṃbīsä padaṃgyo hvāñāmä ttī pyūṣḍe cvī puña [..................] buḍarä dvāśuvoʾ ggaṃgvoʾ
nätāvuoʾ grūcyau syate māñandānu gyastānu balysānu biśśānu [......] uysnaurä puñīnau haṃbīsu bu-
ḍaru pajāysde ce ttätäye saṃghāṭä suträ vätä tcūrupatä gā[hä x x x Overwritten with: x haṣṭātä ysāre.kye] rru tteränu gyastānua balysānu
pajsamu yanä kho drraiśuvoʾ gaṃguvoʾ nätāvoʾ syata kye biśä k[l]ai[śa tvīṣṣe yäḍā]ndä [u hasta]moOverwritten with: ysana ci. rraṣṭo balysūśtu bu-
sta kye ṣä āya uysnorä kye ttīye saṃghāṭä sūträ väte [tc]ūru-[salā]vu gāhu pyūṣṭu yañä tty[e] uysnorä mästarä
mästarä puñīnai hambīsä hämäte tta cu ne rro vā kyai bi[ś]śu uspurru pyūṣṭu yīndä. ttītä gystä balysi tta
hve se pyūʾ bäsīvärāṣṣā kye ttū saṃghāṭu dātu uspurru biśśu pyūṣṭu yīndä. kyerī puña hämāre trāmu māñaṃdu
kye va ju ṣä uysnorä āya kye biśśo tṛsahasrya mahāsahasrya balysāno tcārīmu vätä kuṃjsatä
kerä cerä tte kuṃjsatīje dāne pharāke hämāre {hämāre} u tterä cakravartte rrunde hämāro u ṣä ju hveʾ [hämäta tsā]-
tä biśūnīna ttatana anaṃkhäṣṭä u ṣä ju naḍe biśśānu ttānu cakkravartānu horu horu cerä ttye puña häm[ā́]re [u kye]
vā śye proda-phārrä haurä heḍä [ttye] vā mästarä puñīnai haṃbīsä hämäte || ce buro vā tṛsahasrye mahāsa-

... fourteen blankets x ounces(?) ... the others, all (of them) ... away.

q.l: — || āśiʾrī sureṃdra kṣī a(?)ra with ink dot to upper right? — hvāṣṭyau pūri pā-
ḍai velakä na audä ṣiʾ buri uvaysaṃbatī jsāṃ ṣṣmañä gīstai u paʾjsū avāysai himye dva drai jna ma tuhastä
yiḍi drāma drāma-ṃ ahaṃbusąna salā hve cu pūräna ni haṃbusīdä saṃ eṣṭyai si kṣīra vaśūʾ bāḍä ṣṭi hvāṣṭāṃ
ttgvavāṃ na ni vistātai vaña ttā misali birgaṃdara tsvai si kīrä va yanīṃ khu pyaṃtsāṣṭa tsve himi cu va jsārä byaudai
īme tvī tvī-t-ī vāṣṭa hajsaudai u ṣaʾ pūrä mara kṣī knajä su[reṃdrä ā]śiʾrī hīya mijṣe hīyausti khu vā birgaṃdara -
na ātū vara biśa nai byaudai cvaṃ pā hvaḍāṃda starrä niśāñä ye ī pātcī niśātai ttye mijṣe va vā ttāguttyau jsa
jaṃpha pracā panata u paṃtsai bista serya thauna pajistādä u prabhe āśiʾrī-y-ī vinīyabhadrä gvārä nāte pīḍakä
padeṃdä si cu vā pracā panamāṃde aysī hā gvaścī imi ra saṃ ttaṃdī drai kūsa ganaṃ hauryarä u drai kūsa mau u thau
bistä chā u ṣiʾ ni hā āśiʾrī vinīyabhadrä ttāguttāṃ hirä ni-ṃ hauḍä u ṣaʾ-ṃ pūrä sudana āśirī pūräna khara girye
śā tcau baysga thauna ttāgutai drai thauna hatcastāṃdä vaña hā ṣaʾ-ṃ pūrä vinau mau kṣaṣṭa cyaṃ mau hauḍä stūrä jsārä kṣi kūsa
... the spāta ... I make a report ...
The reverend Sureṃdra the kṣī I — O masters(?), raised a son
from when he was a child till (now). He, for his part, helped him to be initiated in monkhood(?). And there was much ... for me. Two or three times he has ...-ed them here(?).
He spoke such and such unfitting words to me as do not suit a boy: You have only endured(?), in the land it is an evil time.
I did not place (him?) for (our) masters the Tibetans(?). Now Misala has gone to you in Birgaṃdara (thinking): I shall do work. If I were to go henceforth, whatever grain I may have obtained,
all that I would have gathered (and sent) hither. And that son here, the kṣī of Kna, the wife of the reverend Sureṃdra ... But when I came to Birgaṃdara,
I found (him?) there in the house. Next, the ... which they ate, would have been to be thrown away. Next I threw it away. But over that wife of his there
arose causes for quarrel from the Tibetans, and they requested from him *five cloths of twenty ... And ... the reverend Vinīyabhavä took the case.
He made a written statement (as follows): Whatever pretexts may arise, I shall decide it for them. And you just give me as much as three kūsas (of) wheat and three kūsas (of) wine and (of) cloth
twenty chās. And the reverend Vinīyabhava gave/paid them, the Tibetans, nothing. And the son, with the son the reverend Sudana bought one female donkey(?),
four thick cloths. The Tibetans canceled three cloths. Now the son has delivered ... six kūsas of grain for the pack animal(s).
/ x sp[ā]t[a] x ma -ādä pe rka (?) -ā́ ka sī ma drū rrūsi nāti
@ mūra x x ys- c- [ā]ś[i]ʾrī ś- /
/ śaʾtāṃ u ce tau rrahä śmi bū /

q.l: : rruśta vīra baste: pajenu kūri-guṇyau jsa [x x x ha]ṣṭi ma-
nāta: sūhavna āyīmāmane: nivā hīye śukye ahvyāñe
dha-yā parrīya bhavāgra āstanaka audi avīśa būre ysyāme ysi-
rūña maraṃ rāśaʾ tsūti: drahiṣkalī ysimaśaṃde: hye suhiʾ śire
kiṇa: drayau ttiradiryau jsa haṃphva: biśi pīrmāttąma baʾysāni baʾ-
ysūśti kūśāʾṃ: hvāñari ma ni ttā: hvāñari: cu būrāṃ ji ttāhare
baʾysūśti vaski upakąrṇä śtāki himāṃde: tti khu ysīri āʾjsaṃ raṃna mura
mīrāheʾ: harbīśū raṃna maura aspūrri himāṃde: ma na ttā haṃdirye rrāśiʾ
himāmane: ma braṃgąrā: ma dīri-gūttirya: ma kastara: ma na ttā agyau prrattya-
gyau jsi vārūḍya himāmane: baiśi ysaṃthi va ṣṭāṃ ttā hīya dasteṃ rana-ṃ caṃdā-
vąña mvīri māñaṃda-ṃ himāṃde: avmāvāṃ ttąta: himāte: avimāvi pats-
ma: avimāta-ṃ dākṣaʾṇya: ma ni ttā hīsi rrāśiʾ himmane: ma ni ttā baʾ-
ysūñä aysmū panāśmani ma māʾśdiʾ: ma prraṇąhna: baiśä ysaṃthi vaṣṭi
ttā sūdhąna eʾysānai māñaṃdä rraṣṭą sadabhūtti pīsā kalyninaittri byeh-
mine: ttrmū ārāhye yinmane khu namau mahāsthniprrāpta baudhisa-
tva: cirmi āryāvąlaukyitteśvarä baudhasatva māʾśdäʾ: ākāśągarbhi hau-
vą: ksiʾttigarbhi cąrya: simattibhadri vimūhaʾ: majiśrī prraṇąhna: u
ma ttā mnī himāṃde: dädirū jsa-ṃ ttā rraysgi vī vinīy ttrvāsti yin-
mane khu namau bhaiṣająrāji baudhasatva ttrāste: ttrāmą ttā sątvā bā-
ji karmi āvarṇa kauce: baśdeʾ ṣądāvā dīśeʾ yinmane: khu namau
akṣubi jasti baʾysi dīśeʾ: ttrmą ttā satvā bāji dukha karye bu-
ḍi yināmine khu namau mahākārṇakä śākyamāṃ jastna jasta baʾysi
buḍä baudhasatvä cäryāyi jsna: dädäri ttā rraysgą vī baʾysūśtā-
ṣṭa aviṣī byehāmane: khu namau āryāmaittrai baudhisatva bīde: ttr-
mū ttā baudhakṣaiʾttri himāne khu svahāvą lauvidā: ttiri ṣṭā pūña
kuśilamūla namau armyāyi jasti baʾysa vari ysīnī yi bāyāṃ mariṇa-
kālā byāti himāde: simattiveraucināṃ baidi māʾsdīʾji bāʾyi bī-
rāśīʾ: vīnā naṣaʾmāṃde dāvījā-ṃ tcamąña vasūsīde: ttye adheṣṭ-
na: hūna mñadi baiśi cāʾyi mīrīci mñaṃdi sąrvadharmi ttuśā paysānma-
ne: upāyi-kauśila nma pārme haṃbīrāṃde dasau
bhųmi dasau paʾñä: vigihi baudhadharma haṃbīrāṃde: haṃbaḍa āvaṃ
ni baiśi sarvasątva uysnaura ysimaśadya baʾysi himāṃde: ttą hvñari tti pā
|| āśaʾryī āysdi yinīryau: tti-tti-nmani dnive ṣṭāre kalynamaittri āśaʾrī pa-
ḍauysña jsi: simagri kāśivitrī bisaṃgą paha ūsihyādi
pūjākarmyau jsi hva hvą ṣṭāṃ āśaʾryāṃ ttiraṃdarą drūnā parīdą brrīṣṭi:
aysmya jsā ṣṭā: suhiʾ sīravā saṃdurṣṭī prravārṇaji bāḍi pa-
chīśāʾre: kimi jsi bīsaṃgīji geʾ jsi āśaʾrya: mari ūvārye
mahācaitti paṃna byaudāṃdi dye: dnive audi tti pastāṃdi asthīye
si: mānī vā jsāṃ pā drayvā raṃnvā ūvārä vistārya padya pūña kū-
śilamūla śiḍe deyidharma kṣaʾmīdi yūḍe: ūtvaḍire jsa bī-
saṃgīji geʾ parysi viri: ttye haira prracāyiną paḍāṃda bīsaṃgąni ā-
śaʾrya nimadrrādi: uvārąna baʾysūñi aysmyani: nemaṃdrūni pa-
stāṃdi ahavāysye: khīnā ni miñāṃdi: kīḍa būrāṃ jsą ṣṭāṃ pa-
jsaṃ brrīyā pachīśāʾre. viñā ṣṭāṃ himadā hamadā ttāṣṭi parīdi nimaṃ-
dre: styaji kāla parīdi ārauśeʾ: pārśaʾ pąjsaṃ dāśe: bīsaṃgni
vā jsāṃ pā āśaʾrya ttāṣṭi pūṣi parsyari: caityi-vaṃdąnāṣṭi ttiri
vā jsāṃ pā tti namau jastāṃ baʾysāṃ baudhasątvāṃ: devattāṃ parvālā:
pąjsąmi pūjākarma armūvyari parṇāmyari: ttāṣṭi pūṣi parsyari
saṃgasthāñāṣṭi: ttiri vā jsāni pā tta hva hva sthna ve āysnā
vīrä pārihīryau: dānivā gīhaʾni pārśaʾ pąjsaṃ pajāysīryau:
sarvūpakąrṇi pęṇḍvāna: dnive vā jsni pā audi tti pastāṃdi
asthīye: ci ma tvā śaṃdai pūña kūśilamūla himya īde:
cira haiʾtti drayvā ranvā pūña kūśilamūla yuḍādū ma[n]e
ci ma ttyāṃ dva padya {pū} pųṇyäjñānisaṃbhārāṃ saṃgrīttāṃ pūñāṃ kūśilamūlā hīya tvārā himya
ī: audi bvaśte baʾysūśti būre jsā ṣṭā pūña kūśilamūla
ttāhire simągri kāśivitrī bīsaṃgna haṃbrrīhāre: x [x x x]
āśaʾrī āstaṃna yāvi audi sąrva nivāʾña būre: [jsā ṣṭā ?]
... bound to the kingdom. We wish for the eight pleasant commodities [devoid of?] the five ... guṇas with a view to ... of ...
escaping from the prison of saṃsāra. The śrāvaka-pratyeka-buddha-yāna
deliverance he went under the rule of birth from the bhavāgra down to the avīcī hell (and)
pitiful death. For the sake of the benefit and happiness of the three-tiered earth
We seek the very foremost bodhi of the buddhas. Speak! Do not speak! As many
upakaraṇas they need for the pure bodhi, such as gold, silver, coins,
pearls, all the jewels and coins will be complete for them. May we not come under the rule of others! Not braṃgaras, not in an inferior family, not lowly, nor may we
be lacking in aṅgas and pratyaṅgas. Throughout all births, by their hand (= help), may they be jewels
like the cintāmaṇi jewel. May there be immeasurable wealth for them, immeasurable abandonment,
immeasurable dākṣiṇeya. May we not come under the rule of greed for those. May we not
destroy their buddha (bodhi) mind, nor (their) compassion, nor (their) vows. Throughout all births
may we, like Prince Sudhana, obtain truthful ..., teachers, (and) kalyānamitras.
May we be able to please them the way hail! the bodhisattva Mahāsthānaprāpta, thus the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara’s compassion, Ākāśagarbha’s power,
Kṣitigarbha’s career, Samantabhadra’s deliverance, Mañjuśrī’s vows. And
may we not envy them. May we be able to deliver as many of them quickly across the vaineyas
as hail! the bodhisattva Bhaiṣajarāja delivered. May we be able to confess as ransom for those beings such
the lord buddha Akṣobhya confessed. May we be able to carry as ransom for those beings such woes and hardships
as hail! Mahākārṇaka Śākyamuni the Buddha, lord of lords,
carried in his career. May we quickly
obtain so much abhiṣeka for us toward bodhi as hail! the bodhisattva Āryamaitreya obtained.
May *there be for us such a one of their buddhakṣetras like the Sukhāvati lokadhātu. So many merits
(and) roots of goodness may we bring before hail! the bodhisattva Amitāyu into his safe-keeping, (and)
may they be remembered at the time of our death. May Samantavairocana extend (his) rays of compassion upon us.
May the vaineyas be extinguished for us. May the eyes of the Law be purified for us. By his firm support (adhiṣṭhāna)
may we recognize that like a dream all dharmas are empty, all (are) like magic (and) illusion. May they fulfill the pāramitā called upāya-kauśalya (skill in the means of salvation), the ten
earths, the ten powers. May they fulfill the ... buddha-dharmas. Their wishes fulfilled,
may all living beings become buddhas in the world. Speak thus: Then
may we, the donors such-and-such ([34a] the dvaipiṭika Cadrākara-bhadrasīha), become buddhas.
Reverend ones, protect him! There are the donors such-and-such, the kalyānamitra, reverend, from the beginning.
May the entire Kāśavitria bhikṣu-saṅgha deign to ripen (their roots of goodness?)
by (their) pūjā-karmas. They deign to ask (whether) the bodies of the reverend ones each and every one are healthy.
May it be in (their?) mind. They count happiness, satisfaction, and contentedness at the time (in the land) of ...
The reverend ones from ... from the bhikṣu-saṅgha assembly. Here
they obtained the seing of the front(?) of the exalted mahācaitya. They deigned utter to the donor:
Let them please make for us then in the Three Jewels merits and roots of goodness in extensive manner,
in the service of the bhikṣu-saṅgha assembly. For that reason they invited previously the reverend ones of the bhikṣu-saṅgha. With exalted buddha mind the deigned
extend the invitation. They did not consider ... Very many of them
count .... Now they deign ever and again to send you invitations.
They deign to ... the *harsh times. The service and worship are completed. But then
(you) the reverend ones of the bhikṣu-saṅgha must get away (and go back) to your caitya-vandana. But
you must then congratulate and ripen so much worship and pūjā-karma
for the hail! lord buddhas, bodhisattvas, deities, and guardian (deities). You must get away (and go back) to your
saṅgha-sthāna. And then, each in his own place and on his own seat,
you must practice restraint. You must enjoy service and worship with the help of the donors:
sarvopakaraṇas (all utilities of life) by begging. The donors then deign to utter thus:
Whatever there may have been here (on?) this earth,
as many merits and roots of goodness as we may have performed earlier in the Three Jewels,
whatever conveyance there may have been here of those two-fold puṇya-jñāna-sambhāras, the merits and roots of goodness that have been ...-ed.
Until bodhi has been realized the pure merits and roots of goodness
they will share with the entire Kāśivitra bhikṣusaṅgha.
The reverend ... and the others, until sarvanirvāṇa

note.p: Uigur Brahmi from Astana. The two fragments Ast. vii.2.026 and vii.2.027 (InAs., II, p. 662) were orig-inally allotted to the British Museum and numbered Or.8212/1633 and 1634, but were transferred to the India Office Library in 1970. The present location of Ast. vii.2.026 is not known.
With Balaw. 0194 to the left. The akṣaras at the break are mostly divided between the two fragments.

note.p: “No. 5371 22.x.1912.” Sanskrit inscription on silk strip from the Tunhuang Limes (47x4 cm; inscr. 7.5 cm). Ser. II, pp. 701-4, 782-83, pl. XXXIX. Konow, 1939, p. 3. M. Boyer in Serindia, p. 702, read it as [ai]ṣṭasya paṭa giṣṭi ṣapariśa, and Stein interpreted paṭa giṣṭi ṣapariśa as “piece of cloth 46 spans,” referring to the roll of silk mentioned in a Chinese inscription. Konow read the inscription as:

q.l: śriraṣṭasya paṭa dhiṣṭi capariśa “silkroll of Śrīrāṣṭra, forty dhiṣṭiThe same as Kharoṣṭhī diṣṭi, a measure acc. to Konow.”

note.p: Drafts of letter. Lines 1 and 21 begin at opposite ends of the scroll. At end of scroll next to the Chinese name of the sutra (2 lines not mentioned by Enoki) several Khotanese akṣaras (repeated: tcī ḍainä) and before line 21 two lines not read by Bailey but like line 35. Lines 1-20 written with thick pen. On the back of Chinese Saddharma¬puṇḍarīka. Lines 1-20 in Hoernle, 1911, pl. III facing p. 456 (Hoernle has 19 lines, but he omitted line 4 in his count).

Welfare! Thus I had heard that the hail!
daśabala cakravartin Śākyamuni, the Lord Buddha,
had finished his buddha deeds. Staying there
he deigned to go all the way to the Nairañjana river.
Hail to the lord buddhas standing in the ten directions,
In the Year of the Horse, of the month of Haṃdyaja 16th day. ...
Equipped with exalted, heavy, extended merits and roots of goodness. ...

I make a report to the court thus: The humble servant, as for him before now to you ...
the parents ... thus there was water and earth. On account of the royal words (when?) you learn(?) the order ...
the august one (U ū huangzhu) bought the servant (girl?) Masarīka from Ysagāña. And now
he does not at all carry that word in his ears(?). Now (my) refuge is to the court. If the word
*is not in your ears(?), he carries (off) Masarīka, who(?) does the work on the water and land for him.
But if he does not *perform our ..., ...
As for him before now to you, if ... the word of the huangzhu is not in your ears(?), ... he
carries off the ... Masarīka, who(?) does the work on the water and land for him, which (is) the ...
of the great huangzhu. Thus I make report.
To the one equipped with great merits and roots of goodness. From(?) the keepers of the land (to) the humble servant Yū *Saṃgalaka.
(On me) the humble servant here in Ganzhou the order *descended (lit.: sat down?) that: There was a deed of purchase,
and it stood at sixty jin. The humble servant ... On the road the camels died
and ... accordingly were the horses. To the great Lady of China and the great huangzhu thus
honey, *soft molasses, sugar, sweetmeats, ..., pearls, ..., conches. Very much
the consort’s (furen ˚ w) life declined(?). Seven times daily she ...
If it helps her in this life ... led her to kṣānti(?). ...
Then she is there delighted, ... In every hand(?), accept(?) the child called Īniysikhyaṣe(?), a great ... has come to him. There is an orphan(?) here ...
... called Mayamūva. Subsequently one came. Very much his groins were ... and
happiness which there is here in the heart. With pleasure in the heart
I have come to the same ... A separate(?) lotus appeared: White and red, soft. ...
... when there ... remains in the (various) directions(?). Always I say(?)
I make a report to the court, the humble servant Sanaka. Upon the humble servant here an order descended:
Make them look (You must go?) to Shazhou. ... hither the order was: Horses, clothes
they must collect well. Now Tsvaḍa Pada has things (= to pay with?), but he has not promised anything(?).
) ... now (my) refuge is to the court. If the Tibetans here in Akuśī(?) gather orders ... the court
if I can undertake the royal order ...
I make a report asking about the health in reverence of the Yauvarāja, of the lineage of the Vyāśas, equipped with merits and roots of goodness like great suns, the humble servant

Yu Dāhaʾ Paḍi, if thus now at this time and season of the year he may be well, healthy, and at peace. Therefore am I (his) humble servant(?). I shall not die as long as long as I have delight in you(?). And ... sufferings *are ... Fears,
sorrows, which are obtained because of immortality(?), when there will be places for me, when
they become ... black ... calves ... only from joy
dwells in the palace ... I lie down at night the cocks call the law to us(?).
) ... From that man(?) called Tcyā Kvä Khīmu Cu, ...
Thus I make report to the court, the humble servant Kharasanaña, to the great ... Masters *I make report, the humble servant Pacaka from Baramai, the humble servant....

note.p: On the back of Chinese Bodhisattvabhūmi. Long scroll (23 ft 10") with “Gostana Skt.” Kauśika-sūtra, described briefly by Hoernle, 1911, pp. 473-74. No Khot. text. Lines 1-45 on Ser., pl. CXLVII.

On the back of Chinese Tang lü “Penal code of Tang.” Bailey read the piece before it was glued onto conservation paper and read akṣaras at the top and the right edge which are not visible now (marked {} below).

note.p: One Gostana Skt. text (Uttaratantra) with some Khot. text (see Bailey and Johnston, 1935) and two Chinese texts (C 111, 123) on back of Chinese Aparimitāyuḥ-sūtra. C 111 is a “part of a memorandum concerning supply of oil, leaven, rice, and wheat to monks” (Enoki); C 123 “16 characters written at random with the same pen as the Khotanese text” (Enoki). Bailey and Johnston, 1935, pl. II.

tvä jsa hva rahna:gautrivibhāgäśāstri hīya paḍauysa kārya
baʾysñāṃ tcaurakṣaʾṣṭyāṃ pājāṃ dharmāṃ u tcihauryāṃ viśā-

: pūña sāṃ rrā rau ryā ga hū —
First kāryā of the Sūtrālaṃkāra-śāstra. Spoken by the bodhisattva Āryā-Nāgārjuna.
First kāryā of the Madhyama-śāstra. It has been spoken by the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya.
It has been spoken by the bodhisattva [Āryā]maitreya. First kāryā of the Ratnagotra¬vibhāga-śāstra.
Of the sixty-four āveṇika dharmas of the buddhas and the four vaiśāradhyas {came out of the Ratnagotra¬vibhāga-śāstra}.

note.p: On the back of long scroll (7ft 11") with Chinese Aparimitāyuḥ-sūtra. Cf. Hoernle, 1911, p. 474. Lines 1-13 doc., lines 14-71 Pradakṣiṇā-sūtra.
Lines 1-17 in SD IV, pl. XC; SD, TV, pp. 115-17.

q.l: pasa salya cūvija māśti nāmai haḍ(ai) ṣiʾ byāvaja pīḍaka ttyi hira prracina cā ā baramyaja
[tt]ūnakā panaka ṣiʾ cū haḍa tsvi u śā ma cigāna nāvi u tta tta jsa gvāra basti sa kṣīrā bāysd[y]e
— u nārā padīmū bīśa bīsā jsā nāri naṣiʾphaśtu ttuka jsa gvāra tta tta basti ci ṣiʾ x
[x x x x x x x x] cigāna dāya na nā ttu ttyi jsā kṣādātmą prramā khva jsa vā ṣā panaka akṣara nīśä
: ṣiʾ buri cīnä väjalakä ṣacū kīrä tcerai haṃtsa dū saṃgalakā āstaṃna kąmäcū tsuākāṃ u
[su]dattä āstaṃna śvahvāʾ tsukāṃ haḍāṃ jsa haṃtsä kīrä tcerai khu ttā marä janävä vī nä tsvava
ttyā drai pacäḍa haḍa hīñä hīñä dīśtä bisā ysīḍā parauva dī ttye dī ttye hinā-pamūhai
haḍä baśtä sve bidä barīdä kuṣṭi saṃ vaʾysgede khu va bahyä nä hamāve virī baji ba-
ñāña u parauva auski väśtāña u ysai ysai panamāre biśä starāña u parauvā ānāñä
paḍauysä aśä parauvā va pathāñä dädä spāśāña khu parauva-bara bväʾttä u paḍā paḍā jsā
śau chā hīsyara parau tta tta {tva} tvarä khu thyautta : rrvī vī va tta haṣḍi yini: śi dī ṣāʾñä mau khaṣṭi vilakā i-
ysā ttī va vā byāva tha tsūāyi hirtha vīra varī panavu kamala-rāhaʾ pasāña ttā vi ttā tsvau

In the Year of the Sheep, ninth day of the month of Cvātaja. This memo (is) for the reason that Panakā of Baramya *Ttūnakāṃ, when he went as envoy and took one Chinese (woman) here. And he submitted the following case concerning it(?): Take heed of the people of the land(?)!
And I make (her) my wife. The wife belonging to the house (her) I expel. That was the case he submitted. When that
... did not take the Chinese (woman as a) lawful (one). ... Authoritative when with him(?) this Panakā places her akṣara.
This much work is to be done in Shazhou by young Cīnä, together with ... Together with the envoys: Saṃgalaka and the others who are going to Ganzhou, and
*Sudatta and the others who are going to Shuofang, the work must be done. When they set out here in the (Golden) Land (to go) to you
, there were three kinds of envoys. In the hand of each and every one (were) yellow orders. Under each and every
red coat the envoys wear a ... on the shoulder. Wherever they dismount, if there is no tree there, there he must tie on a ...
and place the orders on top of it. And they rise very early. All must be ... and their orders must be ...
The first horse must be *employed for the orders. They must watch until the order-bearer mounts. And first of all
you must come pronto(?) and *deliver the order as soon as possible. I make a report to the court: For (each) one so much is to be prepared: wine (and) food for the small princes(?).
Then we remembered you. Suddenly I got a headache. ...
there where you understand the speech.

note.p: Pradakṣiṇā-sūtra of Zhang Jiang Gun. Tr. Bailey, 1974.

Chinese Vajracchedikā in Khotanese cursive (C 134) on back of Chinese Suvarṇaprabhāsa (C 54). Published with photo Thomas, 1937. New edition of the Chinese Vajracchedikā in Emmerick and Pulley-blank, 1993. FM 25 (KT V, p. 394) is the upper left corner of the ms.
On the back of Chinese “śāstra explaining the anitya or uncertainty of all things” (Enoki).

“I go to the refuge of the Lord Buddha, I go to the refuge of the Law, I go to the refuge of the bhikṣusaṅgha,
I go to the refuge of the bhikṣusaṅgha assembly, a second time, a third
time. The great prince deigns to accept the refuge of the Lord Buddha, the Law, and the bhikṣusaṅgha jewel. May he not
deign to take birth in those three great apāyas without vows.
Deign utter: As I am now bowing with good
faith and with the three saṃskāras
with the priority of the Lord Buddha, the bhikṣusaṅgha assembly ...
with a view (to all those), may he deign to give this beggar food and drink.
May he deign to restrain himself from the all those ten great sins,
and may he deign to fare in the *performance of the ten great goodnesses,
namely, the three kinds with the body,
the four kinds with the tongue, (and) the three kinds with the mind. Just as
they deigned utter firstly, thus secondly, thus thirdly.
... Deign utter: This food and drink ... former(?)
trivarga ... Deign give the *ransom of the production of continuation of his life.
{(18) Welfare! I go in reverence with my forehead to the exalted buddha (18) body of the Law, pure may he deign to (place?) the body in the ten bhūmis(?).}
May they succeed by these merits (and) roots of goodness. When he writes to you,
, for him are fulfilled the six pāramitās, the ten bhūmis, the ten powers,
(his) wishes are fulfilled, all living beings (
will become buddhas in the world. O great prince,
deign thereafter to realize the all-supreme bodhi of the buddhas!

note.p: On the back of Chinese “Sūtra of the great good means” and “part of a story of Kalyānakarī and Pāpakarī” (Enoki). Very regular cursive ductus. Follows P 2893 (Maggi).

. ysarūṃ maugä. rīysū. hąmaṃgä vīśtñä. kūṭñä. ṣvīdana ṣiʾ peṃḍai pāchai
. bidai śakarä parkūnñä haśä jiṃdä ū ūysąna āphārä:: īraṃde. tharka
mijsā. dma-hauṣṭä gūra. kūṃjsa. drrma ttma. ūlña tcāra. raustarä. būysña
p. hamaṃgä vīśtñä nauka kūṭñä ṣiʾ piṃḍai haṃbrrīhñä jarä biṃdä baññä
. hiṃja haśä jidä u phāhäʾ::: gūra. kuṃjsa. hainai caṃda. rrīys. hamaṃgä
vīśtñä nauka kuṭña. ṣvīdana pāchai. jarrä biṃdä khaiya jinākä piṃḍai:
:: hauṣka gūra. rnai. mahābaujä. haṃga. hąmagä vīśtñä
... with ... a ground bean should be soaked. (Such) a pill destroys red swelling. Castoroil and sesame should be placed in equal quantities
and finely ground. It should be made into a pill with camel’s fat. Afterward
it should be dried. Perfume of bdellium and myrobalan should be placed in equal quantities and ground
and blended into it. It should be soaked with cow’s urine. The pill should be heated and
placed on the lower abdomen. It removes enlargement of the abdomen and swelling. bahauʾya, bauṇva, ṣavara
should be placed in equal quantities and pounded together. It should be bound on the swelling. It removes red swelling. vmīrāṃ, aysāʾya, bird cherry(?), dry radishes, and ground flour
should all be placed in equal quantities and finely ground. It should be cooked with *wine. yamaka oil
should be mixed in. Rock salt should be sprinkled on it. It should be bound on the gut. It removes red swelling
and constipation of urine. ... grapes and dry radishes should be placed in equal quantities
and pounded. Flour should be mixed into it. It should be cooked with *wine and bound on the gut. (It makes)
a pill against swelling. Bird cherry(?), dry radishes, bladder sorrel marrow, ground flour, bauṇva,
ṣavara, rājānamva to be burnt(?), pigeon dung, sesame, and linseed
should all be placed in equal quantities finely ground. It should be cooked with *wine and mixed. Sweet flag and orrisroot should be sprinkled on it.
This pill, which is called daśāṃga, should be bound on the gut. It removes red swelling. Dry radishes,
castor oil plant, mujsāka, and the dregs of *wine should be placed in equal quantities and ground. It should be cooked with *wine
and mixed with old ghee. Costus should be sprinkled on it. It should be bound on the gut.
It removes red swelling stomach pains. When the feet are swollen, this is the pill:
the linseed in wheat(?) should be heated and ground. ... should be made, and a pill should be made
with the dregs of *wine. It should be mixed with old cow’s urine. It should be bound on the feet.
It removes the swelling. Leaves of castor oil plant should be soaked
and mixed with sesame oil. Rock salt should be sprinkled on it. It should be bound on the feet. It removes the swelling.
Sesame, turneric, liquorice plant, and yellow flowers should be placed in equal quantities and finely ground.
It should be soaked with bahauya. (Such) a pill destroys swelling of the skin. White onion(?) and white perfume should be placed in equal quantities

and pounded together. It should be kneeded with ghee. (Such) a pill is applied against red, warm swelling. Dry radishes, the dregs of *wine, and castor oil plant should be placed in equal quantities and pounded.
The pill should be cooked in old oil and *wine. It should be mixed with old ghee and costus should be sprinkled on it.
It removes the swelling. ... root, ..., red ochre, should be *placed in equal quantities with dried grapes, cow’s oil
and pounded. It should be soaked in cow’s urine. This pill removes hard swelling of the skin.

..., mudar, sesame, dry grapes, and fat should be placed in equal quantities and finely pounded. It should be kneeded with cow’s oil. This pill is a remover of swelling of wounds. These are the pills applied against liver (swelling). Goat’s brains should be kneeded together, sugar should be sprinkled on it,
and hīśaʾ. It should be bound on the liver (and the ailment) is removed. Goat’s brains
should be mixed together, and wrapped on to the skin. (Such) a pill is applied against liver (swelling). Sesame, linseed,
green beans, and rice should be placed in equal quantities and pounded. This pill should be cooked with milk.
Sugar should be sprinkled on it. It removes the swelling and disturbance of the breath. Castor oil plant, tharka,
marrow, ... grapes, sesame, pomegranate seed, camel’s fat, mudar, goat’s
fat should be placed in equal quantities and finely pounded. The pill should be mixed and bound on the liver. It removes red swelling and cough. Grapes, sesame, red sandal, and rice
should be placed in equal quantities and finely pounded. It should be cooked with milk. (Bound) on the liver (such) a pill is the remover of aches.
Dry grapes, oil, costus, and bladder sorrel should be placed in equal quantities ...

note.p: On the back of Chinese Saddharmapuṇḍarīka. Lines 01-42 love poem, lines 44-223 the Sudhanāvadāna, lines 224-386 the “Book of Vimalakīrti.”
Synoptic edition of the various manuscripts (also P 2896, 2956, 2895, 2022, and 2025) in Dresden, 1977b. See also Kumamoto, 2000. Guide2 [19.1].
The “Book of Vimalakīrti.” Guide2 under [18.26]. From line 368, the parallel text in P[elliot] 2026 (KT III, pp. 48-50 (18)) has been added interlinearly. Provisional translation.

q.l: jsa nairvattīda bāya ācausta tcūra{x}ma yava padaśta aharīne kīḍaiśaʾ sūdarjaye bū-
ma pūrrdaFor pū(ha pū)rrda? *duṣaiʾvurrdaiMs. duṣaiʾcurrdai. kīḍeśaʾ baiśa kṣema būma abvaimvakha nāma vara pichaṣṭu baiśa baʾysa
duragama haudama būña ttye jsa himai satsāra hāysa acala ṣā haṣṭama būña vara dha-
rmakāya akhauṣṭa anābaugai ttaña beḍa haṣṭamya būma hamaye vasva nairvattīda bāya
tcana ttalaka harruñe maista ranīnai vaiysa bāʾyausta ttye baida naitta pha ttāna beḍa tta bai-
da dasta nvaśtāre baʾysaśtai avaiṣī nāste pajsa geʾ satva ttu bāḍa hatsa-āspava haimā-
re raśma-nairhā{rra}rna ttī pharai kūla satva parrīje sādhama būma ṣaiʾ naume vara sījāma
maista cu būrai baʾysāna rahāsa harbaiśu buttai paysaida cu dasama ṣaiʾ dharma-mega dā-
vaja pyara vasva vara byaha sarvajñāne baʾysūñä dasau paʾña urmaysdai bāya va-
māna nai hva hva sa śo bvāña ttaradara baʾysā draya sūbāvu ttu padī śau dharma-kāya
hauvai jsa ttyā pa vasve sābaugī baʾysa sābaugakāyūna pharāka narāmīda nairmya baʾ-
ysa cada sābaugī baʾysa baiśvā drau-mvajsvā bāya dada ysārai kūla tta pātca bāʾyau
jsa nairmya baʾysa mvaʾśvai anūlame kaiṇa baiśa lavadāva dyāre cai vā ṣai kvāysna
ysaiya cu vāṣṭa baʾysūśta butte cu vāṣṭa māra tcabeʾje haṣkīma śāśaʾ yāva
cai vā parainairvye daittai baiśa nairmāṇya baʾysa
tta pyūṣṭä paraiśudhaña kṣettra varai ṣa hama
dyāma baʾysä tta vā ayauṣṭaña kṣettra vara baʾysa dyāma p(ā)tca kā vā ṣaiʾ kṣettra vasve ā-
yauṣṭa ṣaiʾ vā khu bvāña khu vā vara dyāma baʾysa uysdīśa vā ttu artha hvīdai ttā paraiśu-
dhaña kṣetträ ṣaiʾ bvāña ṣaiʾ cu vasve aysmva prrara kūṣṭa ysauttai kāma sañe vara baʾysa
āstai akhauṣṭa ṣai aysmva tcu ne ra vasūśta kāmyau jsa ñūṣṭai bastä āyauṣṭa kṣettra ṣaiʾ
bvāña prrarasta āstā baʾysa baʾysa vā ttī khu vajaiṣḍe dasau dīśaiʾ sāmvaha pana
ttu artha vā vaiña ṇvāya mvaśjaʾ anūlame kaiṇa hvīdai tta baiśa baʾysa sa śau baʾ-
ysa hamaga harbaiśa prrara baiśa dharmakāya svabhāva agunai lakṣaṇa ttyānä cī dharmakā-
ya payseda harbaiśā baʾysā śau hamye kṣaṇa ttī ttaiña beʾḍa baʾysa baiśa sāmvaha
sūttra vī cadraprraye vara ṣai baʾysaña rahāsa vālamāttra śe drau-nauhya
daidai ra pharai baʾysa ttai pyaṣṭa khu jai gaga grruīcyau sye baiśa budhakṣettrau hatsa ṣaiʾ manai
ttī artha kha bvāña kha baijsyāda śe dra-nauhya hvīdai ttā samāhā khu vaiṣṭa akhauṣṭa
drau-nauhna khu hā bījsyādä : daṃdä śe drau-nauha thāña ttye samā(hā) vī baʾysa khu jai ga-
ga grruīcyau sya baiśa budhakṣettryau hattsa dharmakāya prrarai jsa baiśa aguna-lakṣa
nūaiya tta tta dharmadhatta aṇastya baʾysyau jsa habaḍa baiśa drau-masāja naiśta
ṣaiʾ thā kūṣṭa jasta baʾysa nai āʾra vasva dāvīnai tcena tcana daitta harbaiśa baʾysa
baiśa baudhakṣettryau hattsa samāhā hauva jsa byode raidhapahālye maista {ba} anūvyajane
lakṣaṇa bāya baʾysūña bvāma maista baiśa samāhā vī ṣṭāna ʾau vā pyūṣṭä
utca kanä ttara nai naiṣaiʾme vījayaśākhī daśta ttye baida āchai naʾsta ṣaiʾ ttī sve bai-
