... from ... rays come out. Ācausta the fourth: until it burns the kleśas without remainder. Sudurjayā (is)
the *fifth bhūmi, the one *difficult to conquer: it conquers all kleśas. The sixth bhūmi is called Abhimukhā; there all buddhas are in full view.

Durāgamā is the seventh bhūmi; by it saṃsāra becomes distant. Acalā is to be known as the eighth; there the dharma-kāya is unshaken, anābhoga; at that time in the eighth bhūmi pure rays come out of themselves
by which there shines forth ... A great jeweled lotus full of rays sits on it. Much at that time appeared on it.
They study. He takes a consecration of bodhi. The beings in the five stages at that time receive refuge
by (his) ... of rays. Then he delivers many billions of beings. Sādhamā, that is the ninth bhūmi. There there is great success.
However many buddha mysteries there are he realizes and recognizes them all. As for the tenth, that is the Dharmameghā,
the pure cloud of the Law. There he obtains the omni¬science of the buddhas, the ten powers. He conducts the vimāna of the sun.
Not even one is to be known separately of the three bodies of the buddhas, their svabhāva(?). In that manner by the power of the one dharma-kāya(?).
Before them a pure sāmbhogika(?) buddha. From the sāmbhoga-kāya come forth many transformed buddhas.
As many as there are in all the hair pores of the sāmbhogika(?) buddha, so many thousands of billions of rays. From the rays
transformed buddhas next (emerge). On account of the anuloma of (their) compassion all the world spheres appear. Even the one born from the side
or who realizes bodhi or who smashes Māra, performs the teaching until
the one who reaches nirvana appears: all the nirmāṇika buddhas.A new edition and translation of lines 224-232 in Maggi, “Le bhūmi” (forthc.), lines 232-263 in “µMore Verses” (forthc.).
Thus (I have) heard: In a purified field
the viewing of the Buddha is (possible), and similarly in a disturbed field. Then, which is the field that is pure (or) disturbed?

How is that to be known? And how is the viewing of the Buddha there? Teach us that matter! It is said: Then he is to be known in a purified field, he in whose mind nature (prakṛti) is pure, where views (dṛṣṭi) and notions (saṃjñā) have ceased. There the Buddha
dwells undisturbed. That mind which is not yet becoming pure, yoked and bound to views, that is to be known as a disturbed field,
based on nature (prakṛti). ... How is one then to see in the ten directions the buddhas arisen before one’s eyes?
Convey to us now that matter on account of the anuloma of your compassion! It is said: Thus all the buddhas are equal to just one buddha.
All the natures are of the (same) own being (svabhāva) as the dharma-kāya, without marks and characteristics (nimitta, lakṣaṇa). When one recognizes (that) the dharma-kāya
of all the buddhas (is) one, then in one and the same instant at that time all the buddhas appear before one’s eyes.
In the sutra, in the Candrapradīpa, in the mystery of the Buddha as many buddhas appear vālamātra on the tip of one hair.
Thus (I have) heard: Just like the grits and sands in the Ganges, together with all the buddha fields he ...
Then how is the matter to be known that they are accomodated on the tip of one hair? It is said: Then how is the samādhi undisturbed? How are they accomodated
on the tip of a hair? So many are the buddhas in the place of the tip of one hair during the samādhi as
the grits and sands of the Ganges together with all the buddha fields. The dharma-kāya is by nature altogether without marks and characteristics.
*Consequently, therefore, the sphere of the Law borderless (and) filled with buddhas altogether is not (even) the size of a hair.
That place where the lord buddhas do not dwell, by the pure eye of the Law, by which all the buddhas appear,
together with all the buddha fileds, by the power of the samādhi it is obtained. Great ṛddhi-pādas, secondary (and)
primary marks it brings(?), the great knowledge of the buddhas, all in the samādhi. And (I have) also heard:
A drop of water, that much it is not extinguished(?) in the hand of Vijayaśākhī(?). On him illness settled. He then on the shoulder
pulled out (?) filled with herbs. He threw that herb on the ... However, it did not
... nor did it cleanse the illness. Without kriyā he went to ... This is similar to the bodhisattva who only
with words seeks bodhi. He is not intent on the samādhi, bodhi (remains) distant from him. He who concentrates on the anābhoga
career (and) does not worry(?), his samādhi is to be known as very close to right bodhi.
And as he said in the omniscient sutra, in the Mañjuśrī-parivarta in the Tathāgatajñānasamudra-sūtra: And an elephant ... When they know all things to be unoriginated, (then) their
knowledge (kauśalya?) is very great at the time of samādhi those buddhas are not(?) to be known as undisturbed at that time.
Then in the Vajramaṇḍala-sūtra, in the great buddha mystery, it is said: Desire, anger,
folly (are) all to be known as bodhi(?). And in the Karmāvaraṇaviśuddhi-sūtra, there it is
said: The obstructions of desire, anger, folly (are) the obstructions of the Buddha, the Law, and the bhikṣusaṅgha. How does that ...
agree mutually? But that which he calls a mystery (is it?) out of compassion, and also
on account of profit for beings?New ed. and transl. of lines 247-249, 264-266 in Maggi, “Canonical Buddhist Texts” (forthc.).
It is said: Then bodhi is such with respect to nature like the cloudless
sky—nevertheless there come upon it lightening or ... clouds. Thus folly, desire,
anger, the kleśas, (upon) the ... sky(?), all from outside to
inside never in the three times are they found. In that manner all the dharmas
are empty of non-grasping(?), where there is no dharma even the size of an instant. And that is bodhi. Now it is said precisely: obstruction. How much do great bodhisattvas have?
He is not to be called a bodhisattva who has notions (saṃjñā) of anger, desire, folly.

He who has any, for him that is an obstruction caused by acts (karmāvaraṇa). He is not to be called a bodhisattva who has a notion of the Buddha, the Law, and the bhikṣusaṅgha. That is a great obstruction for him to bodhi.
He is not to be called a bodhisattva. And whichever bodhisattva sees the *element of anger
in the *element of nirvana, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified. And whichever bodhisattva
sees the *element of folly in the *element of nirvana, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified.
And whichever bodhisattva sees the *element of desire
in the *element of nirvana, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified. And whichever bodhisattva sees a pupil
as a non-pupil, for him the obstruction caused by acts is purified.
And whichever bodhisattva sees the Buddha, the Law, and, finally, the bhikṣusaṅgha, of the nature of equality,
that bodhisattva is ... And whichever bodhisattva recognizes all things as empty,
unoriginated, undestroyed, extinguished, that bodhisattva is ... And whichever
bodhisattva wishes to serve pleasantly(?) all the buddhas of the three times with divine worship,
in his exalted(?) samādhi he needs a mind undisturbed, unsupported. Thus they will be worship-worthy for him (worshiped by him),
all the buddhas of the three times. And whichever bodhisattva seeks knowledge,
however many, without exception, sutras he wishes to learn, ... he must produce (bhāvaya) a samādhi without vikalpa, undisturbed. As soon as(?) he has explained (it), he understands (adhimuc-)
the meanings all sutras. Whoever may hear(?) this right pure Law of the buddhas obtain
great knowledge. They become free from obstructions, like the sky, undisturbed in mind. They go to the other world, they explain with the help of the bhāvanā the release of pure nirvana.

The Anantamukhanirhāra-sūtra, in which the eight akṣaras are expounded, how are the meanings of the akṣaras of the name of that sutra to be known? It is said: In that sutra bodhi is expounded by many entrances into the Law (dharma-mukha). Whoever makes a bhāvanā there, he explains in this life beginning with deliverance(?). By the
akṣara pa the paramārtha-dharma as unobstructed, selfless, empty, extinguished. The completion for him is
deliverance(?). The akṣara la is to be known as the lakṣaṇas.
Not with those is the Buddha to be appropriated. There the dharma-kāya is without marks and characteristics.
Next, about the akṣara ba, (its) meaning is the viewing of pure equality. For whom his
dharmas are appropriated through folly, there for the knowledgeable ones they are all one and the same. About the akṣara ka, the meaning is he recognizes
the fruition of acts, when he neither obtains acts nor fruition, that is to be known as the confession of acts.
The akṣara called ja, its meaning is birth, aging, and death. They are all unoriginated, undestroyed,
unobtained, that is to be known as the understanding of the Law. About the akṣara dha, the meaning is dhāraṇīs and

displays, markless, empty, without desires, it is nirvāṇa-dharmathā(?). The akṣara śa is śamatha, extinction, the viewing of ..., the Law, empty (are) all the dharmas, exting-uished, there the samādhi is undisturbed. The akṣara kṣa is first extinguished, empty are all the dharmas, without essence, in which there is not a dharma the size of an instant. That is just pure nirvana. If nirvana was really uniform and possessed of guṇas, the Buddha
with all his hearers would enter into it with the assembly (of monks). Where the views have ceased altogether, notions, attachments,
and saṃskāras, there, there is no disturbance, (but) really nirvana. As for the restraint (śīla) (and)
saṃvara of the bodhisattvas, how is that to be known? How is one to stand in the command of the right *assembly of the buddhas of the three times?
It is said to you: How does he seem to you (who says): “Only I practice restrain; those are not practicing restraint”? He possesses bad śīla
... he who does not stand in the non-dual, pure, practice of restraint. He who perceives the dharmas as being without marks (nimitta?)
extended thus in the first khara(?), he is the upholder of the buddhas’ command. Like birds in the sky do not (...)
and do not ... the senses, for him monkhood is pure, faultless. He who does not obtain ... dharmas, for him (his) mind
will go right into (his) jurisdiction. He who does not think mind nor dharmas is to be known as close to bodhi. Then Vimalakīrti,
the exalted great bodhi-seeker, said: “Now I shall introduce Mount Sumeru all the way
into a mustard (seed), (and) neither will Mount Sumeru decrease, nor the mustard seed increase more than *before. Explain the meaning
to us now so far.” It is said to you: The mustard seed, that is to be known as views. Mount Sumeru (is) the Law
(and) stands undisturbed. By the Law that view ceases, and there is no decrease nor increase there. When, with knowledge,
one views it thus, then there is no dharma even the size of an instant. When the view is ... then ... in one and the same instant the Law
will stand. The flames of a lit fire will not be not supported on it ...
That is precisely the nature of the fire. When the samādhi stands undisturbed, (it is) just like the sky without clouds.

All the supports are lost, the notions, the attachments, the saṃskāras. Just like the Agniśauca garment, when they throw it into the fire, all its impurity is burnt (away), (and) the garment remains there clean.a Just so in that manner all the obstructions are burnt (away) by the fire of absence of vikalpas, (and) the bodhi-citta remains there pure. When the bodhisattva sees that unthinkable escape (and) extinction, it is just saṃsāra and saṃskāra, (then) (328) nirvana stands (there) pure.
Next the Licchavi king said to Vimalakīrti, the bodhisattva: He seizes all the roads(?) in the triple-thousand (world)
in (his) mouth. The four great oceans, which
are filled with water, all those he introduces into (his) stomach, he accomodated them without remainder.
All that such great power belongs to the bodhisattva so exalted.
Now convey to us the meaning (of that)! It is said to you: The ... are to be known as just mind,
..., flighty, *empty. All the ... in the triple-thousand (world), in the 500 ..., when
one looks at them, knowledge having arisen(?), all its career is destroyed, it becomes just mind (and) the samādhi stands
undisturbed. Those four great oceans are to be known in the knowledge of the buddha(s). All that knowledge, without remainder,
the bodhisattva introduces into (his) mind. There will be no ... there, not even the size of a hair, no disturbance (or) destruction.
They will career in the land of the buddhas just by the anābhoga career.
Then the good man Vimalakīrti at that time (said?): When not (even) one ... from the ten directions, (then) the bodhi-seekers
went thither. All ... thither in space great seats in count
8000. They all, without remainder, were accomodated on it. They sat down upon the seats in the ten
bhūmis, those bodhisattvas. And that house did not increase at all! How was that assembly accomodated on it?
It is said *to you: Vimalakīrti, for them this house(?) is of the sphere of the Law(?), pure. As for the seats and
the bodhisattvas, they are the dharma-kāya and (its) svabhāva, (and so) they are accomodated on the tip of one hair, (
all the buddhas of the three times together with all (their) buddha fields. The nature of the dharma-kāya is that very one. If, Vimalakīrti,
one oneself realized the release (vimokṣa) of the buddhas for the sake of compassion, a being would just appear
in the form of a layman. Then how would eons be introduced into instants or how fields into atoms? Please

listen to the meaning (of this), the great buddha mystery! It is said to you: Eons are to be known as just views. Views are introduced into an instant. Into whatever instant a view reaches, in the very same instant the Law (also) stands. ... in each instant all the buddhas of the three times together with (their) buddha fields
appear in an atom. Where there is no dharma not even the size of an instant, or no disturbance at all, then, he who sees that,
how does he see it? For the sake of compassion, tell us! It is said to you: It is altogether by viewing that one sees this right viewing.
Without viewing, how would Daśagrīva see the omniscient Buddha, and how (would) now Subhūti the elder
(see) the dharma-kāya? Through his own (?) faith before the Buddha. At that time he saw all the buddhas in full view.
And as he said in the omniscient sutra, in the Prajñāpāramitā: By absence of disturbance, by extinction, in that manner
we see the buddhas in full view. But how does the dharma-kāya stand (there) by absence of disturbance?
All the buddhas of the three times stand (there) in this samādhi, by the help of the production of the samādhi one can see all the lord buddhas.
He to whom it has first appeared thus, only nirvana stands (there) for him all (of it) (?). By the anābhoga career
he has completed the buddha works, he realizes best bodhi. In every instant he turns
the wheel for the sake of beings.
Then how did the five gatis arise, in which(?) one produces forms, sounds, natures, views.
Deign tell us how one may know it! It is said to you: Beings are to be known as just views. There are no real beings.
If there were beings in reality, they would not all be accomodated in the sarvaloka. Form is empty. Always, at all times emptimness. Only
he who (sees?) form and sound similar to ..., is wise there ... views ... going to the five gatis ... will stand(?)
He has cleaned all (in?) his mind. He who recognizes the citta-mātra, altogether (escapes?) from saṃsāra ... Then the kleśa kings and others(?):See Emmerick, 1977c. desire, anger,
folly, (as for) their *counteragents, how must one act? How does one overcome them? It is said to you:
That is to be regarded only as right memory, the nature of equality. Always at all times,
they become nirābhāsa. That (is?) mind. He who first produces various saṃskāras,
at the time of the samādhi he then stands (there) thus like water in a bowl. Then here at the time of illness ... career
is necessary. Teach us now that skill, expediency, how one may know it. It is said to you: The samādhi is to be regarded
as just devoid of vikalpas, pure, undisturbed. That is bodhi, just pure completion, deliverance. How
bodhi pleases ... in ..., do not ask this puzzle, just regard it as extinction,
un-..., unthought memory, in the future do not forget it at all! Being weary, seated, going in a litter,
perform acts! That which arises(?) by help of the production of ..., being awake needs(?) not be awakened. And in the end, he will then
there know everything rightly before his eyes by that anābhoga career. He who has devoted himself to it
however many steps he goes and strides, he goes all of them toward bodhi. When he recognizes the dharmas to be empty, like a dream,
a mirage, at peace, he knows the ... the first bhūmi. Just as he relinquishes life, thereby
he comes to the purified fields, either Sukhāvatī or Abhīrati or among the Tuṣitas, to Maitreya(?). By the help of the production of samādhi
he fulfills the ten bhūmis. And thus by non-obtaining ... dharmas ... he realizes best bodhi.
Those who are bound to the sphere of marks(?), foolish beings, at the time of the teaching of the Law, what(?) skill, expediency (is there) for them?
It is said to them: astīkavādika beings, for them women appear in reality. On account of desire
they go to ... They do not know the meaning of emptiness. For (by?) them medicines are taught to be not good, made of guṇas.

They must remember for the future that they do not have guṇas who shall know that all things are unoriginated. The body (is) ..., filled with impure members, ..., internally ... with breaths. They are 77
thousand, 60 billions. It is very great, which is so very impure, ...
with ... When it is grasped there through desire, that is the root of desire. Through views it is born. When one does not consider it in continuity thus desire it does not arise in the heart.
Like various forms in a dream, of men (and women are not and are stopped by awakening, thus are all the saṃskāras).

note.p: On the back of Chinese Saddharmapuṇḍarīka-sūtra. The “Invocation of Prince Tcū-Syau.” Lines 2-35 tr. Bailey, 1942, pp. 889, 891. Guide2 [18.32]. Lines 1-11 on PLATE 8a.

q.l: : mįsta rrįspūrą tcū syau hīye ājaṣąʾṇą namadryąną dista ni ṣṭau vā: dąsau
dīśaʾ vīra ʾauṇaṃdā drabāḍa ttaiṣṭaṃdi saumūhąʾ: jastauni jastą beʾysą
āspāvi nāsaumanai: beʾśa mįsta mahābūmaprrāpattā baudhasątva
arahaṃʾdą pūñudi śararṇą sątva: tta tti khū sąrbacį dīśaʾ jsa abīrya
vi lvidevi namau akṣauba jasta beʾysą āstani harbaiśa jistauną
jasta beʾysą: ravye pa dīśaʾ jsa namau rahnąkaitta jasta beʾysą āstaną:
haʾrbaiśą jastauną jasta beʾysą ñūhūjsadye dīśaʾ jsa namau armyā-
yi jasta beʾysą āstaną haʾrbaiśa jastauną jasta beʾysą: haudha raichau
pa dīśaʾ jsa namau daudūbeʾsvara jasta beʾysą āstaną harbaiśa jastauna
jasta beʾysą: uskyāṣṭa dīśaʾ jsa namau badiśrī jasta beʾysą āstani
haʾrbaiʾśa jastauna jasta beʾysą: nāṣṭa dīśaʾ jsa n{au}mau verauci jasta
beʾysą āstana harbaiśa jastą beʾysą: cu ra tta ttī dīśauʾ vīdaśauʾ jsa ʾau-
ṇaṃdā jasta beʾysą ʾīde: tta tta khū dirṇaidąra jasta beʾysa: śauttaidrai
jasta beʾysą: ciṃdaprraba jasta beʾysą: nārāyi jasta beʾysą 1
cu ra tti ttī mara myauña sąheʾ lāvadevi: rahnavyauhąʾmaṇḍala vauña rahna-
rāśaʾ ranīne ysāra-vārja śī vaiysa baidi ʾauṇadai: kṣaʾsa kala bau-
dhasatvaunau raudau jsa paiʾjsa: namau daśabąla-cakrravirtta mahākāraṇītta
śāstāra śākhyamauna jasta beʾysą āstana jastauna jasta beʾysa ʾīde:
cū ra ttą ttūṣyąʾ baviña ʾauṇade: mahādarmarāja-abaʾṣaikaprrāpattai
āryā-maittrai baudhasątva paḍauysña jsa: baiʾsta ysāra baudhasątvauna raudi
ʾīde: tta tta khū āryā-maittrai baudhasątva: āryāvalākattaiśvara baudhasatva
dra baudhasątva: āryā-vijrrapauṇą baudhasątva vī būrai: cū ra tta ttī haṣṭū-
sa sai śāstanābaibaraprrasādauna nāvauna raudi ʾīde tta tta khū nadi
upanidi: grahąʾvidattą: sūmąpauña: hūlūra. būjsaja ṣanīraka 2
cū ra tta ttī hauvani hauvana jaśta ʾīde: tta tta khū śakhīmaṃ: śaukacau-
mauṇyą: hārrva raivi draiṇḍa būma-dīvya: kathi-dīvya: rāja-dīvya: kūṣḍi-
dīvye jaśta vī būrai: ʾauda pa(dā)-rāysau daśāpālā jastau vī būrai: habai-
stani mara ṣacū kītha bīsā navāysvą devattą parvālā aśte hīye mi
prrabebā ṣṭārai: drai kūla hauvina hauvina pāraṣądā pāraṣṣadye
{kū ṣṭą tta saṃ ṣṭāvi harbaiśa vā vāṣa.}
hīyvā hīyvā jasta-bavinūā nāvi-bavanūā jastau beʾysāṃ ʾīñakä
dā pvaume beḍa: kūṣṭa tta saṃ ṣṭavi harbaiśa-v-ā vāṣṭa namadryana parya
avihāysye: marau vaska ṣṭau ttye dīśaʾ paiʾṣkala vī maista maṇḍąla-sthau
parī ayīṣ(ṭ)ye: ysarījai sye jsa paṣṭarda śadā: vara ṣṭau hva hva sarau-
vą bairkha pīla āysąna parī ayīṣ(ṭ)ye: harbaiśa ttā hīye hīye
nū byehąʾ paryara pārautte: ttu ttā dāyī darmadauna mestye mveśdaʾ jsa ā-
ṣaʾṇą paryara yuḍai: cu ma maista rraispūra tcū syau dra-vadya kṣaittrvā garkhyau
vaisthryāṃ pūñaṃ kūśalamūlyā hajsauma jsa tvārā hamya ʾīye: ttu
ṣṭau ttā dra-bāḍau ttaiṣṭadau jastau beysau beʾśa pīrmātta u tta tta prrabā-
devittau parvāl dirmadauni pīrī parąṇmye: ttye ttā dā-
yī dirmadauna pārjsai jsą uśa pįʾ ttīśaʾ hūṣauma paryāvį bī-
de: uśaʾdi ttīśauʾda ṣṭauna ttā dīdrma-vądya u cīka sąmāhau-
na paryāvi ra sąmāvąjį: cu būra jsau meʾsta rraispūrą tcū syau a-
rrve hvaḍa khaṣṭa parīye virąṣṭe ttai jsāṃ hā baudhasątvau uvāra
ttaradira beʾdi ṇe vī auśta vijsāṃde: tcause tcaurai hā garkha ā-
chā ttai jsāṃ hā baidāṣṭą kṣaʾṇą-mase rāśaʾ vaunīhaʾ ni byehīde 4
kaumye j ʾaiʾysa abeʾprrāyi pārjsa jsa ttu beʾsą prrīyga pasta
ʾī haṣkaude: ṣeʾ jsā ʾaiʾsą āvā thyau sījaume vī tsīye: parye ye śau
ñā tcacā śīga tsai na hyī
na jsāṃ śrī vījątti saṃgrauma raudi beʾysūñā bveyāṃ gavūā gavivaśe-
ṣṣa hamāvį sthaunavīśeṣa upattivīśeṣą jastau beʾysau u dā ų-
ysdīśākau pīsau kalyāṇąmaittrau jsa hagūjsa hamāve: haiysdą
vī jsāṃ theyi pa mestyau rraįspūrau rīysdvīre śau śī śarādryanā beʾmañā
hamāve: mista rrįspūra tcū syau hīyāṃ cāttuttai tcauṇḍąka āstaṃna
habāḍau parysāṃ vakṣaunarau ttyāṃ pā harbīśvā bāḍūā śarādryanā {one line}
baiʾmañā hamāve: galānaśailā āchanakau satvau āche jsa
pverāṣṭa naraumāṣṭa hamāve: haspīsadau jsau kṣauʾtvā būmvā
prrasaṃbvā rāśaʾ hamāve: ʾauṣka vī jsā draina ranau pārśaʾ pajsaṃ
avaṣṭa ga caḍāve: sadharma ttā dāra vasthu ʾī śāśaʾ pajsamaḍa
śade raysa sarbī sątvāṃ haura hadāra pīsaEmmerick for ms. pīña. pyālyai hūṣą tsīde:
kṣaijai hīña hīyi vā rāśa vaunīhā grau hamāve: na hamā harbī(śa) bāḍū ja va gārą

satva vīśauʾna ranąṇī hīsaume vīra {x} tsīde:
(vertically)
rba āchai ma na hamāvai daura hamāvai para
The imploration, invitation of the great Prince Tcū Syau ...
We take refuge with the lords of lord buddhas in the ten directions, of the three times, standing in full view, all the great bodhisattvas and arhats who have reached the great earth,
meritorious, well-doing beings. Thus, in the eastern direction, in the Abhīrati
world sphere, hail to the lord buddha Akṣobhya and all the other
lords of lord buddhas. In the southern direction, hail to the lord buddha Ratnaketu and
all the other lords of lord buddhas. In the western direction hail to the lord buddha Amitāyu
and all the other lords of lord buddhas. In the direction of the Seven Sages
hail to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara and all the other
lords of lord buddhas. In the upward direction, hail to the lord buddha Bhadraśrī and
all the other lords of lord buddhas. In the downward direction, hail to the lord buddha Vairocana
and all the other lords of lord buddhas,— and whatever lord buddhas there are sitting in the ten directions and subdirections,
for instance, the lord buddha Dirṇaidąra, the lord buddha Śāntendriya,
the lord buddha Candraprabha, the lord buddha Narāyaṇa. 1.
And whatever lords of lord buddhas are here in the middle of the world sphere Sahā, in the temple of the Ratnavyūhamaṇḍala,
in the Ratnarāśi(?), sitting on a bejeweled, thousand-petaled, white lotus, surrounded by 16 trillion bodhisattva kings, hail to the daśa-bala-cakravartin mahākāruṇika(?)
the teacher Śākyamuni and the other lord buddhas.

And whatever 20 thousand bodhisattva kings there are sitting in the dwelling of the Tuṣitas, mahā-rāja-abhiṣeka-prāpta, led by the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya: the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya, and the others: the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva Āryā-Mañjuśrī, the bodhisattva Āryā-Kṣitigarbha, the bodhisattva Āryā-Ākāśagarbha, the bodhisattva Āryā-Bhaiṣajyarāja, the bodhisattva Āryā-Samantabhadra, to the bodhisattva Āryā-Vajrapāṇi. And whatever eighty
hundred(?) śāstanābaibaraprrasāda nāga kings there are, such as Nada,
Upanada, Grahavidatta, Sūmapuṇya, Hulura, Bujsajsa, Ṣanīraka. 2.
And whatever very powerful goddesses there are, such as Śakhīmaṃ, Śaukacaumauṇya,
Hāritī ..., Dṛḍhā Deity of Earth, the Deity of the City, the Deity of Kings,
to the goddess Deity of the Palace. Finally, the gods protecting the directions. Altogether,
the protector deities inhabitants of the city of Shazhou, whose
images are here. For the three billions of very powerful lord buddhas in the various dwellings of gods and dwellings of nāgas belonging to the various asssemblies (of monks).
At the time of the hearing of the Law, wherever you may be, deign to cherish all our invitations!
Deign bless for us here the great maṇḍala-sthāna in the sections of that place!
The earth covered by golden sand, there deign to bless the individual lions, *wolves, elephants, seats!
Deign enter the various ... of them all! Deign make worthy through (your) great compassion this their dharma-dāna of the Law!
Whatever may have become here for the great Prince Tcū Syau conveyance(?) into the three fields through (his) accumulation of heavy, extended merits and roots of goodness,

that very foremost worship and acts of worship for the standing lord buddhas of the three times as well as the (acts of worship) such as prabhāsadharma-dhātu-spharaṇa-viśeṣa-samudgata, (that) deign to ripen (for him)! 3. The pāṇi(?)-jñāna-sambhāra of the bodhisattvas,
the dharma-dāna of the protecting deities may he deign to ripen (for him)!
He shall deign to find for him(?) by support(?) on their dharma-dāna power, strength, splendor, and growth!
And being powerful and strong he shall deign to produce (samāpad) for them (their?) so many kinds of and ... samādhis.
As many medicines, foods, and drinks the great Prince Tcū Syau may deign to prepare, (all) those ... on the exalted bodies of the bodhisattvas.
The forty-four severe illnesses will in an instant no longer obtain control over him. 4.
Supported on whatever ... abhiprāya he may have deigned perform, may this ... prayoga, this ... quickly go to success.
... may he have a gati-viśeṣa in the gatis of the buddha ... of King Śrī Vijita Saṃgrāma, a sthāna-viśeṣa, a upatti-viśeṣa!
May he have a meeting with the lord buddhas and the teachers of the Law, and (his) kalyāṇa-mitras!
May there immediately, O Theyi Pa, O great princes and princesses, be one ... of ... fortunes!
May there be, for the great Prince Tcū Syau’s ... and the other ..., for them at all times ... fortunes!
May there be for sickened beings full of illnesses separation and going away from the illnesses.
May he always, go to a gati *unattached (to the kleśas?) in the worship and service of the Three Jewels! ...

note.p: On the back of long (820x25 cm) scroll containing Chinese Mahāparinirvāṇa-sūtra. Lines 1-131 homage to the buddhas, lines 132-228 confession text.
Homage to the buddhas (“namo text”). Cf. Guide2 [18.6] (under Bhadrakalpika-sūtra). Cf. Or.8210/S. 2471, IOL Khot S. 46. Lines 1-10 on PLATE 8b.

q.l: sidham namau dvāsä kula gyasta baʾysi rahnautta-
ma nma biśūṃ namasūṃ nda haṣṭūsä kula
gyasta baʾysa rahnāvabhāsa nma biśūṃ namasūṃ
nda bistä kula gyasta baʾysa śikha nma bi-
śūṃ namasūṃ nda haṣṭa-sse gyasta baʾysa kana-
drai-sse kula gyasta baʾysa avibhāsąśrya nma biśūṃ namasūṃ
nda sparinau kula gyasta baʾysa pūṣya nma bi-
śūṃ namasuṃ nda dvāsä kula gyasta baʾysa kauṭiṃ-
ñä nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda dvī ysāri kula gya-
sta baʾysa kauṭiṃñi nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda
kṣiʾ-sse kula gyasta baʾysa vimalaprrabha nma biśūṃ
namasuṃ nda haṣṭi-sse ysāri gyasta baʾysa ʾiṃdri-
dhvaji nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda sparinau kula
gyasta baʾysa ʾiṃdradhvaji nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda
haṣta-sse gyasta baʾysa suprribhāsa nma biśūṃ nama-
suṃ nda nau kula gyasta baʾysa krrakasuṃda nma biśūṃ
namasuṃ nda haṣṭā kula gyasta baʾysa caṃdrisu-
ryaprradīpa nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda pa-ysā-
ri gyasta baʾysa prrādyautta nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda
pa-sse gyasta baʾysa prrattāpąna nma biśūṃ nama-
suṃ nda haṣṭa ysāri gyasta baʾysa nāgi n-
ma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda pa-ysāri gyasta baʾysa
ādittyi nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda haṣṭi-sse
ysāri gyasta baʾysa śimathi nma biśūṃ namasu
nda haṣṭa ysārra gyasta baʾysa sālarrāji n-
ma biśūṃ namasūṃ nda bisti kula gyasta baʾysa
kāśavi nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda sparinau kū-
la gyasta baʾysa śākyimųna nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda
dvāsä kūla gyasta baʾysa vipaśa nma biśūṃ nama-
suṃ nda haṣṭā kūla gyasta baʾysa svabhāta-dha-
rmauttara nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nda dasau ysā-
baʾysa himāre haṃbaʾci jsa tcihauʾsi kūla pīrma
haṣṭūsi kū lakṣaʾ byūrä haudi ysāri haṣṭi-sse. cuṃ ye
nma pyūṣḍe siʾ drayvā avāyvā paṃda basta ni ni narya
jsāte u ni prrīyvā ni ttrīśūṃʾ cvai sāje simād-
vaṃ jsi bāye ṣiʾ baʾysuśti jsa ʾiʾīsedai hime ni va-
baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe ni ni garkhyāṃ āchāṃ jsi
ma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe ni ni strīyi hi-
me ʾaudi baʾysuśte namau jñnaulkai gyastä baysä
namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe ni ni avīśiʾ mihānarī ysaṃ-
thi nāste namau aṣaṃgirrāji gyastä baʾysi namasuṃ cvai
nma hvñe ni ʾimauvuā byūmgvā u ni baṃdanaśālvā kaśte
namau anaṃttayaśi nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ. cvai n-
ma hvñe biśāṃ gaṃjsāṃ jsi pahaiṣṭi hime namau
meri nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe na-
rya ysaṃthi ni byehe namau mahāmeri nma gya-
stä namasuṃ cvai nauma hvñe prrīyvā ysaṃthi ni bye-
he namau amettameri nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ
cvai nma hvñe ttrīyiśūʾ ri ysaṃthi ni byehe
namau akṣųbhä gyastä baʾysä nimasuṃ cvai nma hvñe baʾśai
bisaṃgāṃ vī hvaḍi khaṣṭä anāvaraṇä gvaśte
namau rahniketti gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe ha-
ṣṭā kūla kalpa hajsāṃda karma baśdeʾ ttai biśä jāre
namau dudubhesvarä gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe
ttarī śirkä bijāṣä hame khu gyastųñi kūsi pvāʾhna:
ysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe harbiśāṃ biraijāṃ sai-
jmą byehe tsā hime suhye namau sudarśaṃ nma
gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe kalpasthva-v-ī karma baśdeʾ jāre dyena
caṃ gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe dāvnai ttaraṃ-
dari byehe namau gaṃdhauttąmä gyastä baʾysi
namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe ysaṃthvā-v-ī tturrna vasve upa-
lai spye hīya buśi nirme ni ni kūṭhiṃgvā ysaiye
śrī nma ttathāgattau namau padmahastau nma tta-
gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ nauda namau sarva-uttama-paripu-
namau anuttara-padma-vikrrąmi nma gyastä baʾysä naṃa-
suṃ nauda namau rahna-padma-vikrrąmi nma gyasti
baʾysä namasuṃ nauda namau rahna-garbhä nma
gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ nauda namau rahna-śikhi gya-
stä baʾysä namasuṃ nauda rahnauttąmi n-
ma gyasti baʾysä namasuṃ nauda namau
cu ttyāṃ gyastāṃ baʾysāṃ nma pvāʾve pa-
rī pīḍe ʾauʾ vāśeʾ anaṃttanirynī karmāṃ deśana hime
u didarū jsa parilauka bąña satva parsīdi khu gaṃgi ñāya
gruīcyau sya ni vara byąmā tcerā ñāpaṃdai tta tta pa:
namau krrakasuṃdi gyasti baʾysä vī na ʾauʾdi rūji gyasti
baʾysä vī buri ysāri paṃjsa bhadrakalpya gyasta baʾysa
masuṃ nauda namau dīpaṃkari gyasti baʾysä namasu
nauda namau rāji-grmai gyasti baʾysä namasuṃ nauda
namau tcauvabąnī gyasti baʾysi namasuṃ namau ditkabą-
nī gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ namau kauʾḍyāṃ gyastä baʾysä na-
masuṃ namau dvyīyaśāya bisai jasti baʾysī na-
masuṃ namau kṣįmaṃkarä gyasti baʾysa namasuṃ
namau hauymā gyastä baʾysa namasu namau maʾysakāṃ
akṣubhi gyasti baʾysi namasuṃ nda rrivye pa diśiʾ
jsa namau rahnaketti gyasti baʾysä namasuṃ ñūhujsaṃdye
diśiʾ jsa namau armyāyi gyasti baʾysi namasuṃ
uttarye diśiʾ jsa namau duṃdubhisvarä gyasti baʾysi namasuṃ
paḍauysye vidiśiʾ jsa dharaṇeṃdhari gyastä baʾysi namasuṃ
śeʾye vidiśiʾ jsa caṃdriprrabhi gyasti baʾysä naṃasuṃ haṃtsa
parṣäʾ jsa: didye vidiśiʾ jsa nārāyaṃ gyasti baʾ-
ysä namasuṃ nauda tcurmye vidiśiʾ jsa śāṃttiṃdri gyasti
baʾysä namasuṃ nauda uskyāṣṭi diśiʾ jsa bhadraśrī gya-
sti baʾysi namasuṃ nda nāṣṭä diśiʾ jsa veraucaṃ gya-
satvi namasuṃ namau ākāśagarbhi baudhasatvi na-
suvarṇaveṇḍu bhūje. meri bhūje. girūṇḍa bhūje.
attaṃga bhūje. suvarṇi bhūje. svārthä bhūje. sarva-
Welfare! Hail! The twelve billions of lord buddhas called Ratnottama,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighteen billions of
lord buddhas called Ratnāvabhāsa, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The twenty billions of lord buddhas called Śikhin,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred lord buddhas
called Kanakamuni, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The three hundred billions of lord buddhas called Avabhāsaśrī, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The ninety-five billions of lord buddhas called Puṣya,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twelve billions of lord buddhas
called Kauṭinya, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The two thousand billions of lord
buddhas called Kauṭinya, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The six hundred billions of lord buddhas called Vimalaprabha,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight thousands of lord
called Indradhvaja, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ninety-five billions of
lord buddhas called Indradhvaja, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The eight hundred lord buddhas called Suprabhāsa, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The ninety billions of lord buddhas called Krakasunda, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eighty billions of lord buddhas called Candrasūryapradīpa,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The five thousand
lord buddhas called Pradyota, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The five hundred lord buddhas called Pratāpana, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eight thousand lord buddhas called Nāga,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The five thousand lord buddhas
called Āditya, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred
thousand lord buddhas called Śamatha, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eight thousand lord buddhas called Sālarāja,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twenty billions of lord buddhas
called Kāśyapa, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ninety-five billions of
lord buddhas called Śākyamuni, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The twelve billions of lord buddhas called Vipaśyin, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eighty billions of lord buddhas called Svabhāvadharmottara,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ten thousand
lord buddhas called Prasannavadana-utpalagandhakūṭa, (34) I do homage to them all. Reverence!

(Whatever) buddhas there may be everywhere, altogether forty billions, eighteen lakhs, seventeen thousand, eight-hundred in front, he who hears their names, for him the path to the three apāyas is blocked, and he will not go to a hell, nor among ghosts or animals. He who learns them (and) brings them with ..., he can no more be turned away from bodhi. No doubt should be entertained there.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Uttarapradīpa! He who speaks his name will no more be afflicted by severe illnesses.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Jotisaumyagandhāvabhāsaśrī! He who speaks his name will no more become a woman until bodhi.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Jñānolka! He who speaks his name will no more take birth in the great hell Avīcī.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Asaṅgarāja! He who speaks his name will no more fall into misfortunes, contentions, or prisons.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Anantayaśa! He who speaks his name will be freed from all sins.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Meru! He who speaks his name will not obtain birth in a hell.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Mahāmeru! He who speaks his name will not obtain birth among ghosts.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Amitameru! He who speaks his name will not obtain birth among animals.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Akṣobhya! He who speaks his name ... will *distribute unobstructed food and drink to the bhikṣusaṅghas.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ratnaketu! He who speaks his name, whatever sins he has accumulated for eighty billions of eons, they will all be destroyed for him.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara! He who speaks his name will have as beautiful a voice as (that which is produced) by the striking of the buddha drum.

Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ratna-kusuma-guṇa-sāgara-vaiḍūrya-kanaka-giri-svarṇa-kāñcana-prabhāsa-śrīKnown from Suv (see Or.9609B2/1 v5-6).! He who speaks his name he will have success with all his crops, he will be wealthy, blessed.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Sudarśana! He who speaks his name, acts and sins (committed) for eons will be destroyed for him. He will be good-looking, graceful.
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Vairocana! He who speaks his name will obtain the body of the Law.

Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Gandhottama! He who speaks his name, throughout his births the perfume of the pure lotus flower will come out of his mouth. No more will he be born among the leprous.
Hail! to the lord buddha Sūrya-maṇḍala-prabhāsa-śrī I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Sarva-uttama-paripūrṇa-lakṣaṇa-kāya-gātra I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Sarva-samādhi-rutta-vikrama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-kusuma-samantā-anantāvabhāsa-śrī I do homage! (Reverence!)
Hail! to the lord buddha Anuttara-padma-vikrama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-padma-vikrama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-garbha I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Ratna-śikha I do homage! Reverence!
(Hail!) to the lord buddha Ratnottama I do homage! Reverence!
Hail! to the lord buddha Sarva-ratna-pratimaṇḍita-rūpa-dhārī I do homage! Reverence!

He who may hear the names of these lord buddhas, orders them to be written, or speaks (them) will obtain the confession of sins (even) in the ananta-naryas. And so many beings *bound in the next world will escape from them as there are grits and sands in the river Ganges. No doubt should be entertained there. ... I do homage to the 1005 bhadrakalpika lord buddhas, from hail! the lord buddha Krakasunda to the Lord Buddha Rūja(?). Reverence! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Mahā-śākyamuni! Reverence!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Dīpaṃkara! Reverence!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Rāja-grāmaka! Reverence!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Tcauvabąnī! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ditkabąnī! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Kaulyāna!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha dwelling in Dviyaśāya(?)!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Kṣemaṃkara!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha of the hauymas(?)! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha of the maʾysakas(?)!
In the eastern direction I do homage to the lord buddha
Akṣobhya. Reverence! In the southern direction,
hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Ratnaketu. In the western
direction, hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Amitāyu.
In the northern direction, hail! I do homage to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara.
In the first subdirection I do homage to the lord buddha Dharaṇiṃdhara.
In the second subdirection I do homage the lord buddha Candraprabha together with
his assembly. In the third subdirection
I do homage to the lord buddha Nārāyaṇa. Reverence! In the fourth subdirection
I do homage the lord buddha Śāntendriya. Reverence! In the upward direction
I do homage to the lord buddha Bhadraśrī. In the downward direction
I do homage to the lord buddha Vairocana. Reverence! Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Ākāśagarbha!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara! Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Mañjuśrī!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Bhaiṣajyarāja!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Samantabhadra!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Vajrapāṇi!
(Skt.:) Hail to the laukyidārtha buddha bhagavāns standing in the ten directions. Tad-yathā ...

note.p: Confession text also found in Ch.00277 (IOL Khot S. 18) and Ch.xlvi.0013a (IOL Khot 56/1). Synop-tic text and translation in Emmerick, 1977a. Guide2 [18.34].

msIdentifier.idno: Ch.00269 (C 61): KT II, p. 42 (9); SD IV/LXXX-LXXXIX; SD, TV, p. 107

note.p: On the back of “Laṅkāvatārasūtra” (Enoki). Lines 23-108 letter from Chikä Gūlai and Dūṃ Saṃgalakāṃ, lines 109-20 letter from the seven princes.

q.l: / x carä ka x x x
|| mistai rraispū[ri] tta parī hau kṣaṇyä — uvāryau garkha —
va cā rä kai harrda .. uvārya garkha pūñā krraña ña
gūhą salya vā — haurdya — stai stai stai stai stai
.. haudyāṃ rrispūrāṃ rrvī vīrāṣṭā au[rrā]sä ha stai sta
: uvāryā gakha: na ma yi śau ysatha ṣṭā ñātti pūrä . ra
uvāryā garkhā vaisthāryā pu — ra ra ra ra
āśaʾrī kaiṇa rrva va c ṣanīrä śvai: {x x} prraphākaravarda —
.. uvāryāṃ garkhyāṃ pūñau vaisthāryau kūśalamūlyā jsä haphvai ya mistai
sī thū ttayaśī mārgpadaiśai ttravīlai āśaʾrī prrañīdrākarava-
rrda dī pākā naysdä grāṃ brrīystä aysamū jsä aurga drūnā
pūaiʾsāma haṣḍä yanä ña[śa] bīsa ttravīlai prravākaravarrda
khū vā ña[śa] bīsä kṣīra ā dyāmai jsa gvaṣṭū āda ma vaña būrai hī-
yai hīye pūñau kuśalā-mūlyā jsa dākha ma naiśtä
: uvāryau garkha vaisthāryau pñau kųśäla-mūlā jsa haphve yi mistye si thū tta-
yi-śī mārgabūde[śai]. tträvīlai āśäʾrī prrañaidrākaravarrda dī pākā au-
rga drūnā pvaisā .. śtä ṣṭā na mīre ca ma ṣṭā jūhaiʾtte ve . ttī va jsā ttūā
dakhä ṣṭārä avyācä . || uvāryā garkhā vaisthāryā pūñā kuśaʾlamū-
lā jsā haphve: aurrāsä haṣḍä sī ca —
ñauysairä brrī pyarä ṣau staḍesä u mirä eysājai vīdyeheʾ u paysā-
va hvārakä eysāja paḍa tcūkye . u eysāja kha cūlye dī pākā aurga
In the Year of the Ox ...
Report by the seven princes to the court ...
With outstanding, heavy ... one birth, kinsman, sonKumamoto, 1993, p. 157. ...

I do reverence to with a mind of warm love near the feet of the great Sī Thū, the dashi mārgōpa¬deśaka traipiṭika, the reverend Prajñendrākaravardha, endowed with exalted, heavy merits (and) extensive kuśalamūlas, and asking about his health, I, his lowly servant, make a report:
How have I, his lowly servant, become separated from the view in the land of the traipiṭika Prajñendrākaravardha. So far, I have no suffering because of my merits and kuśalamūlas (?).

I do reverence to with a mind of warm love near the feet of the great Sī Thū, the dashi mārgōpa¬deśaka traipiṭika, the reverend Prajñendrākaravardha, endowed with exalted, heavy merits (and) extensive kuśalamūlas, and asking about his health. *Why do I not die ... (?). And my suffering has no remedy (?).

I, miserable, make a report at the feet of my dear father, the ṣau Staḍesä(?), and my mother, the lady Vidyehe. and my own sister, the lady Paḍa Tcū Kye, and the lady Kha Cū Lye, asking about their health.

note.p: Letter from Chikä Gūlai and Dūṃ Saṃgalakāṃ (also in IOL Khot S. 18, Ch.00327), see Kumamoto, 1991a, p. 111, as well as passim for citations from this document. See also Or.8212/162.

q.l: aurrāsi haʾṣḍä .. aurrāsä haṣḍä stai aurrāsä haṣḍä
.. aurrāsä haṣḍä bīsä chikä gūlai u dūṃ saṃgalakā {ha} khu vā ña-
śāṃ bīsāṃ kąmäcū āṃ rrvī parau pastāṃdä si kąmäcū būrāṃ rrispūra
bāyñä. u ñaśāṃ bīsāṃ tta tta parau nä ye si ami ttyāṃ tsvākāṃ rrispū-
rāṃ hīvī pamūhä: u stūra spāśarä u khu jsāṃ ñaśa bīsa radnahä: ā-
vaṃdūṃ khu spāṣṭāṃdūṃ stūra u śau ri va rrispūrāṃ hīvī aṃʾmägaʾ ni mūṃde biśä
pahaiya cū stūra ttyāṃ jsāṃ hervī aśparä ni hauḍāṃdä u ñaśä ra ttā bīsa
vaṣṭi vī haṣḍä nä yuḍä yuḍāṃdūṃ si khu ttā haṣḍä yināṃ si stūra gauda
ṣṭāre kaṇāṃ tta tta parī paśte si bīsāṃ āṃ nä kṣami tsve u nva parau tsvāṃdūṃ khu
jsāṃ paṃdāyi vistā hamyaṃdūṃ varä jsāṃ va väṣṭā hīya śaṃdā ni ya u paṃ-
dāyi snāṃ hīvī pvąʾnä u khu jsāṃ stahä: biśīʾ āvaṃdūṃ varä na cimū-
ḍāṃ jsa haṃgvāṃdūṃ audä ṣacū būrä cū paḍā paḍāSD, TV, p. 108: paḍä paḍā. bisā mahe yaṃdūṃ u rri-
spūra mahe svahäkṣeṃ ṣacū āvaṃdūṃ cvāṃ va nū stūra harya vaʾstairma u hvąṇḍä
u herä u hvaihū:ra ttāṃ biśä cimūḍa hatcastāṃdä cū jsāṃ stūra ya ttāṃ jsāṃ
biśä paṃdāyi vaʾstā tsvāṃdä u tta tta āṃ harya. cū gūmattīrai rrispūrä hī-
ya drayi ula ya tta śaula na parye hamye ttaṃdī ra ṣacū śe vaʾstairmä aśä jsa ā
cū śeʾye rrispūrä stąmä hīya ula ya draya u aśa dva {tta} ṣiʾ ttaṃdī ṣacū śau
aulä ājiṃde ysbaḍäparrūṃ na ṣacū būrä biśä pāyai tsve. cū rrispū-
rä thiyä tcnä hī{vī}ya tcaura ula ya ṣiʾ ttaṃdī ṣacū śau aulä ā cvai cimūḍvā
gūmaistāṃdūṃ. cū rrispūrä yįnakä hīya kṣaʾ ula ya ttä ṣacū drayi āva
u śau aśä. cū rrispūrä śvakalai hīyai ttaṃdī ṣacū śau aulä ā. drvāttīrai
hiye hīvī aulä cvai tcirthūśī jsa giryāṃdä ṣaʾ ttaṃdī dva paḍyehä: śau haḍā
tsva hamye śau-v-ai ra vā aśä ā.
cū hirä śirä dīrä cū vā būḍāṃdūṃ cvāṃ
maṃ dīśta ye ttū cimūḍāṃ padaṃja hauḍāṃduṃ cvāṃ jsāṃ mvaṃ harye ttū jsāṃ cimūḍa ha-
tcastāṃdä u ṣacū ra ttūśā-dastā āvaṃdūṃ stūra jsāṃ vaʾstā tsvāṃdä u ja cū pā
gūmattīrai hiye hīvī draysä bidä ttūrkä uha: hīvī rrvī śkyesä ye ttū
pā biśä cimūḍa buḍāṃdä. khu vā ñaśāṃ bīsāṃ parau pastai ya paśte si
paṃdāyāṃ tta tta tta cimūḍa ṣṭāre ñaśa bīsai ñąmsä phara bvma sti si tta ttāṃ
tsñī ttaṃdī v dasauda corr’d from dra (B.). radnahä: haḍā byaudāṃdūṃ ya śe tcaṃjsä biṃdāṃ maṃ-
gārī ni hamīya ttaṃdī-v-āṃ gārī tta tta hamye cu śa paḍā yaṃdūṃ u vaʾstairma
dva u tta tta hatcastaṃdūṃ cū ttūra ttāttāhä: uhaḍpī tta ñña ñña hirä rau-
stāṃdä u haṃ bāḍä hvaihuʾra jsāṃ vā drayi aśi ājiṃdāṃdä cū nayū chā-
rä nma sūlī ṣaʾ jsāṃ vā śau tcaṃjsä ni ājiṃde ttye stūra biśä ja u herä garvā
pace khu rri hā ā u tcaṃjsä rä va ni byaude biśai cimūḍa thīyāṃdi bnai ma ṣṭi
khu jsāṃ ṣacū vāṣṭä stūrāṃ kįṇa saṃgalakā parye varä jsāṃ va stūra biśä kämä-
cū hñä haṣṭāṃdä śau stūrä ni byaudeṃ. khu ñaśa bīsa ṣacū āvaṃdūṃ cu hīna ya ttye śaʾ māśtä ya tta ñña dasau paṃ-
jsūsä haḍā parya u hna ttī āva cu baʾgarakä attęmä ūha: uha ya
vairä uha: uha: uha: u kṅūrapa sah:nä uha: . u bīrūkä cnä
ttāhä: u bīrūkä {tta vā baiśä mara} dūṃ ttāṃga u saraihä: chārä aha:cī mīṅamūkä bīrūkä
tta vā ṣacū-pavnye haṃtsä hīñä jsa pahaisā ṣacū vāṣṭä hāysa tsvāṃdä tta tta cū
pātcä kąmäcū bisai khahą:nä jsāṃdi {cī} u ttaysī dagyįnä hā ṇaʾstāṃdä ttī m
biśä bādna ārrä ttyāṃ pahaisāṃ īḍāṃdä si cu āṃ maṃ mñāṃ bāḍä vī ā-
phājä ni jāre amnī ārrä ṣṭe
ttī {jsāṃ baʾgarakä kąmäcū bisā ha:hą:nä hī-
ya jaśtä saʾśe u maista-ujai hamya ttī jsāṃ ttā ṣacū bis hna tta tta haṃgāre
si ci burä kąmäcū hauvausta hvaihura īṃde tta biśä jsanāṃ u ajsāṃ sūhä: —
cū bisai uha: khįṇḍä tcirthūśī ñ u kaṃthi jsāṃ ṣacū vāṣṭä spāśe u ha:-
hą:na ra jsāṃ va nä hame u khvai bādna ttū herä bausta} u tta vā hvąṇḍä śaṃdā
tta tta paśāṃdä cv-aṃ hvaihura biśä āṣṭaṃdāṃdä jsąnä cu hvaihu:ra tta baiśä
hama hamya natca kīthāṣṭä naraṃda kīthi ra va ttaṃdī dūṃta īṃdä ttyām jsāṃ kītha v{ī}a nä
khāysä u nä stūra. viña maṃ śā tvaḍa māśtä hamya u hirvī ra vā phara na
ra hīśtä si kīthi va khu ṣṭe cu biḍagā sahnä ṣaʾ pā haṃtsa hvaihu[rāṃ] jsa hamye
cu vā baʾgarakä jsa haṃtsa hvąṇḍä pahaiya tta vā hirvī nārä pūra na paṃʾmaʾ-
cu jsāṃ kąmäcū bādna tta vaña drai pacaḍa ṣṭāre
cū ttūḍīśa u ttūrkä bayarkāva u hāttäbara u īcä iṃjūva tta yīpäknä ttahä: u beḍä-
darūkä ṇaʾsta ṣṭāre ci buri hvaihu:ra tta biśä karattahä: ṇaʾsta u karattaha
cu dūṃva u cahä:spata u sūlya tta jsāṃ kītha khu tta viña drai pacaḍa biśä haṃtsa
ni samīṃde kąmäcū hā hervī haḍä ni ttraṃdä hame śālai āphāje u śālai jsāṃ va
khāysä niśtä. khu ṣacū kītha hna biśä āva hamya u khu hauda haṣṭa haḍā pa-
rye hamya ttī hā mahe tcirthūśī vīrāṣṭä u baʾgarakä vīrāṣṭä tta tta salā paśāṃdūṃ
si cū rrispūra ṣṭāre tti āśiʾrya ṣṭāre ttyāṃ hirvī snä niśtä mahe paḍā paḍā śau
dva kąmäcū vāṣṭä hvąṇḍä paśāṃ u śirä dīrä hīya vā phara spāśāere u mahe
pā tsāṃ. mara vā pā ṣacū tta tta hvāṃdä si hirvī va gaṃjsa niśtä paśarä hvąṇḍä u miśta
hveʾ ni jsāve u ganamai āṣṭaṃdāṃdūṃ haysä.
u ttī vā baʾgarakä attęmä uha: dūṃ
saṃgalakā va hvąṇḍä haṣṭe u gurṣṭai biśāṣṭä u tta tta vā hveʾ si khu āṃ viña kąmäcū
vāṣṭä hvąṇḍä paśarä aśte vīra āṃ jsāve cu uhū:ysä uha: ye cu rrvī parau yi-
nīya u pharāka rrvīya muʾśdäʾ nāve ṣiʾ muḍä cu pā ttattayä uha: ṣiʾ pā muḍä ca-
raihä: uha: jsāṃ kmyāṃ garvā kūśīmʾdä ajsāṃ u ahacī ṣaʾ ṣṭāṃ ṣacū ci jsāṃ hą:nä
ṣiʾ jsāṃ vilakä ṣṭe ttye hīvī viña parau hamidā kathi vīra ni jsāve vina ttikye cu ttā hveʾ
jsāve u paṃdāyai ttattara jsanīṃdä khu ī kąmäcū kmyāṃ nitca kītha bisāṃ hvaihu:-
rāṃ jsa haṃgūjīṃde tti kṣųna mūḍa hvaihura ṣṭāre tti viña hamidā hīya nūvarä
byehīṃde nvaśtai ni paśīṃdä kūṣṭä burä bāḍä hīya naiṣkaica ni hamāve hervī saṃ
śe hvąṇḍye paṃda niśtä. uha: tta tta hveʾ si ya āśiʾrya pā ttūśā-dastā tsīṃdä paṃda-ṃ
cī bāye khu hvaihu:ra ni hamāṃde cī-y-aṃ bāye. haṃtsa aśte jsa tsīṃdä vina ttikye cvaṃ na-
tca kītha bisā hvaihura u cimuḍa ni jsanīṃde ttī-v-aṃ biśä pasavālā padįmāre haṃdi-
raṃ va pacaḍä naiśtä. tti rruṃdä hīya pūra ṣṭāre tta tta śtāka ṣṭāre khu ciṃgvā hīsīṃdä khvaṃ
va vira śikä hamāte ā viśūṃʾ ṣąʾ mārā-pyarāṃ bāḍä ṣṭe mara hvaihū:rāṃ cimuḍāṃ hīya
bīsa hamāṃde tvāka viśʾna nma cī bīḍä. paṃda hīvī maṃ pacaḍä daṃ-mäsū ṣṭe ña-
śāṃ jsāṃ vā bīsāṃ hairthaṃ vī paṃda hamya hirvī ra vā hirä ni paṃmuḍä yuḍāṃdūṃ cu jsāṃ vā
dilakä dilakä būḍä hamye ṣʾ jsāṃ biśä cimūḍvā u ṣacū nva padaṃji bāstä tsve hirvī-v-āṃ
ri maṃ herä niśtä. khu viña tta pve kąmäcū bāḍä hamāte biśä hā haṃdara bāḍa-
dījsā nūvara uha:va u bīrūka ñīṃdä ttyāṃ biśä śikñä jsāve khu jsāṃ paṃda prri-
hīśtä. cu maṃgāra hvąṇḍä cu pharāka rrvīya muʾśdäʾ nāṃdä tta baiśä ja.
nma ṣṭe si hauda vā rraispūra āva u ciṃgvāṣṭä mista haḍa u kṣaʾ-sse kįṇa īrä
u ni ra maṃ bāymai hirä rrispūrāṃ aśtä u nä haḍāṃ. {viña tt˝} khv˝m˘ v˝ viña rrvī vī nva jast-
ñe bvme śau parau hīśtä si khu dilakä herä nä hamāve vina herä ṣiʾ paṃdä na
nirve hame ā paʾjsä maṃ anvaśtä hamye. .. rrva vī vara ttą haṣḍi yąne ñaśa
Information and report of the servant Chikä Gūlai and Dūṃ Saṃgalakāṃ. When to us, humble
servants in Ganzhou they sent a royal order: “you must lead the princes to Ganzhou,”
the order was not “you must see to the clothes and pack animals of of the traveling princes.” And when (we) the humble servants came to Radnahä:,
when we (went to) see to the pack animals, then not one of the princes’ monastery servants remained. All
had fled. The pack animals they had they had given no fodder at all. And we humble servants too
were not able to make a report to you in the vaṣṭa that we are not reporting to you that the pack animals are emaciated.
He orders the kaṇas to say “the servants do not wish to go,” and we went according to the order. When
we had set out upon the road, it was not there the earth of ... and on the road
(there was) fear of enemies. And when we came to Stahä: Biśīʾ, there
we got into company with some CimūḍasSee Hamilton, 1977. all the way to Shazhou. Whatever formerly of servants we ... and the princes,
we came to Shazhou in *safety. Whatever accordingly(?) pack animals remained for us, vaʾstairmas—men
and provisions—and the Uigurs, all of those the Cimūḍas broke up(?). Whatever pack animals we had,
all of those had gone on the road *frightened, and thus they remained. As for the prince from Gūmattīra, he
had three camels—not a single one had gotten away—and he made it to Shazhou with only one vaʾstairma horse.
As for the second, Prince Stąmä, he had three camels and two horses. He brought only one
camel to Shazhou. From Ysbaḍä Parrūṃ to Shazhou he went all on foot. As for Prince
Thiyä Tcnä, he had four camels. Only one of them made it to Shazhou, which we *mingled among (those of) the Cimūḍas. As for Prince Yiṃnakä, he had six camels. Three of them made it to Shazhou
and one horse. As for Prince Śvakala, only one of his camels made it to Shazhou. The master of Drvāttīra’s
camel, which they had bought from the jiedushi (military governor), it was able to go only two ... in one day.
And only one of his horses made it here.
Whatever good or inferior merchandise we had, which we had brought here, which
was in my hand, that we gave to the Cimūḍas as padaṃjā. Whatever ... remained for us, that the Cimūḍas
broke up. And we came to Shazhou empty-handed. The pack animals had gone off *frightened and were lost. Next, as for
the royal gift of the Turkish councilor (öge) in the pack of the master of Gūmattīra, that
the Cimūḍas then carried off. If you had deigned order us humble servants that
“on our (your?) road there are ... Cimūḍas,” (then) we, the humble servants, *would have understood* his ... speech, that ‘so we
have to go,’” (and then) in only ten days we would have reached Radnahä: (and) there would not be upon us here one hair’s (worth of) quarrel. Only, we began to quarrel, because one former ... and
two vaʾstairmas, and thus we broke (them) up. As for Ttūra the ttāttāhä: (toto©) (and) Uhaḍpī (Üg(ä)alpï), they lost (their) merchandise ...
And at the same time the Uigurs brought us three horses. As for Nayū Chārä,
a *Sogdian, he did not bring us a hair. His pack animals were all lost. And the merchandise

he had hidden in the mountains when the king(?) came there, and he did not find a hair there; The Cimūḍas had dragged it all off. Naked here he is. When Saṃgalakāṃ escaped hither to Shazhou (to look) for pack animals, all the pack animals there

they had sent to the army in Ganzhou. I did not find a single animal. When we, humble servants, came to Shazhou, whatever army there was, it was (already) the second month for it. Thus ... ten, fifteen
days passed since they went to Ganzhou, and the army then came. As for the officer (buyruq) Attęmä ūha: uha ya
Vairä uha: uha: uha: and Kṅūrapa Sah:nä uha: and the officer Cnä Ttāhä: and the officer Mīṅamūkä, Dūṃ Ttāṃga and Saraihä: Chārä Aha:cī,
they, now, (being) fugitives with an army of Shazhou’ese, they went away (and came back) here to Shazhou. Thus, because
afterward they slew the Khagan and placed there the tàizi (‘ w) Tegin, so then
all the bādūnas (buduns) blamed these fugitives that “as long as we have dwelt here the disturbances in the land
have not ceased (and) that is your fault!” Then Begrek
*made love to the Lady of the Khagan in Ganzhou, and she became *pregnant. Then he *addressed the army in Shazhou:
“However many powerful Uigurs there are in Ganzhou, we will slay (and) ... them all!
Let the jiedushi sit in the manner of the councilors in Suzhou. From the city he sees to us here in Shazhou. And
there will not be a xa©an, either!” And when the Buduns learned about his doings} And then the men
just abandoned the land, because the Uigurs began killing them all. For the Uigurs
were all the same! The went outside the city, and in the city there are only the dūṃs, and in the city they have neither
food nor animals. Now it has been more than a month here, and still no word
is coming about how it is in the city. As for Biḍagā Sahnä (Bilgä sa©un) he was next with the Uigurs,
and the men who were with Begrek fled. And a wife could not at all *protect (her) sons.Somewhat different translation in Kumamoto, 1991a, p. 112.
Naked they came here. As for the buduns in Ganzhou, they are now three factions.
As for the Ttūḍīśa and Ttūrkä Bayarkāva and Hāttäbara and Īcä Iṃjūva, they are seated at Yīpäknä Ttahä: and Beḍä-Darūkä
All the Uigurs are seated at Karattahä: and Karattaha.
As for the dūṃs and *robbers and *merchants,See Studies II, pp. 148-49. they (are) in the city. As those three factions now all
do not agree together, no envoy can enter Ganzhou at all. On one hand there is chaos, on the other hand
there is no food there. When the entire army had come to Shazhou and when seven eight days had passed,
then we sent word there to the jiedushi at the court and to Begrek at the court
that “the princes who are here are reverend ones; they have no enemies at all; let us tentatively
send one or two men to Ganzhou and let them investigate what is said of good and bad, and we
will go then.” But then they said here in Shazhou that “that’s no problem at all; send (your) men! but the greater
man shall not go!” And we began to send him wheat. But then Begrek Attęmä the councilor dūṃ sent men
to Saṃgalakāṃ and invited him to his house. And he said to us: “How
can you now send a man to Ganzhou? On *what shall he go? He who was U©uz councilor, he since died. Caraihä:
uha: they seek among whatever(?) mountains. And Ahacī, he is (in) Shazhou. He who is khan,
he is still a child. At present his order does altogether not go in the city. The man who goes without him,
him the ttattaras will kill on the road. How (is it?) today(?) in Ganzhou? Whatever Uigurs
they meet living outside the city, those Uigurs are (almost) dead of hunger. At present they altogether
get to examine their own(?) new ones. They do not send (them off). Wherever there is no detailed knowledge(?) of the road,
there is no road even for a single man!” So the councilor said: “... so the reverend ones will go empty-handed!
Who will lead them along the road? If there are no Uigurs, who will lead them? With what will they go? Without him, because(?) the Uigurs living
outside the city and the Cimuḍas will not kill them. They will make them (mere) *shepherds!
There is no other way for them. They are the king’s sons. Thus they are obliged. If they get to China, if
it is well for them there or bad, it is their parents’ land. Here
they will become the servants of the Uigurs and Cimuḍas. Who will bear such an evil name!” That is the extent of the state of the road here. Suddenly there was a road
for (your) humble servants, but we were not able to report anything to you, because
one could only ride in very small stages(?). All this stuff he conveyed among the Cimuḍas to Shazhou according to the custom(?). It is gone.Somewhat different translation in Kumamoto, 1991a, p. 112.
We have nothing at all here. As I now hear, it will be time for Ganzhou. All different
new land-keepers, councilors and officers are settling themselves there. For them all will go well, if only the road is opened.
As for the old men, who received many royal favors, they are all destroyed. Then there is a great
name (= rumor?): “Seven princes have arrived and great envoys to China and 600 jin jade!”
But neither the princes nor the envoys have anything to bring(?) any more. If to us to the court (in Shazhou?), according to the royal
knowledge now one order comes that “if there is not even the smallest thing (left), without anything that road can not be
broken open or it was very difficult for me.

note.p: Letter from the seven princes. New hand from line 112.

q.l: .. rrvī vī vara ttą haṣḍi yąne -: rra — hve sagai —
.. rrvī vī vąrä tta hąṣḍi yanāṃ —
.. haudä rrispūra. mähe vā rrvīye dyme pyatsa auna nąradadū si gūttauṣąnä tsāṃ
.. parauvāṃ tta tta ye sä ṣacū va bvaiysą na mūñarä khu ttā cąpastąkä dīśtä haṣḍi yūḍāṃ-
dūṃ. kąmäcų va viña būrikyä na ra raysde. mñāṃ jsāṃ stūrä baiśä ją cīvarā jsāṃ je
nma [x x]B. [na ra]. stūrāṃ va aśtä herä u na cīvarä vaska. na jsāṃ pā ṣaiʾkä caṃ jsą kamäcu {ā} naradä
hamāṃ. cu jsāṃ pā ttayą-śāṃ hīyą strä yą tta p ją. ną rä stūrāṃ va aśtä herä
u nä cīvarä. na ra jsāṃ ma chīkä prramāṃ īdä stra ū ną ḍū pūhą:yą. khu pā
śvahvā hīsāṃ pātcāṃ maṃ na ciṃgä rruṃdä vaską śkyesä u ną pīḍąkä. hvaḍa khaṣṭä vaską herä
ṣṭāṃ pā hīye jsve. khvāṃ v läkä mvaiʾśdä haraysde. viña būrä va kamäcu pharāka
hvaṇḍä mūḍą hamyą. na jsāṃ va {hąṣḍa}. khāysä khu vā ttī parau hīsīye si {tsūṃ hva me ṣi}
khu dāña ttrāmāñä hamāte ąysnā paskyāṣṭä ną bāyāṃ
We make a report to the court.
The seven princes, we went out in front of the royal sight (saying) “we are going to gūttauṣąnä.”
The order was for us “do not stay long in Shazhou.” When we gave Capastaka a report for you,
till now he has not yet directed (us) to Ganzhou. All the animals our men had are lost. Our clothes are lost.
... there is for the animals, nor for clothes. A there is no one with whom we can get out (and go to?) Ganzhou.
And the animals Ttaya-śāṃ had, they were since lost. There is nothing any more for the horses,
nor any clothes. Neither Chīkä the prramāṃ nor Ḍū the puye has any animals. How (can) we then
come to Shuofang, since we have neither gift nor letter for the Chinese king? Things for food and drink
will go ... How can even so much(?) favor extend to us? Till now there in Ganzhou many
men have died. We have no food. How were then an order to come? How can we have to enter a fire (from which) we can not bring ourselves back!

note.p: On the back of Chinese Vajracchedikā. Conservation paper now covers some of the right margin.

q.l: (look like vertically written very cursive Khotanese)
tcaurya sagrāvasau jsa cu au vvī jsa phara satta : ysathūā ysathūā hūḍai
vasva hauḍa pharaka baista jsā hā prraṇahauna ysatha ysatha uvāra :
pūñau jsai jsāṃ sījṃda : tta prraṇahauna raysga vī : hamye ttaya-śī
baista tcaina pa ṣauʾ pīsai kūra (diff. hand) cu au pīrī ja satta a brraṣṭa naravauṇa kītha-
ṣṭa: aska jsa bāye vāra yauda khve na jsāvai va harga : vāra vaska maista pai ttaya-śī
pauṇeprrasa : cau au pūrau kheṇḍi kai hūṣeʾ jsīye jsīna : bvaysa bāḍa sauhaʾ
jsa: {māhā} lyaye phara vīra gū x danya vīrai : mahā yaudā {bāya raṣṭa}
{ba} bāya raṣṭa dasa khaṇḍa aihaʾ : vīnīyā kūñāṃ je darya ysamaśadai vī
cva au hā gītta pada naravauṇa kītha ṣṭa : thaiya ttīka javaittapūña bīśau
bvejsāṃ ha[x]pha : brrā naṣaʾgaista prrabauda-vada : haʾra hvaña tcaṣu : prruña-
dai pañai brrī ṣadū śakalaka : thaiya ttīka pūñadrajaya bīśau bvajsāṃ
... like the path of the standing buddhas.
... with the four saṃgrahavastus, all the many beings ... In births after births he(?) gave
many pure *gifts. He bound to them exalted vows in birth after birth.
May they succeed for him on account of (his) merits, those vows, quickly. The dashi himself
bound (vows), Tcaina pa, he our teacher. Whoever writes ... to the city of Nirvana.
He leads from on high always ... How can he not go to release, for ... the great Pai dashi
Pauṇeprrasa? ... like moons(?) if his life increases. For a long time in happiness,
in ... Lead us always like a straight thread to the mouth (of deliverance?). The vaineya ... in the whole world
for him who helps them there is a path to the city of Nirvana. The dade Javaittapūña equipped with all merits, awakened, having recognized the path(?), speaking ..., splendid, *shining,
dear to every one, full of faith, very nice. The dade Pūñadrajaya ... with all merits ...

note.p: On the back of Chinese Vajracchedikā. Lines 1, 6b, d, 8 (left) in large bold formal script. Conservation paper now covers some of the right margin.

q.l: || ṣiʾ burä ciṃgna phara || khava ttaura
pīrakhu gąnä śaʾtva 20 20 1 20 2 20 3 20 4 haysgye tcai gva 20 20 20
|| maka[la sa]lya cvātaji māśtä 20 4 mye haḍai.
khace vara. cu ttūnā mārā-pyąra yą ttä śaunau
ḡyastāṃ rruṃdāṃ pharākä pārśäʾ yuḍāṃdä. khu
vā pā thā huṣāvī pātcä mārā-pyąrna pve tsve
śau nauhä pārśäʾ vīrä västātī. viñe biṃdä
muʾśdäʾ pasteṃ byaude. śāṃ-śū hīya vettā biṃdä
muʾśdäʾ pasteṃ byaude. khu parau pvąʾ ī haḍā āstaṃna
ādarä ya khve maṃ yaṃdrrye ni hame. cu jsāṃ va
haṣḍi yuḍe si thyautta va mārā-pyąrāṃ /
ca rai saṃña kaʾñä ttū va x /
In the Year of the Monkey, the 24th day of the month of Cvātaja.
To the ... Thyai Tvąnä Kāṃ ... They who were your parents, they ...
since then you grew up, you went to the feet of your parents
(and) singlemindedly placed yourself in their service. Now
I have ordered a favor to be found for you. For the ... of Śāṃ-śū
I have ordered a favor to be found. When you hear the order, from today
onward you must do the work of Śāṃ-śū. Take heed that it does not become a ... for you here (?). As for
the report you made that “formerly there ... of the parents ...

note.p: On the back of Chinese sutra Fo shuo guanding suiyuan wangsheng shi fang jing tu. Lines 67-97 in KT I-III, p. 147 (88). School exercise, Khotanese alternating with “Gostana Sanskrit” and model lines with copies in an unskilled hand frequently degenerating into mere scrawls (all of which were read by Bailey—probably correctly). Lines 39-65 letter/report with a date (lines 63-64) in the 14th regnal year of the Tianxing era, Year of the Pig (963).
(1-3 poorly shaped repeated groups of akṣaras)

hau śvaikale jsī pa ya sti śa sti
on the tenth day of the month of Hamārīja, the rays of the land (of China?) deign to radiate out to the army. When they order the army to come to them, *they order the army there to be led
among the Khyeṣas. When you hear the order, whatever
) ... sections(?) there are of infantry soldiers,
lead all those according to the old written insctructions of .... The following (are the ones for whom?)
grapes(?) are to be brought as village tax as profit for the infantry soldiers(?): (names).
The following (are the ones for whom?) clothes ... and
When I come to the Khyeṣas, if there is one *army leader
according to the order, they have made ...
they order (you) to request very many blankets for clothing.
The order (went out) on the 28th day of the month of Kaja of the fourteenth regnal year of the Tianxing era, in a Year of the Pig (= 963). We ordered tthem to be placed in (our?) jurisdiction.

note.p: Signature added after conservation: Ch.00120. On the back of Tibetan “namo text” (Tib. no. 339).

q.l: rrvī vī vara tta haṣḍi yani —
uvāryau garkhyau pūñau kūśa(la-mū)lāṃ jsa haphve yau maistai aurmaysda mauñada pyara īma ttaiha: tcana. aurga tsūṃ [drū]-
— rraispūra halai khu tta x x śai kuṣṭa x |
hai yaśvariṇa x khva tta ma da¢y˝ ka ṣṭāve tta tta x a gūmattīrai tsūe -e x jsau [x x x] būñau au x būttau x x -e -ä |
-ā kuṣṭä jsau ye ha -ä hūra nva ṣṭa tca tsa thā ttaya śī hīyai baiṣṭa parehaumana au —
I thus report to the court.
In reverence to my father Ima Ttaiha:tcana, equipped with exalted, heavy merits and roots of goodness, like the great sun I report an inquiry about his health.
... how ... may be, thus I went to Gumattīra (monastery) ...
... where ... the pupils of the dashi we are practicing restraint.

msIdentifier.idno: Ch.00327 (C 64): KT II, p. 52 (13); SD IV/LXXVI; SD, TV, p. 103

note.p: Letter on the back of Chinese sutra Fo shuo guanding suiyuan wangsheng shi fang jing tu. The conservation paper now covers much of the top line as well as several line beginnings (as can been in the SD plate), but Bailey’s first reading antedates this. It is the end of P 2898 (KT II, p. 116 (62)). New edition in Kumamoto, 1991a.

q.l: m- ū [cī]ka gūl[ai]-v-aṃ vā dū[ṃ] saṃgalakā par[au] pastā[ṃda] sa kūṣṭa būrai vā parau na hī-
sīye kṣīrāṣṭa na tsva hama pahī ttā saṃgalakā gśta jsaiṇa vīra haṣḍa yḍai u
hervī-v-aṃ vā parau na ā sa khvaṃ tcerai cū jsā ṣacū tcairthūśī ṣṭe ṣąʾ jsāṃ tta tti hve sä mñau vā he-
rvī tvī kąṇä parau na ā sa khve tcerai aśt āṃ ya cū āṃ hāysa na tsai īṇāvąña kṣīra
ra jsāṃ ma hera śte ū ttūṅa-śīyā āstaṃ jsā ma pharāka haḍa ṣṭāre khvā āṃ va pve-
sīda sa aśtū ā yaṃdą ca ā hāysa na tsūva hervī-v-ai āṃ na bvaiKumamoto; B. khvai. sa ca ttū-v-aṃ hā hū-
ña kmīnai jsāṃ auvā X thįnä-śī hīsīye ṣiʾ jsāṃ āṃ vā ścāna saṃbāvana bīḍa heʾ-
rvī-v-āṃ āṃ hvąṇḍe hakhīśaʾ na bīysaṃjāre X khvāṃ haṃbusaṃ ṣṭāve khvā vā parau hīśta sa ttä
ttaka vā pā satta rrvī parau nva tsvāṃda
[x x x] ttāṃ tcerai īhīye śaṃde bidä ṣṭnaB. śäna; Kumamoto āna. avāyse ā ttäna mīrā. majarūṣa gauśta ttāä pā jsaiṇa
khu āṃ rrvī vī bīsa tta āra īda hamadā-v-ai āṃ hā kveśa hvąṇḍi darvāre ñaśā .. āṃ vā bīsāṃ kveśaʾ hī
vī aurrāsa haṣḍa yūḍādū khvā ma sa dūkha ṣṭāve —
... on the [fifth] day you should go out (= leave).
And Cīka Gūlai deigned (send) an order to Dūṃ Saṃgalakā (?) that “As long as no order comes here
you can not go to the Land (= China).” I put a detailed report in the hand of Saṃgalakāṃ, but
no order came to me saying what I shall do. [25] He who is the jiedushi in Shazhou, he said: “To us here
no order has come at all regarding you, saying what you shall do. What are you doing here that you do not go away? [27] Even here in a foreign land
I have some stuff. And there are many envoys here, eastern ambassadors (ttūṅa-śīya = dongshi œ S) and others. When they ask us
“what are you (all) doing that you do not go away?” I do not know at all what you tell them(?).
Into whatever(?) villages in the land you go, the court ambassador (ttiṅa-śī = tingshi æ S) would come; and he brings us ... respect.
They do not at all take our men into account(?) {And those people with you then went, according to the royal order.} the way it may be proper for them. [29] When the order comes to us (telling us)
... what we shall do, being in a *foreign land ... we shall die right away. [30] We then put the detailed
information and report to you in the hand of Majarūṣa (about) how there is only hardship for us here.
If now the (humble) servant commits any faults toward the royal court, the men there will altogether daringly rush to his side. They will send no men to the side of humble servants.

note.p: On the back of Chinese Saddharmapuṇḍarīka-sūtra.
