|| ydā ñysaira dīryai khvā jsa na gvaś(t)ū: nī jāṃ vā auda mara
hīya cai dyai: saunana va pharāka ya gvaṣṭū. mā jsa: sagīnai ysaira naṣṭau-
ṣke ttana ṣṭau baiṣḍaṃ: ṣaiʾka herä cai dyai ya thyau tta ṣṭauna pajsa haḍā
parsīdū śūjena vījyā ṣāʾ va dīda māśta ṣga khaiṇḍä haba-
ḍä saṃgīnai ysairi naṣ(ṭ)auṣke ttana ṣṭau baiṣḍaṃ —

note.p: IOL Khot S. 20-21 originally one scroll “consisting of two portions of differing sizes, which are sewn together along narrow edge” (Hoernle). IOL Khot S. 20 contains three “registers of sheep in the year chia-shên ... (924? or 984?)” arranged in 4 + 8 + 3 columns (Enoki). No Khotanese.

On a-side, 11 columns of a Chinese text “[w]ritten from left to right. It seems that the text concerns praying to Buddha for good luck in the future and in the travel of an embassy of Khotan sent to Tun-huang under the rule of Chang Chin-shan,” probably dated 922 (Enoki). After this starts Ch.i.0021a.a. On the b-side is the text Ch.i.0021a.b.

msIdentifier.idno: Ch.i.0021a.a: KT II, p. 53 (14); SD IV/XLIX-LI; SD, TV, p. 67

note.p: “Panegyric to king Śrī Viśaʾ Dharma” (Dresden, 1977a). Late formal ductus. The date in lines 20-21 [13] = 982. Lines 1-3 photo in Enoki (C. 109). Cf. the beginning of Ch.i.0021b.b (IOL Khot S. 47).

q.l: [1] || aurgä ī baʾysųñā rāṃdātāṣṭä āraverūcä āstaṃnä hamīḍä ttye vīśeʾra hīye gūtęra
jsa uskhąsta rana vī ysya abhiʾṣeką dījsāką 1 [2] vysñä ys vīysña hamye tathatvrrara attūśī-
ma nmī baʾysñä sąrau harbīśāṃ baʾysāṃ hye aumaunä mista cu ra baudasątva būmaprrpt hvāṣṭa 2
[3] arahadä ṣāvā cu ra khąṇḍakąvaṣṇä cū parīda mūdä dharmagarbha hasyą dharmadhātä
hīya dyaudha hajsara gūstyę tathatąprrarastą śamathaprrara vasva 3 [4] narvakalpa hajsara vī
brrāva sųrā bdacaitta hīyę vīvā jsa naradä. sāṃbhaudaky narmauṇä ūvārä pajsa geʾ vī-
ra sąrvasątvāṃ keṇä [5] mviʾśdīʾjä bveya paśīdä ṇeʾva-rayseṃ khu nä tsīda satva avāya bveysye bā-
ḍi tti haḍę dā jsa ūvra grą vśīʾdi baʾysau jsa vyrya mara nāsīdä ysathä [6] sąmyakädrręṣṭä
vasve-gūtterä rrvī mahāsaṃma rrāṃdä hyę gųtįrä jsa narädą vrrīśmä ḡyasta aśųʾ . cayaṃ rre . ṣvīdä
hūrrāka būmä-dīvya ḡyaśca [7] hūṣauñka āysdirai kkä haḍiṃ valākäteśvarä baudasatvą ū-
vārä gaustamä-deśa ranīje jīnäve vī rrścä hamya āṣaʾ ttye gsta raudä bhalacakrravartta-
rāja rājęśvara {rre} śūkä śāhają darye jabvī vī ttye raudä pūrāṃ pūrāṃ śūrä darjsa
harbīśāṃ rrāṃdāṃ hye vamurākä rre rāysanāṃ hvāṣṭä bīśāṃ rāṃdāṃ biṃdä [9] maittrai hye narmauṇa ssa ysatha pīcha-
ṣṭä ttye śakrra brrąhmau ttī nārāya mįhaiśvarä skaṃdha varūṇä nāvau rre haṣṭä baudasatva haṣṭä parvālā
jīvąsabhava rāja dīvya jaścä [10] cu rä dīśpāla ngapāla tcauhaurä śūkhuṇa śakhīmä yakṣa dīśamū-
ka pātca grahavadatta būjsaju sthnāva cu ra jasta dīvye parvlā nāva rrśtä heṣṭaṃda rauja-lakṣa-
ṇä bįśa [11] cakrravarttä hīya rājāga sąmartha haude rä ranä grahtä parṇyakä āhaurrja hvāṃdä a-
yīkṣyaude rāści raudnä naumä vīśäʾra rraśäʾ pūrysa [12] śrī vīśäʾ dharma baudasattū rre carau mauña-
dä strīyastrīśvāṃ jastvāṃ śakrra jasta brrūñīye jastāṃ myñä ttū mauñadä jabvīyāṃ rādau myāṃ parīvāysau-
da śe-tcūnä miḍāṃjä [13] ttye vīśaʾ darma baudasatv rāṃdä kṣuṇi ye pūha cū hīṅa kamala aśi rä bāstį
salī haudama māścä khu hā panä nva aysm jastuñä kṣamä [14] rrīna āyīma vasve ciṃgv ysye ttye
ysarnai rrvī gūttairä pabhä udeśä haḍi pasta haṣṭä vāṣṭä ṣacū vāṣṭä aspūra ssą pajsāsą śū-
ra-bīja hvṣṭnä pūrä hvāṣṭä bįśa hamagä ṣahaunīya caistą padajūḍi pūrā bvaijsāda śū-
rä pūñūda ṣadu sthyę gūttarasta kamalāysa ttyāṃ hvāṣṭāṃ hye āvasta vīre biśa bāḍä naṣāʾṃdä yāṃ thye-śī
bīśāṃ bvejsā bydä . bvme jsa ysā u bvemi jsa hųṣ ysājsa hvārä hvñä vīcakṣa edrrāṃ jsa śūrä
bāḍäñv phara dyi hdahnä pūñūṃdä sera hvūṃ-śī haḍāṃ krraḍīñä śeʾ . nma-tsvä śūra tsāṣṭä verśṃ-
dä haiga cā kama-śī bīśāṃ bvejsā hvṣṭä nva parau tsvāṃda tta haḍi ṣacū vāṣṭä jasta-kṣīra mau
ñadū ṣacū kathä carau mñädä vasve ssa-vahä ysīrä ā khu ranīja ttrekha tcaṣva śęrkä ttu mauña-
dä brrūñä ṣiʾ kṣīrä rāṃda jsa hatsa pārahā mįsta kūśala vaską pūñāṃ ttye darye jabvī vī janavi
kṣasa vara īdä katha kṣairähaṣṭ ysre ttye darye jabvī vī janavāṃ bāḍvna īda edrrāṃ
jsa kūśalavīrā ṣada śūra bumaya haurä biṃdä darjsa khu māje ysarne bāḍi vīrä
bīje ṣiʾ pā vañä ṣacū gūmättīrä ṣṭe śairka ysara garbha bįysa baudasatva ṣkāṃje bīhī
burä dṣka duṣiʾṣkāṃdä da śerkä dṣkara jsa ṣkaudä dṣkare jsa vadedä pharākau ṣada ys-
vä aysmya thy cū dyāṃdu biysāṃ hya dyma brrūnä jai-v-āṃ rä bhaśje āyysa naṣāṃʾdä kī-
ḍiśʾ bīya karma ttāṃ baiśa jä ttyāṃ haḍāṃ hadavyi jaḍi abstä tta tta khu śala
/ -i dä khu vara byśde sahecäThis line was apparently lost in the conservation process.
(1) Reverence to the buddha kings, Āryāvalokiteśvara and all the others, – (2) arisen from that lineage of the vajra, born in a jewel, upholders of the consecration. 1.

Born in a lotus, arisen in a lotus, having the nature of truth (tathatā-prakṛti), his name Not Empty, a buddha lion, – great example of profit for all the buddhas, as well as the best bodhisattvas, having reached the bhūmis. 2.

(4) The arhats and hearers, as well as the rhinocerus-horned ones (= pratyekabuddhas) who deign to remain in the sphere of the dharmagarbha. – (5) I have escaped to the .. sphere of the dharmadhātu, full of the nature of truth (tathatā-prakṛti), having the nature of extinction (śamatha-prakṛti), pure. 3.
(6) Awakened in the sphere of nirvikalpa, clean, gone out from the fruition of the bodhi-citta. – Sāmbhogakāya and nirmāṇa(kāya), exalted, (7) for the sake of all beings in the five gatis,

They emit their rays of compassion, the elixir of life (amṛta-rasāyana), so that beings may not go to apāyas for a long time, – (8) But they pronounce exalted instructions according to the Law, they take births here as prophesied by the buddhas.
Having perfect view (samyak-dṛṣṭi), (9) of pure lineage, royal, issued from the family of King Mahā¬saṃmata, – Vaiśramaṇa, the lord Aśoka, King Cayaṃ, the milk-giving (10) lady goddess of the earth,

the increasing protector, guardian, envoy(?) Avalokiteśvara, exalted bodhisattva, – (11) arisen worthy of the rule over the Jewel Land of Gostanadeśa, to that king of Gostana, the bala-cakravartin-rāja,
(12) rājeśvara alone ... in all of Jambudvīpa, of the sons of sons(?) of that king heroic, daring, – (13) a king subduer of all kings, the best of rulers over all kings,

the transformation (nirmāṇa) of Maitreya manifest for a hundred births; (14) to him Śakra, Brahma, and also Nārāyaṇa, Maheśvara, – Skandha, Varuṇa, the king of nāgas, eight bodhisattvas, eight guardians, (15) King Jetasambhava(?), the lady goddess,

and also the guardians of the (four?) directions, the four guardians of the nāgas, Śukhūṇa, Śakhīma the yakṣas, Dīśamūka, – (16) next Grahavadatta, ... and also the gods and goddesses, the guardian nāgas, gave the kingship, all the marks of the king,
(17) equipped with the royal members of the cakravartin, and the seven jewels ... they spoke, – (18) they established the kingship, the name of king, victorious in the reign of the vajra,

Śrī Viśaʾ Dharma, bodhisattva and king, like a lamp (19) the lord Śakra might shine among the Thirty-three gods, among the gods, – like that (he) is ... among the kings of Jambudvīpa, (20) the gracious shizun.

Of that Viśaʾ Dharma, bodhisattva and king, it was the fifth year, the head (being) (the regnal period) Zhongxing, – and the horse led (21) the year [= 982], the month (was the) seventh, when there arose for him according to his mind, the divine wish,

the desire for a queen, pure, born among the Chinese, (22) with a view to the continuance of the golden kingly family. – He deigned send envoys hither to Shazhou, a full hundred and fifteen, (23) of heroic roots, best sons of the best,

all equally meritorious, youthful, worthy of display, ..., virtuous, heroic, (24) meritorious, believing, ..., of (good) family, eminent; – ... of those best ones ..., at all times at peace, Yāṃ the thye-śī, (25) covered with all virtues, born with knowledge and grown in knowledge,
speaking tasteful and sweet (words), ... in senses, heroic, (26) he saw much in the lands, – having the qualities of a good man, meritorious, Sera the hvūṃ-śī, second in rank of the envoys.
Famed, heroic, peaceful, energetic, (27) mild, Cā the kama-śī the best of all virtues, – those (three) went as envoys according to the order here to Shazhou.

Like the land of gods (is) the city of Shazhou, like a lamp, pure (like) gold melted a hundred times, – or like a peak studded with jewels, brilliant, beautiful, like that that land shines together with (its) king.

... in this entire Jambudvīpa (36) there are sixteen lands, 86,000 cities, of the lands in this entire Jambudvīpa are inhabitants(?) – with (complete) senses (31) performing good deeds, believing, heroic, knowledgeable, valiant in giving, like in our Golden Land (32) ...

Then there is in Shazhou the Gūmattīra (monastery), beautiful, quite marvelous displays of buddhas (and) bodhisattvas, – difficult to construct, so beautiful, marvelously made, marvelously constructed. For many belief is quickly born (34) in (their) mind who have seen the dear sight of the buddhas.
And their sins are destroyed, their commotions are calmed, (35) the acts smeared with kleśas, all those are destroyed for them. – Among those envoys folly and ignorance, like the śala tree ...

msIdentifier.idno: Ch.i.0021a.b: KT II, p. 55 (14a); SD III/LII-LIV; SD, TV, p. 70

note.p: Travel report (itinerary). Late cursive ductus. Ed. with plates Bailey, 1936. See also Morgenstierne, 1942.

q.l: || vi janivi vī āṃ haṣṭimye haḍai kśarapä hīsīdä hīśanijį katha vī āṃ di kau-
kvāṃ burä katha ṣṭrai tcre caignä drai-haḍāṃjsye śadi bidi paḍysa katha
śaraḍūgä nmä ttye jsi pajsa-haḍāṃjsye śadi bidä tcīnä haura lakä nmä ttye jsa dva-ha-
ḍvāṃjsye śadi bidi īcahana garä nmä vara vi nha gara driya sakhrma ṣṭre
ttye jsa dri haḍāṃjsye śadä bidä katha yabhagau nmä hauhä ttājä hīye ttājä
hīye kamala bidä vara auna tcūrmye haḍai kakvāhartcai nma kītha ṣṭe dī-
na āṣaija ttāja śā mistä ttye biṃdä ttājä ś mįsta garä u vara ṣiʾ katha varä
au tcūrmyai haḍai prrūśavā hīyai bāḍi biṃdä hīsīdä vara va ysarnīje ū-
ca hīyai kamala naraume vara va paḍysa katha ṣṭe syadiṃ nmä nha garä
sakhārma va drayi vara au kṣa-haḍāṃjsye śadi biṃdä katha ṣṭe baurbura naumä sī-
na nauma va mista ttāja ṣṭe vara hvaṇḍa byaḍāṃ biṃdi ttrmīdi sakhārma va tcaura
hvna ttāja auva karnä ttye jsa ravya pa nva ttāje mista katha gīḍagīttä
nmä sagījä vara va sakhārma haṣṭä rrāṃdä hīye aumä varä tcaurvā bā-
ḍvā ttye jsa ravye pa hīdva kṣīrāṣṭä padi ttye ysarnījį nva ttājä vara va ttāja raga biṃda
mista kṣīrä ṣṭe śīlathasa naumä vara ttye hvānä ttāje auva karnä ttāji hye ra-
ga bidä drmä pātca hā byaḍä jsa ttrmīdä sīḍathasä aunä audi ttī-
ḍī bhurai haṣṭa-haḍāṃjsya śadā ṣṭe ravye pa vāṣṭa ttye nva ttāje tharkye hamāre
banāve ttītta devadārä vara va makala mūñīdä ttīḍī va magalacakrra nau-
mä rre mūñe ṣaʾ paḍysa kaśmīrāṣṭä hīdvāṃga katha ṣṭe gara biṃdä vare śau
ravye pa mahuvi ttāja raga biṃdi ttīḍī nä ravye pa vāṣṭä hīdva kṣīrāṣṭä
dva-haḍāṃjsya śadį bidä baurīne mista gara ṣṭe sargūṇi nmä
ttu ś haḍā viheṣṭä hame ttye dī satharä paḍysa au ṣṭe markaṭagra-
ma nma vara va karna drai-sse ttye jsa ravye pa dva-haḍājsye śadi biṃdä  ṣṭe va-
rṇavalā nmä ttye raṣṭä au bahauysna ṣṭre mistä pa-sse ttye jsa ravye pa dva-haḍāṃ-
jsa śadi bidi mista  ṣṭe manattapaurṇa nmä vara bihysa ś mista pajsa ysra va ka-
pīlye ṣṭre ttye jsa ravya pa drrai-haḍājsya śadi bidi kṣīräFor kathä? ṣṭe nalapaṭana naumä mista vara va bi-
hysa ṣṭe ś-haḍāṃjsye śadį bidi kapīlya va pajsa ysrä ṣaʾ bihysa vīysāje
hīye raga biṃdä sakhrma va drrayi sagījā gavāṃ jsa ttye raṣṭä vīysāṃje kaśmīrṣṭa
nva-vadāṃ padä adįṣṭädä kṣīrāṣṭä ś-haḍāṃjsvi vara katha adeṣṭä ttye adiṣṭänä kathe drayi
śmį vīttasa nmä ñ hye ṣṭre vara vi mistä nvi bįsta ysre ñūhūṃjsadä bīs vi jsā
śma katha hya vīysāṃja ṣṭe ṣaʾ katha śau-haḍāṃjsa habistana va dirye kaśmīrä mista auva ṣṭ-
rre kṣaṣṭa ysāre ṣaʾ śau āṃ drai-sse ys karnāṃ u śau karāṃ drai-sse kṣaṣṭyāṃ bīsā jsa va-
ra va mista damarāśʾsta sakhrma ṣṭre pa-sse sagījā gavā jsa ñāttara sakhrma
ahakhīysa rre va abįmanyagauptä nmä hasti pharāka hīnabāy-v-e tcaurä
From the Land on the eighth day they come to Kāśarapä. From the Iron City to
Kaukvāṃ there are four Chinese towns. For a stretch of three days, the first city

is called Śaraḍūgä. From it for a stretch of five days there is (a city) called Tcīnä Hauralaka. From it for a stretch of two days there is (a city) called Īchanagarä. There, on a mountain top there are three monasteries.
From it for a stretch of three days there is a city called Yabhagau at the head of a wide river. From there on the fourth day there is a city called Kakvāhartcai. Below
a lake is a river. Along that (river) is (another) river (and) a great mountain, and there is that city.
From there on the fourth day they come into the territory of the Prrūśavas (Burusho). There,
the head of a golden river comes forth. There is the first city, called Syadiṃ. On a mountain top
there are three monasteries. From there for a stretch of six days is a city called Baurbura.
There is a great river called Sīma. There the men enter (the river) on inflated skins. There are four monasteries.
*Along the river are villages (and) karānas. South of it along the river is a great city
called Gīḍagīttä (Gilgit), made of stone. There are eight monasteries. The residence of the king is there in four lands(?).
South of it is the road to India, along that golden river. There on the shore of the river
is a great city called Śīlathasa. There *along the river are villages (and) karānas on the shore of the river. Again, they enter it with that kind of inflated skin. From Sīḍathasä to Ttīḍī

there is a stretch of eight days. To the south hither along that river there are walnut trees, jack fruit, balsam pear, (and) deodar (trees).See Studies I, pp. 50 (ttīta) and pp. 83-84 (banāte). There monkeys dwell. In Ttīḍī
dwells a king called Magalacakra. This is the first Indian city (on the road) to Kaśmīra. One of its *gates is on a mountain.
To the south, on the shore of the Mahuvi river, south of Ttīḍī hither, (on the road) to India
for a stretch of two days, there is a great snow-covered mountain called Sargūṇi. One can descend it in one day. Below it in *rocky place is the first town, called Markaṭagrāma.
There there are three hundred karānas. To the south of it, (after) a stretch of two days, there is a town
called Varṇavalā. *Throughout that (town) are five hundred large bazaars. To the south of it, (after) a stretch of two days,

there is a large village called Manattapaurṇa. There is one large bazaar (and) five thousand kapīlaya trees. To the south of it, (after) a stretch of three days, there is a land (city?) called Nalapaṭana. There there is a large bazaar.
For a stretch of one day there are five thousand kapīlaya trees. That bazaar
is on the shore of a lake. There are three monasteries with cells of stone (in rock?). *All along that lake there is
a ... road to Kaśmīra. To the land of Adiṣṭädaṃ is a one-day (stretch). There is the city of Adiṣṭaṃ. That city of Adiṣṭaṃ has three

entrances. They are from(?) the river called Vīttasa. There there are 20,000 large boats. The western entrance is in the lake of the city. That city is continuous for a one-day (stretch). In all of Kaśmīra there are
60,000 great towns. That (particular) one consists of 300,000 karānas, and (each) one karāna of 360 houses. There,
there is a large monastery with a dharmarāja (stupa) (and) 500 rock cells. Smaller monasteries
are countless. The king there is called Abimanyagaupta. (There) are many elephants. He has four army leaders.
The army is 100,000 (and/times?) 100,000, all in armor.

note.p: On the back of Chinese Fo shuo shan e yin guo jing [Sutra on the cause and effect of good and bad actions?]. 1) Alphabet; 2) 12 lines of text; 3) in margin of Chinese text. Lines 1-8 and 39-46 in Hoernle, 1911, pl. II facing p. 454; Hoernle refers to this scroll as “002” on p. 452 and as “Ch.xc, 002” on pl. II.

amą yai yā paḍai cu vā kvaOr.kṣa. jna himye aulau aśä jsa ṣacū ttraṃdūṃ. khu vā dirsi nā salya ātū pejsä maṃ śirkä sāṣṭāṃdä. ḍe-kūṃ ū hvū: śaiʾna u ttuṃgava u ttuna ttena u chnä śī u ąmäga
To him, endowed with the experience of the great gift, from the four directions,
in many lands, his great name had gone ...
... to the inner (dwellings?) of the king of kings of China, in many lands, his servant Tcena Haṇi(?)
a giver and minutely a report and ...
to the ocean’s edge in land after land ...,
... the giver of commands, the ... of lord buddhas walking in the air, meritorious, knowledgeable,
heroic, {...} the *ruler of the Golden Land, Thayä Uvī, the master ... and
the queen, with much reverence I make a report, asking about their health.
) ... I entered Shazhou with camels and horses (a mare?). When I came in the thirty Year of the Dragon(?), they looked at me well here, the Ling Gong, the queen and (names).

note.p: On the back of very long scroll (670x25 cm) containing the Chinese Saddharmapuṇḍarīka-sūtra. Mentioned by Hoernle, 1911, p. 455.

note.p: On the back of Chinese Fo shuo yao shi jing. Syllabaries. In the margin of the Chinese text the single akṣara ka. Big bold late formal. [In Hoernle’s article p. 452 it is referred to as “Ch.cviii, 007,” but the plate has the correct sign.] Lines 3-12, 44-46 in Hoernle, 1911, pl. I facing p. 452; Ser., pl. CXLV (complete).

note.p: On the back of long (297x25 cm) old and damaged scroll with holes containing the Chinese Saddharmapuṇḍarīka-sūtra. Conservation paper covers much on the edges. See also Ch.xl.002. Bailey only lines 1-3, 9-12, 92-93(!), 110-113; line 108 in KT V, p. 255 (532).

Tianxing (era) in the ninth regnal year, in the Year of the Horse (= 958), on the tenth day of the Month of Ttuṃjārā.
Learn quickly and thoroughly so that you may not receive the stick!

note.p: On the back of long scroll (765x25 cm) containing the Chinese Buddhāvataṃsaka-sūtra. Traces of akṣaras at the top of the scroll.

note.p: On the back of long scroll (452x25 cm) containing the Chinese Pañcaviṃśatikāprajñāpāramitā-sūtra. 8 lines of syllabaries including special ligatures. Edges covered by conservation paper. Lines 1-3 thin script. The rest large bold late formal.

note.p: On the back of Tibetan Aparimitāyuḥ-sūtra (Tib. no. 310?). Conservation paper on Khotanese side now covers large parts of the text. Report to the court. Year of the Tiger, months of Cvātaja and Kaja. One line between Tibetan texts vertical. Late formal ductus.

(vertical between two portions of the Tibetan text)
ṣaʾ prrañāpārāma ṣṭe peʾjsa gabīra ṣadai hā ña
In the Year of the Tiger, the month of Kaja, here in Yutian ...
born from ... seven princes there were.
... with exalted merits and roots of goodness ...
the buddha(s) all that ... realized bodhi
there in the monastery the towns(?) that day by day(?) they see good in the world ...
... the manner of that ... was thus, that ...
... from the belly there dwelt a little bird(?) ...

... marrow was born.
At that time there in Rājagṛha it was said in land by land(?) Jātamaha ...
... by name they made. But whoever in the world thus obtain sons and daughters those brothers ... for that reason ...
... they see how that prince will grow they became ... at all times in the future they will be better
In a distant land near with warm friendly mind equipped with exalted merits and roots of goodness
... great gift experience not before him(?). Khviṃ Raka(?) who had deigned remember ...
I make a report thus to the court, the humble one, dwelling in Phęma(?), ...
... merits they sent to us, who was angry with us(?) ...
This Prajñāpāramitā is very profound, faith [should be ...-ed] in it.

note.p: Site mark: Ch.0046. 2 syllabaries in unskilled hand. IOL Khot S. 43 and S. 31 join at edge. IOL Khot S. 31 and S. 32 are separated by a space corresponding to ca. one column of the Chin. text. IOL Khot S. 32 and S. 30 are separated by a larger space. On the back of Chinese Suvarṇaprabhāsa T. 16, no. 665, pp. 435A27-B13 [S. 43], B13-B28 [S. 31], B29-C5 [S. 32], 436A19-B7 [S. 30]. Hoernle, 1911, pl. IV facing p. 458.

note.p: On the back of Chinese Suvarṇaprabhāsa (see IOL Khot S. 30). Ch.0040 in Enoki’s catalog is a mis-reading; the top of the final 6 is covered by conservation paper! It is to the left of and perpendicular to IOL Khot S. 43 and to the right of IOL Khot S. 32. The end of lines 3-5 were previously covered by conservation paper. IOL Khot S. 31 and 43 were at one time folded and either side was used as writing paper. PLATE 8c.

note.p: Site mark: Ch.0046. Syllabary. On the back of Chinese Suvarṇaprabhāsa (see IOL Khot S. 30).

note.p: Site mark: Ch.0046. On the back of Chinese Vajracchedikā [T. 8, no. 235, pp. 749A28-B10]. The Khot. texts appears to have been written over Chin. characters. Cf. IOL Khot S. 31 and 43.

q.l: || parau mista tcāṃ tte hvāṃʾ u hūśaiʾna khvau tta ṣṭe /
sa thū mista rraispūra pū yaṃ u śī kvaina —
cā krraśīsa amaga svanī u kva ṣaṇīraka
kīma ttehą śaną yā kī tte.B. tsena. na la pha xB. drū. /
[x] hākvā. saga sera {x vā} hvai jvai —
The order of the great Cao De Wang and his consort ‘How are you,’
that: You, the great princes, Pū Yaṃ, and Śī Kvaina,
Cā Krraśīsa, the amaga Svanī, and Kva Ṣanīraka.
Kīma Ttehą Śana Yā Kī *Tsena La Pha ... (?).

note.p: The Khotanese text is over a Chinese draft letter and consists of the name Kīma Ne Tcūna, corresponding to the Chinese Jin Ningzhu (Enoki, p. 265). Enoki has “Ch.0049.” [Bailey’s Ch.0049, KT II, p. 41 (8), is IOL Khot S. 43.]

Site mark Ch.0046. Top portion of Ch.0050b (IOL Khot S. 36), with which it joins with narrow sliver missing. Almost identical text repeated five times (exercises), twice upside-down at beginning of the scroll (1-2), and three times on the rest of the scroll (3-5). (1-2) are written in less polished script than (3)-(5). Edges now covered by conservation paper. Written on the back of Chinese Vajracchedikā [T. 8, no. 235, pp. 751A20-B5 + B5-22].

q.note: (1) At top of S. 36, upside down. Bailey’s Ch.0050b2.1-3.

note.p: Two joining pieces mounted together. With Ch.0050a (see IOL Khot S. 35).
Recent Chinese inscription in red ink identifying the text on the recto as Jingang ming jing. [Stein’s Ch.00120 is IOL Khot S. 7.]

Mounting paper has: (1) “00328” (in black ink) with “a” added in pencil; (2) “9.I.54” in pencil (date of conservation?). Bottom of Ch.00329 (IOL Khot S. 40). On the back of Chinese Mahā¬prajñāpāramitā-sūtra.
Mounting paper has Ch.00328b. Chinese in cursive Khotanese Brāhmī. One side only.

Top of Ch.00328a. The first line of Ch.00328 = last line of Ch.00329 (the vowel marks on Ch.00329.6 go on top of akṣaras in the first line of Ch.00328a). The two pieces fit together perfectly, but the conservation paper now covers top and bottom lines and right margins. Note the use of rr, which is quite distinct from dr. On the back of Chinese Mahā¬prajñāpāramitā-sūtra. Cf. Or.8210/S. 5212.

I am asking. There *with you in a distant land, born, alive, ...
... jewel of men, if you are at peace, then also healthy.
Then I am happy because of your joy. If Kūṃ Ṣa has come here
among the hills, ... has sat upon the waves (?) and there

note.p: Line 2 large bold late formal script. [No Chinese.]

“To the court then here afterwards ... the *lordly ...”

note.p: The original Ch.no. has been scratched out and is now illegible and “629” written below. On the back of Chinese Suvarṇaprabhāsa (see IOL Khot S. 30). Edges covered by conservation paper. Two pieces that fit together perfectly (Bailey’s a and b). It is to the right of IOL Khot S. 31, which has the beginning of line 1. Cf. IOL Khot S. 33.

q.l: parau m/ista tcāṃ tte hvāṃʾ u / hūśaiʾna u khvau tta ṣṭe u sa thū mista rraispūra
[p]ū yaṃ u śī kvai/na u ttaugä cāk[rr]a ʾeysa vaijalaka
amaga svanī u kīma ttehä śa-
nä u yā kī tsena u la pha drū
hvāṃʾ saga u sera hvai jvai
ka k(a)Just upper half of ka. ||
[The order] of the great Cao De Wang and his consort and ‘How are you,’ that: You, O great prince
Pū Yaṃ and Śī Kvaina and Ttaugä, Cā Krraśīsa, Prince Vaijalaka,
the amaga Svanī and Kīma Ttehą Śana
Yā Kī Tsena La much health!
Hvāṃ Sa(ṃ)ga and Sera Hvai may he live(?).

note.p: A small piece with margins of Chin. characters. Hoernle says it was a strip pasted on to Ch.0049 (IOL Khot S. 43).

note.p: No site mark, but probably Ch.0046. On the back of Chinese Suvarṇaprabhāsa T. 16, no. 665, pp. 433A3-9 (not the same ms. as C 59). Texts a and b on left and right side, c in margin of Chinese. Cf. IOL Khot S. 31, 33, 43.

“The great Cao De Wang and his consort
the great princes and Śī Kvaina and Ttaugä,
“The order of the great Cao De Wang ...
The order of his consort ‘How are you’ ...”

note.p: Long (70 ft 10") scroll containing various Khotanese and “Gostana” Sanskrit texts. Complete photo edition Takubo, 1975. Guide2, pp. 21-22.

Tathāgatoṣṇīṣasitātapatra in “Gostana Skt.,” on which see Hoernle, 1911, p. 472. Lines 1-11 Buddhoṣṇī-ṣavijaya-dhāraṇī, lines 12-195 Sitātapatra (same text as Ch.0041 [Or.8210/S. 2529]). Lines 1-28 on Ser., pl. CXLVI.

q.l: traṃ nmāparājita mahāpratyagirā samāpta || || śāṃ khṅä hvāṃʾ saṃ-
gakä pasti pīḍe bįśä pīrmāttamye baʾysña baʾysuśti brrīya jsī-
nai huṣī pīlai vyachīde sahaicä salya puhye māśti paḍauysye haḍai
ādrä nakṣatträ vī ṣacu kītha āṃ ūspurä dāśe

The saṃgaka Śāṃ Khṅä Óvāṃʾ ordered (this) to be written in love of the the most supreme buddha-bodhi. May his life increase, his sufferings disappear! In the Year of the Hare, on the first day of the 5th month, in the nakṣatra of ārdra, in the town of Ṣacū, it was completed and finished.Year 943. See Hamilton, 1979, pp. 53-54; Guide2, p. 22.

note.p: Bhadrakalpika-sūtra, containing introduction, list of names of the Buddha, and conclusion. Introduction and conclusion edited by Konow, Bks. Second copy of the introduction is in P 2949, KBT, p. 75 (23). Bailey gives the list of names without the accompanying text. Lines 199-228 on Ser., pl. CXLVI; lines 24-50 in Konow, Bks. Sample lines:

q.l: saddham namau krrakasuṃdau nma tathāgatau namau kanamunau nma tathā-
gatau namau kāśapau nma tathāgatau namau śākyamunau nma tathāgtau [!]
saddham dvāsä kūla gyasta baʾysa ratnauttama nma bīśūṃ namasuṃ nauda :
haṣṭusä kula gyasta baʾysa ratnāvabhāsa nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda
bistä kūla gyasta baʾysa śikha nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda : bistä kū-
la gyasta baʾysa kāśava nma biśū namasuṃ nauda || kṣase kūla gyasta
baʾysa vimalaprrabha nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda : sparanau kūla gyasta baʾ-
ysa śākyamuna nma biśūṃ namasum nauda : haṣṭase ysāri gyasta baʾysa
eṃdrradhvaja nma biśū namasuṃ nauda haṣṭase ysāri gyasta baʾysa suprra-
bhāsa nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda : nau kūla gyasta baʾysa kṛkisuṃda n-
ma biśuṃ namasuṃ nda : haṣṭusä kūla gyasta baʾysa kanakamuna n-
ma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda : drraise kūla gyasta baʾysa avabhā(sa)śrya nāma bi-
śū namasuṃ nauda : sparabistä kūla gyasta baʾysa puṣya nma biśūṃ
namasūṃ nauda : dvāsä kūla gyasta baʾysa vipaśa nma biśūṃ nama-
sūṃ nauda : dvī ysāri kūla gyasta baʾysa kauṭęña nma biśū namasūṃ
nauda : haṣṭā kūla gyasta baʾysa svabhāvadharmauttara nma biśūṃ namasūṃ
nauda : paṃ-ysāri gyasta baʾysa prrādyautta nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda paṃ-se
gyasta baʾysa prrattāpąna nma biśū namasūṃ nauda || haṣṭā ysāra gya-
sta baʾysa nāga nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda : paṃ-ysārä gyasta baʾysa
sālarāja nma biśū namasūṃ nauda : haṣṭa-se gyasta baʾysa śama-
tha nma biśūṃ namasu nauda : dasau ysāri gyasta baʾysa prrasana-u-
tpalagandhakūṭa nma biśūṃ namasuṃ nauda : biśīda gyasta baʾysa hi-
māre haṃbaʾcä jsa tcahauʾse kūla pīrma haṣṭusä lakṣa byūrri hauda ysā-
ri haṣṭa-se. cvaṃ ye nma byehe pyūṣṭi ṣiʾ drrayāṃ (avāyāṃ) paṃda basti. ni ni na-
rya jsāte ni prrīyvā ni ttrīyaśūṃʾ cvaṃ sāje samādnuṃ jsa bāye ṣiʾ baʾ(ysū)-
śtä jsa atīsaṃdai hime ni vara byaṃmā tcerā : namau ūttarapradīpä
gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cuai nma hvñe ni na garkhyau āchyau haṃthrrīśtä ||
naumau jauttasaumyagaṃdhāvabhāsaśrī nma gyastä baʾ(ysä) cvai nma hvñe na
na strīya hime odä baʾysuśtä : namau jñānaulko gyastä baʾysä namasūṃ
cvai nma hvñe ni ni avīśäʾ mahānarī ysaṃthä nāstä || namau aṣaṃga
rājä nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ cvai nma hvñe amauvuā byūṃgvā
baṃdanaśālvā na kaśte : || : namau anaṃttayaśä nma gyastä baʾysä
cvai nma hvñe biśau gajsyau jsa pahaiṣṭä hime || namau merä nma gyastä
baʾysä. cuai nma hvñe narya ni ysaṃthä ni byehe || namau mahāmeru
nma gyastä baʾysä cvai nma hvñehv[tcī]ñe. prrīyvā ra ysaṃthä ni nāste :
namau amittamirä nma gyastä baʾysä cvai nma hvñe ttrīyaśūṃʾ ra
ysaṃthä ni nāsti : namau akṣubhä gyastä baʾysä cvai nma hvñe baʾ-
śę bisaṃgnī hvaḍä khaṣṭä anāvarąṇä gvaśte deśanai hime : :
namau ratnakettä gyastä baʾysä cvai nma hvñe ttirä brrñaṃdai hime
khu raṃnīnę daśäʾ : namau armyāyä gyastä baʾysä cuai nma hvñe ha-
ṣṭā kūla kalpa vaṣṭä bisāṃ haṃjsāṃda karma baśdeʾ ttai jāre. mara-
ṇā ve suhāva ysaṃthä nāsti namau dūṃdubhisvarä gyastä baʾysä cuai
nma hvñe didirī śirkä bajāṣä hime khu gyastųña kūsä pāʾhe || namau ratna-
nma gyastä baʾysä cuai nāma hvñe harbiśāṃ barījāṃ sijma
byehe tsā hime sūhye : namau sudarśaṃ gyastä baʾysä cuai nma hvñe
kalpasthyatī karma baśde jāre dyena śirkä hime prraysā : namau viraucaṃ
gyastä baʾysä cuai nma hvñe dātīnai ttaraṃdarä byehe || namau gaṃdhau-
ttaṃ gyastä baʾysä cuai nma hvñe ysaṃthvātī tturrna vasva ūpalä spye hī-
ya buśä narąme ni ni kūṭhegvā ysaiye || namau aparamittagūṇa-
nma tathāga(tau ||) namau sarvadharmanayavikurvattattejau nmau thathāgatau. .
namau guṇasaṃkūsumitau nma tathāgatau 10 1 cu ṣiʾ cu ttyāṃ gyastāṃ
baʾysāṃ nme sāje vāśeʾ o vā pyūṣḍi śe śe baʾysä nma hvñme
jsa kalpasthya karma jāre śeʾna ysathäna baʾysūśti būtte : namau samā-
dhihastau nma gyastä baʾysä namasūṃ : namau samādhihastautarapadmau-
taranakṣatrarāyä nma gyastä baʾysä namasūṃ : namau padmautara-
śrī nma gyasta baʾysä namasuṃ : namau padmahastau nma gyasta baʾ-
ysä namasuṃ : namau sūryamaṇḍalaprabhāsauttamaśrī nma tathāgatau
baʾysä namasūṃ : namau ekaratnachaträ nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ
namau sarvasamādhiruttamavikrrąmä nma gyastä baʾysä namasūṃ : ||
namau ratnakūsumittasamaṃttāvabhāsaśrī nma gyastä baʾysä namasūṃ :
namau anuttarapadmavikrrąmi nma gyastä baʾysä namasūṃ : namau a-
naṃttagadhauttamarāyä nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ : namau ratnapadma-
vikrrąmä nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ namau ratnamaṇḍalattejasamudgata-
prrabhāsautta(ma)śrī nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ : namau ratnagarbhä nma gya-
stä baʾysä namasūṃ || namau ratnauttąmä nma gyasta baʾysä namasūṃ.
namau sarvaratnaprrattamąṇḍatarūpadharī nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ
cu ṣiʾ cu ttyāṃ gyastāṃ baʾysāṃ nmi parī pīḍe au vāśeʾ anattanary-
nī karmāṃ deśana hime didirū jsa pariloka bąnya satva parsīdä khu
gaṃgä nyāya gruīcyau sya ni vara byamā tcerā || namau bhagavate gagana-
jä nma gyastä baʾysä namasuṃ : namau bhagavate vajrrasāraprrama-
rrdanāya tathāgatāya rhate samyak-saṃbudhāya. tad yathā
Welfare! The twelve billions of lord buddhas called Ratnottama, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The eighteen billions of lord buddhas called Ratnāvabhāsa, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The twenty billions of lord buddhas called Śikhin, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twenty billions
of lord buddhas called Kāśyapa, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The sixty billions of lord
buddhas called Vimalaprabha, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ninety-five billions of lord buddhas
called Śākyamuni, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred thousand lord buddhas
called Indradhvaja, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred thousand lord buddhas called Suprabhāsa, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The ninety billions of lord buddhas called Krakasunda,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighteen billions of lord buddhas called Kanakamuni,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The three hundred billions of lord buddhas called *Avabhāsaśruta,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twenty-five billions of lord buddhas called Puṣya,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twelve billions of lord buddhas called Vipaśyin, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The two thousand billions of lord buddhas called Kauṭinya, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The eighty billions of lord buddhas called Svabhāvadharmottara, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The five thousand lord buddhas called Pradyota, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The five hundred
lord buddhas called Pratāpana, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighty thousand
lord buddhas called Nāga, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighty thousand lord buddhas
called Sālarāja, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred lord buddhas
called Śamatha, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ten thousand lord buddhas called Prasanna(-vadana)-utpala-gandha-kūṭa, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The (lord) buddhas everywhere, altogether forty billions, eighteen lakhs, seventeen thousand,
eight-hundred in front, whover hears their names, he has closed the path to the three (apāyas). He also does not go to Hell, nor to the ghosts,
nor to the animal state. Whoever teaches them, gains concentration (samādhāna) from it, he becomes a non-returner from bodhi.
No doubt should be entertained there.
q.note: = Ch.00268 lines 40-70 (IOL Khot S. 12), but with formula “Hail to the lord buddha.” ...
q.l: Hail to the lord buddha Ratnaketu! He who speaks his name will become as brilliant as a bejeweled banner.

Hail to the lord buddha Amitāyu! He who speaks his name, the acts and sins accumulated during eighty billions of eons will disappear for him; upon death he will obtain rebirth in Sukhāvatī. Hail to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara ...
the tathāgata called Aparamita-guṇa-ratna-śrī-vyūha-teja-rāja-kalpa! Hail to the tathāgata called
Sarva-dharma-pratibhāsa-vyūha-śrī! Hail to the tathāgata called
Sahasra-megha-garjita-svara-rājo! Hail to the tathāgata called Suvarṇottama-prabhāsa-śrī!
Hail to the tathāgata called Bahu-vividha-tejo-rāja-śrī-nirbhāso.
Hail to the tathāgata called Asaṃkhyeya-kalpa-koṭi-samudānīta-buddho.
Hail to the tathāgata called Sarva-dharma-naya-vikurvita-tejo.
Hail to the tathāgata called Guṇa-saṃkūsumito. 11. He who
learns, recites, or listens to the names of these buddhas, by the speaking of the name of each buddha,
(his) karmas will be destroyed for eons. In one birth he will realize budhdahood. Hail!
I do homage to the lord buddha called Samādhihasto!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Samādhihastottarapadmottaranakṣatrarāya! Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Padmottaraśrī!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Padmahasto!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Sūryamaṇḍalaprabhāsottamaśrī!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Sarvasūryottamāgniparipūrṇalakṣaṇakāyagātra!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Ekaratnachattra!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Sarvasamādhi-r-uttamavikrama!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Ratnakusumitasamantāvabhāsaśrī!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Anuttarapadmavikrama!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Anantagandhottamarāya!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Ratnamaṇḍalatejasamudgataprabhāsottamaśrī!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Ratnagarbha!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Ratnottama!
Hail! I do homage to the lord buddha called Sarvaratnapratimaṇḍitarūpadhārī!

Whoever orders the names of these lord buddhas to be written or pronounces them will have confession of the acts (that would lead to) unending hells. So many beings imprisoned in the world beyond will escape through him as the grits and sands of the river Ganges. No doubt should be entertained there.

Hail! I do homage to the gracious Lord Buddha called Gagana-śrī-rāja-vimala-rāja-samanaya-nirucira-guṇa-keta-prabhū-padma-kusuma-guṇa-sāgara-vaiḍūrya-raśmi-ratna-biṃba-kāya-gandha-vara-pravara-vimala-pati-ābha-ārca-vicitra-samalaṃkṛtauṣṇīṣa-mūrdha-aparimita-sūrya-pratibhāsa-raśmi-ratna-candra-pratimaṇḍita-sunirmita-praṇidhi-guṇa-vyūha-dharma-dhātu-atyudgata-aṣaṃga-ratna-rāja!
Hail! I do homage to the gracious Lord Buddha called Vajra-sāra-pramardana tathāgata ʾrhant samyak-saṃbuddha! Tad yathā ...

note.p: Lines 840-48 more cursive than the rest of the text.

q.l: . . ttū namau bhadrakalpya-sūttri u sūdhna-patträ sūtträ u kūlyāṃ ja-
stāṃ baʾysāṃ hīye nme. śāṃ khṅä hvāṃʾ : saṃgakä pasti pīḍe. baʾysña
baʾysūśti brrīya. jsnai huṣīye pīlai vyachīṃde. tti ṣṭāṃ puña rrvī vī
buʾysye jsña vī prriyaugaja haiśūṃʾ u tti ṣṭāṃ puña hvū:śęʾna paḍi māṃ tcū kyi-
na haṃbrrīhe u hāysi naysdi śau-gūttirä hvārakyāṃ brrātarāṃ jsa haṃbrrīhūṃ:
biśä satta baʾysa hamāṃde. tti pā a baʾysä hamne nauda : ṣiʾ sūtträ
pūhye māśti 20mye haḍai. ṣacū kīthi na purvabhadriva nakṣaʾträ vī śviʾ ha-
thāgattāya rhette sąmya-saṃbudhāya ttad yathā oṃ śudhane śudhane sarva-pāpa-śudhane śudhe vīśudhe sarva-karmāva-
Homage to this Bhadrakalpika-sūtra and the Sudhānapattra-sūtra and the names of the billions of lord
buddhas. Śāṃ Khṅä Hvāṃʾ Saṃgakä ordered (this) to be written
in love of the buddha-bodhi. May his life increase, his sufferings disappear! I give these merits to the court
for long life. And I share these merits with Óvū Śęʾna Paḍi Māṃ Tcū Kyi(na),
and I share (them) with the brothers and sisters of the same family near and far.
May all beings become buddhas! And then may I too become a buddha. Reverence! This sutra
I Sarvākāra(?) finished on the twentieth day of the fifth month, in the city of Shazhou, under the (25th) asterism of Pūrvabhādrapada at midday.Cf. lines 1103-4.
(Skt:) Hail to the three jewels! Hail to the king who purifies all evil states, tathāgata ʾrhant samyak-saṃbuddha! Tad yathā. Om! ... For the purification of all the impediments of all deeds!

note.p: End and colophon (cursive) of the Sumukha-dhāraṇī.

q.l: sumukha nma mahāynasuträ dāyya byja jsīñi kʾka vījya t¯naʾ u-
spurra dāśyā || || ttū namau sumukha sūttri śāṃ khṅä hvāʾ: saṃgakä pasti pīḍe buʾysye jsña
huṣme udiśāyi : pīla akālamaraṇai vyachme parivarttme vīra tsīṃde. nauda : sahaici
salya naumye māśti pūhye: haḍai ṣacū kīthi na sarvākāri dāśe : ||
The Mahayana sutra called Sumukha, the devotion to the Law, the knowledge protecting life, is finished (and)
completely completed. Homage to this Sumukha-sūtra! The saṃgaka Śāṃ Khṅä Hvāṃʾ ordered (this) to be written with a view to prolonging life.
May sufferings and untimely death go to disappearance and turning around(?)! Hail! In the year
of the Hare, the fifth day of the ninth month, in the city of Shazhou, I finished it completely.

note.p: Deśanā II. The same text as in lines 755-784, with some divergencies.

veraucaṃ gyastä baʾysä āstaṃna biśä gyasta baʾysa haṃtsa parṣiʾ jsa aysä śāṃ khīṅä hvāṃ saṃgakä paṃja-
namau āryāmittrai baudhisatvä namasuṃ || 1 namau āryāvalokteśva-
rä baudhisatvä namasuṃ 2 namau ākāśargarbhä baudhisatvä namasuṃ 3 namau āryāmaṃju-
śrī baudhisatvä namasuṃ 4 namau āryākṣitigarbhä baudhisatvä namasu || [na] namau āryā-
bhaiṣajyarājä baudhisatvä namasuṃ. namau āryāsamaṃttabhadrrä baudhisatva namasūṃ namau
āryāvajrrapṇä baudhisatvä namasuṃ namau āryāmṇabhāvä baudhisatva namasuṃ namau
namau piṇḍūrabharadvājä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau ka-
nakavatsä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau bakulä sthīrä namasuṃ : namau abhijä sthīrä namasuṃ ||
namau kanakabharadvājä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau kāṇḍä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau vajrrīputrä sthī-
rä namasuṃ || namau gaupakä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau pathaikä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau
rāhulä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau nāgasai(na) sthīrä namasuṃ || namau iṃgąṇḍä sthīrä namasuṃ ||
namau ajittä sthīrä namasuṃ || namau va(na)vāsä sthīrä namasūṃ || namau anarrųdä sthīrä na-
nāṃ lokyadhāttnāṃ tad yathā bhūje abhūje veḍa bhūje sūrave x ḍa bhūje mera bhūje garūḍa
bhūje attaṃga bhūje svārtha bhūje sarva-karmākṣaya bhūje svāhā :

msItem.q:
Welfare! The twelve billions of lord buddhas called Ratnottama, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighteen billions
of lord buddhas called Ratnāvabhāsa, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twenty billions of lord buddhas
called Śikhin, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twenty billions of lord buddhas called Kāśyapa,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The sixty billions of lord buddhas called Vimalaprabha, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The ninety-five billions of lord buddhas called Śākyamuni, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The eighteen billions of lord buddhas called Indradhvaja, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred lord
buddhas called Suprabhāsa, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ninety billions of lord buddhas called Krakasunda,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighteen billions of lord buddhas called Kanakamuni,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The three hundred billions of lord buddhas called Avabhāsaśruta, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The twenty-five billions of lord buddhas called Puṣya, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The twelve
billions of lord buddhas called Vipaśyin, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The two thousand billions of lord buddhas
called Kauṭinya, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighty billions of lord buddhas called Svabhāvadharmottara,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighty billions of lord buddhas called Candrasūryapradīpa, I do homage to them all.
Reverence! The five hundred lord buddhas called Pratāpana, I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The five thousand lord buddhas called Pradyota, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighty thousand
lord buddhas called Nāga, I do homage to them all. Reverence! The five thousand lord buddhas called Āditya,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eighty thousand lord buddhas called Sālarāja,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The eight hundred lord buddhas called Śamatha,
I do homage to them all. Reverence! The ten thousand lord buddhas called Prasannavadana-utpalagandhakūṭa,
I do homage to them all. Reverence!
The (lord) buddhas everywhere, altogether forty billions, eighteen lakhs, seventeen thousand, eight-hundred in front, whover hears their names becomes a non-returner from bodhi.
In the eastern direction I do homage to the lord buddha Akṣobhya. In the western direction I do homage to the lord buddha Amitāyu.
In the northern direction I do homage to the lord buddha Dundubhisvara. (In the southern direction I do homage to the lord buddha Ratnaketu.) In the first subdirection I do homage to the lord buddha Dharaṇiṃdhara.
In the second subdirection I do homage to the lord buddha Candraprabha. In the third subdirection I do homage to the lord buddha Nārāyaṇa.
In the fourth subdirection I do homage to the lord buddha Śāntendriya. The Lord Budddha Ratnaketu, the lord buddha Bhadraśrī, the lord buddha
Vairocana, and all the other lord buddhas together with their assembly I, Śāṃ Khṅä Óvāṃʾ the saṃgaka,
I do homage to standing in the five-maṇḍala.
From here, cf. also IOL Khot 83/3.Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Maitreya. 1. Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryāvalokiteśvara! 2.
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Ākāśagarbha! 3. Hail!
I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Mañjuśrī! 4. Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Kṣitigarbha! Hail! I do
homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Bhaiṣajyarāja! Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Samantabhadra! Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Vajrapāṇi!
Hail! I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Māṇabhāva! Hail!
I do homage to the bodhisattva Āryā-Dharmodgata!
Hail! I do homage to the elder Piṇḍurabharadhvāja. Hail! I do homage to the elder Kanakavatsa. Hail!
I do homage to the elder Bakula. Hail! I do homage to the elder Abhija.
Hail! I do homage to the elder Kanakabharadhvāja. Hail! I do homage to the elder Kāṇḍa. Hail! I do homage to the elder Vajriputra.
Hail! I do homage to the elder Gopaka. Hail! I do homage to the elder Parhaika. Hail!
I do homage to the elder Rāhula. Hail! I do homage to the elder Nāgasena. Hail! I do homage to the elder Iṃgaṇḍa.
Hail! I do homage to the elder Ajita. Hail! I do homage to the elder Vanavāsa. Hail! I do homage to the elder Aniruddha.
Hail! I do homage to the elder Cūḍapathai.
Hail to all the buddhas standing in the ten directions (and their) world spheres, such as Bhūje, etc.

note.p: Lines 1101-1106 more cursive than the preceding text; lines 1107-1109 larger cursive.

q.l: ysāṃ u baudhasatvāṃ u arahaṃdāṃ sthīrāṃ hīye nme. śāṃ khṅä hvāṃʾ: saṃgakä pasti pīḍe. buʾysye jsña prriyau-
gä udiśāyi. jsnai huṣvīye pīla akāla-maranai vyachīṃde. nauda : sahaici salya dasamye māśti 8
haḍai. pūrvabhadriva nakṣaʾtträ vī ṣacū na dāśe nauda : || : tti ṣṭāṃ puña mārā-pyarāṃ jsa haṃbrrīhe cu pa-
rya īṃde ttyāṃ ga viśeṣäʾ hamāte. cu jūṃdā ṣṭāṃde ttyāṃ jsna huṣvīye. tti ṣṭāṃ puña hāysi naysdä hvārakyāṃ
brrātarāṃ jsa haṃbrrīhūṃ. haṃbistä ṣṭną āṃ baʾysūśti pariṇmūṃ nauda :
ttāya rhitte sąmasaṃbuddhāya. ttad yathā auṃ śudhane śudhane sarva-pā-
Those names of the billions of bhadrakalpika lord buddhas
and bodhisattvas and arhats and elders, the saṃgaka Śāṃ Khṅä Hvāṃʾ ordered (them) to be written with a view to the requirement for a long life.
May his life increase, may sufferings and untimely death disappear! Reverence! In the Year of the Hare, the eighth day of the tenth month,
under the (25th) asterism of Pūrvabhādrapada in the city of Shazhou, I finished (it).Cf. lines 846-7. Reverence! I share those merits with my parents, who have passed on.
May there be a special place (gati) for them. Those who are alive, may their life increase! I share these merits with the sisters
and brothers near and far. Having shared (them), may I ripen them for bodhi. Reverence!
Hail to the three jewels! etc.

note.p: Hoernle’s “Ch.i. 0021. b.” Vajrayāna texts. Guide2 [18.37]. The manuscript contains three texts: Ch.i.0021b.b (65 lines) covers the whole of one side; Ch.i.0021b.a (47 lines) covers four-fifths of the other side; the third text (13 lines) covers one-fifth of the same side, but starts at the opposite end of the manuscript, so that the ends of the two texts meet (cf. Ser., p. 1452). The third text was not read by Bailey; only individual akṣaras can now be identified, and it is not certain that it is part of Ch.i.0021b.b, though it is possible. Present location unknown. Photo B13451-58 and microfilm. Photos and microfilm are difficult to read; the present text is after Bailey. Cā Kīmä Śanä also wrote the Jātakastava (Ch.00274, IOL Khot 65-82).
Metrical text. The date in lines 43-46 = 971. For the names see Mallmann, 1975. Provisional translation.

q.l: [1] mveʾśdiʾ jsa varą hakṣį pattrīnä : ttuki ttā kaitta {x} akāṣṭa na harśtą ṣaʾ ja na ye dauṣką
ca jä b[v]eyse bāḍä nva hakṣa hauḍaudä sedä ūvārä : [2] asadyau kīry jsa cū vāysa-
nū gu ṣä : hūryara bvāṣṭa jsa ttu mäśpa rraṣṭä : amrrattakū[ṇḍa]lakrrāda-rāji {pa}
paysnä : arpahiʾkrrādä nīlädaṇḍä pacīḍi [3] vi[d]y[ā x]pä āstaṃnä hauva-
nä mįstą : dārañā hvṣṭä aśigrīva hūdahä : dva ṣaṇḍįbhūjicarä
pūrvakä mālä : ʾīchā bīdaubi tcūrä-śaumī śerka [4] rhśai hairūkä
pīrmāttaṃ piṃjsą drāviṇṇḍą krrādi cara kīla kīlä krrādi acalä ṭakirā-
jä : hąyągrīva pacīḍa : māhābilą: amäsųbāhyį asīda-ka-
rma : [5] asądaraṇ naṣṭęvākä vajrrāṇḍāsą krrādi : haṣṭ ysārä y-
geʾśūri krrāda narākṣįʾ : harbīśu namūsūṃ aysą jsṇäkyä ṣṭnä: pa-
śarū hūryarau seddha ūvārä [6] ṇįheʾjära bįśa dīśāṃʾ byįnadāṃ
ra vajrrakūśa āstaṃnä dvāraplä tcahaurä: haṣṭa pūjinīyi :
haṣṭį māttara pātcä: ttārāgyį ʾekigyaṭilą ttrīlākyittagārä: [7] cū tta
mārīca seda lācani nvęyą brrūkūṭä āra-ttārru cū ra vajrra-śakhalä : ā-
ra-mūmäkä sąrasvą rayanīḍa ttaradira ttrāmīryau hamirrvā mi [8] cvi ra jsā
pīlä mara āchai pvęṇi: hatharkyi gārīyų hūnä vīśuʾnä amaṃgalīyi
pavasvyį hīra ʾīde bīśi byjärä tta tta khva pāśąra baurä: [9] dreṣṭrri saṃnāhi [s]i-
da saṃttamäkā hūra ma mūäʾśdäʾ jsä ttū sęda ūvārä: khvi ra jsä vęrśuʾ tvā sa-
dį na nvatte ttī mahābūvā hye devatta pātcä: [10] kada x bājąstą: śakrra-kṣe-
yį-darūṇi: hatsa parvāra jsa mihākętta yaudi ttaradarä dāttavi khva mūñīda
raṣṭį: amanūṣa-rjä pajsa hauvanä mista: [11] cu ra dīśāpāla haṣṭį gūtta-
rä nāva: pajv kūlvā ahärīnaka pātcä maṇḍalä-sthāṃ prrtta devatta bī-
śä harbīśū habaista saṃ cū būrä hamāvai: [12] mahā vā spauśīryā mūʾśd[ī]ʾ-
nai tceṃnä jsä byehūṃ mū-ysaṃthi mara madrvā sędä: vañä ra ttū biʾysñi są-
mį byāva yinīryā khva narūpąra beysśti ttye hakṣa prrabvanä
[13] bauga va krrāddha-rāji hīyai ttu parau ūvārä: na pahaijärä raṣṭä vī khva
na jīryā bįśa: cu būra mä vajrradāttä ttye maṇḍalä vīrä vyachavą-dāva gya-
sta bęysą hamīḍi [14] harāśaʾra bāysvę mä beṃdāṣṭį vaysñą: byājira ki-
rma jīnyara vāysni pymä: cū būra vā ysaṃthvā aysą jaḍī prracai ā-
varṇä hajsädeṃ bęśdeʾ garkhye [15] vañi ama dāyį baiysñä sąrva hūryi-
rä deśanä karmāna bīśāṃ: anāsrrą rī savara ṣaʾ sūrai hamāvai a
dīśāʾ karma aysä ma na ttā tsīme [16] saṃtsāra myñä dūkhāṃ vaṣayā byędä
śena tcūnä rrudi bveysą jsīnä hamāve gyaśtä rīñä raiysdvąrāṃ respūrāṃ ha-
baiśa ysatha vaṣṭä jāsamara hamānai [17] sījāñāka madrā baiśa pīchaṣṭa sedä
tsą shye bāḍa saṃpatta sauhi yaudį hṣī marrjsāṃ jāṃde-ṃ karma cā kimä
śanä cu rä śuʾsteṃ tvā deśanä aysä vyachīmę [18] raṣṭyį vasvą dāya prrarą
vījsyānai vajrrasątva paṣąʾ jsa hätcą byehīne pīrmāttä lāäyī sędä
cū burä jsā bāvīnai lākāttarä: harbīśä sījīye ñavānä raysgą-t-ī
[19] sūmīra garä śaśvā jsā ttīma hamagä. sūmīra garä pūṣą ttrāyau tta śaśvāṃ
myñä bīśī hā baiśnä hatsa tcauryā dvīpyau: ttrahi sąlya pā saṃtsārī baiśa
bāvaña gīśīñä [20] ttī drā-mūjsi harbaiśa ttrvāyį stāsą jsā ṣkāṃjā vīna
rana padīmä ṣkāja hūrrāgye ma ja hūsą byadanä ma jsą haspīsą jauyi jāmana-masą [21] cū ttį krrīyāṃ ū-
vārä gyastuñi gueṃ pūṣa dyau vajrra-sątva tcauryā bvaiyā śrrī-vajrra-sa-
tva dįśanä cvai cā kīmä-śanä hīye aysmū jsa padaidai ūsp-
ra dāśā || thyena tcūnä sūhye bāḍį pūhye kṣuṇä pasa sälya ttaujįrä mā-
śtä hdūsąmye haḍai nadąva kūṣḍvī nä dā rāysąnāṃdi baudhasąttu vīśaʾ śūrä cai-
ga rāṃdānä rrādi hīye bveysyę ḡyastuñe ūvārye dra-vargye jsīña prrī ūdaśaiyą
cā kīma-śanä hīye gauttrą aysmū jsą edrai jsa śuʾste u padaidai u pīḍai || ||
In compassion there truth ..., ... considers, unconsidered does not remain. That was not difficult, that for a long time, according to truth they gave exalted siddhi(?).
On account of evil acts, which ... vāsanas, give ... that right road! ... Amṛtakuṇḍalin krodha-rāja, Arpahiʾ-krodha, Nīladaṇḍa in turn.
Vidyā ... and the others powerful great ones. The best of (in?) dhāraṇīs, Aśigrīva, the su/sat-puruṣa. The two, Ṣaḍbhuja-cara and Pūrvaka-māla. Icchā bīdaubi the four-faced, beautiful one.
The *five mystery-*giver(s) drāviṇḍą krodha cara kīla kīlä krodha Acala, Ṭakkirāja, Hayagrīva in turn. Mahābala, amäsųbāhyį asiddha-karma.
The burner of evil ones, Vajrrāṇḍāsą krodha, the eighty thousand Yogeśvara-krodha Narākṣįʾ, to all of them I bow and do homage. Release me(?)! Give me exalted siddhi!
Restrain the ... in all the directions, the vajra-kośa and the others, the four gate-keepers, the eight pūjaneyas(?), and then the eight mātras(?). Ttārāgyį Ekajaṭila, Trilokya-ttagārä
The things that appear as mirages ... following ... Bhṛkuṭī, Ārya-tārā, as well as Vajrra-śakhalä (Vajra¬śṛṅkhalā?) Ārya-mūmäkä, Sarasvatī, Rayanīḍa, go into (my) body, into my limbs!
Whatever sufferings, illnesses, fears, anxieties, distresses, evil dreams, unfavorable, ... things there are, make all dissolve, like snow in autumn.
dreṣṭrri saṃnāhi [s]i-da saṃttamäkā give me out of compassion this exalted siddhi! If (my?) energy does not ... this siddhi, then the deities of the mahā-bhūtas.
They look after (me/them?) bājąstą: śakrra-kṣeyį-darūṇi together with retinue Mahāketu always. Body ... if they dwell truly(?), the five great powerful amanuṣa-rājas.

As well as the protectors of the directions, the eight gotra-nāgas(?), next all the ones in the five kulas(?). All the deities prrtta of(?) the ones standing in the maṇḍala, all of them altogether as many as there are.
Look at me with your eye of compassion. Let me obtain here in this birth siddhi in the mudrās(?). Recall now this buddha ... as the nirupara(?) bodhi, by the might of its truth.
... this exalted order of the krodha-rāja. Do not ... as many here in the vajra sphere in this maṇḍala all the lord buddhas altogether who have ...
Stretch out your arms upon me now! Make the karmas dissolve, destroy the covering of vāsana! All the āvaraṇas, severe sins, I have acculmulated in births on account of folly.
Now, you buddha lions of the Law give me confession of all karmas! The ... saṃvara, may it become clean! I confess the karmas. May I not go thither!

In the middle of saṃsāra, in the domain of sufferings, may Śena Tcunä, the king’s life be long, together with the lady queen, the princesses, and the princes. May I remember all births throughout my births.

Making the mudrās succees, they all appear in full view(?). May the success and happiness of a happy time always increase! ... they have destroyed the karmas for me(?), Cā Kīmä Śanä, I who prepared this confession, may I ...

May I see the true pure nature of the Law(?). May I obtain the foremost vajra-sattva together with his assembly. May all the ... appear, all the ..., lokottara. May it all succeed ... quickly for him.

Like Mount Sumeru (and) a seed of mustard. Mount Sumeru I introduce into the middle of the mustard (seed), all of it completely together with the four continents. ... of saṃsāra then I would make turn in the bhāvana.
Then I would introduce all the ... on the tip of a hair, without the saṃskāras I would make jewels(?) ... ...
I who have ... completely that exalted buddha dhyāna(?) vajra-sattva with the four rays Śrī-vajrasattva the confession which Cā Kīmä Śanä has made with his mind is completely finished.

The fifth regnal year of the happy time (regnal period) Tianzun, in the Year of the Sheep (= 971), the month of Ttuṃjārā, the 17th day, ... residing in the palace, ruling in the Law, the bodhisattva Viśaʾ Śūra, king of kings of the Chinese—with a view to ... of his long, divine, exalted, ... life, I Cā Kīmä Śanä prepared, made, and wrote it with (my?) gotra, mind, and senses.

note.p: “The Vajrayāna verses of Cā Kīmä-Śani.” Tr. Bailey, 1978, with some revised readings (see Guide2, p. 39). Cf. the beginning of Ch.i.0021a.a (IOL Khot S. 21). The text on the b side, 13 lines going in the opposite direction was not read by Bailey. Only individual akṣaras can now be identified, and it is not certain that it is part of the text on the a side.

q.l: [1] siddhaṃ aurga [ʾī] baysñāṃ rrādau-t-āṣṭä: āryavįrūca āstani hamīḍa ttye vīśaʾr[i]
hīye gūtteräni hamye rani vī ysāyi: [2] abiṣekä dījskä vīysaña ysā vīysąña ha-
mye ttathattā-vrrarä attuśīmä nāmai baʾysuña sar: siddhavīdyādarā j hūrāki ṇe x
tcura-vadī kīrä jsa [3] cu [py]ūvīʾde gūstya rąheśāʾ mistyāṃ ttatrāṃ jsa niradä vasveKBT: bvaste. pārmą padi bā-
yīdä kṣasä. baudhacaittä hīvye vīvā jsa nirada. [4] vajrra-pārma baʾysñä rahāsä. tcana ṣṭāṃ
grśte vajrrą-satvä uvārä. aharīni baʾysuñä gūttįra dījsākä: ttani cu vīna ttīmaKBT: ttrrīsa. na hama vī-
vā-vargą. savrrini baʾysūśtiB.: baʾ tsunau. pīrmāttamą hvāṣṭą. [5] sagrahāvasyā *tcahaureMs. re tcahau. muiʾśdiʾ prracįną. tcana haṃ-
dāḍi satva baʾysśtāṣṭą: ṣāʾ māh-pārauma gārśti vasvą: tcahryā ddharmyā ṣʾ cu rahniva-
jrra [6] rahįśvā dharmyā bvāme jsa naradi {j} jñāna-pārāma pīrmāttama hvṣṭa ttāhirji mesta vasva
adū ag pāʾ darmavajrrą cu ṣṭā gauśte najsaḍanä [7] vasvą ādarna vī ñānarthā rąṣṭa
ṣāʾ karmavajrrą cu pārma gārśte. tcahauryā pārāmā hīyą mā-v-ū rīnä dānapārma
cvaį grūsīdą lāsaṃ [8] cu ṣṭau tcarkāñi vasva vīvā gihni: pajsa ge vīra sarvasatvā kiṃṇą.
rahiśe tcarka naharyā cu pacaḍani: abīysādye gāttrani āvastā satva 8 [9] cve uskhastą
pįsāre ranyā uḍą ttu parāhīne bu tcu rruśā aga: ttani ṣʾ nāma mālą devatta hvāṣṭą
śīlą-pārāma baʾysuña najsaḍani: 9 [10] kṣāṃʾtta-pārāma ṣʾ devatta gīttą: ṣāʾ cu yaṃda ʾ-
jsiṃʾ baʾysnä bīśāną: vīra-pārauma ṣʾ devatta nįttra tcana byehīde rraysgąna bąʾ-
ysųśti hvāṣṭi: [11] dhyāna-pāraumä ṣāʾ devatta pūṣpą: akhamįstą brrīyīne agavīką: hajva-
ttįvīji ṣąʾ pārauma hvāṣṭą ṣāʾ dhųpi devatta āvāḍālāki: 10 1 [12] vīra sañi buśaṃjsa
tte bvaijsīje uvārre: cu baʾśti tcu patsyā satsārrve bśä: vasva prraṇahauni ṣąʾ rrude
jsa añaṣṭi: ṣʾ vajrralāka mįsta devatta hvṣṭą 10 2 [13] ca byādā pāraumvā hastimį rāśąʾ
śera mįsta hauva visvą bvāma rraṣṭa ṣ jñnapārāma devatta mestą. jaḍīne vāmnį natcī-
phāka janāką 10 3 [14] ajattą ṣʾ devatta. māryau jsa avurrdą. bīysānāmi jsa bīysānāme
baʾḍa vajrra-pārāme ākṣīva prracįna. paṣṭāña dāvīnai rraṣṭa parau 10 4 [15] uysānā
bātta vasva dharma anātmi ṣāʾ vajrra-devatta-prāma gāhya anapūrrvā mistą samāhāna ra-
hāsą. vajrrmai byehaʾ dharmakāyą vasvą 10 5 [16] harbiśe baʾysñe bvāmi gīhni: daśte saña hī-
ye parapāką prracainą tcūra-vadye pįṣkeca jsa hagyeḍa satvą. ttana ṣṭāṃ nāma mį hvāṣṭa vajrrakūśą
10 6 [17] uvārye baʾysūñe caryi prracįnä gujsabrrīyį. ʾiʾdryā hageva raṣṭą. ttanai ṣāʾ nāma hvā-
ṣṭi vajrrapāśą haraṣṭą natcani hadāḍį satva baʾysūśtṣṭį 10 7 [18] hama-hadarāña jsa
āvastį gāttrį baʾysūñe hajsara vī parajsa śaumä muiʾśdäʾ prracaina dharmadhāttā keʾtti: ttanį ṣāʾ nā-
mą vajrrasphṭa uvāra 10 8 [19] cu ṣṭā baʾśa bāva sarvadarma anātmä anāstana bā krra ʾī-
yāda naṣauʾda ttu vajrrayāni māyāna bīrāśe. ttye keṇā gāśte vajrragaṇḍą uvāra: [20] baysū-
ña pīrmātta yāna mīḍāji ṣiʾ ra ttā ʾaurgą saki(ci) jsṇakyi ṣṭāni. ttara jsā pajsami ṣārī yąnämä
pātca bīśuñe vāysanä drīṣṭīyę pāra. [21] baka-ādarna neravabāsa haysīde. vī-
jsyāne mulaja baʾysa devatta krrādha ttathattā-vrrari maraṇa-kle dedai dasta [22] ma jsa bāyī-
dį hīyvīā kūlvā vījsyāne vajrra-satva parṣaʾ jsa hatcą habāḍa vāma bedāṣṭi bvįyą pa-
pajsai bveyā jsa tsve hamānai aysä
śīda [23] ysīce śīye āṣanį cu ra hiṃje ysąrūnį: ttera biʾdi ma beda ttakyį bveyą
vaṣṭīde hamaune paṣiʾ jsa hama-nasą hamagi: vīna jaḍī ṣąmāra yāda paraśādha ʾīme
[24] dīśāʾ vīdaś jsa jista baʾysa anatta baudhasatvyā jsa hatsa ṣāvā-kramni yanī-
mį pūji pajsa bvīnū spyā jsa carā arga hįśīʾ{bye}ne harbeśa bāḍa [25] byehīne pīrmā-
ttamą dhāyą rrāśti cu vā mu-ysītha cu vā hada-ysatha āvarṇa hajsāde jaḍī prra-
(cai)na (a)hakhįṣṭe [26] merū pyara ysurra prracįnä cu bura vā yāla arā jsa jūṣū kūlą a hīye
pīsāṃ hama dāyāṃ ttyāṃ hve ʾīmä gajse
hera nāsmi byūṃg biśdeʾ brrīye prracaina cū vā ma ttakyį tcesta tta karma: [27] vaña a-
ma dāyą baʾysūña sarauva byājara karma jīnyara vāysina pyāma geśīme
pīrmātta dāyī cakrra haṣṭūsa kṣairadairsa kūla māra hīye hīnä [28] harbaiśa vīśeʾra jsa a
purrda yinīme byehīne tcra rreda-pāla pacaḍni kṣiʾ abiʾña hadrāysyi tsū āśäʾ
tcana byāśeʾ lvadā anatti hīsīme [29] vajrrakūlą rraysgi thy vījsyne mulajä tta {tta}
ttu cakrra vīśeʾ{cu}ri: rana vįysi: vįśu-virrji jsa hatsi ttyāṃ hīye bījākṣaʾra
hva hva pajsaṃ {hūrīda hva hva ma} [30] byehīnai pīrmttama seda uvāri lāyī mi lākttara ʾipįhī raysgi kṣāʾ-gavu
satva bīśū jsāṇakyi ṣṭāni: [31] namadrvāna ttrāmāde baląprravįśāṣṭi abiʾyipū-
ra kūṣṭi baiśa pvaiṇa naṣāʾdi biʾysuña bumi byehīde mestą: śiṃ kūnä rau tcū
bueysa-jsīña hamāve [32] jaśte rīña raysdvyārā rrespū(rā) hatsi bueysa bāḍa sapatta sāha
aṇeʾscya rāśäʾ bveysa-jsī{n}ña hamāvį nva a{ysa}ysm kīrā sījāṣṭyą ūvārä
yāda hūṣī [33] paracakrra hīna jsā pveṇa harīysa dārabaikṣa hīyi phera
brrathu bāri śve śalarba tcmų cu ra āchā hvą hvą na hamāṃde haiṣṭi vī mara mā-
je bāḍä vī [34] mara jsā sījīdį madrrū maudrrai {dai karma} cā kīma-śani cu tvā sa deśani śuʾstą khva na hamye ʾī śalāvyā
jsa nvaśtā būma vi ñaśaki ye ʾidrre nvāśkye || ||
[35] pīḍai kṣa ga vī ysamaśadi vī byehīdai tvaka būaima rauśaʾde kara jsā pāraume baiśa sątva baiysa hamādį cakrravartta aṇeʾstyi-rāśaʾ ṣaʾ ttā pā baiysa hamāvį
[36] siddhap ʾaurga tsū vajrrą-sątva paṣaʾ jsa hatsi cū paurde ysąmäśade biśa sątva-dāttä
dva-pądya lāki vī avathīyi parau vįrśaʾ pjsę jsä. [37] nyāṃdi hastamä bumä mįysdyānau
vaską kaḍa ūvāra muäʾśdäʾṣe pastargāṃ vaską ñaharka daji vīnaustą ha(da)ña ysīthi haurāki
pīrmātta ñąha : ttanai tsū ʾaurga sąkąʾca jsāäṇe ṣṭnä [38] biʾysą ynä hastamä dā dūkhā jänākä dū-
ṣaʾbaustä bįysā dā {dā kirmai jīnākä} būmä mistä : drrą-bāḍau beysā hī ghye rahsä cvi nä spąva
mįste puñi bumä hauvaṃ khvaṃ pīnä bįysā pyatsa artha jsą rra x x ysą jäḍa karmau ||
[39] cā kīmä-śani cū vañi ttye kalyākyįʾ bāḍä bīse ysaṃtha. bakyi va ʾedre vatvavapattye
ysīra tta tta kṣamä khva dįmä pīrmāttama hautą: [40] yanīry āysdi h ha bāḍa va-
ysñä khva ra byehūṃ hastara sījāṣṭä ūvārä: vąjrrą-sątva hīye tv pāṣa ūvārä
parau pahąuna khva a na jsīvana jsāvę: [41] hvāṃda ttrattrąkalpadāräñi maṃdrrį vīstāṃda hā
Welfare! [There be] reverence toward the buddha kings, all of them, Āryā-Vairocana and the others, arisen from the gotra of his vajra, born in a jewel.
The holder of the abhiṣeka, born in a lotus, arisen in a lotus, having the nature of truth (tathatā-prakṛti), his name Non-empty, a buddha lion, siddha-vīdyādhara giver of ... by (his) fourfold act.
Those who hear the deliverance in the mystery gone out of the great tantras lead (along?) the six paths of pure pāramitā. They have gone out from the fruition of the bodhi-citta.

The vajra-pāramitā, the buddha mystery, from which the exalted vajra-sattva is named, upholder without remainder of the buddha gotra. Because, without seed there is no vipāka-varga. Through *saṃvaraB.: saṃvṛtya “by connotation.” (is) the best foremost bodhi.
On account of the compassion of the four saṃgraha-vastus, by which beings are nurtured toward bodhi, this mahā-pāramitā is called pure, through the four dharmas, this one, which (is) the ratna-vajra.
Gone out from the knowledge of the dharmas in the mysteries, the best foremost jñāna-pāramitā, real, great, pure, *undimmed, *undefiled, what is called dharma-vajra in (this?) manner. 6.
Pure, informed about ādharaṇa(?), true, this karma-vajra which is called a pāramitā, their mother, queen of the four pāramitās, (is) the dāna-pāramitā, which they call Lāsā.

Whatever plesures (there are?), with the help of pure fruition, for the sake of beings in the five gatis, what (is) in the mystery of play and pleasures in turn, by an unawakened gotra are beings *attached(?). 8.
Those garlands *raised up, covered with jewels that *perfume of śīla, *which (are its?) shining members, therefore this name: the deity Mālā the best, the buddha śīla-pāramitā in turn. 9
The kṣānti-pāramitā, this (is) the deity Gītā, this one who makes songs by the tongue of the buddhas. The vīrya-pāramitā, this (is) the deity Nṛtyā, by which they obtain quickly best bodhi.
The dhyāna-pāramitā, this (is) the deity Puṣpā, *unshaken by the ... of desire(?). The best pāramitā of knowledge, this is the deity Dhūpā ... 11.
The exalted meritorious perfumed energy (and) saṃjñā (saṃjñas?), who ... in the forest of saṃsāra, pure vows, she is *undespised by light(?). this (is) the great deity Vajralokā, the best. 12.
She(?) who obtained in the pāramitās best control, good, great, power, pure, true knowledge, this is the great jñāna-pāramitā deity, the repressor (and) destroyer of the flood of ignorance. 13.
Ajitā, this (is) the deity unconquered by the māras; through awakening at the time of awakening, on account of the ākṣepa of the vajra-pāramitā. The divine true command should be set out upon(?). 14.

He knows the self (to be?) pure dharma, anātma, this (is) the vajra-devatā-pāramitā, hidden(?), of those in sequence, the great samādhi(s), the mysteries. He obtains the pure dharma-kāya made of vajra.See Emmerick, 1981b, p. 451.

With the help of the entire buddha knowledge, on account of the ripening (paripāka) of skill in the means, she gathers beings from the four-fold *division: therefore my(?) name is the best Vajrāṅkuśī. 16.
On account of the exalted buddha career *overcome, *longing of the senses, true, therefore this (is) best name: Vajra-pāśī, extended within she nurtures the beings toward bodhi. 17.

(Her) gotra *attached to *same-and-otherness she *enters the entrance to the buddha sphere. For the sake of compassion she observes the dharma-dhātu. Therefore this (is her) exalted name: Vajra-sphoṭā.
Whatever ... sarva-dharmas (there are, are) anātma, without beginning, ..., always extingushed: she propounds this Vajrayāna (as) *Mahayana(?). Therefore she is called the exalted Vajra-gaṇṭhā.
The foremost gracious buddha-yāna, to you I do reverence, homage, bending over, with my forehead I do ... worship (and) then all kinds of vāsanas (and) dṛṣṭis ..

Through little care(?) they lead (to?) niravabhāsa(?). May I see the mūlaja buddhas, the deities, the krodhas. At the time of death they appear to him/her as so much(?) tathatā-prakṛti, they give abhiṣeka, just so they appeared exalted to you(?).
They lead from me in their own kulas(?). May I see the vajra-sattva surrounded by his assembly. Filled with rays may I be able to go onto the waves(?) they emit rays (?)
yellow, white, blue, as well as red, green. Those so many rays stand on ... May I have the same share as (and) be equal to the assembly. Without the darkness of folly may I always be purified.

From the directions and subdirections, to unlimited lord buddhas together with the bodhisattvas ... I shall make worship and homage with incense and flowers. I shall go in reverence, I shall always give.

May I obtain the supreme rule of the Law. Whatever *uncounted obstructions I have accumulated in this life, hatever in other lives on account of folly, to these teachers of the same Law(?) may I be able to tell (my) sins(?)

Or whatever evil deeds (I have committed) on account of anger (toward? my) mother and father, through envy ... acquisition of things, calumny and sins on account of desire, or whatever those karmas (are) ... thus for me(?).
Now you, buddha lions of the Law, dissolve (my) karmas, destroy the confusion of the vāsanas. May I turn the formemost wheel of the Law! 16 (or) 36 billions armies of Māra,
all with the vajra may I conquer! May I obtain the four ṛddhi-pādas in turn, the six abhijñas, may I walk in the air, may I cross over ..., may I come to unlimited lokadhātus!
May I very quickly see the *vajra-kula, the mūla-ja cakra-vajra(?), the jewel lotus together with its ... leaf(?). Worship severally of their bījākṣaras.
May I obtain the foremost exalted siddhi, laukika ... lokottara quickly all the beings in the six(!) gatis, standing bent in reverence.
At (my?) invitation may they all enter the bala-praveśa, Abhaya-pura, where all fears are extinguished. May they obtain the great buddha earth! May Śiṃ Kūnä Rau Tcū have a long life!

May he have long life in endless dominion (and) exalted success in his deeds according to his mind! For the lady queen together with the princesses and princes for a long time may success and happiness grow!
Foreign armies, fear and dread, the *disturbance of famine, storm and rain, – ... locusts, ..., as well as illnesses, may they severally not be at all here in our land!
May the mantras and mudrās succeed for Cā Kīma Śani who prepared this confession. – If there had not been for the difficulty of ślokas, ...
I wrote it for the world in the six gatis. May they obtain ... knowledge, ... – May all beings become buddhas, and may also this cakravartin of endless dominion become a buddha!
Welfare. I go in reverence to the vajra-sattva together with his assembly, who has conquered all the sattva-dhātus in the world(?) – two-fold laukika ... command, by support on energy.

They will be seated in the best earth for the sake of the ones to be pitied, very exalted compassionate, for the sake of the ..., – a giver of painful chastisement and punishment in another birth, foremost ..., therefore I go to him in reverence standing bowed in respect.

The buddha-yāna, the best Law, destroyer of woes, the *awaker of wrong knowledge, great earth, – he who ... the hidden mystery of the buddhas of the three times, the great merit earth I am able to fall before the buddhas(?). Through (its) meaning ... he destroys (my?) karmas, mine.
Cā Kīmä Śani’s, whose births are now in this ... land, – (my) senses small, ... in (my) heart it pleases (me) to see the supreme power.
Protect me ... time/land now, so that I may obtain better exalted success, – this exalted community of the vajra-sattva. ... so that ...
They have spoken the *Tantra-kalpa-dhāraṇī, they have placed the mantras, ...

note.p: Square double wooden tablet containing two documents (1/1-2). 18x18.5x3 cm. Clay seal still intact.

q.l: ysai ttye pracaina cu ni ṣṭā kṣīʾrū kīrä nä hau-
ste pīhya ve 2500 mrä aurīṣṭa spāta
salī 1 māśtä 10 haḍā 22 ṣṣę kṣųṇä miṣḍā gyastä
hvaṃni misti rrāṃdäna rrāṃdi viśya sīhye ttye scye
ṣ girya-vāḍä pāḍa ttye pracaina cu hamīḍa bi-
rgaṃdaraja ʾauya pharṣṣa visaunana mrä jistāṃ-
dä 2000 ṣṣau guṇakä salya bisā namatä paji-
stāṃdä ttī mī pharṣa visauna mrä paji(stä?) śau dva na
ttī nä mī ʾauvaRead auya? mrä ni hauḍä yuḍāṃdä ttī mī ṣiʾ naḍä bra-
dāysai tta hve sä aysä nä ʾāṃ kṣīʾrva kīrä
ni hauvä ttī mī hamīḍa ʾauya tta hvāṃdä sä vañ-e śe
hvaṃḍye kṣīrū kīrä thaṃjāṃ mrā jsa nāsmani ttī mī
mī pharṣa visauna hauḍāṃdä 2500 mūrä ttī mī bra-
paysā brātä brīyakä nma ttū ṣṭāna a-
ysä vaṃña parāthū pīhya ve 2500 mūrä
aśtä haṃdära-prrūyī pharṣa visauna ṣeʾ tta hve si
gänä aysä vaṃña ttū naḍāṃ brīyakä hauḍä pha-
rṣa visauna mūrä nä ni vara puḍä nātä bradāysai mrä
nai nä varāṃ vistātä ṣä gvārä aurīṣṭa spāta visa-
lä na ye u aurīṣṭa pharṣa śirārrjāṃ u aurīṣṭa
biśūṃ — haṃgramajā ʾauyāṃ tti burä vara bynä
ya parramai ṣuyaraṃ || parramai puñadattä || parra-
mai saṃgakä parramai malārrjāṃ || ttī ra ṣāʾ pāḍa prąm-
na himi khuī spā(ta) visalä pyaśdä u parramā haṃgrī
ma āṃ aysī ra pīḍeṃ ʾauyāṃ kaʾrä kharadattä ʾauyāṃ
parauna u naḍāṃ bradāysai salāna ṣi naḍä
ʾī āstaṃna pharṣa visauna rrāśya hi-

q.l: mi hāvigārī cu padīmātä pharṣa padīmä
q.note: Left inside edge of cover tablet:
q.l: khu vā brātarāṃ mūrä hämāde 2500 pharṣa nāsti
|| salī 2 10 māśt[ä] 10 1 ṣ[i] kṣuṇä miḍāṃ gyast[i] hvaṃn[i] m[i]sti rrāṃ-
dä viśaʾ dharmä ttye sce ṣā draṃmāja-vāḍi pāḍa ttye pracaina cu bu-
śai māmattī upadatti birgaṃdarajibrirgaṃdara corrected to birgaṃdara? dūmesalā bradāysai
u virsa u brīyakä hamīḍa ṣṭna hīvī pājä pārä pāsti pī-
hya ve mūri 1000 nāṃdä mī tti draya brātari [mā]mattī upadatti-
na biśi praṃnavi mūri 1000 baña byaha-ṃ ʾāna ni vara vāra
ye u ttyāṃ mī yseryeṃ -- mūrāṃ ysaṃthaji ganaṃ haurīdä paṃ-sa
lyepa kūsa 30 u pa -- [sa vi]śtñä khaysmaṃji vīra kuṣṭa ṣṭā ga-
naṃ ni hauḍi yanīdi -- khu kṣīra ganaṃ viṣṭī tta tta māmattī mūri hau-
rīdi ni haḍi hauḍi yanīdi ttī naḍauni brīyaki biśa bāyi ttuā-
nī bīsauñä parī khuai kṣamī u nai [ṣa]va rrāśa u ni haḍā ttye pracaina ttū
pāri nāṃdä cu rvī ganaṃ puḍa yi tti buriri corrected from tti? vara byni vya pumaṣīrai
br[y]anaṃdä u daṃtä u kīśaina nerattä u pumaṣīrai ʾīrasaṃgä u kījai
paśterai ttī ra ṣe draṃmāja-vāḍi pāḍa prąmāṃdara himi khu hā virsa u brīya-
| virsa | haṃ gu ṣṭi | | ki haṃguṣṭi viśtāri aysī ra pī-
brī | ya kä | haṃ gu ṣṭi | ḍeṃ kaʾ[rä] ʾṇakä naḍauni bradāysai
salāna u vir[s]a x x x
four parramais parramais (2) of Birgaṃdara (were?) in the assembly
when(?) this document concerning a deed of purchase (was drawn up)
[for the reason that the] pharṣa Visauna
because he could not do state work,
Before the spāta Visala (and the man) Datta Brīyaka.
Year 2, *month 10, (day?) 11, the regnal year of the gracious lord great
king of Khotan, Viśaʾ Dharma. At that time, this document concerning money-makers was (drawn up) for the following reason, that
Buśai (the buśai?) Māmattī Upadatta resident of Birgaṃdara *received the *individual work capacity of Dūmesalāṃ Bradāysai,
Virsa, and Brīyaka all together for the price
of 1000 mūrās. So the three brothers received from Māmattī Upadatta
all the *stipulated 1000 mūrās, (there) being *more or less of them. There was nothing missing there.
And so, of these 1000 mūrās, they shall pay in wheat with interest 500 (mūrās-worth),
in total: 30 kūsas, and *500 (mūrās-worth) shall be placed in the *public granary*. *In the case that
they cannot deliver the wheat when there shall be wheat in the country, then they shall pay Māmattī the mūrās.
But, if they cannot pay him, then you can lead the man Brīyaka into your house (and)
make him your own servant, howsoever pleases you, and he shall be in his (own?) jurisdiction neither by night nor by day. For that reason
they received this notice of debt(?), (namely) that they had promised (to deliver) wheat to the court. The following were the witnesses: Pumaṣīrai,
*Paśterai. And then this deed concerning money-makers shall become authoritative, when Virsa and Brīyaka
place their finger(mark)s on it. And I, the scribe *Āṇaka
wrote it at the man Brīyaka’s

q.l: gūha-kaṃga ttā pārrva dva u birga[ṃ]daraje gīhā 5 śau gūha-
kaṃgä ttara gayseta haura u śau phęma CHIN u pārrvi āṃ phę-
māṣṭa gūhye pajīdä kīrarai śe hvaṃḍye śau śīgä u 4 hvaṃḍāṃ
śau śīgä hvaṃḍye(?) 50 5 hvaṃḍye haura SIGNUM x 30 7 śīga
2 cow’s hides should be delivered to you. And 5 *auxiliaries from Birgaṃdara, one cow’s
hide deliver there in Gaysāta and one in Phęma. And to be delivered to Phęma.
... they request ... Per one workman one śiṃga and for 4 men
one śiṃga, to the man 55(?). Give to the man(?) 37 śiṃgas.

q.l: @ spāta tturgäśi spāta sīḍaki puʾsūṃ vaña vā phęmāṃ śūkṣu-
hina parau ā si peṃʾbaʾṣī hīyā dva aśāṃ dmanā-
ṣṭa stūra śtāka dasau ttye prracaina vina 20 1 rrvīya gana-
stūri pārrve śau hvaṃḍe tta 30 7 u phaṃnāje gī-
hā nau hālai stūra haura 3 seṃjsīṃji 10 4 mye
I, the spāta Tturgäśī, ask the spāta Sīḍaka: Now, hither from Śukṣūha of Phęma
an order has come that for the bingmashi’sYoshida, 2004, p. 28: 兵馬使使 bingmashi “commissioner for foot and horse.” stable for two horses
ten pack-animals are needed. For that reason 21 vinas, 17 royal ganamvās.
Of the 15 belonging to the yauvarāya (every) “half” manSee Or.6396/2 line 2, where this term is defined as “children and old men.”
should deliver one animal. Your men are 37. And the gīhās in Phaṃnai
(are) nine and a “half.” Give each 3 animals. On the 14th
day of Siṃjsīṃja the *message went out to you.

[x r]o [x] x [x] hā karya sahyä cu vara hvąndä u stūra ku-ṃ nä hā puñadāysä p[u- ?
[x x x x x pha]rṣavata ra hama pīre vā muho vara pāḍa haure u cu ra ma /
[x x x x x x x x x x] vā h-a x mata hvāña päUncertain. /
Let him not now make any unpleasantness for the pharṣavata on my account! I spoke this word
before here in the city *regarding the house. Then I spoke with the gracious one.
The gracious one did not give me this house, because I heard that they intend to give this house to Prince Kheysara.
Now Puñadāysa has brought (it) to you and brought that document from the gracious one.
... May you deign to make an effort in that matter that the men and draught animals there where Puñadāysa ... them for me
... you yourself write the pharṣavata or give to me the documents and whatever ...

kṣīra tsāṣṭā himi. u pātcä tta ṣau viṣṇadatta tta byāta yanīrau khu thyau beʾ-
Bowing down to the earth before the assembled Saṅgha in Saṅghapālāna I make a report.
I, gracious lord, if there (where you are) the monks’ bodies individually are healthy and
there is peace in (their) mind, (then) I am content. Now I am making propitiation to you. Exert (your) effort in better manner,
and remember the land. Whatever evil things there are intended here in the land, if
they are dispelled and you remember me thereafter in better manner and ...
... I ask ... are dispelled. And if here
in the land there comes peace, then afterwards remember Ṣau Viṣṇadatta so that he quickly

shipment they gave (paid) 1500 mūrās. And thus ...
being in the .. of His Gracious Lordship. Then they requested upkeep:
1200 mūrās. For that reason you shall send without delay without ... Accordingly
the total amount of it was 29 mūrās. Your men (are) nine. Your mūrās will be 262.Actually, 9 x 29 = 261.

On wrapper: “Huntingdon [sic] document on wood.” Wooden tablet in shape of paddle, inscribed on one side (see AKh., p. 269: “the traditional wooden board which ... takes the place of the slate”), effaced but some¬what legible, mostly numerals or (illegible?) Tibetan? The tablet is inscribed “I.1 11.i.08,” where “11.i.08” may be the date the object was found. According to the wrapper, it was sent to F. W. Thomas at India Office Library, Whitehall, from [E. Leumann in] Freiburg im Breisgau, ca. 1924. 47x4.5-11.5 cm.

The following were the tax collectors who delivered sacks and aysdāṃ to Phęma: For ten men 1 sack, [1] rope.
In ...’s year Viṃkausa delivered 3 sacks, 3 ropes, and 4 khas of aysdāṃ. Auśyaka 2 khas of aysdāṃ. Budadatta
Iresa 1 sack, 1 rope, 2 khas of aysdāṃ. Saṃgaśūrai 1 sack, 1 rope, and 2 khas of aysdāṃ. Saṃgaka 1 sack, 1 rope ...
Braśūrai delivered 4 khas. Māmattī 2 khas of aysdāṃ. Suhadatta 2 sacks, *3 ropes. Brapuña 1 sack.
This is the promised amount of sacks:
This is the promised amount of aysdāṃ:

In the fifteenth regnal year, this much stuff was ordered for (each) half man in Gaysāta:
an amount of 606 mūrās per capita. And hemp cloth for winter clothing
9 chās 2 tsunas; for (a piece from) a seventy-chā roll the mūrās become 616.
And hemp cloth for summer clothing was ordered 8 chās 6 tsunas; for (a piece from) a sixty-chā (roll),
the mūrās for it become 516. And cotton cloth for winter clothing was ordered
1 chā 5 tsūnas, so for (a piece from) a fifty chā-roll the mūrās become 225. And
summer clothing, its amount was ordered (as) 170 mūrās. And for a half man, in total,
2133 mūrās (worth of stuff) was ordered, with the exception of the amount of seventy chās for the gracious lords.

note.p: Suv H 6.5.72-80, 6.6.1-3. See Kha. i.138b5 (IOL Khot 22/11). Original now missing, copy on microfilm IOL 17A, fol. 209. [Original now on Or.15000/599.6.]
Sgh? I have not been able to find where Bailey saw this.

Bailey’s fragments Khot(IO) 17.1-3 must have been damaged and badly put together in the lamination process. Not all the text seen by Bailey can now be identified. His original 17.2-3 seems to be lost, while the Sanskrit mentioned in fn. 1 on p. 350 and c-side of 17.3 are in one big fragment, of which there is only one side, here 17.x. Note that Bailey has Khot(IO) 17.1 and 2 twice (see IOL Khot 174/12). Sgh [10] 6.8-13/14.2. In reverse on Khot(IO) 17.2. Verso now lost.

I thus make report to the Lord Minister, the ṣṣau Viṣṇadatta. — I (am)
Yseviḍta,Cf. Hedin 12 b1 phąnāji auva haṃdasti ysiviṭi. resident in the Six Towns. O Lord, the aḍāsvnas (?) have ordered from me royal cloths.
On the seventh day of the month of Skarihvāra of the 35th regnal year. This letter (is) for this reason that Sinila of Phaṃnai
and Ṣanīraka of Birgaṃdara received woolen cloths and hemp cloth pieces. And the amount of it (was) 1000 mūrās. Makala [received ?] cloth
24 chās belong to the spāta Vidyadatta, 40 chās to Svarrjāṃ, 23 chās to Puñaśālyā, 20 chās ...
Pieces of cloth from Āskūra 20 and two here accordingly of mūrās. Sarkāṃ a woolen cloth 19 chās, (also imposed?) upon (him is?) one piece of cloth.
Suhena woolen cloth 20 chās, and (also imposed?) upon (him is?) one piece of cloth together with the mūrās. Its total 1000. And hemp pieces of cloth ...

jari u ma ṣai vā hajsęmyari khu ttiña māśta paphve himi khu aḍa [m]ā-
śta ysaṃthi ttädrmi ttī jsāṃ vā kṣauva hajsęmyari thyau ttye hvaṃḍye dīśta cu va
haṃbā buḍi paḍāṃda ttā parau hauḍeṃ kṣauvā kiṇa u na-ṃ vā hauḍāṃda khu x
hīsīdi makali vā hajsęmyari lyibaʾ āṃ ma pajīdä pa {x} rsaṃdai ha-
jsęmyarī vā aśau gänña himi khu vā kṣauva u tti mūri paiya ni hīsī
The spāta Sudārrjāṃ orders thus: To the Year-leader the pharṣa Sāṃdara.
Now the money-collectors nowCf. P 97.1.1. here have asked me for a total amount of mūrās: 20,000.
Whichever ones are missing and the ones that the three men placed after them, those mūrās
they ordered me to request with eight mūrās of interest. As soon as the order arrives, quickly *send this thing to me
and gather ... so that it is collected in this month. If another month,
(then) the interest (is) as much.Cf. Hedin 3.15 (KT IV, p. 60). Then gather the vouchers,Cf. Hedin 5.16. (and) quickly (place them) in this man’s hand, whatever
amount he brought here. I gave you an order regarding the vouchers previously (= a while ago), but you have not given them to me. When ...
come, gather them for Makala (to bring) here. They are requesting the complete *outstanding amount her.
Gather it for him as he passes through.Cf. P 103.37.5. You must buy horses. If the vouchers and those mūrās do not arrive ...

... *because on the 22nd day of Ttuṃjārā in the 36th regnal year they requested stuff for those who are going to *Ārma.

[The spāta] *Sudārrjāṃ orders thus: To the pharṣa Sāṃdara and Darauka Yseviṭa.

This is) Miṃjukā by name; in the form of an ox.
(This is) Miṃkhalacā by name; in the form of a stag.
She makes weak/(feel) bad. Mṛgarājā by (her Skt.) name.
(This is) Mattrąnaṃdī by name; in the form of a cat.
She pulls out a child’s tongue and, in the mouth, foam comes out.
(This is) Śakunī by name; in the form of a bird.
She makes weak/(feel) bad; she causes diarrhea.

A drawing of the piece on the right is in IOR MSS Eur F 302/12, where it has been given the incorrect sign. Kha. i.E.0005 in a later hand.

q.l: “May (this) protective amulet of Surade’sCf. Reuter 2 a2-3 (KT V, p. 394): pūña/de rakṣa sarva/kālya ṣī[vi] / haḍā[ya ... – a. Surade also in Or.11344/8, Or.11252/31, IOL Khot 2/1. protect him all the time, by night (and) by day!”

note.p: According to Ser., p. 176, these are 8 frgs. of a wall painting with two bands of ornament; the upper band has a series of trumpet-shaped blossoms on a maroon background which are bordered above and below by a broad white line, part of which contains a Brahmi inscription. The drawings are preserved in Hoernle’s papers (IOR/MSS EUR F 302/12).
Inscription on silk banner. Hoernle provided a preliminary, but quite correct, reading and translation.

q.l: . . pasi salya rarūyi māśta 20 6 mye haḍai x thyai ahā [yi]
pasta haiṣṭe beʾysūśta brrīyi harbīśai āvama prra[ṇi]-
In the year of the sheep, on the 26th day of the month Rarūya. Thyai gave order to give it to you, in love of Bodhi. May all his wishes and resolves (praṇidhāna) succeed! Reverence!

note.p: Overlaps with SI P 3 fol. 2r3-3r3. Guide2 [18.11], p. 25 “143 S.A. 12” is a lapsus. Wille, 1996, p. 388, no. 14.
